column5:
Welcome to Salem & the Mid-Willamette Valley â€“ Absolutely Oregon!

TravelSalem.com is your connection to Salem and the Mid-Willamette Valley as the official tourism and meeting website for visitors to this region of Oregon. Locate all the riches of the area and entertaining things to do. Unique character can be found at our attractions, galleries, eateries, shops, and events. You will find vibrant scenery at every turn, so be sure to bring your camera and share your favorite photos with us!

column5:
A separate form must be completed for each event. Events that fit the criteria below will be posted within one month of the submission date.

Criteria

  • Located in Salem, Marion County or Polk County
  • Open to the public and of interest to visitors
  • Not a meeting or convention
  • Not for religious, political, personal, pornographic, or propaganda purposes

Instructions
Please complete the fields below in order to have your event(s) listed on the TravelSalem.com event calendar. Thank you for providing us with this valuable information.

We appreciate only the submission of events that fit the above criteria.

Once submitted, your event will go through an approval and editing process to insure it meets the TravelSalem.com event criteria. If your event doesn't fit the criteria you will receive an email notification. Events that are submitted close to the actual event date(s) may not be posted in time. If your event happens before it is posted to the calendar, you will not be notified.

Please allow a month or more lead time so your event can receive the maximum exposure.

Do you have changes to a current event listing?
To insure accuracy please email dhendrix@TravelSalem.com with your updated event information (include: title & date of your event, the changes and a phone number to reach you).

Thank you,

TravelSalem.com Staff

column5:
Where to stay in the Salem area? There are plenty of lodging options! You might like to stay within walking distance of the Capital, downtown historic district and Bushâ€™s Pasture Park. Or perhaps youâ€™d prefer one of our unique Salem bed and breakfast inns, many in excellently restored historic homes. From a lovely creekside Victorian to a country home in one of the oldest Oregon vineyards, we have it all.

The regionâ€™s diverse lodgings cater to your every need, with options from fireplaces and player pianos to steam rooms, jacuzzis, tennis courts, computer services and full breakfast fare. Enjoy your sleep because there is plenty to see!

column5:
Home to the only Nordstrom between San Francisco and Portland, and situated just off I-5, Salem is a key shopping destination for the Willamette Valley. From major names in retail to unique shops with local products, we have it all. Stroll past the historic faÃ§ade of the Ladd & Bush Bank as you peruse the cityâ€™s charming downtown shopping core, filled with boutiques and cafes, specialty shops and antiques. Our downtown malls, Salem Center and Reed Opera House, and nearby Lancaster Mall feature 200 popular and specialty stores for all your shopping needs.

One of the most exciting changes in downtown Salem is the recent re-opening of the historic McGilchrist and Roth Building. Originally built in 1916, this beautifully renovated building is home to three new shops, including Gayleâ€™s Italian Market, an authentic Italian shop featuring artisan cheeses, meats, wood-fired pizza and more.

column5: Salem is a marvelously art-friendly town! Weâ€™re proud to host Oregonâ€™s largest art fair and festival each summer. Our downtownâ€™s First Wednesdays always attract a vibrant crowd, featuring artists and musicians performing at stores during evening shopping hours. Theater performances and concerts attract well-known talents to our region, and are always well attended. And if you enjoy visual arts, our museums and galleries are known for their imaginative exhibitory. Outdoor concerts are always a special part of our summers.

column5:
Absolutely Hospitality

Unique venues that meet your exact needs and affordable accommodations. These are just a few reasons Salem should be on your meeting, event, conference, wedding, retreat, reunion â€˜short list.â€™ We invite you to â€˜tourâ€™ the venues listed here, complete a request for proposal or bid request or contact us for more information and free planning assistance.

Meeting facilities

Salem offers an incredible variety of meeting venues, from modern facilities to restored historic sites. The city offers 450,000 square feet of meeting and exhibit space, for groups from 10 to 7,000.

Transportation

Portland International Airport is 50 minutes north of Salem and is serviced by all major airlines. Ground transportation is available and easily coordinated by your travel professional.

Where to stay

Salem offers more than 1,900 quality guestrooms, from small independent hotels to premier business-class accommodations. Most hotels have meeting facilities, and many offer â€˜turn-keyâ€™ service for groups from 10 to 300.

What to do

Our wineries, rivers, gardens and historic sites offer discoveries at every turn. Golfers will enjoy courses from breathtaking alpine to classic parkland layouts along the Willamette River. Groups can visit our award-winning wineries. And for strolling and shopping, Salemâ€™s historic downtown offers a charming mix of stores, galleries, restaurants and parks.

column5:
WINERIES, CIDERMAKERS & CRAFT BREWERS

Within a short drive of Salem â€” and right in town â€” itâ€™s possible to taste a world of wine, cider and brews. While largely known for its world-class Pinot noir, the Willamette Valley produces a wide range of award-winning wines and has also attracted a new crop of cider makers and craft brewers. No matter which direction you take, youâ€™ll find cozy tasting rooms and opportunities to chat with producers while quaffing a glass of your favorite beverage.

For in-town tasting, visit Grand Vines and sip from a rotating list of local, regional and international wines. Live music is often on the menu, along with antipasto plates, sandwiches, soups and salads. Save room for handmade goodies from Extreme Chocolates. 

Honeywood Winery, Oregonâ€™s oldest producing winery, offers complimentary tastings of its varietal, fruit and specialty wines â€“ including mead â€“ and a gourmet marketplace selling Oregon foods and wine-related gifts.

For a wine loop south of Salem, start with Willamette Valley Vineyards. Founded in 1983, the estate is one of Oregonâ€™s leading wineries, best known for award-winning Pinot noir, along with excellent Riesling, Chardonnay, and Pinot gris. The winery sits on a picturesque hilltop, with a tasting room and deck that offer sweeping views across the valley. Enjoy a picnic lunch assembled from the local cheeses and artisan products from the tasting room. Look for annual events like the Pinot and Chocolate Celebration, Pear, Wine and Cheese Jubilee, Fatherâ€™s Day Weekend, and the fall Grape Stomp Competition.

Farther south, overlooking the Ankeny National Wildlife Refuge, is Ankeny Vineyards. There, owner Joe Olexa and winemaker Andy Thomas turn out small, handcrafted lots with an emphasis on Pinot noir and Pinot gris. Nearby Trinity Vineyards, a family-owned boutique winery producing Pinot noir, Pinot gris, Viognier and RosÃ©, features a tasting room deck overlooking the vines and with views of the surrounding hills.

To the east of Salem lies a handful of small wineries, including Pudding River Wine Cellars, a winery producing small lot, boutique wines like Pinot noir, Chardonnay, Pinot gris, Viognier, and Riesling. In Aumsville, Piluso Vineyard and Winery offers red and white varietals along with port and dessert wines. Pilusoâ€™s Vintnerâ€™s Garden is a delightful spot to enjoy a bottle of wine and a picnic.

By far, the largest concentration of wineries and vineyards is west of Salem. Visiting one, or a handful, makes for a pleasant and easy daytrip.

Head west along Highway 22 to loop through the Van Duzer corridor. Here vines get the benefit of temperate afternoon breezes and cool evenings â€“ perfect growing conditions for exceptional Pinot noir. Wineries in this area include Johan Vineyards, Firesteed and NamastÃ© Vineyards. At Van Duzer Vineyards, visitors are treated to award-winning wines and breathtaking views of the valley from the trellised terrace off the tasting room â€“ the perfect spot for a picnic lunch.

If youâ€™d rather break up a day with a more traditional lunch stop, head to Left Coast Cellars; the cozy cafÃ©, decorated with a Scandinavian twist, features soups, panini sandwiches, pizza and small plates that complement the house wines. From there, head south to Eola Hills Wine Cellars. Open year-round and producing more than two dozen wines, Eola Hillsâ€™ serene setting and koi ponds offer a relaxing spot to pass an afternoon.

Another option for a wine loop west of Salem is up and along the ridge of the Eola Hills. This will take you by Cubanisimo Vineyards, St. Innocent Winery, Witness Tree Vineyard, Redhawk Vineyard & Winery, and Stangeland Vineyards and Winery â€“ each one producing standout wines.

CIDER & BREWS

Traditional hard cider is experiencing a revival in the Willamette Valley. Two early adopters are Wandering Aengus Ciderworks and E.Z. Orchards. For a taste of both, head to Wandering Aengusâ€™ tasting room and sidle up to the sustainable hardwood bar to sample from a rotation of ciders, ranging from semi-dry to floral. Lite fare, local beers, wines and cheeses are also available.

Beer-lovers should seek out Gilgamesh Brewing, whose innovative brews have spawned a devoted following. Gilgamesh can be found at their own tasting room (open on select dates), on local menus, or at frequent pop-up events.

Salemâ€™s Ram Restaurant & Brewery is home to Big Horn Brewing Company and its ales, lagers and handcrafted brews. Just across the Willamette in Independence (once the hop capital of the world) is an outpost of one of Oregonâ€™s most lauded brewers, the venerable Rogue Ales. Raise a glass of artisan brew at the Chatoe Rogue Tasting Room, take a tour of the adjacent hop fields and processing facility, or relax with a friendly round of croquet.

column5:
Wild Oregon

Oregon features some of the most scenic wild areas in the United States, and the Willamette Valley is no exception. You donâ€™t have to venture far from Salem to find rolling green hills, waterfalls, old-growth forests and wetlands.


View Nature - Itinerary 1 in a larger map

Oregon's Natural Wonder: Silver Falls State Park

Located 25 miles east of Salem lies one of Oregonâ€™s most spectacular natural wonders Silver Falls State Park. The crown jewel of the Oregon State Park system, Silver Falls is the stateâ€™s largest park (9,000 acres) and home to one of America's most impressive waterfall hikes. The Trail of Ten Falls is a designated National Recreation Trail and lures photographers, hikers and waterfall enthusiasts alike. There are exactly ten falls on this 8.7-mile loop (which can be reduced via two cutoff trails) and many have natural pathways that allow hikers to walk behind the falls for a truly breathtaking perspective. Silver Falls also offers opportunities for fishing, swimming, picnicking, mountain biking and overnight camping. Campers can get cozy in an RV, tent, rustic cabin or yurt â€“ some of which are also pet-friendly. (These lush surroundings served as a backdrop to some of the scenes in the first Twilight movie and the South Falls had a cameo in Yogi Bear.)

Visitors to Silver Falls will want to spend time in the historic town of Silverton - named one of Americaâ€™s coolest small towns by Budget Travel Magazine in 2009. Enjoy a cocktail and casual fare at the Creekside Grill & Grotto Martini Bar or a fine dining experience at the award-winning Silver Grille Cafe. Silverton is also home to The Oregon Garden, a stunning 80-acre botanical garden. The Gordon House - the only house in Oregon designed by renowned architect Frank Lloyd Wright â€“ also sits on the Garden grounds. Guided tours of both The Oregon Garden and the Gordon House are offered regularly. 

Looking for additional recreation information? Check out our natural attractions and parks pages on our website.


Nature in downtown Salem and beyond

If youâ€™re short on time, nature is still close at hand. Accessible from downtown, Salem's Riverfront Park meanders along the Willamette River and features flat, paved trails that make for an easy and picturesque stroll. Enjoy a delightful old-time carousel and the Eco Earth Globe, made up of 86,000 colorful tiles.


View Nature - Itinerary 2 in a larger map

At the north end of the park, the Union Street Railroad Bridge, built in 1912-13 and recently refurbished for pedestrians and cyclists, offers clear views upstream and downstream while connecting to Wallace Marine Park in west Salem.

Stock your daypack with lunch from Croissant & Company â€” where youâ€™ll find sandwiches, salads and pastries â€” and take the short drive to Salemâ€™s 900-acre Minto-Brown Island Park. With a network of paths along the Willamette River and through a varied landscape of abandoned filbert orchards, pastures, woods and wetlands, itâ€™s a prime spot for bird watching. Keep your eyes peeled for large osprey nests.

West of Salem lies the Baskett Slough National Wildlife Refuge. The 1,000-acre sanctuary, carved from cropland, forests, grassland and wetlands, is home to wintering geese, great blue heron, hawks and eagles, along with many other types of wildlife. In spring, when the refuge is awash in wildflowers, you may even catch a glimpse of the endangered Fenderâ€™s blue butterfly. Hiking and walking trails zigzag the refuge, with wildlife observation platforms providing a vantage point for taking in the scenery.

After a day of exploring hill and dale, youâ€™ll have worked up a hearty appetite. Sate it with Adam's Rib Smoke House. Known for their outstanding slow-smoked barbecue meats, homemade side dishes and uncompromising commitment to service. Thirsty? Their tap room boasts over 30 beers and growing!

Welcome to the Travel Salem media room!

Travel Salem represents Oregonâ€™s capital city, Salem, as well as the Marion county and Polk county region. Travel Salemâ€™s Public Relations team is happy to assist journalists with a variety of services including:
â€¢ providing unique story ideas
â€¢ press releases regarding the latest industry news
â€¢ fact checking
â€¢ photos
â€¢ providing additional resources

â€¢ providing unique story ideas
â€¢ press releases regarding the latest industry news
â€¢ fact checking
â€¢ photos
â€¢ providing additional resources

And we know what you want â€“ to take advantage of innovative marketing solutions that are flexible and deliver measurable results.

Travel Salemâ€™s Membership Program is your ticket to marketing success and we're ready to serve you! Travel Salem is the official public relations and marketing organization for the Mid-Willamette Valley. Travel Salemâ€™s award-winning sales and marketing strategies positively impact the regionâ€™s economy by attracting leisure visitors and convention, meeting and event businesses that contribute more than $500 million dollars to the economy and employ 6,000 people in the region. Let us help you capture your share of that $500 million.

As a Travel Salem Member, not only can you choose from a variety of marketing options, but you can custom design a Membership package that best meets your needs. Travel Salem has designed a cutting-edge Membership system -- the first of its kind for convention and visitors bureaus -- and is leading the way within the industry. Give us a call, we are always happy to meet with you! You may also have some questions regarding Membership that can be answered by reviewing Travel Salem's FAQs.

Customize your Membership package by becoming a Basic Member, and gain access to Travel Salemâ€™s U-Pick Marketing Options, or save 10% by selecting a Pre-Packaged Option. As a Travel Salem Member, your business will actively participate in and contribute to Salemâ€™s more than $511 million tourism economy!

Whether youâ€™re a nonprofit, small business or large corporation, Travel Salemâ€™s Membership program will enhance your visibility and deliver results. Join Travel Salem today and support a regional effort to position Salem and the Mid-Willamette Valley area of Oregon as a unique destination and to attract customers to your business.

Thank you for your support!

column4: Local Events, Activities, Programs and Exhibits
column5:

Ongoing

February 14, 2009-May 23, 2010
Facing Statehood
Facing Statehood, an interactive exhibit, lets visitors experience stories of the Kalapuya Native Peoples and the early settlers. Explore the controversial actions leading to Oregon statehood. Contribute your own hopes and dreams for Oregon's future. $6 Adults; $5 Seniors (55 +); $4 Students (with ID); $3 Youth (6-17); Children under 6 free. 10 a.m.-5 p.m.
Mission Mill Museum, part of Willamette Heritage Center

Salem, OR 97301

Historical journey of Marion County, exhibits 150+ photos & artifacts. Free admission, donations accepted. Tues.-Sat. noon-4 p.m.
Marion County Historical Society, part of Willamette Heritage Center
260 12th St. SE

column5:
Visually discover the Salem areaâ€™s unique experiences that will transform your â€œReel virtualâ€ù visit into a â€œReal timeâ€ù visit. These lively â€œexperiencesâ€ù will help you discover the real you. Are you a Family Voyager, Naturalist, Adventure Seeker, Gourmand, Relaxer or a Culture Seeker? Find out by viewing these reels, then let us help you plan your real visit to Salem, Oregon and the Marion & Polk County region!

The Family of Voyagers

Vacations for you are a family affair, so you look for destinations with activities for kids and kids at heart, like childrenâ€™s museums, sporting events and the outdoors.

View this experience.

The Culture Seeker

Youâ€™re one who likes the finer things in life, and seek out arts, heritage and culture when you travel.

View this experience.

The Adventurer

Youâ€™re an adrenaline junkie, and like to vacation where you can push the envelope with activities like skydiving, mountain biking or running.

View this experience.

The Gourmand

When you travel, you pack a suitcase, your guidebooks, and a big appetite for exploring the local culinary scene.

View this experience.

The Naturalist

Youâ€™re at peace in nature, and make a point of vacationing where you can get outdoors for activities like bird watching, biking, boating and strolling through lush gardens and fields of flowers.

View this experience.

The Relaxer

When you vacation, it means getting away - by yourself or with the ones you love - to relax and recharge with spas, intimate inns, wine tasting, shopping and golf.

View this experience.

column5:
Showcase experience: Marion County (Salem Area)

The Santiam Canyon area is home to the Willamette National Forest, Detroit Lake State Recreation Area and Silver Falls State Park. The Willamette National Forest has some of the best hunting areas in the Oregon Cascades providing a huge area open to the public for hunting. Best hunting opportunities are for Elk, Deer and Black Bears. Potential hunters must contact the Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife for regulations. Detroit Lake State Recreation Area provides many easily accessible locations for avid fishermen. Rainbow Trout, Kokanee, Land-Lock Chinook and a few Bullhead Catfish can be found in this 400+ foot deep lake. Detroit Lake is also great for all water activities including water skiing. The Detroit Recreation Area offers winter activities such as skiing, snowboarding, snowmobiling, sledding or just having a good old-fashioned snowball fight. Silver Falls State Park is nestled in the lower elevation of Oregonâ€™s Cascade Mountains in a temperate rain forest. It is here that hikers can experience The Canyon Trail which is a nationally recognized trail system that leads hikers to 10 majestic waterfalls, ranging from the grand South Falls (177 feet), to the delicate Drake Falls (27 feet). Four of these falls have an amphitheater-like surrounding where you can walk behind the falls and feel the misty, crisp spray.

Travel Salem
181 High St. NE
Salem, Oregon 97301
503-581-4325 
800-874-7012
www.travelsalem.com

Lodging

You might like to stay within walking distance of the Capitol, downtown historic district and shops. Or perhaps youâ€™d prefer a Salemâ€™s unique bed and breakfast in a restored historic home or beside a scenic vineyard. The Salem area offers diverse lodging that cater to your every need, with options from fireplaces and player pianos to steam rooms, Jacuzzis, pools and full breakfast fare.

column5:
Showcase experience: Marion County & Polk County (Salem Area)

Hallie Ford Museum of Art, Salem
Oregonâ€™s second largest art museum featuring the collection, preservation, exhibition, and interpretation of historical and contemporary art with an emphasis on regional art.
700 State St.
Salem, OR 97301
503-370-6855
www.willamette.edu/museum_of_art

World Beat Gallery, Salem
Cultural exhibitions from Salemâ€™s ethnic communities displayed all year. 2010 themes include Samoa, India, international marriage customs and winter holidays around the world.
189 Liberty St. NE, #211B (Located inside Reed Opera House)
Salem, OR 97301
503-581-2004
www.salemmulticultural.org

Willamette Heritage Center, Salem
Willamette Heritage Center preserves three 1840â€™s Mission houses and a 19th century woolen mill; the Museum interprets Western Oregonâ€™s settlement and industry. Visit Oregonâ€™s American Treasure. Mon.-Sat., 10 a.m.-5 p.m.; closed major holidays.
1313 Mill St. SE
Salem, OR 97301
503-585-7012
www.WillametteHeritage.org

Salem Art Association & Salem Art Fair & Festival
Once home to the Bush familyâ€™s farm equipment, the Bush Barn Art Center in Salem is a renovated historic building now housing two contemporary exhibition galleries, and a consignment and rental gallery. The Camas Gallery features the work of over 150 artists from the Pacific Northwest and beyond. A.N. Bush Gallery presents major exhibitions of regional, national and international artists. The Focus Gallery is a more intimate exhibit space that showcases the finest contemporary work being made by artists living in the Salem area. The Salem Art Fair & Festival is one of Oregonâ€™s premier cultural events and is the largest juried art festival of its kind in the state. Held the third weekend in July and set among historic oak trees, the Art Fairâ€™s Artist Marketplace features over 200 of the top fine artists and craftspeople from around the country. Art from a wide variety of mediums include painting, ceramics, glass, jewelry, wood, photography and fiber. Performing art is provided with 50 free performances by regional and national acts.
600 Mission St. SE
Salem, OR 97302
503-581-2223
www.salemart.org

Confederated Tribes of the Grand Ronde Pow-Wow
The Confederated Tribes of the Grand Ronde represent native peoples from the Umpqua, Molalla, Rogue River, Kalapuya and Chasta regions. The tribes annual Pow Wow and Pow Wow singers are very important in the Native American culture. Without them there would be no dancing. The songs are of many varieties, from religious to war to social and hold special meaning to those who know the song. Dancers are an important part of the life of the American Indian. Most dances seen at Pow Wows today are social dances which might have had different meanings in earlier days. The outfits worn by the dancers, like the styles of clothing today evolve over time, it is not a stagnant culture, but a vibrant and changing way of life. Visitors to the Pow Wow learn about the tribes culture and sense of community. Many visitors are touched by the deep meaning and beauty of this Pow Wow.
9615 Grand Ronde Rd.
Grand Ronde, OR 97347
503-879-5211
www.grandronde.org

Antique Powerland Museums, Brooks
Antique Powerland Museums is a power equipment heritage site established by a group of enthusiasts dedicated to the preservation, restoration and demonstration of steam powered equipment, antique farm machinery and implements. This site interprets the heritage of the agricultural industry in regards to the apparatus used to plant, harvest and process crops. The Antique Powerland site is home to a diverse set of museums and heritage clubs with activities related to blacksmithing, fire apparatus, electric railroads, miniature railroading, Caterpillar equipment, antique cars and motorcycles, early day trucks, large steam engines, steam operated cranes and model railroading. The Annual Great Oregon Steam-Up event is held the last weekend of July and first weekend of August.
3995 NE Brooklake Rd. NE (I-5 exit 263)
Brooks, OR 97303
503-393-2424
www.antiquepowerland.com

Champoeg State Heritage Area, St. Paul
Champoeg is the site where Oregonâ€™s first provisional government was formed by a historical vote in 1843. This heritage area also features a unique combination of history, nature and recreation with interactive living history programs, camping opportunities, walking and cycling paths, and the Historic Butteville Store founded in 1863 which is considered the oldest operating store in Oregon.
7679 Champoeg Rd. NE
Saint Paul, OR 97137
503-678-1251
www.oregonstateparks.org

Return to Reel to Real Experience Homepage

column5:
Showcase experience: Marion County (Salem Area)

Balanced diets, river biology and the human body? Kids donâ€™t need textbooks when they can immerse themselves in hands-on exhibits, like those at the A.C. Gilbertâ€™s Discovery Village in Salem. Stop at Salem's Riverfront Carousel on your way home. This old-world style carousel is enjoyable for all ages; just close your eyes and become a kid again.

Visit the Wild West, run the river in a log canoe, or take a walk down storybook lane - all to the sounds of fairy-tale music and childrenâ€™s laughter at the Enchanted Forest. Children young and old can visit an authentic English village or haunted house before taking in a kaleidoscope of lights during the daily Fantasy Fountainâ€™s Water-Light show.

Take a seat in the Governorâ€™s chair at the Oregon State Capitol. Parents can photograph their future lawmakers as they help to draft legislation in the ceremonial office where bills are signed and press conferences are held.  Guided tours will teach you about the history of Oregon, the Capitol building and the stateâ€™s legislative process.  When the legislature is in session, visitors can sit in the Gallery above the House and Senate floors to watch proceedings in person.  Before you leave, climb to the Golden Pioneer, a symbol that sits atop the capitol, honoring the sacrifices made by pioneers on the Oregon Trail.  From here, you can see the city of Salem and catch a glimpse of the green fields of the valley beyond. Everyone who makes it to the top will receive a certificate of achievement signed by the Governor.

The historic Willamette Heritage Center, offers hands-on activities for kids to experience how life once was.  Ever wonder what it was like to be a pioneer?  Take part in traditional crafts and childrenâ€™s games, or watch reenactments of Kalapuya Indian activities.  With Mill Creek running through the grounds, the museum is a tranquil park-like destination.

Hear a ball crack against the bat and enjoy a hotdog smothered in mustard at a Salem-Keizer Volcanoes baseball game. The club was named the â€œBest Class A Short Season Franchiseâ€ù in the nation by Baseball America.

Enjoy a family dinner while taking in a movie at the Northern Lights Theater Pub. Early shows are open to all ages and the theater serves kid friendly food along with adult fare. From light comedies to PG-rated action flicks, this theater has films the whole family can agree on.

Whether youâ€™d like to stay within walking distance of the Capitol, downtown historic district and shops, or youâ€™d prefer a unique bed and breakfast beside a scenic vineyard, the Salem area offers diverse lodgings that cater to every need and many that come complete with fireplaces, Jacuzzis and pools, as well as restored historic homes and full breakfast fare.

Travel Salem
181 High St. NE
Salem, Oregon 97301
503-581-4325 
800-874-7012
www.TravelSalem.com

A.C. Gilbertâ€™s Discovery Village
116 Marion St. NE
Salem, Oregon 97301
503-371-3631
800-208-9514
www.acgilbert.org

Salem, Oregon 97301

The historic Willamette Heritage Center, offers hands-on activities for kids to experience how life once was.  Ever wonder what it was like to be a pioneer?  Take part in traditional crafts and childrenâ€™s games, or watch reenactments of Kalapuya Indian activities.  With Mill Creek running through the grounds, the museum is a tranquil park-like destination.

Hear a ball crack against the bat and enjoy a hotdog smothered in mustard at a Salem-Keizer Volcanoes baseball game. The club was named the â€œBest Class A Short Season Franchiseâ€ù in the nation by Baseball America.

Enjoy a family dinner while taking in a movie at the Northern Lights Theater Pub. Early shows are open to all ages and the theater serves kid friendly food along with adult fare. From light comedies to PG-rated action flicks, this theater has films the whole family can agree on.

Whether youâ€™d like to stay within walking distance of the Capitol, downtown historic district and shops, or youâ€™d prefer a unique bed and breakfast beside a scenic vineyard, the Salem area offers diverse lodgings that cater to every need and many that come complete with fireplaces, Jacuzzis and pools, as well as restored historic homes and full breakfast fare.

column5:
Showcase experience: Marion and Polk Counties (Salem Area)

Oregonâ€™s Willamette Valley was once a rich mix of wildlife habitats. Valley wetlands were once extensive, with meandering stream channels and vast seasonal marshes. Today, the Valley is a mix of lush farmland, gardens, wineries and unique cities. Ankeny National Wildlife Refuge near Jefferson, Oregon was created to provide vital wintering habitat for Dusky Canada geese. The Refuge contains about 2,800 acres of flat to gently rolling land near the confluence of the Willamette and Santiam rivers south of Salem, Oregon. Ducks, geese, swans, shorebirds, and bald eagles are common in the fall and winter and the northern saw-whet owl is a resident. Basket Slough National Wildlife Refuge near Dallas, Oregon is situated in open farmland near the eastern foothills of the Coast Range. The Refuge consists of 1,173 acres of cropland, which provide forage for wintering geese, especially the Dusky Canada goose. Baskett Slough also provides habitat for a wide variety of birds, mammals, reptiles and amphibians.

Breitenbush Hot Springs mission is to provide a safe and potent environment where people can renew and evolve in ways they never imagined. Natural hot spring pools along with tiled tubs and steam saunas are set in the 154 acre wildlife sanctuary in the Willamette National Forest near Detroit, Oregon. Ancient forest, river and mountain trails along with meditation, reflection and yoga connect visitors to nature and erase the everyday pressures.

Located on 80 acres in Silverton, Oregon The Oregon Garden offers 20 specialty gardens, water features, conifer garden, garden art, wetlands, the Rediscovery Forest, kids garden, and 400-year-old Signature Oak tree. A diverse bird population is right at home within The Oregon Garden and the view is spectacular.

Nearby is Schreiner's Iris Gardens. Stroll through their brilliant 10-acre iris garden and order bulbs from acres of iris fields. Take home your favorite to remember your visit.

Roses, roses and more roses can be enjoyed at the Heirloom Rose Garden in Saint Paul and in Salem at Bushâ€™s Pasture Park. Known for the worlds most fragrant roses, Heirloom Roses offers three large display rose gardens containing 1,500 varieties of roses. Bushâ€™s Pasture Park Rose Garden sits along side the grand 1878 Italianate Bush House. This garden is a true treasure comforting many rose bushes including the Tartar Old Rose Collection that survived the arduous overland Oregon Trail migration between 1841 and 1869. These hearty rose plants are part of the legacy of the Oregon pioneers and are a gift for future generations.

column5:
Showcase experience:  The trip to Salem youâ€™ll remember for years

Historic Downtown Salem
Unique eateries, historic landmarks, one-of-a-kind shops, theaters, art galleries and picturesque Riverfront Park and Carousel are part of downtown. Visitors appreciate historic downtownâ€™s beautifully landscaped sidewalks as well as the sky bridges that connect shopping to free covered parking. Downtown Salem has a combination of historic landmarks, big name stores and boutique shopping opportunities. Events such as First Wednesday add to the ambiance of this vibrant downtown.

Woodburn Premium Outlets, Woodburn
Shop Brilliantly. Tax-free outlet shopping at 112 stores including Ann Taylor, Banana Republic, Bose, Columbia Sportswear, Nike and more.
1001 Arney Rd.
Woodburn, OR 97071
503-981-1900
www.premiumoutlets.com/woodburn

Aurora
Aurora was Oregonâ€™s first National Historic District and has been an antiques center since the early 1970s. Known as Oregonâ€™s Antique Capital, the downtown historic buildings are filled with 25 antique and specialty shops plus eateries. Aurora is home to the Pacific Hazelnut Candy Factory. The Factory roasts and seasons nuts and chocolate coats hazelnuts, almonds, walnuts, prunes and pretzels. With their secret recipe for hazelnut toffee this candy factory is truly gourmet.
Aurora Colony Visitors Association
PO Box 86
Aurora, OR 97002
503-939-0312
www.auroracolony.com

Salem Golf Club
Salem Golf Club is an absolutely unique Golf Digest four star experience. Two miles from Salemâ€™s city center. Playing golf at Salem Golf Club becomes a nature walk with all its natural beauty. Trees line the fairways and numerous wildlife (deer, squirrels, geese, ducks, hawks and osprey flying overhead) can be seen. Eighteen holes of natural secluded beauty without commercial development. Rudyâ€™s at Salem Golf Club serves only the best corn-fed prime beef. The steaks are cut in the restaurant daily, all of the soups, salad dressings and desserts are homemade.
2025 Golf Club Rd. S
Salem, OR 97302
503-363-6652
www.salemgolfclub.com

OGA Golf Course
This 18-hole public course is challenging and home to many Northwest tournaments. Groves of Filbert trees line the fairways. The on-site restaurant, Orchards Grille, is dedicated to providing dining and social interaction in an atmosphere of subdued elegance, with the fine food and gracious service in a picturesque setting.
2850 Hazelnut Dr.
Woodburn, OR 97071
503-981-6105
www.ogagolfcourse.com

column4: Salem and Mid-Willamette Valley Packages & Specials
column5:
Pondering where to stay and what to see and do while in Oregonâ€™s capital city and the region? Let these creative packages and specials make your stay an Absolutely wonderful experience.

  • Limited Time Offers
  • Year Round Packages & Specials

Top

Limited Time Offers

50 Plus Shopper Perks, Woodburn Premium Outlets
April through December 2015
Join us on Tuesdays for the 50 Plus Shopper Perks. If you are at least 50 years of age you can take advantage of an added 10% savings on Tuesdays by simply presenting a photo identification with your proof of age to the cashier at participating stores. View a list of participating stores at Customer Service located next to Levi's. For more information call 503-980-6442. Woodburn Premium Outlets â€¢ 1001 N Arney Rd, Woodburn, OR 97071

Wine Tour Packages, Starlight Limousine
October 1-December 1, 2015 
8 passenger 6 hour Wine tour. Call 503-566-7827 or 503-983-6332. Reservations online: www.starlightlimousineservices.com A deposit of 50% is required. Refund with 30 day cancellation. $495.00, plus gratuity. www.starlightlimousineservices.com.

Christmas Package, Oregon Garden Resort
November 27 through December 2015
Celebrate the season with this enticing Christmas Package from the Oregon Garden Resort. Start the day with a delicious Continental buffet breakfast before exploring all the beautiful seasonal decor throughout Silverton. Return to our Northern Oregon resort and experience Christmas in the Garden, which features ice skating, artisan vendors, thousands of Christmas lights, fire pits, carolers, Santa, and more. Starting at $139. To purchase this package call 503-874-2500 or visit www.oregongardenresort.com/special-pkg/christmas-packages.aspx. 

Year Round Packages & Specials

A Grand Romance Package ~ Grand Hotel in Salem
This wonderful package includes overnight accommodations for two in your choice of suite, champagne or cider, fresh flowers and our complimentary hot continental breakfast buffet. Enjoy a late checkout of 1 p.m.
For package pricing or to purchase this package, call 877-540-7800 or 503-540-7800 or visit www.GrandHotelSalem.com. This package does not have an expiration date.

Advanced Purchase Package ~ Phoenix Inn Suites South Salem
Are you a business traveler who has a packed calendar of obligations? If you have weekly or monthly travel requirements, you can take advantage of Phoenix Inn's Advanced Purchase Package. This package offers a discounted rate when you reserve a room at least 5 days in advance with payment paid in full with no refunds, cancellations or changes.
To purchase this package call 503-588-9220 or visit www.phoenixinnsuites.com. (Note: Advanced purchase packages can be booked onlinewww.phoenixinnsuites.com and must be booked 5 days in advance.) This package does not have an expiration date.

Complimentary Reserve Tasting for Two ~ Willamette Valley Vineyards 
Receive a complimentary reserve wine tasting for two at Willamette Valley Vineyards. Enjoy six of our award-winning, delicious and sustainable wines at our beautiful Estate Winery. Hours: 11 a.m.-6 p.m. daily.
To receive this deal, you must print a coupon by clicking here and bring it to Willamette Valley Vineyards. No expiration, coupon required. 503-588-9463 or 800-344-9463. www.wvv.com

Create Your Own Stay ~ Grand Hotel in Salem
Create your own stay! Choose one option or choose them all! From A.C. Gilbert's Discovery Village to Special Romance Packages such as balloon rides, romantic dinner and flowers. Let your imagination run WILD!
To purchase this package visit www.GrandHotelSalem.com. This package does not have an expiration date.

Dinner Escape Package ~ Oregon Garden Resort
Get away from it all with the Dinner Escape package at the Oregon Garden Resort. Enjoy a guest room with a fireplace and private patio, two dinner entrees in the Garden View Restaurant, a bottle of wine, breakfast for two and admission to the stunning 80-acre Oregon Garden. Packages start at $109 weekdays, $159 weekends.
To purchase this package visit www.oregongardenresort.com/Packages.htm or call 503-874-2500 or 800-966-6490. This package does not have an expiration date.

Dinner and Movie Package ~ Grand Hotel in Salem
Need a fun night out? Try this package on for size. Start your stay in a suite of your choice. Check in, relax and enjoy dinner at Bentley's Grill (a $75 value). Our on-site restaurant features the finest in Northwest cuisine and one of Willamette Valley's grandest wine selections. Movie passes for two await you in your room at check-in and are valid at any one of Salem's Regal Cinema movie theatres. In the morning, enjoy our complimentary continental breakfast buffet and a late checkout of 1 p.m.
To purchase this package visit www.GrandHotelSalem.com. This package does not have an expiration date.

Explore the Waterfront Package ~ Shilo Inn Suites Salem
Package includes a one night stay at the Shilo Inn Suites in Salem, a gift certificate for 4 to A.C. Gilbert's Discovery Village and 4 tokens for Salem's Riverfront Carousel. Package price: $92 plus tax (additional nights $79.95 plus tax).
To purchase this package call 800-222-2244 or visit www.shiloinns.com. Requires 48 hour notice and has no expiration date.

Girlfriend's Getaway Spa Package ~ Oregon Garden Resort
This includes overnight accommodations, choice of entrÃ©e from the regular dinner menu for each person, bottle of our house label wine served at dinner, one 50 minute Moonstone Spa service for each person on the reservation, $20 retail Moonstone Spa credit for each person on the reservation, breakfast and admission to The Oregon Garden. Starting at $498. To purchase this package call 503-874-2500 or visit www.oregongardenresort.com/special-pkg/girlfriends-getaway-spa-package.aspx. This package does not have an expiration date.

Grand Wine Package ~ Grand Hotel in Salem
Start your day with complimentary wine tasting at Willamette Valley Vineyards. Sample some of the Valley's most enological treasures. Continue your day with a self-guided tour of the Willamette Valley's many vineyards, and finally, a complimentary bottle of Willamette Valley Vineyards wine and an Oregon Wine Guide await you in your room of choice. The Grand Hotel in Salem wine glasses are yours to keep. In the morning, take advantage of our wonderful complimentary continental breakfast buffet. As a final touch, enjoy a late checkout of 1 p.m. Package pricing: Deluxe King - $169, Deluxe Double Queen - $179, King Suite - $189, Double Queen Suite - $199, Jacuzzi King Suite - $229. Additional tax to be added.
To purchase this package call 877-540-7800 or 503-540-7800 or visit www.GrandHotelSalem.com. This package does not have an expiration date.

Mid-Valley Wine Trail or Bust! ~ Grand Hotel Salem
Looking for the ultimate Wine Package?  Look no furtherâ€_youâ€™ve just found it! Enjoy a day or two in the middle of the Willamette Valley, sampling some of the most extraordinary wines around! Available 7 days a week, you choose your dates, book your room and let us help you book your tastings! This package includes:One night stay in a Deluxe King or Deluxe Double Queen. Early Check-in of 12 noon. Four wine tasting passes per guest. Special offers on wine at Bentleyâ€™s Grill from participating vineyards. Complimentary hot breakfast buffet each morning. Late check-out of 1pm day of departure. Choose from these wonderful wineries to visit on The Mid-Valley Wine Trailâ€_Chateau Bianca, VanDuzer Vineyards, Namasteâ€™ Vineyards, Firesteed, Johan Vineyard, Eola Hills Winery, and Left Coast Cellars. Must be 21 years of age or older to reserve this package. Contact the Grand Hotel for rate information 503-540-7800 or 877-540-7800 or book online at www.grandhotelsalem.com. This package does not have an expiration date. Grand Hotel Salem â€¢ 201 Liberty St. SE â€¢ Salem, OR 97301.

North Santiam River Trips Package ~ Grand Hotel Salem
Ever thought of taking a group fishing? Or down the rapids of Packsaddle Park? North Santiam River Trips would like to take groups of four to twenty-four on an adventure of a life time! Four different trips are designed for team work, individual challenges and good group fun. Each trip is unique and will work with you and what your goals are for the day.
Packsaddle Park â€“ Enjoy the biggest rapids and the most thrills.
Fishermanâ€™s Bend â€“ Some whitewater fun, fishing and a relaxing, well-balanced trip.
The Stayton Run or Greenâ€™s Bridge â€“ A few rapids, but moderately tranquil run.
Make reservations at the hotel and plan to stay the night after a great day on the river. Special rates for all groups booking trips with North Santiam. 
Contact the Grand Hotel for rate and booking information 503-540-7800 or 877-540-7800. This package does not have an expiration date. Grand Hotel Salem â€¢ 201 Liberty St. SE â€¢ Salem, OR 97301. 

Northern Lights Package ~ Shilo Inn Suites Salem
Package includes a one night stay at the Shilo Inn Suites in Salem and a $25 gift certificate good for movie tickets and food and beverages at Northern Lights Theatre Pub. Package price: $94.95 plus tax (additional nights $79.95 plus tax).

For a guided tour of the Willamette Valley, contact Danny @ Dannyâ€™s Affordable Wine Tours, 503-871-9144, for more information. Contact the Grand Hotel for rate information 503-540-7800 or 877-540-7800 or book online at www.grandhotelsalem.com. This package does not have an expiration date. Grand Hotel Salem â€¢ 201 Liberty St. SE â€¢ Salem, OR 97301.

Get closer to the one you love amidst our naturally refreshing sanctuary with the Spa Romance Package at the Oregon Garden Resort. Surrounded by 80-acres of botanical beauty, our full-service Moontone Spa facility offers five treatment rooms, a beauty salon, fitness center, outdoor pool, hot tub, manicure-pedicure room, and a luxurious lounge. Willamette Heritage Center's AAA Offer ~ Willamette Heritage Center 
A tour of Mission Mill Museum interprets the history of the Thomas Kay Woolen Mill - designated an American Treasure by the National Park Service - which produced wool products from 1889 to 1962 and represents one of Oregon's earliest and strongest industries. Mission Mill also interprets the history of Jason Lee's Methodist Mission to Oregon which settled in the Willamette Valley in 1834 before the major Oregon Trail migrations. $2 off admission by showing your AAA card.
To redeem this special, present your AAA card at the time of purchase. No expiration date. AAA card must be current. 503-585-7012 or www.WillametteHeritage.org

Limited Time Offers

50 Plus Shopper Perks, Woodburn Premium Outlets
April through December 2015
Join us on Tuesdays for the 50 Plus Shopper Perks. If you are at least 50 years of age you can take advantage of an added 10% savings on Tuesdays by simply presenting a photo identification with your proof of age to the cashier at participating stores. View a list of participating stores at Customer Service located next to Levi's. For more information call 503-980-6442. Woodburn Premium Outlets â€¢ 1001 N Arney Rd, Woodburn, OR 97071

Wine Tour Packages, Starlight Limousine
October 1-December 1, 2015 
8 passenger 6 hour Wine tour. Call 503-566-7827 or 503-983-6332. Reservations online: www.starlightlimousineservices.com A deposit of 50% is required. Refund with 30 day cancellation. $495.00, plus gratuity. www.starlightlimousineservices.com.

Christmas Package, Oregon Garden Resort
November 27 through December 2015
Celebrate the season with this enticing Christmas Package from the Oregon Garden Resort. Start the day with a delicious Continental buffet breakfast before exploring all the beautiful seasonal decor throughout Silverton. Return to our Northern Oregon resort and experience Christmas in the Garden, which features ice skating, artisan vendors, thousands of Christmas lights, fire pits, carolers, Santa, and more. Starting at $139. To purchase this package call 503-874-2500 or visit www.oregongardenresort.com/special-pkg/christmas-packages.aspx.

Meeting Services

Travel Salem is a full-service Association, ready to assist you in all aspects of planning including service-related bids, day tours and activities, dining and hotel accommodations, transportation and information packets. Let us:

  • Coordinate proposals for accommodations, facilities and catering.
  • Assist with pre-and post-conference tours and activities.
  • Arrange site inspections with meeting planners.
  • Provide visitors guides, maps, brochures and customized information.

Directory of Services

Check out the Travel Salem Members that offer:

  • Advertising/Marketing
  • Audio-Visual
  • Awards/Trophies
  • Caterers/Concessions
  • Florist/Nursery
  • Meeting/Event Planning
  • Party Rentals
  • Photography

  • Signs
  • Speakers
  • Transportation
  • Video Production
  • Wedding Services

Contact

Storylines

The History Behind Oregon's Capital & A Pioneering Spirit

Trappers and farmers established some of the earliest permanent settlements in the Willamette Valley region, nestled between the Cascade and Coast mountain ranges...click here for the complete storyline.

Salem's Riverfront Park -- One Park, Many Sights

Bounding the historic downtown district to the west is Salemâ€™s Riverfront Park. Breathtaking views of the river combine with opportunities for outdoor concerts and community events in this picturesque setting...click here for the complete storyline.

Fun for the Entire Family

A neighbor to Salemâ€™s Riverfront Park is A.C. Gilbertâ€™s Discovery Village. This hands-on childrenâ€™s museum appeals to many generations of people who enjoyed A.C. Gilbertâ€™s Erector Set and numerous other inventions...click here for the complete storyline.

The Local Arts Appeal

Salemâ€™s visual and performing arts community is active throughout the year...click here for the complete storyline.

Native American Influence

The Kalapuya Native Americans were the first to reside in what is now Salem. An estimated 80,000 Kalapuya resided in the Willamette Valley and would travel from the Willamette River to gather wild foods such as camas, wapato, and tarweed, and would hunt for deer...click here for the complete storyline.

Fun Activities -- via al fresco

Outdoor activities abound in and near Salem. With the Willamette River flowing through the city, there are many opportunities for water sports â€“ from water-skiing to kayaking and canoeing to fishing for Trout and Salmon...click here for the complete storyline.

Weird and Wonderful

A few unusual sights can be found West of Salem off Highway 18. Although these sights are well known to residents in the area, they continue to attract a lot of attention and generate questions from visitors...click here for the complete storyline.

Culinary -- Your taste buds will thank us

Oregonâ€™s Willamette Valley was a magnet for pioneers seeking rich soils, a mild climate and a healthy growing season for food crops...click here for the complete storyline.

Fruit of the Vine

Salemâ€™s surrounding countryside is home to vineyards and wineries whose wines compete with the finest vintages of Europeâ€™s Alsace, Burgundy and Rhine regions...click here for the complete storyline.

Out and About with the Girls

Home to the only Nordstrom between San Francisco and Portland, and situated just off I-5, Salem is a key shopping destination for the Willamette Valley; perfect for a retreat with the girlfriends. From major names in retail to unique shops with local products, Salem has it all...click here for the complete storyline.

A Photographer's Dream -- Vibrant Gardens

It is little wonder that the Salem area is fortunate to have so many fine gardens. Favorable climatic conditions and the expertise of the people involved in these gardens have led to a rich diversity in design and plant content...click here for the complete storyline.

Interesting Characters

 

Jim Bernau -- A Grower's Passion

The Early Days - As a native Oregonian, Jim Bernauâ€™s love of wine started at the young age of 12. His father, a big booster of new enterprises, did legal work for many small start-ups and often brought home samples of their work...click here for the complete bio.

Roger Tofte -- The Enchanted Forest Story

About the Creator - Roger Tofte, born in 1930 in Chipawa Falls, Wisconsin, moved to Astoria, Oregon when he was 5 years old. In his junior year in high school, he moved to Silverton, Oregon where he graduated from Silverton High School...click here for the complete bio.

 

Mileage & Fast Facts

 

Mileage & Fast Facts

Salem is Oregonâ€™s state capital and the government seat of Marion County...click here for the complete information sheet.

 

 

 


This Project is made possible by a grant from the Oregon Tourism Commission.
This Project is partially funded through City of Salem Transient Occupancy Tax Funds.

December 17, 2012

Printable PDF Version

Kara Kuh
Travel Salem
503-581-4325 ext. 25
kkuh@travelsalem.com 

Travel Salem Hires New Public Relations Manager

SALEM, OR â€” Travel Salem is pleased to announce Kara Kuh as the organizationâ€™s new public relations manager. In this role, Kuh will develop and implement public and media relations activities that promote Salem and Marion and Polk counties for leisure tourism and event business.

Kuh has more than 11 years of experience working in nonprofit communications and public relations. Before joining Travel Salem, she served as the communications specialist for Willamette Humane Society for five years. Prior to that, she worked as the media relations and marketing manager for the American Cancer Society in Portland, Ore.

A native Oregonian, Kuh earned a bachelorâ€™s degree in business administration and marketing from Pacific University in Forest Grove, Ore. While studying at Pacific, she also completed a marketing and PR internship with the Washington County Visitors Association in Beaverton, Ore.

â€œKaraâ€™s many years of experience in communications and media relations will help us promote Salem and the surrounding area as a key destination for leisure and business travelers,â€ù says Irene Bernards, Travel Salemâ€™s Marketing and PR Director. â€œWe look forward to her contributions and are happy she is part of our team!"

###

***Travel Salem is a non-profit organization that promotes the greater Salem area as a premier, year-round destination for conventions, events and leisure travelers. Tourism economic impact for the region is $500 million annually. Travel Salem manages the award-winning Travel CafÃ©, the official Salem area destination visitors center located at the historic Grand Hotel building (181 High St. NE, Salem), two I-5 satellite visitor information locations at the BEST WESTERN PLUS Mill Creek Inn (3125 Ryan Dr. SE) and the Red Lion Hotel (3301 Market St. NE), and a full-service travel planning website www.TravelSalem.com.***

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
September 17, 2012

Printable PDF Version

Irene Bernards
Marketing & PR Director
503-581-4325 ext. 27
ibernards@TravelSalem.com 

WILD PEAR RESTAURANT & TRAVEL SALEM TO REPRESENT

WILLAMETTE VALLEY AT FEAST PORTLAND

World-class culinary event â€“ September 20-23, 2012

SALEM, Ore. â€“ Oregonâ€™s world-class celebration of food and drink called â€œFeast Portlandâ€ù will take place September 20-23, 2012 downtown Portland. Feast will be held in Pioneer Courthouse Square and hold events like the Sandwich Invitational, an Asian-inspired night market, high profile chef demonstrations, conversations with food thought leaders and a whole lot of eating and drinking.

While Portland will be the center of this festival Salem has been offered the opportunity to shine and represent the Willamette Valley at the Travel Oregon ~Oregon Bounty Grand Tasting Tent â€“ Saturday, September 22 from 3:00-4:00pm. Celebrated Salem chef Jeff James, representing the Wild Pear Restaurant, will be highlighting a sample dish using the freshest ingredients from local family farm E.Z. Orchards. Chef James along with, sisters and co-owners of the Wild Pear Restaurant, Cecelia and Jessica Ritter will be on hand to talk to event goers and promote the agricultural bounty of the Willamette Valley and the Wild Pear. Kevin Zielinski with E.Z. Orchards will be serving tastes of their hard cidre and sharing information about their traditional French method of fermentation. Travel Salem representatives will be in attendance promoting Salemâ€™s culinary scene as well as the amenities of the mid-Willamette Valley.

â€œOregon is a true cornucopia and the Willamette Valley is the corner stone of Oregonâ€™s bountiful harvests,â€ù said Irene Bernards, Marketing & PR Director for Travel Salem. â€œMarion County is Oregonâ€™s number one agricultural producing county and we have the opportunity to showcase the delicious offerings of the region and how local chefs partner with farmers and unify agricultural assets into culinary delights,â€ù said Bernards.

Travel Salem approached the Wild Pear Restaurant about representing the Willamette Valley due to their commitment to local, seasonal and organic ingredients and how they use these ingredients in familiar and unexpected ways, whenever possible.

â€œWe are honored to be representing the Willamette Valley at the Oregon Bounty Grand Tasting Tent, â€œ said Cecilia and Jessica, Wild Pear Co-Owners. â€œWe are extremely fortunate to have Chef, Jeff James represent The Wild Pear and our Mid-Willamette Valley region. Chef James has been a guest chef at the James Beard House in New York and also selected for L'Ecole des Chefs in Lyon, France and the Oregon Bounty tour for the United States Dept of Agriculture in Japan. Chef Jamesâ€™ culinary culture and talents has paired well with our company where he has spent the last two years. With a diverse ethnic background of European and Asian descent, we embrace the flavors and styles of many cultures. Our food is best described as New American, which reflects the bold, bright and fresh flavors of our region and the world. We work with local farmers and purveyors to use product that is locally sourced, seasonal, and organic as much as possible.â€ù

For more information regarding Feast Portland visit www.FeastPortland.com.

###

***Wild Pear Restaurant - Cecilia and Jessica Ritter have a knack for taking neglected properties and giving them new life. Their first project in 2000 was the circa 1900 Roberts General Store on River Road South and more recently, since 2004, the circa 1880 Adolph Block Building on State Street in Downtown Salem. Both locations are a reflection of their enthusiasm and passion for what they do. But saving old buildings is just a byproduct of their real businessâ€_food & entertaining.
The sistersâ€™ first entrepreneurial venture into the food industry began back in 2000 when they conceived of and opened Wild Pear Catering and Fine Foods in the old Roberts country store. After a couple of years cultivating a loyal lunch and catering clientele, the two young women were barraged with requests to provide a more full-service venue. And so, dinner service and Karlâ€™s Place, their wine bar, was introduced in June of 2003. The demand for the sisterâ€™s food was so great that they decided to broaden their scope and in June 2004, opened Wild Pear Restaurant & Catering at 372 State Street in downtown Salem, Oregon, where they continue to remain the original â€œwild pair.â€ù
The Ritters make a dynamic business team. Ceciliaâ€™s career has largely been in the service and restaurant management end of the hospitality business, beginning in her late teens with service to beginning management in her early twenties. She continues to use her extensive food, wine and service knowledge in leading her team.
Jessicaâ€™s background has been in the kitchen and catering service from running kitchens to managing catering companies. She has a culinary degree from Boston University, where she had the privilege of having Julia Child as one of her instructors and culinary mentors. Together, the sisters, create the seasonally inspired menus used throughout their company and together manage the large talented staff. ***

***Jeff James Bio - When James' early plans to become a professional drummer or DJ at a radio station fizzled and his only work experience was driving tractor and bailing hay he fell into the restaurant business where he's thrived for almost 30 years. His time as Exec Sous Chef at Salishan Lodge when it was the only 5 star/5 diamond rated resort in Oregon led him to Washington's Methow Valley as Exec Chef of the Freestone Inn then Sun Mountain Lodge. He returned home to the Willamette Valley to open j.james. After selling his eponymous restaurant of 10 years he's teamed with the dynamic duo of the Wild Pear, his wife Cecilia Ritter James and her sister/partner Jessica Ritter at their longtime popular eatery in the heart of the capital city. They've also been caterers to the Governor for the last twelve plus years. (James Beard House guest Chef. Selected for: L'Ecole des Chefs in Lyon, France and the Oregon Bounty tour for the United States Dept of Agriculture in Japan.)***

New Hours for Travel Salemâ€™s Travel CafÃ© Visitors Center

SALEM, Ore. - Beginning July 1 Travel Salemâ€™s Travel CafÃ© Visitors Center will have new hours; Monday through Friday 10:30am to 3:30pm, closed Saturday and Sunday.  These changes are a result of program realignment due to budget restrictions. Travel Salem will continue to maintain program continuity and delivery in a manner that is consistent with visitor expectations.

â€œThe new hours reflect the time of the day with the highest visitor volume,â€ù said Angie Morris, Travel Salemâ€™s CEO.  â€œOur professional staff serve as the regionâ€™s concierge providing Salem visitors with expert local resources and recommendations to help them explore what the area has to offer,â€ù said Morris. The Travel CafÃ© Visitors Center offers wine tasting, ticket sales to events and attractions, GPS rentals, and customized itineraries to name a few.

Travel Salem oversees a visitor information network that includes an official Oregon Travel Plaza located at the BEST WESTERN PLUS Mill Creek Inn, which is open 24 hours a day, 7 days a week; as well as locations at the Red Lion Hotel, Salem Conference Center, Salem Airport, Amtrak, Lancaster Mall, Aurora Airport and the Willamette Heritage Center at The Mill.

After hours visitors will be able to access the Salem Area Visitors Guide, maps and other high demand resources via an outdoor brochure rack. Travel Salem offers Wi-Fi services so visitor information can also be obtained by visiting www.TravelSalem.com.

Local Museums Launch Joint Ticket
Absolutely Heritage: Four Museums for One Ticket

SALEM, Ore. â€“ Four local heritage museums have joined forces to launch a joint admission ticket. The ticket, named the Absolutely Heritage ticket, allows admission to all four museums for $20 and is being sold through Travel Salemâ€™s AbsoluteyTix.com. The participating museums include the Willamette Heritage Center at The Mill, Bush House Museum, Historic Deepwood Estate and the Hallie Ford Museum of Art.

â€œSalem is rich in heritage,â€ù said Peter Booth, Executive Director of the Willamette Heritage Center at The Mill.  â€œBe it the Native art at Hallie Ford, the historical legacy of the Bush family, the Victorian charm of Deepwood or the raw industrial power of the Industrial Age as it came to Oregon. This ticket makes it easier for the visitor and residents alike to discover the cultural treasures here within our community,â€ù said Booth.

The Absolutely Heritage Ticket can be purchased at Travel Salem (181 High St. NE, Salem) or through AbsolutelyTix.com.

TRAVEL SALEM NAMED TOP 100 BEST GREEN COMPANIES TO WORK FOR IN OREGON

SALEM, ORE. â€“â€“ Travel Salem has been selected as a â€œTop 100 Best Green Companies to Work For in Oregonâ€ù by Oregon Business magazine. Weighing in at number 84, Travel Salem was one of only five Salem area businesses recognized.

â€œWe are committed to maintaining a â€_green companyâ€Ÿ and are thrilled to be counted as one of Oregonâ€Ÿs most sustainable organizations,â€ù said Angie Morris, CEO of Travel Salem. â€œSustainability is not only a philosophy, but it has become a way of doing business because â€_greenâ€Ÿ business practices matter to our customers.â€ù

Travel Salemâ€Ÿs â€œGreen Team,â€ù a group of employees charged with making the workplace more sustainable, led the way in developing an eco-savvy culture with buy-in to sustainable practices. Travel Salem is certified EarthWISE through Marion Countyâ€Ÿs business environmental assistance program, incorporating sustainable practices in the business such as recycling, reducing waste and saving energy. Travel Salemâ€Ÿs Travel CafÃ© and administrative office was designed with sustainability in mind: using recycled and earth-friendly materials and features that allow for generous natural light, among other things.

The 100 Best Green Companies in 2012 were selected based on Sustainable Practices sections in both employee and employer surveys completed last year by nearly 20,000 employees from 431 for-profit companies and nonprofit organizations.  The â€œ100 Best Green Companies to Work For in Oregonâ€ù is featured in the June â€œGreen Issueâ€ù of Oregon Business magazine.

Other Salem Businesses Recognized:  #7 Salem Conference Center; #37 Green Acres Landscape; #41 AJâ€Ÿs Auto Repair; #50 Cascade Employers Association; #64 Capital Auto Group & #84 Travel Salem.

Salem Selected for 2013 BMW MOA Rally

Motorcycle event attracts 9000 riders

SALEM, Ore. â€“ The BMW Motorcycle Owners of America (MOA) has selected the Oregon State Fairgrounds in Salem, Oregon as the location for their 2013 International Rally. The event will be taking place July 18-20, 2013. â€œWeâ€™ve had some really great events in Oregon in the past years,â€ù explains BMW MOA president Greg Feeler. â€œOur Rally in Redmond in 2010 was one of our best ever. We are very excited about Salem next year!â€ù

In partnership with the Oregon Sate Fair and Expo Center, Travel Salem was instrumental in attracting the BMW MOA group to Salem. The Rally was initially bid on four years ago, and Travel Salem just recently hosted a two day tour for the rally event planners. The event has grown to average over 9,000 riders and offers its members a place to meet new people, as well as vendors who manufacture specialty motorcycle items. Event attendees can also test ride new motorcycles, or participate in one of 100 seminars and classes being offered.

â€œThe BMW MOA is the largest brand specific motorcycle club in the world that is not owned or operated by the manufactures.  They are a great group of people who are looking forward to their 2013 Rally and spending quality time in the Salem area,â€ù said Debbie McCune, Director of Sales for Travel Salem. â€œSalem is a hospitable community and we want this group to feel welcome, enjoy the area, and come back time and time again,â€ù said McCune.

Founded in 1972, the BMW MOA promotes relationships between individual members and BMW motorcycle clubs, unifying smaller clubs across the US. According to BMW MOA, the economic impact of this group on the Salem area is estimated between $4 and $6 million dollars.

For more information about the BMW Motorcycle Owners of America, visit www.bmwmoa.org or call headquarters at 636-394-7277.

Riverâ€™s Edge Summer Series at Independenceâ€™s Riverview Amphitheater

Featuring The Deadliest Catch, a Night with Capt. Sig Hanson

INDEPENDENCE, Ore. â€“ Riverâ€™s Edge Summer Series will be presenting eight weeks of free concerts, movies, and events at the Riverview Park and Amphitheater in Independence, Oregon. Starting July 1 and running through August 31, the series features blockbusters like Cars 2 and Star Trek, concerts from local and out of state bands, and special events such as a classic car show.

The highlight event will be a showing of the hit reality show The Deadliest Catch on July 21. Captain Sig Hansen will be in attendance to answer questions from the audience. The Discovery Channelâ€™s, Deadliest Catch, has won four Emmy awards and is about the dangerous life of Bering Sea crab fishermen . A crab feed will start at 11:00am, with the show starting at 7:00pm. Tickets are $20 for general admission and $30 for reserved seating. There will be parking at the riverfront.

For more information visit www.independenceamphitheatre.com.

For  tickets, contact Alex Trevino by phone at 503-508-6696 or by email at trevinoenterprise.12@gmail.com.

Travel Salem Announces Recipients of Annual Absolutely Fabulous Awards

SALEM, Ore. â€“ Travel Salem is proud to announce the recipients of the 2011-12 Absolutely Fabulous Awards presented at their May 17, 2012 Marketing Exchange luncheon.

The annual Ab Fab (Absolutely Fabulous) awards recognize people and organizations in the Salem area (including Marion & Polk counties) that have pushed the envelope and turned ideas upside-down and inside out to capture the best return on their marketing, collaboration, partnerships, innovation and regional strategies! They are Absolutely Fabulous!

The eight Travel Salem Ab Fab awards were presented to:

  • Dwane Brenneman â€“ Absolutely Dedicated Award
    For his dedication to Travel Salem and serving as the Associationâ€™s Chair 
  • BEST WESTERN PLUS Mill Creek Inn â€“ Absolutely 24/7 Award
    For serving as a Travel Plaza visitor information center for the Salem area
  • A.C. Gilbertâ€™s Discovery Village â€“ Absolutely Hands-On Award
    For their Hands-On approach to supporting childrenâ€™s education through fun; developing promotions that add to Salemâ€™s vibrant community and quality of life; and working in partnership to attract visitors to the community.
  • Jerry Lauzon â€“ Absolutely â€œOOM-PAPAâ€ù Award
    For his 20+ years as the Mt. Angel Oktoberfestâ€™s volunteer PR & Marketing Director and his ability to bring people together for the good of the community.
  • Lancaster Mall â€“ Absolutely Active Award
    For being active in the community and for the health of area residents (e.g. mall walkers program; serving as a visitor information location; tour & travel trade fair) 
  • World Beat Festival/Salem Multicultural Institute â€“ Absolutely Global Award
    For their tireless efforts to support all cultures and celebrate diversity.
  • Enchanted Forest â€“ Absolutely Inventive Award
    For 40+ years of innovation and outstanding creativity that has attracted millions of visitors to the area.
  • Nancy Stockdale â€“ Absolutely Fabulous Award
    For her entrepreneurial spirit; creative thinking and her support of Salemâ€™s cultural community.

Interested in volunteering?

By joining Travel Salem as a â€œBoosterâ€ù volunteer, you will become part of Salemâ€™s official marketing team. Our teamâ€™s mission is to promote Salem as a leisure and meeting destination to attract visitors from the U.S. and abroad and to help visitors with information to make their stay in Salem more enjoyable.

  • Assist visitors in the Official Salem Area Visitors Center
  • Assist visitors at event informational tables
  • Prepare welcome packets that are distributed to event and convention visitors and delegates
  • Assist with light administrative duties
  • Fulfill visitor information inquiries
  • Boost the Salem economy by serving as public relations representatives for the city and its attractions

Share and be â€œIn the Knowâ€ù!

Monthly meetings held at attractions in and around Salem help our Boosters to be among the first to know about community enhancements and events. Consider joining SCVA to show your enthusiasm about Salem, to become more involved with the community and to help enhance the livability and economy of our city.

For more information, contact: Barb Cowan at 503-581-4325 ext. 21, bcowan@TravelSalem.com or download the Volunteer Information Sheet and deliver it to the Travel Cafe/Visitor Center at 181 High St. NE, Salem.

Interested in learning about tourism marketing opportunities? Want to plug-in to regional marketing programs to promote your business? Travel Salem's Marketing Exchange Luncheons connect businesses and their products and services with visitors, convention delegates, meeting planners, professional travel planners and the media. These bi-monthly events feature engaging topics presented by industry specialists, as well as provide an excellent forum for you to network and collaborate with your partners in the industry. Stay connected with the Marketing Exchange!

Upcoming Marketing Exchange Luncheons:

Please call Tara at Travel Salem to reserve your space, 503-581-4325, ext. 158. 

  • November 19 -- Marketing Exchange Luncheon ~ Chemeketa Center for Business and Industry

column5: Marion & Polk counties offer a wide array of activities to enjoy. You can take a walk next to a beautiful waterfall, or find yourself running along the Willamette River, or barrel tasting a new vintage at one of our many wineries. The Oregon Garden is the most magnificent in the valley with its more than 20 different specialty gardens to please anyone. It is a region to explore and be inspired to create your own adventure, so what are you waiting for?
