column5:
New brand spotlights the best of what Oregon has to offer

SALEM, ORE. â€“â€“ Travel Salem has formally launched a new brand identity that represents the culture, history, capital city, heart of Willamette Valley the best of what Oregon has to offer â€” and further strengthens the alliance in creating a solid front in marketing and positioning the Salem area as a premier destination to the greater community.

â€œAbsolutely Oregonâ€ù
Located in the heart of the state, the Salem area highlights the best of what Oregon has to offer. Oregon is recognized worldwide as being clean, green, innovative and progressive. In the forefront is Salemâ€_developing and investing in green job opportunities by attracting environmental and energy related companies to the area. Salemâ€™s groundbreaking of the Sanyo solar cell factory last October and the development of 515-acre of â€œshovel readyâ€ù land in the Mill Creek Corporate Center are examples of how Salem embodies Oregonâ€™s reputation as a green and sustainable state. Additionally, Salem area businesses and organizations are contributing in a unified approach to being green by becoming EarthWISE certified, a Marion County program that recognizes businesses that have made a commitment to environmentally friendly practices.

Travel Oregon has had great success in marketing and promoting the state. Oregon is home to some of the greatest attractions, events, outdoor recreation, agriculture, and arts and culture. Those very features are seen in abundance in the Salem area and embodies the best of what Oregon has to offer: A lively downtown surrounded by historic buildings, museums, and attractions; beautiful and natural environment ideal for outdoor recreational activities; unique festivals and events showcasing the vibrant and diverse community; and the advantage of relishing some of the stateâ€™s best performing and visual art in an urban setting, yet be minutes away from a rural retreat with award-winning wineries amid breathtaking views in the heart of the Willamette Valley.

After reviewing research from focus groups, online surveys, and a visitor profile study, Travel Salem found that the word â€œAbsolutelyâ€ù (e.g., â€œAbsolutely beautiful,â€ù â€œAbsolutely spectacularâ€ù) was consistently used by residents and visitors to describe the attractiveness of the area; prompting the formation of the slogan â€œAbsolutely Oregon.â€ù

â€œWe wanted to capitalize on the great diversity and vibrancy that Salem possesses,â€ù said Angie Morris, chief executive officer for Travel Salem. â€œSalem is clean, green, and rich in diverse products and recreational opportunities. Itâ€™s also the capital city, which is very significant to the region and a great point of interest for visitors. Thereâ€™s a little bit more Oregon here in Salem than anywhere else,â€ù said Morris.

Visual Element
Travel Salem established a Brand Council, chaired by Roger Yost, that consisted of board members (representatives from Salem and Marion and Polk counties) to oversee the formation of the visual aspect of the brand. Travel Salem contracted with In House Graphics, a graphic design company based in Salem, to develop the visual element of the brand.

â€œThe actual look of the logo is meant to be sparse and sophisticated but convey the richness of our region,â€ù said Morris. â€œThe actual graphic representation of the image and the colors and fonts were chosen to convey to the visitor and anyone that sees it what the region is all about as a destination.â€ù

Specific Components
Travel Salemâ€™s logo consists of several components that symbolize the overall concept of the brand:

  • Dancer: Salem is a culturally significant city through diversity and arts (performing, visual, etc.). These things are woven into the community and are part of what shapes this city. Salem is active with one-of-a-kind events and activities. The Dancer illustrates the personal aspect of the community and true movement. Oregonâ€™s State Motto is, â€œShe flies with her own wings.â€ù Oregon is referred to as a woman. As Oregonâ€™s state capital the dancer also represents Oregon.
  • Urban Landscape: Salem is Oregonâ€™s capital city, where Oregonâ€™s history is alive. It is a bustling community with diverse jobs opportunities (e.g., government, business, industry).
  • Buildings: Salem is a major city in Oregon with a lively downtown that embraces its historic assets to create a vibrant destination.
  • Mountains and River: Salem is nestled in the heart of the Willamette Valley in a beautiful setting surrounded by mountains, agriculture and rivers. It is urban yet minutes away from nature. Salem is a healthy environment with many outdoor recreational opportunities.
  • Crops and Wine Country: Salem is in partnership with nature in the midst of wine country. Agriculture is still very much a part of this urban city with rich soil, green verdant countryside, commodities, bounty and beauty.
  • Absolutely Oregon: As Oregonâ€™s state capital, the Salem area absolutely represents Oregon. It is where state government and law regarding our state take shape, and where Oregonâ€™s first provisional government was formed (Champoeg/Marion County). The bounty of the region in regards to agriculture, history, culture, natural attractions, scenic beauty, cleanliness, hospitality of the people, and large and small communities is uniquely Oregon.
  • Colors: Sage green represents the environmental and outdoorsy aspect of the region. Gold represents the Capitol (gold pioneer) and the maroon represents the vibrancy and richness of the Salem area.
  • Font: The flowing and scripted font for â€œTravelâ€ù conveys life, excitement, art, movement, and vibrancy. â€œSalemâ€ù has a bold and prominent font, expressing the city and the region takes itself seriously as a premier destination.

Establishing Salemâ€™s Brand
â€œAbsolutely Oregonâ€ù fits well in Travel Salemâ€™s efforts to position the Salem area as a premier destination. Using the â€œAbsolutelyâ€ù piece of the slogan as a transferrable marketing element, other industries, businesses and organizations will have the opportunity to create their own catchphrase while establishing synergy in all marketing efforts to create one brand for Salem.

Travel Salem convened a group of key stakeholders to develop a solidified brand position for Salem. Key stakeholders included Mayor Janet Taylor, Mike McLaren of the Salem Area Chamber of Commerce, Ray Burstedt of SEDCOR (Strategic Economic Development Corporation), and Suzi Bicknell of Go Downtown! This group reviewed opportunities related to â€œAbsolutely Oregon,â€ù and settled on an approach that would help give Salem a solidified platform to position and market economic development opportunities. Using Absolutelyâ€ù as the through line that ties Salemâ€™s brand together, key economic development partners will incorporate the following into their own brand and marketing strategies:

  • Salem Area Chamber of Commerce: â€œLeading Businesses Absolutelyâ€ù
    SEDCOR: â€œAbsolutely Readyâ€ù
    Go Downtown!: â€œGo Downtown for Absolutely Everythingâ€ù

â€œWith the recent name change to Travel Salem and this Salem brand that the organization has created, it has become more clearly defined the important role of our community in attracting tourism to support the economy of the area,â€ù said Janet Taylor, mayor of Salem. â€œThe fact that it ties into the State tourism strategies allows us to leverage our local dollars to reach a wider range of travelers. We are so fortunate to have the passion and skills of our Travel Salem organization to lead this effort,â€ù said Mayor Taylor.

â€œItâ€™s important that Salem has a strong branding strategy to be competitive among growing cities,â€ù said Bicknell, executive director of Go Downtown! â€œFurthermore, itâ€™s significant that individual entities within Salem carry on the same message to solidify the Salem marketplace.â€ù

â€œThis provides great opportunities for all organizations in the area to be connected in a unified approach and at the same time keep their own flavor,â€ù said McLaren, chief executive officer for the Salem Area Chamber of Commerce.

The Association has trademarked â€œAbsolutely Oregonâ€ù and â€œTravel CafÃ©â€ù and will be implementing these verbiages into all marketing efforts.

All businesses and organizations are encouraged to get on board and tie-in to Salemâ€™s brand. If a business or organization is interested in tapping into this powerful brand identity, please contact Travel Salem which will oversee and ensure the integrity of the â€œAbsolutely Oregonâ€ù brand.

###

***Travel Salem is a non-profit organization that promotes Salem and Marion and Polk counties for leisure tourism and convention and event business. The local annual economic impact of the greater Salem area visitor industry is $511.8 million. Travel Salem manages the Official Salem Area Visitors Center currently located at Mission Mill Museum (until January 31, 2009 then located at 181 High St. NE, Salem) and the Official Salem Area Website www.TravelSalem.com***

column4: My business is not directly involved with visitors. Should I join Travel Salem anyway?
column5: While you may not offer a service directly to the visitor, your business might be important to front line hospitality businesses like hotels, restaurants, car rental agencies, etc. Many "non-visitor industry" businesses join Travel Salem to form relationships with front-line visitor service businesses. Some examples are web designers, banks, accountants, promotional products companies, and video production companies.
column6: While you may not offer a service directly to the visitor, your business might be important to front line hospitality businesses like hotels, restaurants, car rental agencies, etc. Many "non-visitor industry" businesses join Travel Salem to form relationships with front-line visitor service businesses. Some examples are web designers, banks, accountants, promotional products companies, and video production companies.

column4: How is the Travel Salem different from a Chamber of Commerce?
column5: Convention and Visitors Associations (CVA) are similar to Chambers of Commerce in that both organizations develop the economic health and vitality of the community. CVA's use tourism and convention marketing as an economic development strategy. A Chamber of Commerce will usually have a broader focus for developing the business community.

CVA's use tourism and convention marketing as an economic development strategy. A Chamber of Commerce will usually have a broader focus for developing the business community.

column5:
The industry has become more sophisticated in how destination marketing organizations (DMOs) market their products and services, and deliver value to the communities they serve. Travel Salem has evolved over the last couple years as well reinventing itself to be more in line with industry standards and progressive in its approach.

After researching membership structures regionally and nationally, Travel Salem developed a brand-new concept for membership that allows businesses to pick and choose which marketing options best meet their needs, and ultimately control their financial investment. The new program offers marketing options not previously available and the dues reflect this change. The dues are cost effective for the return on the investment â€“ averaging $450 for an entire year of promotion. Membership with Travel Salem delivers tangible benefits through value-driven programs and services.

Travel Salem remains committed to a basic level of marketing support for the City of Salem. The following services will continue to be provided at no charge to businesses within Salem city limits â€“ leads for conferences and events, weekly consumer and industry e-newsletter, regional and national public relations efforts, and leisure and conference advertising.

column4: Why is Travel Salem charging for marketing services that used to be free?
column5:
Marketing options such as the Visitors Guide listings used to be free, right? Not exactly, listing fees were included in the display advertising rates. These fees are now sold separately so Members can mix and match options to build their own marketing package. The goal is to give Members more flexibility in choosing marketing services. For instance, some businesses want a listing but not a display ad, and vice versa.

What about putting a brochure in the Visitors Center â€“ that used to be free? Yes â€“ it was a free service previously. Because of limited space for displaying brochures, Travel Salem is now charging a nominal annual fee for businesses who want their materials distributed. These fees go back into supporting the operation of the Visitors Center.

Another reason for the change is that for every $1 received from the City of Salem, Travel Salem has to generate an additional $3 from outside sources. We are flanked to the north and south by organizations with multi-million marketing budgets. And in order to operate as a regional DMO serving Salem, Marion and Polk counties, Travel Salem needs broad-based financial support to succeed in this extremely competitive tourism industry.

column4: Why is there an â€œinsideâ€ù and â€œoutsideâ€ù pricing structure?
column5:
Travel Salem must operate under the City of Salemâ€™s Charter which states that transient occupancy tax dollars (TOT or lodging tax dollars) collected by the City of Salem can only be used to promote the city of Salem. However, the City of Salem also understands that the assets of the entire region benefit Salem, and conversely that Salemâ€™s assets benefit the region. In order for Travel Salem to serve as a regional DMO, the Association must generate additional revenues to leverage current marketing dollars provided by the City of Salem.

The â€œinsideâ€ù pricing is for businesses located within Salem city limits. Businesses located â€œoutsideâ€ù the Salem city limits pay an additional percentage. For Travel Salem to operate within its contractual obligations with the City of Salem and within the parameters of the law/City Charter, the â€œoutsideâ€ù fees are a necessity.
column6: Travel Salem must operate under the City of Salemâ€™s Charter which states that transient occupancy tax dollars (TOT or lodging tax dollars) collected by the City of Salem can only be used to promote the city of Salem. However, the City of Salem also understands that the assets of the entire region benefit Salem, and conversely that Salemâ€™s assets benefit the region. In order for Travel Salem to serve as a regional DMO, the Association must generate additional revenues to leverage current marketing dollars provided by the City of Salem.

column4: I don't have time to go to networking events. Will I miss out on other benefits because I can't participate?
column5: While networking is a great membership benefit, there are a lot of other benefits that don't require your participation. Some examples are listings in Travel Salem's publications, newsletter inserts and advertising leads, to name a few.
column6: While networking is a great membership benefit, there are a lot of other benefits that don't require your participation. Some examples are listings in Travel Salem's publications, newsletter inserts and advertising leads, to name a few.

column4: Do Visitors really come to Salem? What do they come to see?
column5: Visitors really do come to Salem! Some of our most visited attractions are the State Capitol, Bush House, Historic Deepwood Estate, AC Gilbert's Discovery Village and Salem's Riverfront Carousel. Also, visitors to regional attractions like Silver Falls State Park, The Oregon Garden, and Woodburn Company Stores use Salem as "home base" for their adventures in the two county area.

Travel Salem: New Brand, Name & Award Winning Location

We are excited that you have stopped by TravelSalem.com to inquire more about what is happening at the Travel Salem office. Below you will find resourceful information about the move, new brand and name change. Check back often as we will be updating information as the project progresses!

Sincerely,
Travel Salem Staff

column5:
Located in the heart of the Willamette Valley along the Interstate-5 corridor, Salem offers a convenient destination for visiting the Oregon State Capitol, historic museums, wine country, The Oregon Garden, and many more exciting attractions and activities.

Salem's Airport, McNary Field, is just 3 miles from downtown Salem. The airport offers convenient access to General Aviation and Corporate Jet Aircraft. The airport has full service FBO and 24-hour fueling services available. Car rentals are available at the Salem airport terminal building.

Salem is an easy town to travel within, using a car or our local transit system, Cherriots. We are proud of our location and hope you visit soon!

Stay safe during winter, download "The Oregon Winter Driving Guide" for tips on how to arrive safely at your destination.

column5:
E-Postcards (e-vites ) Instructions For Use

To complement your marketing efforts, we have a variety of e-vites to promote your Salem, Oregon conference, meeting or event. Each postcard is ready for customization and is designed to showcase the beauty of the Salem area.

To use this tool with an Internet Explorer browser:

  1. Click on the type of e-vite. It will open a new window.
  2. Click "File" menu
  3. Select "Send"
  4. Select and click "Page by E-mail"
  5. Customize with copy. You will be able to enter your own text between the header and footer.
  6. Load email addresses
  7. E-mail
    8.

Are you a business traveler who has a packed calendar of obligations? If you have weekly or monthly travel requirements, you can take advantage of Phoenix Inn's Advanced Purchase Package. This package offers a discounted rate when you reserve a room at least 5 days in advance with payment paid in full with no refunds, cancellations or changes.

To purchase this package please call 503-588-9220 or visit www.phoenixinnsuites.com. (Note: Advanced purchase packages can be booked online www.phoenixinnsuites.com and must be booked 5 days in advance.) This package does not have an expiration date.

column4: Oregonâ€™s Visitor Industry Honors Travel Salem
column5:
Travel Salem received the Oregon Governorâ€™s Creative Tourism Development Award Sunday, April 19, 2009 at the 25th Annual Governorâ€™s Conference on Tourism held in Salem at the Salem Conference Center. This prestigious award was presented to Travel Salem from the Oregon Tourism Commission for the creation of the Travel Salem Travel CafÃ©. The award recognizes an innovative program, promotion, or product by an Oregon individual, organization, business, community or region which epitomizes a new way of thinking about the tourism and hospitality industry.

On hand to accept the award for Travel Salem was Angie Morris, President & CEO; Irene Bernards, Tourism Marketing & PR Director; Debbie McCune, Director of Sales; Kathie Reeves,Â Marketing & Online Manager; Sue Nichols, Community Development Director; and Anthony Tham, Public Relations Manager.

â€œThis project started with a vision to dramatically improve how we showcase our region and how we connect with the visitor. As the project moved forward, the concept gained momentum and support from partners who believed in its ability to drive economic development. The Travel CafÃ© is the direct result of our community pulling together to create something fresh and exciting â€“ for both visitors and local residents. By design, it reflects the beauty and vibrancy of our region, and enhances our ability to sell the Salem area as a true destination,â€ù said Morris.

Travel Salem has been recognized five other times throughout the Associationâ€™s history with Governorâ€™s Tourism Awards including the 1991, 1993 and 2005 Governorâ€™s Regional Tourism Award, which recognizes cooperative marketing efforts; the 1997 Governorâ€™s Tourism Award; and the 2008 Tourism Industry Awareness Award.

The TravelSalem.com website is the official tourism and meeting website for Salem and had 250,000 visits to the site during 2007-08.

column4: Travel Salem partners with Box Office Tickets on AbsolutelyTix
column5:
Travel Salem has partnered with Box Office Tickets to bring AbsolutelyTix, a new ticketing network for Salem and Marion and Polk counties. The new AbsolutelyTix network makes it easy for local arts, non-profit, and other community organizations to promote events, sell tickets and transact other business over the Internet. It also provides a single source of online information about upcoming local shows and events.

â€œAbsolutelyTix furthers our mission to be a comprehensive resource for visitors through our Travel CafÃ©, which will now serve as a centralized ticketing outlet,â€ù said Angie Morris, President and CEO of Travel Salem. â€œIt also gives us the opportunity to support our local nonprofit organizations and partners by providing a much-needed service for ticketing. We partnered with Box Office Tickets because of its state-of-the-art ticketing, access to services and local focus." What's more, notes Morris, five cents from each ticket sold on www.absolutelytix.com will be donated to an area non-profit organization each year.

Box Office Tickets Inc., the first ticketing company to bring Web 2.0 to local arts and cultural communities, has been empowering the event and entertainment industry through innovative services since 1993. Known for the quality of its customer service and technology, boxofficetickets.com is a national brand with proven experiences in handling all types of events â€“ the arts, sports, business conferences, etc.

"We're pleased to partner with Travel Salem to create a local ticketing network that will help connect people to events and support the local economy," said George Domurot, President/CEO of Box Office Tickets Inc. "Our online ticketing and transaction capabilities combined with Travel Salem's marketing and visitor outreach enables local organizations to promote their events and sell tickets to a much broader audience through the network."

The AbsolutelyTix network is open to all theaters and groups with ticketing needs in Salem and Marion and Polk Counties. There are no fees for network partner organizations.
Those interested in partnering with Travel Salem in AbsolutelyTix should contact Angie Morris at 503-581-4325, ext. 26 or amorris@travelsalem.com.

column4: Travel Salem join forces with SalemAlive.com â€“ Absolutely Eventful to bring new, comprehensive website of Salem Events
column5:
Since the summer of 2007, a group of Salemâ€™s large downtown employers have been actively pursuing Vision 2020 projects to enhance the heart of the City - downtown, north downtown, and the Edgewater/Wallace area of West Salem. From this collaboration, SalemAlive.com, a comprehensive website of Salem events, has been created.

Travel Salem provided the TravelSalem.com website as a host for SalemAlive.com. Residents and visitors can easily access additional information regarding attractions, special packages, and promotions to encourage the discovery of their community and the two-county region.

One of the Vision 2020 goals, identified in community conversations last year, was to better coordinate the marketing and advertising of City Center activities. A subcommittee was formed specifically tasked with creating a broad-reaching, single source of events information to bring Salem residents and visitors to the City Center. The subcommittee includes several local businesses including Travel Salem, Grand Hotel in Salem, Willamette University, Mission Mill Museum, , Go Downtown Salem!, Chemeketa Community College, Chamber of Commerce, Salem Health, and Elsinore Theatre.

SalemAlive.com went live on March 30 and allows residents to search for activities within the City Center, by location or interest area. SalemAlive.com also offers residents the ability to â€œself-submitâ€ù events that may be of interest to residents and visitors alike.

column4: The Importance of a Thriving Downtown for Tourism
column5:
Visitors to a region or city can get a good feel for a community from its downtown. Unique boutiques, one-of-a-kind shops, diversity of local performing and visual art, a mixture of restaurants, combined with outstanding architecture, history and festive events and promotions, characterize a successful downtown. Visitors are attracted to downtowns such as this and Salemâ€™s downtown fits that illustration perfectly. Successful downtowns are viewed as a destination in their own right. Travel Salemâ€™s Visitor Profile study points out that downtown Salem is viewed as a leading activity during a visitors stay.

Traditionally, a downtown serves as a town square or hub for community gatherings; known for its sense of welcome and hospitality. Although unique shops and promotions are available in other shopping venues, the downtown atmosphere cannot be duplicated.

The distinct look and feel of Salemâ€™s downtown core is created by the richness of its history. The Historic Elsinore Theater, a 1926 Tudor Gothic movie palace, and the Reed Opera House, are examples of the significance of historical entities in a thriving downtown community.

As Salemâ€™s living room, historic downtown is a vibrant downtown with all the elements needed to maintain its â€œdestinationâ€ù status. With its inviting atmosphere and coordinated events such as First Wednesday, downtown Salem introduces visitors to the distinctiveness of Salem and encourages the consideration of what the rest of this region has to offer.

Downtown Salem is the focus of Salem Vision 2020, a community-wide team, chaired by Mayor Janet Taylor, that works to shape the future of Salemâ€™s City Center. The foresight of Vision 2020 is to transform Salemâ€™s downtown into a vibrant, year-round regional destination for employees, visitors, and residents by the year 2020.

With its current amenities, development, revitalization and community involvement, downtown Salem will continue to be one of the regionâ€™s major destinations.

~ Angie Morris, Travel Salemâ€™s CEO

* Originally printed in Statesman Journal, 3/22/09

column4: The Value of Twitter in 2,247 Characters
column5:
Twitter is a social networking site that allows friends, family, and co-workers to communicate and stay connected through the exchange of short (140 characters or less) and frequent answers to one simple question: What are you doing?

It has quickly evolved into a tool that businesses and organizations use to market themselves to a generation focused on obtaining information using technology.

Travel Salem has been using Twitter to communicate and stay connected with consumers and regional partners through the exchange of quick real-time updates. News, upcoming events, and promotions are some examples of what Travel Salem has been tweeting about to an audience of local, national, and international â€œfollowersâ€ù (people that follow our tweets). In addition, information sent on Twitter is displayed on a public timeline, making tweets (the message that is sent out) viewable to more than 14 million users in the U.S. alone. Talk about getting your name out there!

Travel Salemâ€™s social media strategy using Twitter has already seen amazing results â€”the Travel CafÃ© coverage on KGWâ€™s Live@7, Statesman Journal covering tweets during a recent Santiam River rafting trip, and numerous blogs written about local attractions and lodging facilities from a well-known travel writer from California.

Are you using Twitter already? Follow us at www.twitter.com/travelsalem and weâ€™ll follow back! Referencing fellow â€œtweepsâ€ù (people/businesses that use Twitter) on tweets enables us to package the Salem region as a whole by driving consumers that view our tweets to your businessesâ€™ page.

Interested in â€œjumping on the bandwagon?â€ù Contact Anthony Tham, Travel Salemâ€™s Public Relations Manager, to assist you in setting up your Twitter account and for effective strategies to strengthen your brand and positively position your business or organization in front of consumers. If youâ€™re not looking to create an account but want to be involved, you can feed us information about your business so that we can use to develop a tweet under Travel Salemâ€™s account, which represents the Salem region. Information can range from upcoming events, news, promotions, etc. Send possible tweets to Anthony Tham, atham@travelsalem.com with â€œTwitterâ€ù on the subject line.

column5:
Salem area events are extremely important in attracting visitors to the area but they also add to the quality of life here in Salem and the Marion and Polk counties region. Please remember to post your events for FREE at TravelSalem.com through a self-submittal online process. Be sure to visit TravelSalem.com to learn about the various events taking place in your community. Letâ€™s help support these events and encourage visitors to take an extra day, or two, in Salem to enjoy these unique activities.

Here is a sample of a few upcoming events that help make the Salem area such a great place to live, work and play!

Silverton Hills Strawberry Festival
06/21/2009
Celebrate Father's Day with shortcake and all-you-can-eat strawberries served in the pavilion in Coolidge McClaine park. Also crafts, music & fun activities for the whole family. Fee charged. 11:00 a.m.-4 p.m.
Coolidge McClaine Park
Coolidge & Charles Streets
Silverton, OR 97381
503-508-9591
www.homerdavenport.com

Salem Keizer Volcanoes
06/23/2009
Opening Night! Come help us celebrate. Admission starts at $7. 6:35 p.m.
Salem Keizer Volcanoes Stadium
6700 Field of Dreams Way
Keizer, OR 97303
503-390-2225
www.volcanoesbaseball.com

12th Annual World Beat Festival
06/27/2009-06/28/2009
Immerse yourself in everything the world has to offer. While our 2009 focus is â€œInto Africa,â€ù and the far-reaching influences of that diverse continent, our numerous will performances/lectures showcase global culture. Requested $3 donation. Sat. 10 a.m.-11 p.m., Sun. 10 a.m.-6 p.m.
Salemâ€™s Riverfront Park
116 Marion St. NE
Salem, OR 97301
503-581-2004
www.worldbeatfestival.org

Eoff Electric Supply July 4th Celebration 
07/03/2009-07/05/2009
Family-friendly, traditional community Independence Day celebration. Fireworks over the Willamette River Friday & Saturday nights, July 3 & 4. Large carnival, live music, classic and antique car show, food/beverage booths. $3 suggested donation per adult, children free. Fri. 4-11 p.m., Sat. noon-11 p.m., Sun. 2-7 p.m.
Salem's Riverfront Park - downtown Salem
116 Marion St. NE
Salem, OR 97301
503-910-4487
www.entertainmentconsultantsllc.com

Marion County Fair
07/09/2009-07/12/2009
â€œGreen and Growing, Celebrating 150 Years of A Clean and Green Oregon.â€ù There is so much going on at the Marion County Fair, it may be the best kept secret in the county! Adults $7.50, youth (ages 6-11) $3.50, 5 and under are FREE, family ticket (includes 2 adults and up to 4 youth) $24. Free parking. Thurs. 10 a.m.-10 p.m.; Fri. & Sat. 10 a.m.-11 p.m.; Sun. 10 a.m.-6 p.m.
Oregon State Fairgrounds
2330 17th St. NE
Salem, OR 97301
503-585-9998
www.mcfair.net

Wine and Food Festival - 2009
07/11/2009
Hot jazz, cool wine and great food combine for a great summer event.  Featuring 15 wineries and live music by Portland's Kate Davis, Bobby Lincoln and Ronnie Steen trio and others. $20 includes 10 pours and admission to all music. Free parking.
Historic Deepwood Estate
1116 Mission St. SE
Salem, OR 97302
503-363-1825
www.historicdeepwoodestate.org

The 60th Anniversary Salem Art Fair & Festival
07/17/2009-07/19/2009
Two-hundred artists from across the U.S. and Canada selling their wares, live music and performances, hands-on activities for kids, food courts, wine and beer gardens, tours of Bush House Museum and free exhibits at Bush Barn Art Center. $5 suggested donation. Fri.-Sat. 10 a.m.-7 p.m. & Sun. 10 a.m.-5 p.m.
Bush's Pasture Park
600 Mission St. SE
Salem, OR 97302
503-581-2228
www.SalemArt.org

39th Annual Great Oregon Steam-Up
07/25/2009-07/26/2009 & 08/01/2009-08/02/2009
You can see lots of antique operable steam powered tractors, sawmill, large engines, farm equipment in a parade; camping available. Admission $8, children 12 and under free.
Antique Powerland
3995 Brooklake Rd.
Brooks, OR 97303
503-393-2424
www.antiquepowerland.com

Polk County Fair
08/06/2009-08/09/2009
Good old fashion Family Fair, great food, free kids area, teen zone with Guitar Hero and Wii games, 4-H & FFA exhibits, livestock auction, clowns, entertainment and much, much more. $6 adults, seniors 62+ & kids 11 - 15 $3, 10 and under free, season passes available. Thurs.-Sat. 10 a.m.-10 p.m., Sun. 10 a.m.-6 p.m.
Polk County Fairgrounds
520 S Pacific Hwy W
Rickreall, OR 97371
503-623-3048 or 888-229-6818
www.co.polk.or.us/fair

column4: Past M.E. Luncheon Videos & Presentation Info
column5:
Did you miss the last Travel Salem Marketing Exchange? Click on a date below to view the presentation information and video online.

  • March 18, 2010 - Hosted by Marco Polo Global Restaurant featuring Jennifer McCormick of Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.
  • January 21, 2010 - Hosted by Keizer Renaissance Inn featuring Jennifer Larsen Morrow of Creative Company.
  • November 19, 2009 - Hosted by Mission Mill Museum part of Willamette Heritage Center featuring keynote speaker Melody Johnson of International Culinary Tourism Association.
  • September 17, 2009 - Hosted by Alessandro's Ristorante and Galleria featuring keynote speaker Jim Bernau, Founder of Willamette Valley Vineyards.
  • July 16, 2009 - Hosted by Willamette Valley Event Center featuring keynote speaker Chris Coleman, Artistic Director of Portland Center Stage.
  • May 28, 2009 - Hosted by Red Lion Hotel Salem featuring keynote speaker Scott West, Chief Strategy Office with Travel Oregon.

column5:
Oregon State Capitol
900 Court St. NE
Salem, OR 97301
503-986-1388
www.oregonlegislature.gov
Recommended Time Allotment: 1 hour
Marble adorns Oregonâ€™s Capitol built in 1938. Atop the dome sits the â€œGold Pioneerâ€ù. Tours of the building and tower are available, call for times.

Willamette Heritage Center
1313 Mill St. SE
Salem, OR 97301
503-585-7012
www.WillametteHeritage.org
Recommended Time Allotment: 2 hours
Willamette Heritage Center preserves three 1840â€™s Mission houses and a 19th century woolen mill; the Museum interprets Western Oregonâ€™s settlement and industry. Visit Oregonâ€™s American Treasure.

Lunch and Shopping.
Historic Downtown Salem.
Roughly bounded by Chemeketa, High, Ferry, and Front Streets.
Recommended Time Allotment: 2 hours
Visitors appreciate historic downtownâ€™s beautiful architecture, mix of delicious eateries, unique shops, art galleries, salons, and major department stores. Entertainment and walking tours available (self-guided).

World Beat Gallery
189 Liberty St. NE, #211B (Located inside Reed Opera House)
Salem, OR 97301
503-581-2004
www.salemmulticultural.org
Recommended Time Allotment: 30-45 minutes
Cultural exhibitions from Salemâ€™s ethnic communities displayed all year.  2010 themes include Samoa, India, international marriage customs and winter holidays around the world.

Historic Elsinore Theatre
170 High St. SE
Salem, OR 97301
503-375-3574
www.ElsinoreTheatre.com
Recommended Time Allotment: 1 hour
Enjoy a performance or classic film in Salemâ€™s restored 1926 vaudeville theatre. From â€œBach to Rockâ€ù and â€œBroadway to Balletâ€ù the Elsinore has it all.

Bush House Museum/Salem Art Association
600 Mission St. SE
Salem, OR 97302
503-581-2228
www.salemart.org
Recommended Time Allotment: 30 minutes (or 1 hour if weather permits for garden viewing)
Built in 1878 by Asahel Bush II, this Italianate-style Victorian mansion and Conservatory in Bushâ€™s Pasture Park features changing exhibits, original fine art and furnishings.

Deepwood Museum and Gardens
1116 Mission St. SE
Salem, OR 97302
503-363-1825
www.historicdeepwoodestate.org
Recommended Time Allotment: 30 minutes (or 1 hour if weather permits for garden viewing)
An 1894 Queen Anne Victorian, located on 4.5 acres of historic gardens and nature trails, featuring exquisite stained glass and golden oak woodwork.

Dinner.
Contact Travel Salem for recommendations or review the dining section of TravelSalem.com.
181 High St. NE
Salem, OR 97301
503-581-4325 or 800-874-7012
Salem offers dining for all likes and price ranges. From Chinese cuisine to Italian elegance, Salem has it and more.

column5:
Schreiner's Iris Gardens
3625 Quinaby Rd. NE
Salem, Oregon 97303
503-393-3232 or 800-525-2367
www.schreinersgardens.com
We invite you to visit our lush 10-acre display garden, just north of Salem, Oregon. Schreinerâ€™s Iris Gardens is one of the Worldâ€™s largest Iris growers and we are proud to be family owned. We have acres and acres of iris that bloom during May and are absolutely spectacular to see. The fields are colorful rainbows that attract the attention of travelers since our farm can be seen from Interstate-5. We encourage you to visit us during our May bloom season, however we are open and ready to greet you throughout the year.
Contact:  Steve Schreiner, iris@schreinersgardens.com
Group Size:  No maximum
Cost:  Free
Month(s) of Operation:  Year-round. Bloom Season is in May (best time to visit)
Bus Parking Available:  Yes
Handicap Accessible:  Yes
Public Restrooms Available:  Yes
Recommended Time Allotment:  1 hour

The Oregon Garden
879 W Main St.
Silverton, Oregon 97381
503-874-8100 or 877-674-2733
www.oregongarden.org
The Oregon Garden is one of Oregon's most popular destinations! While visiting you will discover thousands of plants that are displayed in more than 20 specialty gardens within the 80-acre garden. You will also find that The Oregon Garden is much more than a garden. We offer serene water features, garden art, wetlands with native birds, a playful garden just for kids, a 400-year-old Signature Oak tree and the Gordon House, the only house in Oregon designed by the legendary architect Frank Lloyd Wright. We welcome you to discover how easy it is to relax and soak in Oregonâ€™s natural beauty at The Oregon Garden.
Contact:  Douglas Jenkins
Group Size:  No maximum, groups over 14 eligible for group rates
Cost:  Group rates November-March, $6 per person / April-October, $8 per person; Individual rate November-March, $8 adult, $7 senior & $6 student / April-October $10 adult, $9 senior, $8 student Children 7 and under are free (*all prices subject to change)
Month(s) & hours of operation:  May-September 10 a.m.-6 p.m. / October-April 10 a.m.-4 p.m.
Bus Parking Available:  Yes
Handicap Accessible:  Yes
Public Restrooms Available:  Yes
Recommended Time Allotment:  2 hours

LUNCH
Oregon Garden Resort
895 W Main St.
Silverton, Oregon 97381
503-874-2500 or 800-966-6490
www.oregongardenresort.com
Beautiful setting overlooking The Oregon Garden.

E.Z. Orchards Farm Market
5504 Hazel Green Rd.
Salem, Oregon 97305
503-393-1506
www.ezorchards.com
Your group will love E.Z. Orchards Farm Market â€“ a true farm experience for groups of all sizes. Our 4th generation farm grows apples, pears, peaches, pumpkins and corn. We offer blossom tours in the spring and have a fun filled Harvest Festival each October with:  hay rides, Lewis & Clark theme corn maze, mountain men re-enactors, pumpkin patch, petting zoo, live bluegrass music, pony rides, and tasty fall treats. Summer months bring fresh fruit milk shakes, smoothies and delicious strawberry, blackberry and peach shortcakes. E.Z. Orchards has the best selection of Oregon and northwest gourmet food in the Willamette Valley. And we offer the finest local fruits and vegetables.
Contact:  John Zielinski, john@ezorchards.com
Group Size:  75-100 people November-September or up to 300 people in October
Cost:  Varies
Month(s) of Operation:  Year-round, Sundays only in October
Bus Parking Available:  Yes
Handicap Accessible:  Yes
Public Restrooms Available:  Yes
Recommended Time Allotment:  1 hour

Willamette Valley Pie Company
2994 82nd Ave. NE
Salem, Oregon 97305
503-362-8857
www.wvpie.com
If your group is ready for a mouthwatering experience they will find it at the Willamette Valley PieCompany. Let us treat you to the best from our land to your hands! We will teach you about the berry industry from farm to finished product. We'll take you through berry fields, show you our processing facility and guide you through the process of making our hand-crafted all-natural fruit pies. You'll even have an opportunity to enjoy a slice!
Contact:  Marlene Gunderson, info@wvfco.com
Group Size:  30 or less, 50-60 with advanced notice (group will be split)
Cost:  Free
Month(s) & hours of operation:  Year round, Monday-Friday 7 a.m.-6 p.m., Saturday 9 a.m.-5 p.m., closed Sundays.
Bus Parking Available:  Yes
Handicap Accessible:  Yes
Public Restrooms Available:  Yes
Recommended Time Allotment:  1 hour

OVERNIGHT
Grand Hotel Salem (groups or FIT)
201 Liberty St. SE
Salem, Oregon 97301
503-540-7800 or 877-540-7800
www.grandhotelsalem.com

Shilo Inn Suites (groups or FIT)
3304 Market St. NE
Salem, OR 97301
503-581-4001 or 800-222-2244
www.shiloinns.com

www.wvpie.com
If your group is ready for a mouthwatering experience they will find it at the Willamette Valley PieCompany. Let us treat you to the best from our land to your hands! We will teach you about the berry industry from farm to finished product. We'll take you through berry fields, show you our processing facility and guide you through the process of making our hand-crafted all-natural fruit pies. You'll even have an opportunity to enjoy a slice!

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
June, 2015
Printable PDF Version		Kara Kuh
Travel Salem
503-581-4325 ext. 24
kkuh@travelsalem.com

Global Greeter Network Announces Salem Oregon as the 100th Destination
 

SALEM, OR â€” The Global Greeter Network (GGN) is proud to announce Salem, Oregon as the100th destination in its networks. Salem joins cities such as Paris, Buenos Aires, London, New York, Berlin, Shanghai and 93 other cities throughout the world as an official Greeter destination, where thousands of volunteers worldwide share their personal insights and knowledge about â€œtheir cityâ€ù with visitors. 

What is Greeters?
The Greeter program is still unknown to many people, but the concept is rapidly catching on throughout the world. In the last three months, more than 10 cities have joined the network including Sofia, Bulgaria; Sydney, Australia; and Vienna, Austria.

The concept is simple and based on the idea that most people are truly proud and passionate about their city.  A Greeter volunteer shares knowledge about a destination - not as a tour guide but as a resident of the city, sharing his or her personal story and knowledge about the history and culture of the city. Greeters follow a strict no tipping policy. The walk - or greet, as Greeter destinations call it -  is a gift from the host city to the visitor.

History
The Greeters program officially started in 1992, but was founded on principles introduced by the late Lynn Brooks, who was born and raised in New York in the 1920s. Lynn was troubled by the poor image of the city and decided to show people the â€œgood side of her village.â€ù Based on Lynnâ€™s initial work, the Big Apple Greeters Program was born. Over the last five years, the Greeters concept has gained momentum as more people want to start a local Greeter organization in their community to build upon the services offered to visitors. 

Facts and Figures

  • At the end of 2013, there were approximately 50 to 60 destinations participating in the Global Greeter Network.  At the end of 2015, well over 150 destinations will be involved.  At the end of 2016, itâ€™s anticipated that between 350 and 400 destinations will have joined GGN â€“ representing a growth rate of 700% over three years.
  • As a mostly virtual organization, GGN receives no formal funding. All advertising is based on free publicity, social media and â€œword of mouthâ€ù marketing. 
  • Greeter services are completely free. Sometimes visitors do not know how to accept this type of service for free as they expect one needs to tip the Greeter but it is a completely free service. Greeters are willing to share their time and information with visitors because they love their city. 
  • The Greeter program works in partnership with local tourism organizations, based on the logical concept that the best ambassadors for a city are its inhabitants. This is the strength of the Greeter concept and likely the main reason there is a growing number of destination marketing organizations such as Travel Salem that are interested in setting up a local Greeter organization. Each destination marketing organization creates the digital infrastructure (i.e. website, matching the volunteer Greeter with the visitor, providing information) while maintaining the global concept. 

Greeters in the USA
Now there are USA-Greeter destinations in New York, Chicago, Houston and Salem, Oregon. Additional Greeters destinations are expected to be formed in the USA soon.

More information
For more information about the Global Greeter Network, go to www.GlobalGreeterNetwork.info or email 100members@globalgreeternetwork.info. For more information about the Salem Greeters program, please visit www.salemgreeters.com.

###

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
April 21, 2015
Printable PDF Version		Kara Kuh
Travel Salem
503-581-4325 ext. 24
kkuh@travelsalem.com

Absolutely Fabulous Awards Luncheon to Recognize Outstanding Tourism Industry Partners
Historian John Ritter to Serve as Keynote Speaker

SALEM, OR â€” Travel Salemâ€™s sixth annual Absolutely Fabulous Awards luncheon â€“ aka the Ab Fab Awards - will be held Thursday, May 21, from 11:45 a.m. to 1:30 p.m., at the Salem Convention Center (located at 200 Commercial Street SE in Salem). John Ritter, professor and locally renowned historian, will serve as the keynote speaker for the luncheon and will discuss the history of Salemâ€™s underground tunnels and passageways.

The Ab Fab awards recognize tourism industry partners who went above and beyond in 2014 to increase the economic impact of visitors. The award recipients are movers and shakers whose collaboration, innovation and vision are â€œabsolutely fabulous!â€ù

This yearâ€™s Ab Fab Awards luncheon is sponsored by Courthouse and the Salem Convention Center. Attendees are encouraged to bring brochures and business cards to promote their businesses and enter for a chance to win door prizes and gift baskets provided by area businesses. The cost to attend the luncheon is $18 in advance or $23 at the door. Reservations are required and can be made online at www.travelsalem.com and clicking on the â€œMembersâ€ù drop-down tab or by calling 503-581-4325, ext. 158. For more information, go to www.travelsalem.com

###

***Travel Salem is a non-profit organization that promotes Salem and Marion and Polk counties for leisure tourism and convention and event business. The local annual economic impact of the greater Salem area visitor industry is $511 million. Travel Salem manages the Official Salem Area Travel CafÃ©/Visitors Center located at the historic Grand Hotel building (181 High St. NE, Salem), two I-5 satellite visitor information locations located at the Best Western Mill Creek Inn (3125 Ryan Dr. SE) and the Red Lion Hotel (3301 Market St. NE), and the Official Salem Area Website www.TravelSalem.com***

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
April 21, 2014
Printable PDF Version		 Kara Kuh
Travel Salem
503-581-4325 ext. 24
kkuh@travelsalem.com

Absolutely Fabulous Awards Luncheon to Recognize Outstanding Tourism Industry Partners
Travel Oregon CEO Todd Davidson to Serve as Keynote Speaker

SALEM, OR â€” Travel Salemâ€™s fifth annual Absolutely Fabulous Awards luncheon â€“ aka the Ab Fab Awards - will be held Thursday, May 15, from 11:45 a.m. to 1:30 p.m., at the Salem Convention Center, located at 200 Commercial Street SE in Salem. Todd Davidson, Chief Executive Officer at Travel Oregon, will serve as the keynote speaker for this yearâ€™s awards luncheon.

Travel Salem Partners with The Hoop to Build Tournament Attendance in 2014
Partnership Expected to Help Generate More Than $1.15 Million in Economic Impact 

SALEM, OR â€”Travel Salem is pleased to announce a new partnership with The Hoop that will build attendance for the sports facilityâ€™s 2014 basketball tournaments.

The Hoopâ€™s expertise lies in the organizationâ€™s ability to execute and host national, regional and local competitions and sporting events at competitive levels that players expect. Travel Salemâ€™s marketing expertise includes a collaborative approach that will enhance The Hoopâ€™s current tournaments and assist with the creation of a new tournament.

Currently there are nine basketball tournaments scheduled at The Hoop for 2014. Travel Salem will assist with the March 29-30 March Madness Tournament and the May 24-26 Double Pump Northwest Tournament, which are expected to generate an estimated economic impact (EEI) of $1,080,000. Travel Salem will also assist in the creation of a new December tournament, which is expected to generate an EEI of $72,000.

Debbie McCune, Travel Salemâ€™s Director of Sales, has been working with The Hoop on this united effort. â€œGroup business such as this is needed in the â€˜shoulderâ€™ season (the period in-between a destination's low and high seasons) to drive business to area lodging facilities, restaurants, retail and other businesses. With more out-of-town teams participating, Salem will realize a substantial economic benefit, and we look forward to future tournaments building on the success of the 2014 events,â€ù said McCune.

Entry fees for out-of-town teams will be waived for one year to encourage more teams to participate. Representatives with The Hoop are confident that this approach will attract teams from surrounding states that might not have considered traveling for these tournaments before. â€œOnce the teams experience The Hoop - which is one of the largest private facilities in the Northwest, with 51,000 square feet and 6 basketball courts and staff highly skilled in managing tournaments - they will make these tournaments an annual event,â€ù said James Johnson, The Hoopâ€™s Director of Operations. 

Travel Salem will work with lodging facilities to conduct pick-up reports to help with tracking the economic benefit of the tournaments. Travel Salem will also provide marketing assistance (through TravelSalem.com, social media and public relations efforts) and visitor information to encourage tournament attendees to experience all that Salem has to offer.

Global Greeter Network Announces Salem Oregon as the 100th Destination
 

SALEM, OR â€” The Global Greeter Network (GGN) is proud to announce Salem, Oregon as the100th destination in its networks. Salem joins cities such as Paris, Buenos Aires, London, New York, Berlin, Shanghai and 93 other cities throughout the world as an official Greeter destination, where thousands of volunteers worldwide share their personal insights and knowledge about â€œtheir cityâ€ù with visitors. 

What is Greeters?
The Greeter program is still unknown to many people, but the concept is rapidly catching on throughout the world. In the last three months, more than 10 cities have joined the network including Sofia, Bulgaria; Sydney, Australia; and Vienna, Austria.

The concept is simple and based on the idea that most people are truly proud and passionate about their city.  A Greeter volunteer shares knowledge about a destination - not as a tour guide but as a resident of the city, sharing his or her personal story and knowledge about the history and culture of the city. Greeters follow a strict no tipping policy. The walk - or greet, as Greeter destinations call it -  is a gift from the host city to the visitor.

History
The Greeters program officially started in 1992, but was founded on principles introduced by the late Lynn Brooks, who was born and raised in New York in the 1920s. Lynn was troubled by the poor image of the city and decided to show people the â€œgood side of her village.â€ù Based on Lynnâ€™s initial work, the Big Apple Greeters Program was born. Over the last five years, the Greeters concept has gained momentum as more people want to start a local Greeter organization in their community to build upon the services offered to visitors. 

Facts and Figures

  • At the end of 2013, there were approximately 50 to 60 destinations participating in the Global Greeter Network.  At the end of 2015, well over 150 destinations will be involved.  At the end of 2016, itâ€™s anticipated that between 350 and 400 destinations will have joined GGN â€“ representing a growth rate of 700% over three years.
  • As a mostly virtual organization, GGN receives no formal funding. All advertising is based on free publicity, social media and â€œword of mouthâ€ù marketing. 
  • Greeter services are completely free. Sometimes visitors do not know how to accept this type of service for free as they expect one needs to tip the Greeter but it is a completely free service. Greeters are willing to share their time and information with visitors because they love their city. 
  • The Greeter program works in partnership with local tourism organizations, based on the logical concept that the best ambassadors for a city are its inhabitants. This is the strength of the Greeter concept and likely the main reason there is a growing number of destination marketing organizations such as Travel Salem that are interested in setting up a local Greeter organization. Each destination marketing organization creates the digital infrastructure (i.e. website, matching the volunteer Greeter with the visitor, providing information) while maintaining the global concept. 

Greeters in the USA
Now there are USA-Greeter destinations in New York, Chicago, Houston and Salem, Oregon. Additional Greeters destinations are expected to be formed in the USA soon.

More information
For more information about the Global Greeter Network, go to www.GlobalGreeterNetwork.info or email 100members@globalgreeternetwork.info. For more information about the Salem Greeters program, please visit www.salemgreeters.com.

###

column4: Willamette Valley Visitors Association Elects Irene Bernards as Board President
column5:
Irene Bernards, Travel Salemâ€™s director of marketing and public relations, has been elected by the Willamette Valley Visitors Association (WVVA) as the 2009-10 board president.

WVVA is the Regional Destination Marketing Organization for the Willamette Valley, which includes counties of Marion, Polk, Yamhill, SW Clackamas, Linn, Benton and East Lane. The WVVA Board of Directors is made up of representatives from each regionsâ€™ Destination Marketing Organization; promoting leisure visitation to the Willamette Valley through a myriad of marketing strategies including online, print, advertising, social media, public relations, and unique partnerships.

â€œTourism is a $496 million dollar industry for the Salem area,â€ù said Bernards. â€œThe Willamette Valley Visitors Association is one of Travel Salemâ€™s major marketing partners that helps increase those visitorsâ€™ expenditures.â€ù

As board president, Bernards will oversee the Associationâ€™s administration, marketing and promotions.

column4: Innovative Partnership between Travel Salem and  Willamette Valley Vineyards
column5:
Through a ground-breaking partnership with Willamette Valley Vineyards (WVV), Travel Salemâ€™s award-winning Travel CafÃ© Visitors Center now offers visitors and local consumers the opportunity to taste the â€œFruit of the Vine.â€ù Travel Salem has partnered with WVV to create a tasting room and retail outlet for their high-quality, sustainable wines at the Travel CafÃ©. In addition, Travel Salemâ€™s conference room has been named the â€œWillamette Roomâ€ù sponsored by WVV.

This unique partnership between a winery/vineyard and a tourism agency will allow visitors to experience wine from one of Oregonâ€™s oldest and most sustainable wineries, and pique their interest to learn more about WVV and the regionâ€™s rich wine country. This new concept will ultimately lead to an increased regional economic impact from tourism.

â€œWillamette Valley Vineyards is proud to be partnering with Travel Salemâ€™s revolutionary Travel CafÃ©,â€ù says Jim Bernau, founder and president of WVV. â€œThis new downtown facility is one of the major touch points for visitors to the Salem area. Offering tastes of wine at this location will grow visitor interest in the Oregon wine industry â€” one of our regionâ€™s most valuable assets â€” and help make lifelong Salem area customers of some of these visitors.â€ù

â€œPart of the original vision for the Travel CafÃ©, this innovative partnership provides yet another reason for visitors to make the Salem area a stop on their journey,â€ù explained Travel Salem President and CEO Angie Morris. â€œBy serving as a mini-attraction, the Travel CafÃ© seeks to give visitors a taste of what the region has to offer. We wanted a partner that exemplified the best of the tourism industry â€“ innovation, sustainability and an internationally recognized brand. We got all of that and more with Willamette Valley Vineyards.

Travel Salem and WVV launched this partnership by kicking off their shoes at the Mini Grape Stomp event held at the Travel CafÃ© on September 16, 2009. Bernau and Morris teamed up and went toe-to-toe against Ray Burstedt, president of SEDCOR and Austin McGuigan, community development director of Polk County â€” in a grape stomping competition right outside the Travel CafÃ©. The stomping of Morris and the swabbing of Bernau propelled the Travel Salem/ WVV grape stomping team to an easy victory.Â 

This partnership expands on Travel Salemâ€™s commitment to reinvent the way a community connects with visitors and local consumers. The Travel CafÃ© offers Garmin GPS units pre-programmed with Salem area tours, AbsolutelyTix ticketing network, Wi-Fi access, plasma screens with ads and scrolling events, and now wine-tasting with WVV. The Travel CafÃ© is becoming an attraction in and of itself!

Wine-tasting will be available Monday-Saturday, 11:00 a.m. â€“ 4:30 p.m. at the Travel CafÃ© located at 181 High St. NE, Salem. Eight distinctive wines will be featured; offering something for every palate. The wines will be served using a state-of-the-art Enomatic wine serving system. Visitors and local consumers can purchase four tastes for $6.00, which will include a one-of-a-kind Riedel wine glass. Bottles of WVV wines are also available for purchase.

About Willamette Valley Vineyards: Willamette Valley Vineyards was founded in 1983 by Jim Bernau after an inspirational visit to the west-to-south facing slope of volcanic flow in Turner, Ore., where the winery is now situated. Best known for its acclaimed Pinot Noir, WVV wines are distributed throughout the United States, Canada, and the Pacific Rim. WVV manages 300 acres of vines, which are all certified sustainable, LIVE and Salmon Safe. As Oregonâ€™s only publicly held winery, the winery is listed on NASDAQ under the symbol WVVI. For more information, call (800) 344-9463 or visit www.WillametteValleyVineyards.com.

Travel Salem is committed to strengthening the communities that it serves. In efforts to further enhance the vitality of our communities in the region, Travel Salem has introduced â€œAbsolutely Giving Back.â€ù

Travel Salem holds various events throughout the year such as Marketing Exchange Luncheons, Team Salem meetings and special events.Â  These activities involve hundreds of people and in an effort to â€œAbsolutely Give Backâ€ù Travel Salemâ€™s staff and meeting attendees are encouraged to bring canned or non-perishable food items to these events. The contributions will be collected and donated quarterly to various local charities or aid organizations. Travel Salem will also be a collection point for new and used winter coats for children with distribution occurring as soon as possible to meet the immediate need of many shelters.

Upcoming opportunities to give back include a free international seminar with Travel Oregonâ€™s international marketing team held exclusively for Travel Salem members; and at upcoming social media seminars in November. Read the articles in this newsletter for more details about these meetings.

Join Travel Salem in our â€œAbsolutely Giving Backâ€ù campaign!

column4: Travel Salem Ranked 21 out of 100 Best Nonprofits to Work For in Oregon
column5:
Travel Salem has been selected as a â€œTop 100 Best Nonprofits to Work For in Oregonâ€ù by Oregon Business magazine. The rankings were unveiled at a banquet held at the Portland Art Museum on Tuesday, September 29, 2009, featuring a keynote from former Governor Barbara Roberts. Travel Salem was recognized as the 16th best small nonprofit and 21st overall.

â€œThose of us who choose nonprofit careers do so for the chance to serve a cause greater than ourselves,â€ù said Angie Morris, president and CEO of Travel Salem. â€œTravel Salem attracts and retains amazing, talented staff, who bring their â€˜A-gameâ€™ and give a little bit of their heart to their job every single day. There is no question why they are some of the best in the industry.â€ù

The rankings were based on the confidential input of employees who answered 60 questions about workplace satisfaction such as benefits, management, trust, work environment and development. More than 200 nonprofits participated and 6,700 employees completed the survey. The free, voluntary survey was independently calculated by research partners Davis, Hibbitts and Midghall.

The â€œTop 100 Best Nonprofits to Work For in Oregonâ€ù is featured in the October issue of Oregon Business magazine.

column4: Travel Salem Pins Down 2009 West Coast World Championship Youth Wrestling Tournament
column5:
Travel Salem has secured the 2009 West Coast World Championship Wrestling Tournament hosted by Rocky Mountain Nationals (RMN). This event will take place at the Oregon State Fair & Expo Center on December 11-12, 2009 with nearly 1,500 K-8th grade participants from across the country hitting the mats for the first time in Salem.

Since 1999, RMN has been hosting some of the largest and most successful tournaments for young wrestlers. RMNâ€™s mission is to promote wrestling and ensure lasting rewards for youth which include: 1) Athletic rigor within a spirit of fair competition; 2) Self-discipline and perseverance through training; 3) Leadership and team-building skills; and 4) Lasting friendships and memorable experiences. Through sportsmanship and related tournament activities, Rocky Mountain Nationals encourages friendships, strengthens families and fosters good citizenship.

Travel Salem Marketing Exchange Luncheon
Melody Johnson of International Culinary Tourism Association Presents:
â€œCulinary Tourism: Successful Ingredients in Economic Developmentâ€ù
Thursday, November 19, 2009
11:45 a.m. - 1:15 p.m.
Mission Mill Museum, Dye Room
1313 Mill Street SE
Salem, ORÂ  97301
RSVPs and prepayment of $18 required / $23 at the door
Limited Seating

Reserve Your Seat Today - Save $5 with advanced registration if purchased by November 13!
-- Online - use your credit card at Travel Salem www.TravelSalem.com/Members/marketing-exchange-luncheons
-- Phone - use your credit card to reserve your seat by calling 503-581-4325, ext. 30
-- Mail - send your check to: Travel Salem Marketing Exchange Luncheon, 181 High St. NE, Salem, OR 97301

Keynote Speaker: Melody Johnson is the Community Manager for International Culinary Tourism Association and has been associated with Erik Wolf and the ICTA since its inception in 2003. Melody has received numerous awards from the Tourism Industry including the prestigious Oregon Governorâ€™s Tourism Award. She will be sharing how Culinary Tourism creates economic and community development and how the region can grow this market. A topic that is pertinent to all businesses.

Promote Your Business:Â  Make the most of this luncheon by planning to network with other attendees before and after the meeting. Remember to bring your business cards and company brochures for the Marketing Exchange table.Â 

Â Enter-to-Win! â€“ Spa package from LaLumiere worth over $100! A one hour massage and half hour facial would delight any recipient, especially around the hectic holiday season. And even if you are not the lucky winner, you can check out other spa services offered by LaLumiere on their website www.lalumieremassage.com. column5:
Travel Salem promotes the Salem area as a leisure tourism and convention and event destination strengthening the communities it serves through increased visitor expenditures - $496 million in 2008.Â  However, Travel Salem is also committed to strengthening the region by giving back through the organizationâ€™s â€œAbsolutely Giving Backâ€ù program.

Travel Salem holds various events throughout the year such as Marketing Exchange Luncheons, Team Salem meetings, and special events. Travel Salem also operates the Travel CafÃ© Visitors Center located downtown Salem at 181 High Street NE.Â  These activities, along with the Travel CafÃ©, attract thousands of people. In an effort to â€œAbsolutely Give Backâ€ù Travel Salem is collecting canned or non-perishable food items and new and used winter coats for children throughout the year at the Travel CafÃ©.

Travel Salem will donate the contributions in a timely manner to various local charities or aid organizations.

Support Travel Salemâ€™s â€œAbsolutely Giving Backâ€ù campaign and your local community by visiting the Travel CafÃ© (181 High St. NE, Salem) with contributions.

column4: What the Heck is Social Media? Learn for Free!
column5:
Are you curious about engaging with consumers and building relationships with them through social media tools such as Twitter and Facebook? Do you want more results out of the time you put into social media? Come to one of Travel Salemâ€™s FREE interactive social media seminars and learn about the social networking tools that are changing the way businesses and organizations connect with consumers, and strategies on how to effectively utilize these tools.

Based on proficiency, participants have the option of attending one or both of these one and a half hour seminars. The novice seminars will focus on the introduction to each social media platform. This includes Twitter, Facebook, Flickr, YouTube, and blogs. An in-depth look of each platform â€” including instruction on signing up, usage, etiquette and more â€” will be discussed in this novice, interactive seminar. This seminar is targeted at participants who are thinking about doing social media for their company/organization and those who are in the beginning stages and want to learn more about social media.

For the advance user, the seminars will focus on the proven strategies that have effectively increased relationships among businesses/organizations and their consumers. Weâ€™ll be taking an in-depth look at case studies and discuss how to utilize each platform in synergy to achieve your overall goal. This seminar is targeted at participants who are looking to establish a stronger social media presence in the online community.

Dates and times to choose from:

Monday, Nov. 16 (at the Travel Cafe)
1pm-2:30pm: Novice
3pm-4:30pm: Advance

11:30am-1pm: Advance

1:45pm-3:15pm: Novice/Advance Combine

There is no fee to attend these seminars which will take place at Travel Salemâ€™s Travel CafÃ© (181 High St. NE, Salem) in the Willamette Room (except for the November 19 session which will take place at Mission Mill right after the Marketing Exchange Luncheon). Participants may bring a laptop to engage in this immersive experience. Free Wi-Fi is offered at the Travel CafÃ©. Participants are encouraged to come prepared with questions. Space is limited. column4: Salem Area Draws in Convention Business
column5:
Travel Salemâ€™s convention/group sales and marketing efforts generated $5.8 million for the community in 2008-09 by attracting 43,378 convention delegates, meeting attendees and event participants to Salem. Travel Salem markets the Salem area as a premier destination; working closely with meeting and event planners who are the key decision-makers as to where meetings/conventions/events will be held.

The Salem area is fortunate to have a diverse range of indoor facilities and outdoor spaces to market for conferences, sporting events such as softball or wrestling, RV rallies, weddings and reunions, and much more. However, it is more than the facility that attracts groups to Salem. Our location, the value of the experience, the attractions and activities, and the unparalleled service and hospitality; attract not only new business, but ensure repeat business.

Travel Salem recently pinned down the 2009 West Coast World Championship Youth Wrestling Tournament hosted by Rocky Mountain Nationals. This event will take place at the Oregon State Fair & Expo Center on December 11-12, 2009 with nearly 1,500 K-8th grade participants from across the country. Families will be accompanying these athletes and many will be experiencing Salem and Oregon for the first time. Providing these guests with visitor information to promote lodging, dining, shopping and touring is vital to their enjoyment and to the local economy.

Partnerships play a key role in pulling all the pieces together to book a convention/group to Salem. Travel Salem partners with all facilities to ensure we are aggressively promoting our destination and capturing business.

You can help boost our economy by bringing your group to Salem. Contact Travel Salem for free assistance 503-581-4325, ext. 28. Travel Salemâ€™s Travel CafÃ© Visitors Center is located at 181 High Street NE in vibrant downtown Salem.

~ Angie Morris, President and CEO of Travel Salem
*Originally printed in Statesman Journal, 10/18/09

column4: SAVE THE DATE â€“ Tourism Summit, January 14, 2010
column5:
Travel Salem, in partnership with Travel Oregon, is hosting a regional Tourism Summit on Thursday, January 14, 2010 from 1:30-3:30 p.m. at the Red Lion Hotel and Conference Center (3301 Market St. NE, Salem). Join in the discussion!

This Summit is a forum to discuss how tourism connects to businesses and powers local economies. A diverse panel has been selected in an effort to put together a broad cross-section of expertise on a variety of issues (e.g. land use, industry, recruitment, retail, development, lodging, policy, education, etc.). Confirmed panelists include: Shelly Hansen, Confederated Tribes of the Grand Ronde; Steve Johnson, VIPs Industries; Austin McGuigan, Polk County Community Development; Stacy Palmer, Silverton Chamber of Commerce; Ray Burstedt, Strategic Economic Development Corporation; Steve McCoid, Oregon Restaurant Association; Teri Sunderland, Woodburn Company Stores; Craig Smith, Chemeketa Community College; and Hazel Patten, Community Volunteer.

The summit will be moderated by Travel Oregonâ€™s Chief Strategy Officer Scott West. This free â€œtown hallâ€ù forum will foster a brainstorming roundtable designed to bring out the perceptions and reality of tourism as it relates to the business environment.

This discussion will be a catalyst to a statewide discussion so please plan on attending!

Free and open to the public. RSVP to the Travel Salem office, 503-581-4325, ext. 30 or assistant@TravelSalem.com.

column5:
Travel Salem, in partnership with Travel Oregon, is hosting a regional Tourism Summit on Thursday, January 14, 2010 from 1:30-3:30 p.m. at the Red Lion Hotel and Conference Center (3301 Market St. NE, Salem). Join in the discussion!

This Summit is a forum to discuss how tourism connects to businesses and powers local economies. A diverse panel has been selected in an effort to put together a broad cross-section of expertise on a variety of issues (e.g. land use, industry, recruitment, retail, development, lodging, policy, education, etc.). Confirmed panelists include: Shelly Hansen, Confederated Tribes of the Grand Ronde; Steve Johnson, VIPs Industries; Austin McGuigan, Polk County Community Development; Stacy Palmer, Silverton Chamber of Commerce; Ray Burstedt, Strategic Economic Development Corporation; Steve McCoid, Oregon Restaurant Association; Teri Sunderland, Woodburn Company Stores; Craig Smith, Chemeketa Community College; and Hazel Patten, Community Volunteer.

The summit will be moderated by Travel Oregonâ€™s Chief Executive Officer Todd Davidson. This free â€œtown hallâ€ù forum will foster a brainstorming roundtable designed to bring out the perceptions and reality of tourism as it relates to the business environment.

This discussion will be a catalyst to a statewide discussion so please plan on attending! Free and open to the public.

column4: What the Heck is Social Media? Learn for FREE!
column5:
Are you curious about engaging with consumers and building relationships with them through social media tools such as Twitter and Facebook? Do you want more results out of the time you put into social media? Come to Travel Salemâ€™s FREE interactive social media seminars and learn about the social networking tools that are changing the way businesses and organizations connect with consumers, and strategies on how to effectively utilize these tools.

This seminar will focus on the introduction to each social media platform. This includes Twitter, Facebook, Flickr, YouTube, and blogs. An in-depth look of each platform â€” including instruction on signing up, usage, etiquette and more â€” will be discussed in thisÂ interactive seminar. In addition, we will discussÂ proven strategies that have effectively increased relationships among businesses/organizations and their consumers. Weâ€™ll be taking an in-depth look at case studies and discuss how to utilize each platform in synergy to achieve your overall goal.

There is no fee to attend this seminar which will take place at the Stayton Library (515 N 1st St, Stayton) on Monday, January 25 from 1 p.m. to 4 p.m. Participants may bring a laptop to engage in this immersive experience. Free Wi-Fi is offered at theÂ library. Participants are encouraged to come prepared with questions. Space is limited. Contact Anthony Tham to reserve your spot at atham@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325, ext. 25.
