FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
April 21, 2015

 

Andrea Foust, Membership and Public Relations Manager
Hallie Ford Museum of Art at Willamette University, Salem, OR
503-370-6855
www.museum-art@willamette.edu

Tom Prochaska and Christy Wyckoff: In the Footsteps of Charles Heaney

Salem, Oregon  â€“ A new exhibition, "Tom Prochaska and Christy Wyckoff: In the Footsteps of Charles Heaney," opens May 9 and continues through July 19 in the Print Study Gallery at Willamette Universityâ€™s Hallie Ford Museum of Art.

In September of 2014 Oregon artists Tom Prochaska and Christy Wyckoff set out to follow in the footsteps of artist Charles Heaney (1897-1981), who was a significant mid-20th century Oregon artist known for his paintings and prints inspired by the landscape and settlements of Central, Eastern, and Southern Oregon as well as Nevada.

The exhibition features approximately 30 drawings created by the artistsâ€™ during their recent road trip as they traveled and camped at various places identified in Heaneyâ€™s work. The exhibition also includes comparative works by Heaney, drawn from the permanent collection of the Hallie Ford Museum of Art.

â€œAlthough Heaney was on our minds as we worked at sites connected to him,â€ù Wyckoff explains, â€œwe primarily responded in our individual ways to the landscape in front of us rather than making â€˜art about art.â€™â€ù

Prochaska and Wyckoff will present a free illustrated talk about their project on June 14, at 2:00 p.m. in the Roger Hull Lecture Hall at the museum.

This exhibition has been organized by Professor Emeritus of Art History and Senior Faculty Curator, Roger Hull. Financial support for the exhibition has been provided by grants from the City of Salemâ€™s Transient Occupancy Tax funds, the Oregon Arts Commission and a Career Opportunity Grant from the Oregon Arts Commission.

About the artists

Tom Prochaska is a painter, printmaker, and sculptor who earned his Master of Fine Arts degree at the Pratt Institute and taught at the Pacific Northwest College of Art from 1988 until his retirement in 2013. He has exhibited throughout the United States and abroad.

Christy Wyckoff earned his MFA degree at the University of Washington and taught for 33 years at the Pacific Northwest College of Art, retiring in 2012. A printmaker, he has exhibited widely and was represented in the Tacoma Art Museumâ€™s 2014 survey "Ink This! Contemporary Prints in the Northwest." He is the recent recipient of a Career Opportunity Grant from the Oregon Arts Commission in support of a number of projects including his involvement with "In the Footsteps of Charles Heaney."

ADDITIONAL PRESS KIT ITEMS

About the Hallie Ford Museum of Art

Oregon's third largest art museum features works by Pacific Northwest and Native American artists, and includes a diverse collection of traditional European, American and Asian art, as well as artifacts that date from antiquity. Frequently changing exhibitions include lectures, special events, tours, artist demonstrations and educational opportunities for children and adults.

The museum is located at 700 State St. in Salem. Hours are Tuesday through Saturday from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. and Sunday from 1 to 5 p.m. The galleries are closed on Monday. General admission is $6, $4 for seniors and $3 for students 18 and older. Students 17 and under and children are admitted free. Admission is free for everyone on Tuesdays. For more information call 503-370-6855 or visit willamette.edu/go/hfma.

# # #

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
March 26, 2015

 

Catherine Alexander
Willamette Heritage Center, Salem, OR
503.302.4645
www.WillametteHeritage.org

Teddy Roosevelt Historical Tribute to Visit Salem on April 27

Salem, Oregon  â€“ â€œTeddy Rooseveltâ€™s Oregon Roadshow,â€ù a live performance by historical recreator Joe Wiegand, will visit Salem for a special event at the Willamette Heritage Center (1313 Mill Street SE) at 6:00 pm on Monday, April 27, as part of a one-week tour of schools and museums sponsored by the Oregon Historical Society and Wells Fargo.

After visiting in 2012, the Willamette Heritage Center is thrilled to host the 26th president again in Salem. Enjoy locally made pies and coffee, as well as have an opportunity to ask the President your questions. Tickets to the performance are $20 per person if reserved by April 20, and $15 for WHC members. To make reservations and purchase tickets, please contact Amy Vandegrift at 503.585.7012 x253 or amyv@willametteheritage.org. 

For the past three years, Wiegand has entertained and educated people of all ages as he traversed more than 3,500 miles across Oregon. This year, in his fourth annual visit to Oregon, he will travel from Portland to Prineville, with stops in Jefferson, Bend, Hood River, and more. Visit ohs.org to view the complete schedule.

â€œOHS is thrilled to again partner with Wells Fargo to bring this educational experience to schools and historical organizations throughout the region,â€ù said OHS Executive Director Kerry Tymchuk.

Wiegand has been bringing T.R. to life for years with his unparalleled grasp of history and uncanny resemblance to the 26th president. His depth of knowledge about the personal anecdotes in Rooseveltâ€™s life make his audiences feel they are truly in the presence of the former U.S. president and adventurer.

â€œWells Fargo is celebrating its 163rd anniversary this year. Weâ€™ve never lost sight of our history and the role Wells Fargo played in our countryâ€™s development of the West,â€ù said Tracy Curtis, Wells Fargoâ€™s Oregon regional president. â€œWeâ€™re grateful to the Oregon Historical Society for organizing this unique educational experience. Children and adults alike will delight in seeing our former president come to life.â€ù 

An author, naturalist, explorer, soldier, conservationist, and president, Rooseveltâ€™s history is larger than life. His fascinating career boasted many accomplishments, including the creation of Crater Lake National Park in 1902.

â€œSo many of T.R.â€™s contemporaries testify to the way he entertained audiences with inspirational and humorous stories from his youth, his ranching days, Cuba, and the presidency,â€ù Wiegand said. â€œI really enjoy sharing T.R.â€™s funny stories of life in the White House with six kids and telling anecdotes from his many adventures, from bear hunts to the Panama Canal, from Africa to the Amazon.â€ù

For more about the Willamette Heritage Center, visit www.WillametteHeritage.org

For more about the Oregon Historical Society, visit www.ohs.org

For more about Wells Fargo, visit www.wellsfargohistory.com

# # #

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
April 11, 2014

 

Toby Olsen
Regional Director Hampton Inn and Suites, Salem, OR
503-362-1300
www.salemsuites.hamptoninn.com

Hampton Inn and Suites Salem, OR Named National Lighthouse Award Winner

Salem, Oregon (Grassroots Newswire). Hotel ranked in top five percent of Hampton Hotels in U.S.
Hampton Hotels, Hilton Worldwideâ€™s global brand of mid-priced Hampton Inn and Hampton Inn & Suites hotels, has honored Hampton Inn and Suites Salem, OR with the companyâ€™s Lighthouse Award, designating it as one of the hotel chainâ€™s top performing hotels among more than 1,900 Hampton properties.

Hampton Inn and Suites Salem, OR was recognized for its high rankings in overall accommodations, service and quality. The award criteria was based on customer feedback measured through guest satisfaction surveys on the hotel, as well as product quality and service scores measured quarterly by the Hampton Hotels brand.

"The competition to be among the elite group of Hampton Lighthouse Award winners becomes stronger each year as the Hampton brand continues to add more hotels and continually looks for ways to strengthen the guest experience. This makes us especially proud to receive the honor," said Chris Merritt, general manager, Hampton Inn and Suites Salem, OR.

The four-story, 86-room Hampton Inn and Suites Salem, OR is located near such area attractions as Silver Falls State Park, Oregon State Capitol, Oregon State Fairgrounds and Riverfront Park. Standard hotel amenities include Free Hot Breakfast Buffet, Free Wifi, 24 Hour Fitness Center, Indoor Pool and Whirlpool. For further information or to make reservations for the Hampton Inn and Suites Salem, OR, please visit www.salemsuites.hamptoninn.com or call 503-362-1300 or 1-800-HAMPTON. 

About Hampton Inn & Suites
Read more about Hampton Hotels at www.hampton.com.

column4: Travel Salem project wins Merit Award for CB|2 Architects
column5:
The American Institute of Architects (AIA) Salem Chapter awarded Travel Salemâ€™s Travel CafÃ© a merit award during the 2009 AIA Salem Design Awards banquet at the Northwest Viticulture Center on January 21, 2010.

A jury of three distinguished architectural professionals selected Travel Salemâ€™s Travel CafÃ©, designed and built by CB|2 Architects & Construction in Salem, for its demonstration of a consistent hand in the development and execution of an idea of reuse and renovation. The design provided a level of attention and refinement that was successful in creating a welcoming area for people to gather and obtain information about the Salem area. A kiosk area was established using existing wood columns, and the existing brick walls brought warmth and material expression to the space and also gave further reference to the existing structure. The jury further comments that the design of the â€˜Jewel Boxâ€™ glassed-in conference area feature successfully extends and unifies the space.

â€œThe 2009 architectural design award of the Travel Salem interior, places this elegant space; one that brings historic preservation and modern design together into a seamless and well-thought out design, into the top tier of Salem and Portland architectural interiors,â€ù said Peter Strauhal, AIA Salem president-elect. â€œSalem is truly blessed to have such a well-crafted public space to learn more about the vibrant communities and diverse activities and attractions in the region.â€ù

Travel Salemâ€™s Travel CafÃ© is one of only four projects to win an award. A design-build process with CB|2 Construction allowed the project to meet the demands of a limited budget and tight schedule. The design vision was to express the character of the historic building by opening up the space and exposing brick walls and wood columns that had been concealed from past renovations in what use to be a downtown bridal shop. CB|2 Architects created a bold, progressive expression with a central reception pavilion, glass conference room, and rich material and color palette. The Travel CafÃ© was designed with sustainability in mind, including: use of recycled materials saved from demolition; earth-friendly options when purchasing new materials; electrical and HVAC zoning changes to conserve energy and maximize resources; and creative use of natural light to minimize energy consumption. The design creates a variety of spaces that can evolve depending on use and function. Diligent attention to details and craftsmanship was a goal, which is reflected throughout the project.

â€œThe Travel Salem project provided an opportunity to celebrate key Salem-area sights and businesses in a prominent historic downtown location,â€ù said Garth Brandaw, principal of CB|2 Architects. â€œAngie Morris came to us with the vision, and we were committed to making sure it reflected the quality and character of our community.â€ù

â€œThis award reflects and comments on Travel Salemâ€™s desire to blend the old with the new in visioning the Travel CafÃ©,â€ù said Angie Morris, president and CEO of Travel Salem. â€œWhile the project was intended to reinvent how our community could connect with the visitor through a vibrant and dynamic space, it also reflects Travel Salemâ€™s continued commitment to the tradition and history of our region. CB|2 brought extraordinary talent and vision to masterfully blend old with new and design a space that takes form and function to a whole new level.â€ù

Travel Salemâ€™s Travel CafÃ© is a full service visitors center aimed at connecting with visitors and consumers in new and exciting ways. This one-of-a-kind visitors center offers a wide array of services â€” personal assistance, event ticket sales, wine tasting, GPS rentals, free Wi-Fi â€” and provides the platform for innovative partnership, events, and technology to mash up and ultimately drive economic impact for the Salem region.

column4: Willamette Heritage Center adds to the depth of Salem's history and historic resources
column5:
Last September, Mission Mill Museum and the Marion County Historical Society announced the two groups would be merging to form a unique partnership, which became a reality January 1, 2010 with the creation of the Willamette Heritage Center.

The fusion of Mission Mill and Marion County Historical Society strengthens the attractiveness of both organizations and further enhances our regionâ€™s clout as a major heritage destination. The Willamette Heritage Center will provide enrichment to the regionâ€™s culture, history, artifact collection, interpretation, preservation and overall education of our community. It opens doors to new opportunities and programs â€” such as a potential national heritage area designation for the Willamette Valley, and an opportunity to gain accreditation from the American Association of Museums, which in turn would strengthen support for future tours and exhibits.

According to Travel Salemâ€™s Visitor Profile study conducted by Dean Runyan Associates, 41 percent of all Salem area visitors are very satisfied with the historic attractions; and visiting a historic attraction is one of the top three activities that visitors enjoy while in the region. Travel Salem works to promote Salem as a heritage destination because cultural and heritage visitors are also interested in wine, outdoor recreation and a variety of interests that can be found in abundance in the Salem area.

Visitors are looking for an experience â€“ a meaningful and authentic experience. Salemâ€™s historic attractions have done a wonderful job of creating that kind of experience for visitors through living history, exhibits, holiday lights, teas, wine dinners, concerts, education and special events. Blending the gems of history with all of the attractions of the region make the Salem area a vibrant and sought after destination.

The creativity and forward thinking of and the collaborative initiative is a perfect example of Salemâ€™s pioneering spirit, and illustrates what can be accomplished with innovation and a united vision. Travel Salem salutes our historic partners and the new Willamette Heritage Center!

~ Angie Morris, President and CEO of Travel Salem
*Originally printed in Statesman Journal, 1/31/10

column4: Historic vote in Congress will boost inbound travel to the Salem area and stimulate local economy
column5:
Travel Salem welcomed news today that the U.S. Congress passed legislation to create economic growth and thousands of new American jobs by welcoming millions more international travelers to the United States. The Travel Promotion Act will allow the United States to establish a multi-million dollar promotion program to compete on the global stage for the billions of dollars and immeasurable goodwill that would come with overseas travelers. The bill is expected to become law within 10 days.

â€œThe Salem area is an international destination with visitors from all corners of the globe,â€ù said Angie Morris, president and CEO of Travel Salem. â€œInternational travelers seek out Salem for its authentic experiences, abundant and unique outdoor recreational opportunities, culinary bounty and rich historic amenities. This monumental legislation establishes a new revenue stream necessary to compete on the global stage. Travel Salem will continue its partnership with Travel Oregon as we look for new ways to attract international travelers and leverage this new legislation.â€ù

â€œThis is a historic victory for the U.S. economy and the one in eight American workers whose jobs depend on travel,â€ù said Roger Dow, president and CEO of the U.S. Travel Association.Â  â€œThe United States Congress has sent a clear message that travel is a high priority to our nation and that tangible steps must be taken to increase travel to and within the United States. We are extremely grateful to the billâ€™s champions: Senators Reid, Dorgan, Ensign and Klobuchar in the Senate and Representatives Delahunt, Blunt and Farr in the House.â€ùÂ 

The Travel Promotion Act establishes a public-private partnership to promote the United States as a premier international travel destination and communicate U.S. security and entry policies. According to analysis by Oxford Economics, the bill is estimated to drive $4 billion in new consumer spending annually, provide $321 million in new federal tax revenue each year and create 40,000 U.S. jobs nationwide. Further, it is expected to reduce the federal budget deficit by $425 million over the next 10 years, according to the Congressional Budget Office.Â 

Overseas visitors spend an average of more than $4,000 when they visit the United States.

The Travel Promotion Act is modeled after successful state-level initiatives and is funded through a matching program featuring up to $100 million in private sector contributions and a $10 fee on foreign travelers who do not pay $131 for a visa to enter the United States. The fee is collected once every two years in conjunction with the Department of Homeland Securityâ€™s Electronic System for Travel Authorization. No money is provided by U.S. taxpayers.

The U.S. Travel Association is the national, non-profit organization representing all components of the $770 billion travel industry. U.S. Travelâ€™s mission is to promote and facilitate increased travel to and within the United States. For more information, visit www.ustravel.org.

Â

column4: Foster Strong Customer Service Culture through â€œQ Careâ€ù Program
column5:
Tourism is an $8.4 billion industry in Oregon and one of the stateâ€™s largest employers. Superior customer service is a top priority for the tourism industry to ensure repeat visitation and promote a positive community brand. Just like photos and videos are used by visitors to remember and share their memories, the type of service a visitor receives impacts how they share their experience with friends and family. Youâ€™ve heard it before, customers that have a bad experience with a business tell at least 10 friends â€“ thatâ€™s not the kind of â€œword of mouthâ€ù exposure that helps the bottom line. Going the extra mile for your customers will provide a huge return for the long-term health of your business. And many times itâ€™s the small things that make a big difference.

Some employees just have a knack with customers â€“ they know how to please and deliver value because helping customers just comes naturally to them. These employees are incredibly valuable as they create loyal customers. Businesses can foster a strong customer service culture by encouraging all employees to become certified customer service professionals through Travel Oregonâ€™s free â€œQ Careâ€ù program. This online certification program develops strong customer service skills necessary for personal and professional growth.

The Quality Care (Q Care) Customer Service Training Program is a statewide certification created to support the growth of the tourism and hospitality industry through enhanced guest experiences. But you donâ€™t have to be a tourism-related business to participate or reap the benefits of a robust customer service program. The Q Care program provides Oregon employees with the tools and resources needed to better serve customers and visitors alike.

If growing your bottom line and increasing your market share are important to your business, invest in training your employees to be quality ambassadors for your organization. There is no expense to you other than staff time to complete the Q Care Training which only takes one hour. Itâ€™s free and available online so employees can complete the certification at their convenience. Visit www.oregonqcare.com for more information.

~ Angie Morris, president and CEO of Travel Salem

You donâ€™t have to have a distinctive eye for art to enjoy yourself at Travel Salemâ€™s Travel CafÃ© (181 High St. NE, Salem) during First Wednesday on April 7th from 5-8 p.m.

â€¢ Brownell Photography will have a display of photos ranging from portraits, weddings, business/commercial and general events. Photographer Marlin Brownell will be sharing information on photography and videography.  
â€¢ Oregon Garden Resort is providing a sampling of sweet and savory appetizers, along with the Moonstone Spa who will be on hand for free consultations for facial services. They will also be raffling off a Tulip Festival Package.
â€¢ The Oregon Garden will be there to talk about the garden blooms and plants, and upcoming events.
â€¢ Salem Art Association is featuring samples from their upcoming shows: â€œArt in Poetryâ€ù and â€œAssembled: Narratives in Wood and Metalâ€ù.
â€¢ Willamette Art Center will be demonstrating pottery skills and techniques you can learn in the classes they offer.  
â€¢ Willamette Valley Vineyards has two features this month. Patrick Spencer will be educating visitors on cork reharvesting and Willametteâ€™s cork recycle program, and of course we will have tastings of their delicious and sustainable wines. First Wednesday Special: Build Your Cellar. Buy two bottles and receive a third bottle for only $5.00!

Join us for a fun-filled evening of arts, activities, food and wine!

Contribute to Travel Salem's "Absolutely Giving Back" program by dropping off a canned item, non-perishable food item, or new or gently used clean child's light jacket or sweater.

column4: Travel Salemâ€™s Travel CafÃ© wins Green Building of the Year
column5:
Travel Salemâ€™s Travel CafÃ© was recently named Green Building Retrofit of the Year at the 2010 Mid-Willamette Valley Green Awards ceremony held at Willamette University. The awards were put on by the Friends of Straub Environmental Learning Center.

The award recognizes outstanding efforts and leadership in green building practices. A green building is one that focuses on resource efficiency â€“ energy, water, and materials â€“ while reducing building impacts on human health and the environment through better siting, design, construction, operation, maintenance, and materials removal.

The Travel Cafe was dï»¿esigned and constructed by CB|2 Architects & Construction (winners of an architectural design award in January for the design of the Travel CafÃ©), ï»¿aï»¿nï»¿dï»¿ ï»¿has green all over its blueprint:

â€¢ recycled materials saved from demolition were used
â€¢ when purchasing new materials, earth-friendly options were chosen
â€¢ electrical and various heating, ventilating and air conditioning zoning changes were made  to conserve energy and maximize resources
â€¢ creative use of natural light were incorporated in the design to minimize energy consumption.

In addition to the sustainable features of the Travel CafÃ©, Travel Salemâ€™s staff and volunteers take great strides in reducing our carbon footprint. As a Marion County EarthWISE Certified business, we do our part by recycling, reducing waste, purchasing environmentally-friendly products, and the little things such as flipping the light switch off when not in the office for an extending period of time and turning off computer monitors at night.

You know how Kermit the Frog says â€œItâ€™s not easy being green?â€ù To be green, in other words, to be sustainable, is actually quite easy. It just takes a little bit of effort, which will eventually go a long way in protecting the environment and the planet we live on. If youâ€™re a business located in Marion County, the free EarthWISE certification program is a great way for your business and employees to be environmentally friendly. Visit Marion Countyâ€™s website for more information on how your business can be EarthWISE certified.

Photo caption: Kathie Reeves, marketing and online manager, represented Travel Salem at the Green Awards on March 13, 2010.

column5:
StatesmanJournal.com's Best of Mid-Valley invites readers to nominate and vote for their favorite people, businesses and things to do in Marion and Polk counties. Travel Salem is nominated under four categories:

- Professional Services: Best Green Business
- Professional Services: Best Nonprofit
- Professional Services: Best Customer Service
- Entertainment: Best Place to Taste Wine

Looking at the entire list of nominees, we can say that we are in pretty good company! There are so many great places that "go green" or do amazing things for our local and extended community. And let's not even go into the amount of places in our region that offer up outstanding views and atmosphere while enjoying a great-tasting glass of wine!

So, that being said, we ask that you participate! Vote for your favorites, not just in the categories above, but in the many categories that are listed on StatesmanJournal.com. You can vote once per day up until April 6th.

And while you're on there, remember to vote for us too :)

column4: Music Festival Electrifies a New Era of Engagement
column5:
Going into its fourth year, the Cherry City Music Festival has continued to ignite a new era of engagement among a younger generation, and brings their talents to the forefront of Salemâ€™s music scene. Last year, 142 bands participated in the Festival, attracting more than 20,000 people during what was an electrifying weekend filled with great music offered to a mix of Salem visitors.

The music these extraordinary bands play varies but their energy, creativity, passion and talent transcend all differences. These artists have worked hard at their craft; offering unique gifts of masterful sounds and experiences.  The Cherry City Music Festival gathers people interested in specific genres and unites them by serving up an array of options that expands their musical palette. The passion is contagious and many share their same enthusiasm toward independent music. They have the keen ability to influence their own generation; empowering renewed dedication to keep the vibrant arts scene alive and well in Oregonâ€™s capital city.

The Cherry City Music Festival is a perfect example of social media marketing at its best. The majority of the event is promoted through Facebook, Twitter, blogs and word of mouth. Using these social networking sites, an online community of local and national fans interested in the Festival is weaved together months prior to the event. All of the volunteers for the festival are also found through these avenues, building buzz about the festival!

The 4th annual Cherry City Music Festival will take place April 8-10, 2010 at venues throughout Salem. Registration for the bands will take place at Travel Salemâ€™s Travel CafÃ©. For more information about the Cherry City Music Festival, visit www.cherrycitymusic.com, or for information about other Salem area events, visit www.TravelSalem.com.

~ Angie Morris, president and CEO of Travel Salem
*Originally printed in Statesman Journal, 3/28/10

This monthâ€™s Team Salem meeting will be on Thursday, April 15th from noon to 1:30 pm at the LaQuinta Inn and Suites, 890 Hawthorne Ave. SE, Salem. The meeting will be a brown bag, so please bring your own lunch. Cookies, coffee and sodas will be provided by our host LaQuinta Inn and Suites.

The conference season is upon us! Weâ€™ve noticed a real upswing in services requested by visiting groups, and we want to hear from you so we can all work together to offer the best experience for our visitors. We are here to support each other so please try to attend.

Please RSVP by Monday, April 12th to Christine Edick, Travel Salem's convention and member services manager at cedick@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325, ext. 58. We look forward to seeing you soon!

column5: No matter the season, thereâ€™s plenty to do in and around Salem. Whether youâ€™re visiting for pleasure or business, youâ€™ll enjoy the regionâ€™s many attractions. The Salem Heritage Network (SHINE) and Discover-Neighborhood-History (DISCOVER) provide information and events for Salem's historical sites and neighborhoods. You will also find colorful gardens, unique childrenâ€™s activities, historical museums, and wineries reminiscent of France waiting for you.

The Salem Heritage Network (SHINE) and Discover-Neighborhood-History (DISCOVER) provide information and events for Salem's historical sites and neighborhoods. You will also find colorful gardens, unique childrenâ€™s activities, historical museums, and wineries reminiscent of France waiting for you.

column5:
HISTORY

As the state capital, Salem is steeped in history â€“ from the Capitol building itself to stately homes with storied pasts. Three historic properties â€“ Bush House Museum, Deepwood Museum and Gardens and Willamette Heritage Center â€“ are located within easy walking distance of one another. 


View History Itinerary in a larger map

At the Bush House Museum, an elegant 1878 Italianate mansion built by pioneer businessman Asahel Bush II is set in a 100-acre park, step inside and step back in time with a guided tour of the museumâ€™s exhibits of textiles, photos and historic artifacts.  

The nearby Deepwood Museum and Gardens, designed by noted Northwest architect W.C. Knighton and built during the 1890s by Dr. Luke Port, is a gabled Queen Anne with enchanting gardens designed by the Northwestâ€™s first female landscape architecture firm, Lord & Schryver.

Willamette Heritage Center  illuminates the lives of early settlers and local industry. The 1889 Thomas Kay Woolen Mill is the best preserved Victorian-era factory in the American West, with period equipment and detailed exhibits, including a woolen dye shop, machine shop and original water turbine. The grounds also boast four pioneer-era buildings; three relate to the early Methodist Mission established in Salem by Jason Lee. All feature period furnishings and exhibits exploring the lives of early settlers.

A trip to Salem wouldnâ€™t be complete without a visit to the Oregon State Capitol. During the summer months, take a tower tour to the observation deck at the base of the domeâ€™s crowning Golden Pioneer statue. Or enjoy a self-guided tour of the state art collection, which was recently reinstalled within the capitol and features more than 150 of Oregonâ€™s well-regarded artists. 

For lunch and shopping, head downtown to the renovated Reed Opera House. Completed in 1870, itâ€™s filled with a unique assortment of shops and dining options. Fancy some sweets? Stop in at the Little Cannoli Bakery for authentic Italian pastries, including the bakeryâ€™s namesake. 

If youâ€™re in the mood for a walk, stroll the Court Chemeketa Historic District, where youâ€™ll find a large concentration of architecturally significant homes.

If time permits, a short drive east of Salem will take you to Frank Lloyd Wrightâ€™s Gordon House. Named for the family that originally commissioned the â€˜Usonianâ€™-style home in 1957, itâ€™s the only example of Wrightâ€™s work in Oregon, and the only Wright work in the Pacific Northwest that is open to the public.

For a historically inspired dinner, you might head west of town to Roberts Crossing. The 1915 building was originally a grocery store. Today youâ€™ll find a cozy dining room and a menu boasting small plates along with heartier fare.

Continue your history theme into the evening with a show at the art deco Historic Elsinore Theatre. Live music, dance, and classic films are all part of the fun at this meticulously restored 1926 vaudeville house.

Looking for additional Cultural & Heritage information? Check out our museums and historic sites page on our website.

GARDENS

With beautiful public gardens, a flourishing nursery industry, and delightful residential gardens, the Willamette Valley is filled with botanical inspiration.

Several of the most beautiful gardens are clustered near downtown Salem and within walking distance of each other. The 100-acre Bushâ€™s Pasture Park is an oasis of fruiting and flowering trees, native plants, a formal rose garden and majestic oaks framing an open meadow. The gardens, part of a Victorian farmstead established by pioneer businessman Asahel Bush II, include an 1878 Italianate mansion, now the Bush House Museum, and a conservatory built in 1882. Renovated in 2011, the conservatory is filled with hundreds of plants, some very unusual, along with information on the role of conservatories during the Victorian era.


View Garden Itinerary in a larger map

At the adjacent Deepwood Museum and Gardens, visitors can explore the formal gardens laid out in the 1930s by Lord & Schryver, the Northwestâ€™s first female landscape architecture firm. Youâ€™ll find traditional boxwood gardens, an English tea house garden, and all manner of graceful arches, gazebos, ornamental gates and fences. A nature trail, resplendent with native plants, weaves its way along the western border of the property. While the gardens at Deepwood are a delight in any season, the perennial borders are a riot of color from spring to fall.

Save time to stroll State Capital State Park, lined with cherry trees that burst into bloom each spring, and Willson Park, with hundreds of varieties of trees, shrubs, flowers and an array of sculpture, three fountains and the new Oregon World War II Memorial with a 33-foot-tall, 15-ton obelisk.

Across the street on the campus of Willamette University is the Martha Springer Botanical Garden, a modest but diverse display of flowering plants and water features in a peaceful setting.

From here, the bustling downtown eatery Wild Pear Restaurant makes a delightful spot for lunch. Serving up an array of brightly flavored salads, sandwiches, tasty soups (donâ€™t miss the curried coconut and butternut squash) and delectable desserts. Afterwards, explore the unique shops and galleries along State Street.

The Oregon Garden, located in nearby Silverton, features a series of distinct garden areas landscaped into the propertyâ€™s gently rolling hills. Explore on foot or take a narrated tram tour through the impressive plantings, garden art and water features. Families will enjoy the Childrenâ€™s Garden, with its interactive in-ground Hobbit house, tree fort, and furniture filled with colorful, kid-friendly plants. Lunch here is also an option, either at the Garden CafÃ© or the restaurant in The Oregon Garden Resort.

The Willamette Valleyâ€™s nursery industry means awe-inspiring seasonal displays and demonstration gardens. 

In spring, the season kicks off with the Tulip Fest at the Wooden Shoe Tulip Farm. During the month of April, visitors are greeted by a sea of brightly colored tulips and daffodils on 40 acres and a range of fun activities.

During May and early June, the iris and peony take center stage. At Schreinerâ€™s Iris Gardens, 10 acres come alive with 500 varieties. Stroll the garden, enjoy a picnic lunch and head home with fresh cut flowers or rhizomes for your own garden. Adelman Peony Gardens is a peony paradise, with displays of hundreds of varieties of spectacular blooms, from heirlooms to the newest selections, along with cut flowers and live plants for sale.

For those interested in local gardens, the Gilbert House Children's Musuem Garden Tour takes place the first Friday and Saturday of June. The self-guided tour highlights the best of local green thumbs.

A rose is a rose is a rose at Heirloom Roses in Saint Paul, where youâ€™ll find thousands of beautiful, fragrant roses displayed on five acres of themed gardens. Roses are in bloom from May to October and peak during June.

Looking for additional garden information? Check out our gardens or nursery and florist page on our website.

column4: Meeting Planners look to Green Venues
column5:
Sustainability is abuzz, and meeting planners â€” those that make decisions on where events, meetings, and conventions will be heldâ€” are paying attention. Considered one of the catalysts in the revitalization of downtown Salem, the Salem Conference Center (SCC) has been a spark for driving economic impact and job creation to the area. Last year, SCC held 565 events that served more than 87,000 delegates â€” resulting in roughly 11,000 guest rooms booked at the Grand Hotel in Salem, and many other rooms booked at multiple properties throughout the city.

SCC increasingly satisfies the growing expectation of meeting planners and convention attendees for environmentally responsible venues. SCC is closing in on becoming LEED certified; an internationally recognized verification that a building is designed and built using sustainable practices.  Next year, plans are in motion for solar panels to be installed on the roof to reduce energy consumption and costs. SCC already participates in a pilot program for composting, which allows food and waste from the catering kitchen to be recycled. These are just some examples of the Salem Conference Centerâ€™s sustainable attributes that serve as a marketable asset to attract conventions and events to the Salem area.

Sustainability is also in Travel Salemâ€™s DNA. Travel Salem is certified EarthWISE â€” a Marion County program that recognize businesses who commit to environmentally friendly practices. Last year, Travel Salem assisted 87 conventions and distributed more than 7,000 biodegradable welcome bags. At the upcoming Association of Oregon Recyclers Conference to be held at the SCC in June, Travel Salem will embrace the â€œgreenâ€ù montra by arranging an information table staged with Salem area resources and staff who will provide the highest level of hospitality and encourage delegates to get out and experience the areaâ€™s sustainable visitor amenities. For more information on how Travel Salem can assist your group with a diverse range of services for your convention or event contact Debbie McCune, Travel Salemâ€™s director of sales, at 503-581-4325, ext. 28.

~ Angie Morris, president and CEO of Travel Salem
*Originally printed in Statesman Journal, 4/24/10

column4: Tourism Boosts All Sectors of the Economy
column5:
Travel Salemâ€™s â€œstreet teamsâ€ù hit downtown Salem last week during National Tourism Week (May 8-16) to ask Salem residents about what tourism means to them and how it affects their lives. We also reached out through social media channels to hear from online followers.

A Local Perspective
How does tourism to the Salem area help the local economy?

â€¢ â€œTourism brings in money. Visitors take good thoughts of Salem back to their own communities.â€ù Hazel P. from Salem

â€¢ â€œOf course! Tourism helps any economy.â€ù Don A. from Salem. (Don had a visitor with him from Bellingham, Wash.)

â€¢ â€œYes, more people visiting means more money for the local economy.â€ù Eric C. from Salem

Where would you take visiting friends or relatives to showcase your city?

â€¢  â€œDowntown â€“ cute shops, good restaurants and a nice atmosphere. I think people would also take visitors just outside of town to Silver Falls State Park and The Oregon Garden.â€ù Brant W. from Salem

â€¢ â€œLocal wineries, downtown and Silver Creek Falls.â€ù Randy M. from Salem

â€¢ â€œI just had visitors here enjoying Salem! We went to A.C. Gilbertâ€™s Discovery Village, Salemâ€™s Riverfront Carousel and Willamette Valley Vineyards.â€ù Wendy J. from Salem

â€¢  â€œSalemâ€™s downtown has nice local shops and a nice classic feel.â€ù Don H. from Portland

We also asked folks how much money Salem area visitors generate to our local economy. Some of the responses included: $12,000, $1.5 million, $3 million and $50 million. In reality, roughly $500 million is generated by visitors to the Salem area. All of the respondents were pleasantly surprised to learn about tourismâ€™s significant impact.

Just the Facts
Tourism is a vital component of economic development, serving as one of Americaâ€™s largest industries and employers. In the Salem area, tourism is responsible for generating $18.6 million in tax receipts (2008 Travel Impacts research by Dean Runyan Associates), and the $500 million generated by visitors in the Salem area is responsible for 6,000 jobs. Simply put, when people travel, the economy grows, jobs are created, and the money goes right back into the local community.

One Degree of Separation
We all encounter someone directly involved with the tourism industry each day. It can be at the local coffee shop or specialty boutique; during lunch at your favorite restaurant; enjoying the agricultural offerings of a farmersâ€™ market; while purchasing tickets to a theatrical performance; laughing over a glass or mug of award-winning wine or beer; or while fishing, birding or hiking. It can be as simple as fueling your car. All of these experiences and many more are tied to the tourism industry. Now think of all the indirect connections. What about the farmer that provides the ingredients for that amazing meal, or the paper product vendor that supplies your favorite coffee shop? And what about the realtor who is working with someone who, after visiting Salem, is now interested in relocating? Tourism touches all of us and connects with all corners of the economy.

Mirror, Mirror on the Wallâ€_
Promoting the Salem area isnâ€™t about finding the â€œfairest of them all;â€ù it is about promoting all of the various amenities of the region in an integrated way that connects with people and their interests. Selling the entire Salem area â€” not placing all of our marketing eggs into one basket â€” is important to attract a wide variety of people with diverse interests, who will stay longer to experience all the region has to offer. A visitor could experience a white water rafting trip on the Santiam River and then spend the evening at Historic Deepwood Estateâ€™s Wine Festival. That is the beauty of the Salem area â€” it really does have something for everyone!

Understanding and Confirmation
As our â€œstreet teamsâ€ù discovered, the majority of people interviewed understand that tourism is a good, robust industry that adds to Salemâ€™s economic health. Some of our interviewees actually had visitors with them, which made it evident that visitors are among us each day adding to the vitality of our region. There was one couple that was from Sausalito, Calif. and, although they didnâ€™t participate in our research, they were thrilled to learn about the Travel CafÃ© Visitors Center and how it can assist them with planning their Salem adventureâ€_another happy customer!

 Yes, tourism works for America and Salem!

~ Angie Morris, president and CEO of Travel Salem
*Originally printed in Statesman Journal, 5/16/10

column4: Travel Salem Named Top 100 Best Green Companies to Work For in Oregon
column5:
Travel Salem has been selected as a â€œTop 100 Best Green Companies to Work For in Oregonâ€ù by Oregon Business magazine. The rankings were unveiled at a luncheon held at the Hilton Portland & Executive Tower on Tuesday, June 1, 2010. Travel Salem was one of only five Salem businesses recognized â€” and the only nonprofit â€” ranking 80th overall.

Travel Salemâ€™s â€œGreen Team,â€ù a group of employees in charge with making the workplace more sustainable, led the way in developing an eco-savvy culture that buy-in to sustainable practices. Travel Salem is certified EarthWISE through Marion Countyâ€™s business environmental assistance program; incorporating sustainable practices in the business such as recycling, reducing waste and saving energy. Travel Salemâ€™s Travel CafÃ© and administrative office was designed with sustainability in mind; using recycled and earth-friendly materials, natural light, among other features. Last March, the Travel CafÃ© received an award for â€œGreen Building Retrofit of the Yearâ€ù at the 2010 Mid-Willamette Valley Green Awards.

Based on its widely recognized â€œ100 Best Companies to Work For in Oregonâ€ù project, the 100 Best Green Companies were determined by an anonymous employee survey and an independent assessment of the employersâ€™ sustainability practices. There were 503 organizations and more than 26,000 employees participating in the project. Companies must enter either the 100 Best Companies survey or the 100 Best Nonprofits survey to be eligible for the 100 Best Green ranking. Last year, Travel Salem was recognized as the 16th best small nonprofit and 21st overall to work for in Oregon. The next 100 Best Nonprofits rankings will be announced in September.

The â€œ100 Best Green Companies to Work For in Oregonâ€ù is featured in the June â€œGreen Issueâ€ù of Oregon Business magazine, which is out now.

column5:
En route to Travel Salemâ€™s first annual â€œAbsolutely Fabulousâ€ù Awards Luncheon, on May 20 at Willamette Valley Vineyards, attendees experienced Oregonâ€™s version of the â€œred carpetâ€ù â€“ a lush and rolling hillside up to the winery; stopping every so often to enjoy the amazing panoramic views of our very own â€œgreen carpet,â€ù also known as the Willamette Valley.

May is National Tourism Month, and as we gathered for the â€œAb Fabâ€ù awards, it was the perfect time to recognize tourism industry partners who have gone above and beyond this past year to attract visitors to our region and drive $500 million in economic impact to our communities.

The Ab Fab Awards paid tribute to many exceptional tourism partners, hereâ€™s a few: â€œAbsolutely Greenâ€ù Award to the Salem Conference Center for their numerous green initiatives to reduce their carbon footprint; â€œAbsolutely Thinking Bigâ€ù Award to the Willamette Heritage Center for their ability to think big and create an umbrella organization that will benefit a number of heritage resources; and the â€œAbsolutely Fabulousâ€ù Award went toâ€_ the Statesman Journal for their commitment to spreading the word about the wondrous bounty of the region, and sharing stories about how tourism touches every corner of the economy and improves the quality of life for all of us that live here. Visit TravelSalem.com for the complete list of winners.

During the Ab Fab awards ceremony, I looked out and saw the folks who day in and day out, follow their dreams and pour their hearts into their work, making the Salem area one of the best places on the planet to call home. Not only does Travel Salem applaud the achievements of our award recipients, we also applaud all of our partners in the tourism industry. You are all Absolutely Fabulous!

~ Angie Morris, president and CEO of Travel Salem
* Originally printed in Statesman Journal, 5/30/10

column4: Create a recreational 'bucket list' of sorts
column5:
I recently floated the Santiam River, courtesy of North Santiam River Trips, with a group of adrenaline junkies from Travel Salem, the Statesman Journal and Travel Oregon. The day was filled with adventure and surprises as we connected with nature and a few wild rapids.

I quickly learned that first is not always best when rafting. I was the human â€œSham-Wowâ€ù towel at the bow of our raft, while the rest of the crew was safely shielded by my â€œexuberanceâ€ù to be first.

My next adventure took me to Black Rock Mountain Biking facility in Polk County, near Dallas. Nestled in a lush, old-growth forest, this mountain bike course is not for wimps. Built by mountain bike enthusiasts and maintained by the honor system, this track attracts serious international and domestic off-road bikers.

My senses were heightened during my ride. The sights, sounds, smells of the forest, and taste of the earth as I paid homage to the â€œdeity of dirt,â€ù made this physical experience truly memorable. No cars, no crowds, no clutter - just me and the trail.

After my ride, I realized that even at my age I was still able to â€œshred it,â€ù and that I live in a spectacular area with diverse and abundant recreational opportunities all close to home.

My recreational â€œbucket listâ€ù still has plenty on it such as: snowshoeing through Opal Creek; soaking in the geothermal hot springs at Breitenbush; a hot air balloon ride with Balloon Flying Service; and catching that illusive Santiam River salmon, in the third swirling eddy, to the right of the petrified fallen fir tree, at mile three of the float. However, jet skiing on the Willamette River sounds good tooâ€_so many choices!

Visit the Travel Salem Travel CafÃ© Visitor Center at 181 High Street NE in historic downtown Salem to create your own recreational â€œbucket list.â€ù TravelSalem.com

~ Angie Morris, president and CEO of Travel Salem
*Originally printed in Statesman Journal, 7/18/10

column4: Travel Salem Marketing Exchange Luncheon - September 16, 2010
column5:
Travel Salem Marketing Exchange Luncheon

The Many Shades of Green: How to help save the planet and make your business more profitable

Featuring
Alan Pennington
Waste Reduction Coordinator for Marion County Public Works-Environmental Services

Thursday, September 16, 2010
11:45 a.m. - 1:15 p.m.

Creekside Golf Club
6250 Clubhouse Dr. SE
Salem, OR

Feast your eyes on the many shades of green at Creekside Golf Club while enjoying a delightful lunch. Alan Pennington will be presenting methods to make your business more profitable while helping save the planet. Call now to reserve your seat!

Keynote Speaker: Alan Pennington, Waste Reduction Coordinator for Marion County Public Works and EarthWISE program manager for the County will be introducing the unique EarthWISE program and how it can add to profitability, and environment and economic sustainability. He will also be discussing the solid waste and recycling programs, and impact on the environment.

Promote Your Business: This is your opportunity to promote your business and services! Remember to bring your business cards and brochures for the Marketing Exchange table.

Enter-to-Win! â€“ West Side Wine Store is providing a fabulous wine basket with 3 bottles of 90 Point wine as rated by Wine Spectator magazine, a Vinturi wine aerator and wine opener valued at over $100! Be sure to enter your business card for a chance to be one of the lucky recipients. Guests must be present to win.

RSVPs and prepayment of $18 required / $23 at the door RSVP a must!
Reserve Your Seat Today - Save $5 with advanced registration if purchased by September 13th!
-- Online - use your credit card at TravelSalem.com
-- Phone - use your credit card by calling 503-581-4325 ext. 58
-- Mail - send your check to: Travel Salem Marketing Exchange Luncheon, 181 High St. NE, Salem, OR 97301

Please remember that when we receive your RSVP, we will order and pay for your lunch. If you are unable to attend, payment for lunch is still required. Thanks for helping to make Travel Salem luncheons a success.

YOU WILL WANT TO ADD TO YOUR BUSINESS SAVVY AND NETWORK BY ATTENDING THIS MARKETING EXCHANGE

See you on September 16, 2010!

Thanks to our event sponsors:

As part of Travel Salemâ€™s â€œAbsolutely Giving Backâ€ù program, attendees are encouraged to bring new school supplies (crayons, colored pencils, watercolors, glue sticks, pencils, pens, scissors, construction paper, white glue, non-toxic white washable paint, or felt-tip markers). column4: One-year Anniversary Party! Come Sip New Release Wine and Drop Off your Corks!
column5:
It started with a romping grape stomp outside the front doors of Travel Salem last year, but this year we celebrate the one-year anniversary of Travel Salemâ€™s partnership with Willamette Valley Vineyards to create a downtown Travel CafÃ© where visitors can come to sip some of the valleyâ€™s most delicious wines! Come join us next Thursday, October 14th for a wine tasting party from 5 to 7 p.m. Oct. 14 at the Travel CafÃ© on 181 High St. NE.

Enjoy new releases of Willamette Valley Vineyards sustainable wine: 08 Pinot Noir, 08 Signature Cuvee Pinot Noir, 08 Estate Chard, and 07 Syrah, as well as delicious library wines.

Weâ€™re also trying to collect a massive pile of corks to send to the cork recycler, so bring by your corks, by the load, if you have â€˜em! Whoever bring the most corks, wins a prize! Learn about Willamette Valley Vineyards cork recycling program from their Cork reHarvest director. The party will be catered by Wild Pear restaurant, a favorite of locavores. www.wildpearcatering.com

The first 25 guests will receive a complimentary â€œItâ€™s Willamette Dammitâ€ù T-shirt.

Weekly tastings are available from 11 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. Mondays through Saturdays at Travel CafÃ©, 181 High St. NE.

General Admission: $10.00 includes Riedel wine glass
Wine Club Members: $5.00 includes Riedel wine glass

For more information, call (503) 588-9463 or go to www.willamettevalleyvineyards.com.

column4: Travel Salem Receives $7,500 from Travel Oregon to Produce an Interactive Online Map
column5:
Travel Salemâ€™s proposal to produce an interactive online map was one of 10 tourism destination projects in the state to garner a portion of a $60,000 grant by Travel Oregonâ€™s Matching Grants Program. Travel Salem received $7,500 to produce an interactive map featuring cultural and heritage highlights in Marion and Polk County. Created in 1986, the annual Matching Grants Program supports new projects that improve local economies and communities by enhancing, expanding and promoting Oregonâ€™s visitor industry.

â€œThis dynamic, colorful map will help connect visitors with some of our most prized cultural heritage attractions from one user-friendly format,â€ù said Angie Morris, CEO of Travel Salem. â€œThe ultimate goal of the map is to encourage visitors to stay longer in our communities and to take full advantage of the rich cultural diversity of our region.â€ù

The Matching Grants Program selection committee, representing private and public sector organizations, selected this yearâ€™s grant finalists from a pool of 29 applicants. The 10 commission-approved projects are located throughout the state and, when complete, will fulfill a range of local, regional and state needs for improved tourism capacity.

â€œThe grant dollars provide seed money to projects that will increase Oregon destinationsâ€™ visibility among potential visitors.â€ù said Carole Astley, industry relations manager at Travel Oregon. â€œThe 10 applicants we selected are thinking about long term return-oninvestment for developing and promoting tourism in the regional areas their organizations serve.â€ù

Those interested in taking advantage of this interactive online resource to promote their attraction can contact Irene Bernards at ibernards@TravelSalem.com. â€œWe encourage cultural and heritage nonprofits in Polk and Marion counties to leverage the dollars weâ€™ve received through this grant,â€ù said Morris.

column4: Travel Salem Ranks 37 on List of 100 Best Nonprofits to Work For in Oregon
column5:
Travel Salem has been selected again as one of Oregonâ€™s â€œTop 100 Best Nonprofits to Work For in Oregonâ€ù by Oregon Business magazine. The rankings were unveiled at a sold-out event held at the Portland Art Museum on September 22, 2010. Travel Salem was recognized as the 24th best small nonprofit and 37th overall.

â€œThose of us who choose nonprofit careers do so for the chance to serve a cause greater than ourselves,â€ù said Angie Morris, president and CEO of Travel Salem. â€œTravel Salem attracts and retains amazing, talented staff, who bring their â€˜A-gameâ€™ and give a little bit of their heart to their job every single day. There is no question why they are some of the best in the industry.â€ù

The rankings were based on an independence assessment of employerâ€™s workplace practices and the confidential input of employees who answered 60 questions about workplace satisfaction such as benefits, management, trust, work environment and development. The criteria employees ranked as most important were: â€œtreatment of employees by supervisors,â€ù and â€œpride and belief in the organization.â€ù More than 150 nonprofits participated and almost 5,000 employees completed the survey. The free, voluntary survey was calculated by research partners Davis, Hibbitts and Midghall along with a research editor at Oregon Business magazine.

The â€œTop 100 Best Nonprofits to Work For in Oregonâ€ù is featured in the October issue of Oregon Business magazine.

column4: Donâ€™t Miss the Parade of Sweetness!
column5:
As summer fades and the days shorten, Willamette Valley hosts one of the most colorful yet under-the-radar events of the year. The event isn't formally announced but is possibly Oregon's oldest celebration, going on without fail and fanfare for years. . . it's the annual fall HARVEST, coming to you LIVE from a farm near you!

During the harvest, Willamette Valley comes alive and puts on its true colors: crisp yellow of apples, plump orange of pumpkins, sugary-sweet red of tomatoes and indigo of grapes ready for the winepress. Sure, it's nothing as flashy as a parade of floats, but harvest time is a wonderful parade for the taste buds!

It's easy to seek adventure beyond our borders, but any foodie worth their salt knows they need to appreciate what's right in front of their nose first. Instead of booking a flight to culinary capitals like Italy or Southern France, delve deeper into the culinary treasures in our own backyard: visit Prudence Uncorked (www.prudenceuncorked.com) to taste Oregon wild mushrooms on the menu. Save money on a Provence cheese tour, stop at Willamette Valley Cheese Company (www.wvcheeseco.com) and munch on award-winning Herb de Provence Havarti. No need to fly to the East Coast for apple cider to swig down with a homemade donut stop by E.Z. Orchards Farm Market (www.ezorchards.com) to get both. Or, if you like your cider hard, try Wandering Aengus' (www.wanderingaengus.com) brews made in the American cider tradition. Pick up a loaf of old-world sourdough at the Bread Board Bakery (www.thebreadboard.net) in Falls City.

Consider making the Salem area's agritourism hotspots the highlight of a trip, not just the side attraction. Our farms, orchards, wineries, breweries, restaurants, bakeries and artisan-crafted food stops are truly national and international treasures. For information about the area's agritourism destinations, visit www.TravelSalem.com.

Help Promote Oregon Bounty - Travel Oregon's Fall Travel Promotion, Oregon Bounty, is underway! 

Oregon Bounty kicked off August 23rd with this year's theme Oregon Bounty Wanderfeast. The campaign features ten chefs, over ten weeks, pursuing ten tastes they're crazy about, including wine, seafood, artisan spirits, mushrooms, craft brews and more. Go here to read an overview of the promotion and the "Win an Oregon Bounty Wanderfeast" contest.

Oregon Bounty is a million dollar campaign with an estimated 52 million impressions delivered to consumers in our target markets. New this year, we will feature interactive, expanding banner ads on culinary, travel, lifestyle and local websites like Sunset, Trip Advisor, Facebook, Yelp, Frommer's, OregonLive.com, SeattleTimes.com, SacBee.com and SFGate.com. All drive traffic to the redesigned culinary website, TravelOregon.com/bounty.

We created a marketing toolkit to help you draw upon the campaign to amplify your local marketing efforts. View the toolkit here. To make this promotion as successful as it can be, we encourage you to use the tools provided for your own consumer outreach. Together we can increase Oregon's overall share of voice and get folks traveling to and within our state.

The toolkit provides a variety of opportunities to customize the campaign for your own marketing efforts. We encourage you to:

  • Place a banner ad and Oregon Bounty logos on your website (starting Aug. 23)
  • Publish an e-newsletter article in your existing consumer communication pieces (starting Aug. 23)
  • Embed the Wanderfeast videos on your website (the first videos will be at youtube.com/TravelOregon starting Sept. 12)
  • Tweet and update your Facebook profile (please use #ORBounty as your hashtag); you can also retweet Travel Oregon posts
  • Encourage other businesses to use these tools

All the materials you need are provided in the toolkit. You will find other resources and news about Oregon Bounty as it happens on our dedicated news room page at TravelOregon.mediaroom.com.

For support in working with media interested in Oregon Bounty, please contact Michelle Godfrey at 503-378-8861 or Michelle@TravelOregon.com.

Otherwise, if you have questions about Oregon Bounty or the toolkit please contact Amy Nyberg at 503-378-8801 or Amy@TravelOregon.com.

Thank you very much for your support of Oregon Bounty.

column4: Salem Bewitched by the Spirit of Volunteerism
column5:
*Originally printed in Statesman Journal, 10/31/10

With Halloween around the corner, weâ€™re all a little more attuned to paranormal activity in our beautiful communityâ€”paranormal being defined as: â€œbeyond the range of normal.â€ù 'Tis the season when leaves decay, pumpkins are carved with ghoulish faces and folks dress-up front yards and themselves in ghostly, spooky ways. Letâ€™s face it, itâ€™s the time of year we invite spirits to come out and haunt us! Iâ€™d like to mention a few â€œbeyond normalâ€ù happenings Iâ€™ve witnessed; a unique â€œspiritâ€ù haunting our community. Donâ€™t be alarmed, this spirit is a happy one: itâ€™s the spirit of volunteerism and it has taken hold of our community.

Hereâ€™s a few examples of paranormal sightings observed from our Travel Salem office. One is the dedication of our volunteers who help staff our Travel CafÃ© Visitors Center: people like Bob Krebs, retired from the Oregon Department of Transportation (ODOT) Rail Division, who is also an expert tour guide and regularly shares his knowledge of the Salem area with visitors.

Another is how local businesses supported the recent Extreme Makeover â€“ Home Edition cast, crew, producers and stars when they came to help renovate and film the Oregon School for the Deafâ€™s Nightmare Factory. When Travel Salem put out the call to local businesses to create gift and VIP bags for the Extreme staff, we were flooded with support, to the tune of $80,000 worth of products, services and vouchers. The executive producer of Extreme Makeover personally relayed thanks to the community and said the gesture attested to our communityâ€™s generosity.

And what about community events organized by dedicated volunteers who contribute countless hours to showcase our region as a fun place to live, work and play? Salemâ€™s First Wednesday is a perfect example of the collective work and genius of local businesses to create a dynamic venue that brings the community together while generating economic growth.

The spirit of volunteerism still looms large over the land. Keep your eyes peeled for new sightings of this paranormal activity! Happy Halloween and remember to do your part to keep this happy haunting alive!

~ Angie Morris, president and CEO of Travel Salem

Travel Salem is pleased to announce Jenie Skoy as the Association's new PR Manager. Jenie has a wealth of experience as a former magazine editor, newspaper reporter and freelance food and travel writer. Jenie grew up in Idaho and worked for more than a dozen years as a professional writer based in Salt Lake City, Utah.

Jenie holds a degree from Utah State University in English literature with a minor in print journalism. Sheâ€™s written for publications such as Sunset, USA Today, Fodorâ€™s travel guides, Dining Out, Utah Style and Design, Digital iQ magazine, Ancestry, Park City magazine, the Wasatch Journal and many others.

Jenie has also worked as a freelance PR writer, writing for clients as diverse as Microsoft and Beehive Cheese Company.  She also worked as the editor of Growing Edge magazine in Corvallis, the associate editor of Utah Business and Digital iQ magazines in Salt Lake City, Utah, as well as a special sections editor at the Register Guard in Eugene.

As an avid food blogger and photographer Jenie loves to cook and enjoys doing anything in the wilderness including rock climbing, hiking, fly-fishing and camping. She loves to cycle in Minto Brown Island Park, and dine in Salemâ€™s downtown restaurants.  Jenie also teaches yoga in Salem in her spare time.

Jenie claims that her true gift as Travel Salemâ€™s public relations manager is her tenacity at promoting Salem and Marion and Polk countiesâ€™ rich destination attractions and activities to local and national media.

column4: Travel Salem Hires MEDIAmerica as Publisher of the Salem Area Visitors Guide
column5:
Travel Salem recently announced MEDIAmerica as the new Salem Area Visitors Guide publisher.  In its seventeenth year, the Salem Area Visitors Guide is the official visitors guide and resource for visitors to the Salem and Marion and Polk counties region.  The guide is distributed to 800 locations throughout Oregon, Washington, California and British Columbia and serves as the response piece to all Salem inquiries generated through Travel Salemâ€™s advertising, public relations and consumer engagement strategies.

MEDIAmerica is an integrated publishing company focusing in three core areas that touch everyoneâ€™s lives: business, home and travel.  Oregon-owned and operated since 1981, MEDIAmerica is the most consistent and successful publishing company in Oregon. Since 1995, MEDIAmerica has established itself as the leader in Pacific Northwest travel and tourism publishing and content development.  Some of MEDIAmericaâ€™s titles include: Oregon Business Magazine, Oregon Home Magazine, Discover Portland, Oregon Things to See & Do, Oregon Official State Travel Guide and Green Living.

â€œMEDIAmerica will take the Salem Area Visitors Guide to a new level through creative content, layout and strategies to drive consumers to direct point of sale opportunities on the TravelSalem.com website.  Travel Salemâ€™s partnership with MEDIAmerica is beneficial to the entire region!â€ù said Irene Bernards, marketing and PR director for Travel Salem.

Advertising sales for the Salem Area Visitors Guide will begin in November and run through January.  Businesses interested in learning more about Travel Salem and the Salem Area Visitors Guide can contact Irene Bernards at ibernards@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325 ext. 27 or Salem Area Visitors Guide advertising opportunities contact Terra Moreland at terram@mediamerica.net or 503-445-8830.

  • Back to newsletter

column4: Calling all Wrestling Fans: Oregon State Fair Expo Center Hosts the West Coast World Championship for K-8 Wrestlers
column5:
SALEM, ORE. â€“â€“ Travel Salem is pleased to announce the Oregon State Fair Expo Center will host the 2nd annual Rocky Mountain Nationalâ€™s West Coast World Championship on December 10th and 11th at the Expo Center at 2330 17th street in Salem at 8:30 a.m. The event is one of the highest profile K-8th grade wrestling competitions in the West Coast region and the venue offers competitions held on 10 mats throughout the center with a seating capacity of 4,000 spectators.

Last year, over 500 athletes competed from across the Western U.S. including members of several mat clubs from Marion and Polk counties. Participating clubs this year include the Dallas Mat Club, Team Aggression and Salem Elite Mat Club, among others.

The competition is a rare opportunity for elementary-aged youth to get a taste for competing against some of the best youth wrestlers in the West at an event judged by certified High School wrestling referees. This is the second year the Oregon State Fair Expo Center hosted the event.

â€œWe can look forward to building something very special for the great people in Oregon our second time around,â€ù said Ed Gutierrez, director of Rocky Mountain Nationals events. â€œOregon offers up some of the best wrestling in the country and we want to complement what they are already doing, but add a different flavor. We adopted the slogan to inspire, encourage and recognize these kids. Itâ€™s inspiring to see these little guys compete. We make the competition more than an event, but an unforgettable weekend.â€ù

Mat clubs can enter their wrestling teams online for $36.00 before Sunday, December 5 at midnight. If a wrestler does not make weight, he can pay another registration fee of $20 to declare another weight. Late registration is $56 at weigh-ins.

To volunteer for the event contact Debbie McCune at 503-581-4325 ext. 28 or email her at dmmcune@TravelSalem.com. RMN needs help organizing, distributing information and awards, setting up, tearing down and coordinating things throughout the day.

For participants- Weigh-ins begin on December 10th from 4 to 7 p.m. in the arena of the Expo Center.

General admission to the event is $12. Receive a $2 discount when you bring in a can of food to donate to the Marion-Polk Food Share.

Rocky Mountain Nationals (RMN) is a youth wrestling program based in Colorado which provides opportunity for youth to participate in wrestling championships which encourages their development not only as athletes but as students as well. Involvement with wrestling and sports in general has been shown to increase youths' self esteem, confidence, and social skills. For more information, visit www.rockymountainnationals.com or contact Ed Gutierrez at 303-635-1549.

column4: Join us for Travel Salem 101 â€“ Thursday, February 10th 3:30-5 p.m.
column5:
PLACE:          Travel Salemâ€™s Travel CafÃ©, 181 High St NE, Salem, OR 97301
DAY:              Thursday, February 10, 2010
TIME:             3:30 to 5:00 p.m.

Travel Salemâ€™s members and interested community businesses are invited to join Travel Salem staff for a free session developed to help tourism professionals, visitor-related organizations, and other industry members wanting a better understanding of Travel Salemâ€™s mission, how to get involved in its many opportunities and the potential benefits to your organization or business by partnering with your local destination marketing organization.

The Travel Salem 101 will include: advertising, consumer (visitor) marketing, customer service training, media and public relations, industry relations, niche markets, partnerships, Salem Area Visitors Guide, TravelSalem.com, research, visitor information and convention sales and service strategies. We are also offering a wine tasting after the meeting with Willamette Valley Vineyards.

Sessions are limited to 10 people, and reservations are taken on a first come/first reserved basis. Call today to reserve your seat by Tuesday, February 8th! Call Sue Nichols at 503-581-4325 x22.

column5:
On cold January days that require bundling up, donâ€™t forget weâ€™re on the downswing of winter. The Winter Solstice has come and gone, which means weâ€™re headed for longer days and more exposure to direct sunlight. Keep this in mind when deciding whether to stay in hibernation or wake up! I suggest waking up! Open your front door to a little fresh wintry air and find ways to bloom in the midst of winter, there are so many things to do in our region! Follow the lead of the Helleborus or Christmas Flower who blooms this month in shades like black, wine and berry. Go to The Oregon Garden to visit her and other winter-blooming flowers like red Camelias or the tropical-smelling Daphne Odora. Itâ€™s the quieter off-season at The Oregon Garden and the animals know it. This month your companions will be deer, Cedar waxwings, palliated woodpeckers and a rare green heron who comes to soak up the peace â€” and also eat bullfrogs.

Be like the wildlife and find places where youâ€™ll be away from the crowds. Be the only cyclist at Minto-Brown Island Park on a clear day or take a horseback ride through Santiam State Forest with Into the Wild Equine Adventures who offer three-hour to one-day rides and are currently offering  a special of buy one ride package and get one for a companion free through May 31, 2011. When thereâ€™s wind out, unfurl a kite into the sky at Salemâ€™s Riverfront Park.

Valentineâ€™s Day is around the corner, create a hand-made card for your loved one at Historic Deepwood Estate's Valentineâ€™s Day card making class on Feb 7th from 1 to 3 p.m. Or power-up your intellect by attending Deepwoodâ€™s free Heritage Talksâ€” start with the American Character discussion on Feb. 9th.

Invite your northern friends to migrate south for the winter â€” down to our region! Pick up a two-for-one Amtrak Cascades voucher at our Travel CafÃ© on 181 High Street NE and share it with those northerners who want to bypass the hassle of driving (the Amtrak route also offers WiFi). Your guests can hop on the Amtrak in Vancouver, Canada or in Seattle or Portland and come play in Salem for the weekend!

Or simply declare your last work day: â€œFlower Fridayâ€ù and buy blooms for your office, or order summery local jams from Fresh to You, a company that will also come to your home and help you spruce up your winter-weary yard with landscaping tips. Thereâ€™s so much to explore, go ahead and let go of that urge to hibernate! Wake up instead! Today is one day closer to spring than yesterday! Happy blooming!

~ Angie Morris, president and CEO of Travel Salem
*Originally printed in Statesman Journal, 1/23/11

  • Back to newsletter

column4: First Wednesday -- Love in the City
column5:
Travel Salem
181 High St. NE
Wednesday, February 2, 2011
5:00 â€“ 8:00 p.m.

Put a little bit of love in your heart this season! Bring your loved ones to Travel Salem for a heart-warming experience as we feature three local wineries in an exclusive wine tasting event at our Travel CafÃ©. Enjoy buttery cheeses from Willamette Valley Cheese Company, shop around for clothing and gift ideas for your loved ones and find information about how to get involved in YWCAâ€™s Women helping Women programs! Plus, come check out our pal, Sal, the famous Golden Pioneer!

  • Consigning Women â€“ Salem is all about recycling â€” what better way to embrace this philosophy than purchasing from one of our local consignment shops! Pick something out for yourself or a loved one while here!
  • Latitude One â€“ Dallasâ€™ delicious Italian restaurant is back by popular demand! If you didnâ€™t sample their dishes last year, you wonâ€™t want to miss the red velvet cake and other decadent treats the Chef will be baking up for our February event.
  • Willamette Valley Cheese Company â€“ Enjoy local, delicious, buttery cheeses for pairings with our local wines. Free tastings as well as cheeses for purchase. Youâ€™ll want to take some home!
  • YWCA â€“ Learn about their outreach programs and events for women and children and how you can become involved.
  • Special Complimentary Wine Tasting Event!!
    ---> Firesteed Cellars â€“ The wines of Firesteed display distinctive varietal character and consistently â€˜over deliverâ€™ in terms of value for the price. Try for yourself the Premium Citation Chardonnay, 2006 Willamette Valley Pinot, and Dry Riesling.
    ---> Left Coast Cellars â€“ Theyâ€™ll be pouring tastes of three of their estate-grown, hand-crafted Pinot Gris and Pinot Noir wines. Wine will also be available for purchase.
    ---> Willamette Valley Vineyards â€“ Special Pre-release pouring of their 2008 Pinot Noir style Port. Complimentary tastes of this limited wine. Perfect for pairing with Valentineâ€™s Day chocolate. (stemware not included.)

Contribute to Travel Salem's "Absolutely Giving Back" program by dropping by a new or gently used, clean childâ€™s winter coat.

column4: Taste Oregon 2011 â€“ An Oregon Restaurant & Lodging Association Event
column5:
February 7, 2011 | Salem Conference Center

Whet your appetite and make plans to attend Oregon Restaurant & Lodging Association's Taste Oregon Legislative Reception this February at the Salem Conference Center in Salem, Oregon. This biennial event kicks off the new legislative session by showcasing Oregon's premier cuisine provided by ORLA members from around the state. Restaurant and lodging operators have the unique opportunity to meet some of Oregon's top policy makers who support hospitality and the issues affecting our industry.

Taste Oregon will showcase an array of specialties from member locations including Bandon Bill's Seafood Grill, Buffalo Wild Wings, Little Cannoli Bakery, Prudence Uncorked, Taprock Northwest Grill and Thirsty Lion Pub & Grill (to name a few).

The reception opens at 5:30 p.m. This is a hosted event however registration is required. RSVP by contacting Megan Danilson at 503-682-4422. If you'd like to participate as a sponsor or vendor for this special event, email sponsor@oregonrla.org today.

  • Back to newsletter

column4: AbsolutelyTix: Ticketing Outlet for Events or Tour Admissions
column5:
The new year is just underway, which means a new year of events, art exhibits, theater performances, movie showings, and more! Your one-stop source for ticketing needs is AbsolutelyTix, a state-of-the-art network for Marion and Polk Counties. AbsolutelyTix allow consumers to easily purchase tickets at the Travel CafÃ© or online, and provides a single source of online information about upcoming local shows and events. 

More than 29 partners (and growing) â€” local arts organizations, non-profits, and other community organizations â€” have partnered with Travel Salem to sell tickets and transact other business over the Internet. Some partners include: Oregon Symphony Association in Salem, Willamette University Theatre, Salem Chamber Orchestra, and Salem Film Festival. Tickets for events, theater performances, concerts and more from our AbsolutelyTix partners are available for purchase online and at the Travel Cafe (181 High St. NE, Salem). Visit AbsolutelyTix.com for a complete list of upcoming events, shows, and performances.

Those interested in partnering with Travel Salem to promote events and sell tickets through the AbsolutelyTix network should contact Barb Cowan at bcowan@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325, ext. 21.

column4: Leverage Travel Oregon's National Adventurecation Campaign
column5:
Travel Oregon will be launching their spring 2011 campaign in March. Similar to previous campaigns, they will be incorporating â€œdealsâ€ù into the campaign landing page. The goal is to showcase a variety of deals to further stimulate consumers to travel within Oregon and we want to make sure the Salem area has a big presence!

The deals can be in any of the following categories. The theme of the campaign is outdoor adventure/recreation, but that shouldnâ€™t limit the types of deals you submit:

  • Eat & Drink â€“ deals from restaurants, breweries and wineries
  • Places to Stay â€“ deals from hotels or specialty lodging
  • Activities â€“ deals on activities, events or special attraction passes

Click here to submit your deals through our online form. Deals must be submitted by February 28th to insure inclusion in Travel Oregon's spring campaign.

If you have questions, please contact Kathie Reeves, Marketing Manager, at 503-581-4325 ext. 24 or kreeves@TravelSalem.com.
