column4: Travel Salem Marketing Exchange Luncheon - March 17, 2011
column5:
Travel Salem Marketing Exchange Luncheon

 Community Spirits: Turning Ghost Stories into Tourism Dollars

 Thursday, March 17, 2011
11:45 a.m. - 1:15 p.m.
(RSVPs needed today!)

Dallas Event Center
939 Main St.
Dallas, OR 97338
Downtown Dallas parking map

Stories are magical! They can bridge generations and inspire listeners. Come learn tricks for harnessing the power of storytelling to drive business! Learn how one group took storytelling and turned a small community gathering into an unforgettable event that now draws more than a 1,000 people! Attend the Marketing Exchange luncheon to learn tricks of the storytelling trade. Call now to reserve your seat!

Keynote Speaker: Marilyn Morton, a third generation Oregonian, director of the Monmouth-Independence Chamber of Commerce and a member of the Independence City Council will share some hair-raising stories about how channeling Independenceâ€™s ghostly past has driven tourist dollars to their community!

Promote Your Business: Hands down it is proven that networking has the highest ROI for businesses big and small. Promote your business and services with compelling marketing materials and networking at this luncheon. Remember to bring your business cards and brochures for the Marketing Exchange table.

Enter-to-Win! Jeff Mexico is giving away gift certificates to the Fox Theatre, The Courtyard Coffeehouse and Deli, and Dallas Motor VU Drive. Be sure to enter your business card for a chance to be the lucky recipient. Guests must be present to win.

 

Reserve Your Seat Today! Save $5 with advanced registration if purchased by March 15th!

-- Phone - use your credit card by calling 503-581-4325 ext. 58
-- Mail - send your check to: Travel Salem Marketing Exchange Luncheon, 181 High St. NE, Salem, OR 97301

column5:
Our region is full of places steeped in history, so when you go outside this spring, keep your ears tuned for stories from Oregonâ€™s past, they travel like dandelion fluff on the air! Listen carefully, you may hear something remarkable.

Stories abound here, from A.C. Gilbertâ€™s magical tales of pole-vaulting and toy-inventing to the stories of two lady landscape architects (Elizabeth Lord and Edith Schryver) whose garden designs are memorialized at Bushâ€™s Pasture Park and Historic Deepwood Estate.

Learn a story about how Salem looked to early pioneers through a view of native plants and trees at the remnant oak savannah at Bushâ€™s Pasture Park. In March at the Bush Barn Art Center you can learn how artists are using the past for inspiration in the â€œParks for the Peopleâ€ù exhibit featuring a display of several artists commissioned to draw or paint figurative works based upon historic photos of Lord and Schryver.

At Historic Deepwood Estate on March 15th from 11:30 a.m. to 1:30 p.m., learn about silk art embroidery, a craft that upper class Victorian women employed to earn an independent living. Listen to lectures by Donna Cardwell, author of Silk Art Embroidery, A Womanâ€™s History of Ornament and Empowerment, along with silver and linen expert Lisa Hand from Wind Horse Antiques. The event is accompanied by three-course tea and a house tour.

And at the Historic Elsinore Theatre later that evening at 7 p.m., youâ€™ll be transported back to the Oregon Trail through an Oregon Film special screening of Meekâ€™s Cutoff, an Oregon film featured in Sundance, Toronto and Venice film festivals that depicts a short-cut taken by a group of Oregon pioneers that had fatal results. Tickets to the benefit for the Oregon Cultural Trust can be purchased at www.elsinoretheatre.com.

Salem has stories underfoot, so walk slowly as you go about. Retired Linfield College historian John Ritter and creative director for QA Properties, Rebecca Maitland, have been exploring 18 buildings downtown, digging for clues to Salemâ€™s past. They plan to host tours that show, in part, a bustling underground center of commerce during the Wild West days. Highlights of the underground tour include an antique bank vault, a stairwell that leads nowhere, a 1930â€™s grocery drop with painted grocery aisles and lockers, a 1920s mural in an old underground cafe and an intact gold drop at the Capitol Building Center (where they claim you can still see specks of gold.) Tours plan to start this June.

In coming weeks, historian Hazel Patton, who spearheaded Salemâ€™s Riverfront Carousel, and a group of history lovers are organizing artifacts from the early days at the Oregon State Hospital (including the tub that was thrown out the window in One Flew over the Cuckooâ€™s Nest) for the new, upcoming Oregon State Hospital Museum which will open in April of 2012 on the OSH campus in one of the remaining Kirkbride buildings.

And speaking of history in the air! At Willamette University on February 26th and 27th, the Willamette Master Chorus and a few WU choirs will fill Hudson Hall and literally breathe life into a piece of musical history, Handelâ€™s brilliant oratorio, the Messiah, first performed in Dublin in the Spring of 1742.

We know the power of stories and storytelling at Travel Salem and thatâ€™s why next month, weâ€™re hosting a storyteller at our Marketing Exchange event. Marilyn Morton, director of the Monmouth/Independence Chamber of Commerce will come to tell how storytelling turned Independenceâ€™s Ghost Walk from a small gathering into an event that serves more than a thousand! On March 17th, hear Marilyn speak about â€œCommunity Spirits: Turning Ghost Stories into Tourism Dollars!â€ù from 11:45 a.m. to 1:15 p.m. at the Dallas Event Center on 939 Main Street. For more information visit: www.TravelSalem.com.

~ Angie Morris, president and CEO of Travel Salem
*Originally printed in Statesman Journal, 2/20/11

Liquor Depot Has Exciting News

Liquor Depot (previously known as West Salem liquor) is under new ownership and management.

The GRAND OPENING for the new location (next door to current store) will be announced later this month. Come meet the new owners and managers and help us celebrate the exciting new changes.

As a new addition to the services, Liquor Depot is offering FREE delivery to businesses. Now open 7 days a week. Mon.-Thurs. 10 a.m-8 p.m., Fri.-Sat. 10 a.m.-9 p.m., and Sun. 11 a.m.-7 p.m.

The store is bringing in new and exciting spirits, mixers and gifts on a weekly basis. A new gift design program that allows you to choose your spirits and/or mixers for fun gift baskets or bags has been incorporated. The gifts are made to order and are available already assembled. Jazz up the your gifts with greeting cards and other creative gift items.

To keep up with our exciting changes or get ideas for drinks, gifts, or an upcoming party follow us on Facebook.

Salem, OR 97304

column4: Travel Salemâ€™s Annual Absolutely Fabulous Awards Luncheon -- May 19, 2011
column5:
Travel Salem's Annual
Absolutely Fabulous Awards Luncheon

Thursday, May 19, 2011
11:45 a.m. - 1:15 p.m.

Northern Lights Theatre Pub
3893 Commercial St. SE, Salem

You won't want to miss the annual Travel Salem Absolutely Fabulous Awards Luncheon "with a twist." Held during National Tourism Month, the "Ab Fab" Awards will recognize tourism industry partners who have gone above and beyond in 2010-11 to promote the Salem area. These award recipients are movers and shakers who have pushed the envelope and turned ideas upside-down and inside out to capture the best returns on their marketing, collaboration, partnerships, innovation and regional strategies! They are Absolutely Fabulous!

Enjoy a playful atmosphere at Northern Lights Theatre Pub while networking and celebrating National Tourism Month. The $496 million generated by visitors each year to the Salem area along with 5,600 direct jobs, is significant and worth commemorating!

This year's Ab Fab awards will be emceed by Erick Kountz of Positively Twisted. He will teach creative thinking and networking techniques through entertaining and thought-provoking exercises. LivePostcard will be there to photograph you in a fun, Hollywood "red carpet" setting as you pose with local celebrity, Sal the Gold Pioneer! Call now to reserve your seat!

Promote Your Business: Don't forget to bring your marketing materials (business cards and brochures) to the luncheon to promote your business and services! This is Travel Salem's annual event, so plan plenty of time to network.

Enter-to-Win! Woodburn Company Stores will give away $300 worth of gift certificates, JoyRide Cycling Studio will give away $150 worth of indoor cycling classes and Adelman Peony Gardens will have a drawing for the colorful table centerpieces. Be sure to enter your business card for a chance to be a winner. Guests must be present to win.

Reserve Your Seat Today! Save $5 with advanced registration if purchased by May 16th!

column4: Small and Grand Gestures to Tell Mom you Love Her!
column5:
Motherâ€™s Day is just around the corner. As a child, I loved picking wild purple orchids, tying them with a pretty ribbon and giving them to my mother and grandmother. Itâ€™s these simple gifts that are sometimes the most powerful â€” on the giving and receiving end!

While looking for Motherâ€™s Day gifts this season, donâ€™t forget those small, child-like things you once did, offering hand-picked flowers, creating fun, homemade cards, or making a handmade passport for Mom that she can redeem for family outings such as a performance, gallery walk or wine tours or even for a weekâ€™s worth of house cleaning or cooking by you! Or give her the gift that keeps on giving (and that the whole family can enjoy too!). Order her a Pie of the Month â€“ 12 pies from Willamette Valley Fruit Company and enjoy pie throughout the year. Or pick another product throughout the month like bread, soap, chocolate, or give her a gift card from a local coffee shop like Governorâ€™s Cup Coffee Roasters.

Hereâ€™s another idea: take her to a place like Wavra Farms and Nursery in southeast Salem and let her pick her favorite flowers and ask the nursery to plant them for her. Then pour her a glass of her favorite pinot noir on the deck overlooking her new flower planters.

There are so many simple things you can do to show Mom your love. Another idea is to devote your time to creating new memories together by exploring our region.

Hereâ€™s a few local suggestions:

Treat her to a free carriage ride at the Bush House Museum (with paid admission to the house), then take her to Historic Deepwood Estate, for their Annual Champagne Brunch on May 8th, with sumptuous dishes and desserts followed by a tour of the home. Is your mom a bird lover? Take her to Left Coast Cellars' Birdathon with the Portland Audubon Society to wander a 300 acre estate in search of birds on May 7th at 10 a.m.

Or try this grand gesture: What mom wouldnâ€™t love to float in the clouds on a hot air balloon ride with a champagne toast afterwards? Let Jim Desch from Balloon Flying Service of Oregon be your Captain Kirk over the Willamette Valley.

Head over to the Stangeland Vineyards and Winery tasting room on May 8th for a Motherâ€™s Day chocolate and wine tasting from 2 p.m. to 4 p.m. Go on a walk with Mom (and the birds) at the Silver Falls Motherâ€™s Day Birding and Wildflower Festival on Saturday, May 7th and Sunday, May 8th from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.

Overwhelm your mom by immersing her in a kaleidoscope of fragrant peonies at Adelman Peony Gardens on Saturday May 7th and Sunday May 8th from 9 a.m. to 7 p.m. â€“ admission is free! Or stroll through a rainbow of irises at Schreinerâ€™s Gardens from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.

~ Angie Morris, president and CEO of Travel Salem
*Originally printed in Statesman Journal, 2/20/11

Travel Salemâ€™s members and interested community businesses are invited to join Travel Salem staff for a free session developed to help tourism professionals, visitor-related organizations, and other industry members wanting a better understanding of Travel Salemâ€™s mission, how to get involved in its many opportunities and the potential benefits to your organization or business by partnering with your local destination marketing organization.

The Travel Salem 101 will include: advertising, consumer (visitor) marketing, customer service training, media and public relations, industry relations, niche markets, partnerships, Salem Area Visitors Guide, TravelSalem.com, research, visitor information and convention sales and service strategies. column4: Travel Salem Honors Exceptional Tourism Partners at â€œAbsolutely Fabulousâ€ù Awards Event!
column5:
Travel Salem announced the recipients of their â€œAbsolutely Fabulousâ€ù Awards at the Second Annual â€œAb Fabâ€ù Awards Luncheon Thursday, May 19, 2011 at Northern Lights Theatre Pub. Local celebrity, Sal, the Golden Pioneer jumped down off the Oregon State Capitol to greet visitors to the event!

Mayor Anna Peterson was there to help celebrate the event and read a proclamation from the City of Salem to recognize National Tourism Week.

The Ab Fab Awards recognize tourism industry partners who have gone above and beyond in 2010-11 to increase the economic impact of visitors. These recipients are movers and shakers whose collaboration and partnerships, innovation, vision, awareness, environmental initiatives, product development and regional strategies are Absolutely Fabulous!

Listed below are the winners of the 2011 Ab Fab Award in each category:

â€œAbsolutely Carpe Diemâ€ù Award - Salemâ€™s Underground Tours â€“ Rebecca Maitland
For seizing the opportunity of bringing to life another cultural asset to share with visitors and the community.

â€œAbsolutely Pioneeringâ€ù Award - Virginia Green
For her absolute support of all things heritage in Salem.

â€œAbsolutely Keystoneâ€ù Award - Chemeketa Community College
For the way they champion education and training in the tourism industry!

â€œAbsolutely Greenâ€ù Award - Grand Cru Wine Tours â€“ Byron Williams
For their commitment to having a sustainable business from first sip to last nibble.

â€œAbsolutely a Home Runâ€ù Award - City of Salem Softball Program
For elevating Salem softball to the National level and bringing millions of dollars in economic impact to our community.

â€œAbsolutely Gets it!â€ù Award - Willamette Art Center â€“ Karl Knudson
For the wonderful way theyâ€™ve brought art to the people!

â€œAbsolutely Thinking Bigâ€ù Award - The Confederated Tribes of Grand Ronde
For their remarkable collaboration with our heritage sites to give visitors a truly authentic taste of Oregon.

â€œAbsolutely Fabulousâ€ù Award - Ron Cooper
For the way his stellar photographs help brand and promote our beautiful region.

â€œWe are extremely proud to honor these amazing people in the tourism sector, who, through their tireless work, creative energy and remarkable vision make the Salem area one of the best places on the planet to call home!â€ù said CEO of Travel Salem, Angie Morris, about the recipients of this award. â€œThey truly have demonstrated a commitment to creating the best of what Salem has to offer, helping strengthen community and building the travel industry in powerful ways!â€ù

â€¢ A.C. Gilbertâ€™s Discovery Village. Join Bubble Girl for some summer fun and pick up the summer camp guides for day camps for ages 3-12 at A.C. Gilbertâ€™s Discovery Village. Take time to smell the roses! Support the childrenâ€™s museum by purchasing a ticket to their 16th Annual Garden Tour featuring eight fabulous gardens in Keizer on June 3rd and 4th. â€¢ Adelman Peony Gardens. Come enjoy a glorious display of bursting peonies in vibrant colors and wonderful shapes! Free catalogs. Door prizes.
â€¢ Into The Wild Equine Adventures. A special four-legged equine guest will be here to promote their horseback riding pre-season special (Buy one ride package, get a companionâ€™s package free) which runs through June 30th.
â€¢ Riverview Community Bank. Founded on a desire to see success in our community, Riverview has been providing sound financial support for more than 86 years. Come find out more about our local Aumsville branch.
â€¢ Wavra Farms & Nursery. Come see their gorgeous planted container pots, hanging baskets, sedum pots, herb pots, and gift shop items on sale to brighten up your home and patio!
â€¢ Willamette Heritage Center at The Mill. Gear up for an exciting summer for the entire family and out-of-town guests. Come experience our exhibits, summer day camps and our newest event, Rhythm at the Mill. Enjoy 14 historic buildings, stroll along the mill race and snack on a picnic sitting on our grassy lawn. While youâ€™re here, donâ€™t forget to stop in at Danner & Soli and Mission Mill CafÃ©. Summer is for making memories! Come make some with us!
â€¢ Willamette Valley Vineyards. Select award winning, sustainable wines will be poured. Join them on June 19th for their Father's Day Concert, BBQ and Wine Club Pick Up Party.
â€¢ World Beat Festival. Showcasing dancers from Sisters of the Desert Moon, Romance, a Mexican bolero band, and more to promote the upcoming festival! New York-based Pistolera will headline the 14th annual Salem World Beat Festival June 25 and 26 at Salemâ€™s Riverfront Park. Come check it out!

column4: Travel Salem Named Top 100 Best Green Companies to Work For in Oregon
column5:
Travel Salem has been selected as a â€œTop 100 Best Green Companies to Work For in Oregonâ€ù by Oregon Business magazine. The rankings were unveiled at a luncheon held at the Hilton Portland & Executive Tower on Wednesday, May 25, 2011. Travel Salem was one of only five Salem area businesses recognized and the organizationâ€™s ranking went up significantly from 80th last year to 54th this year.

â€œWe are committed to maintaining a â€˜green companyâ€™ and are thrilled to be counted as one of Oregonâ€™s most sustainable organizations,â€ù said Angie Morris, CEO of Travel Salem. â€œWeâ€™re also pleased about the substantial progress weâ€™ve made over last year in dramatically improving our ranking to 54th on this prestigious list. Sustainability is not only a philosophy, but it has become a way of doing business because â€˜greenâ€™ business practices matter to our customers.â€ù

Travel Salemâ€™s â€œGreen Team,â€ù a group of employees charged with making the workplace more sustainable, led the way in developing an eco-savvy culture with buy-in to sustainable practices. Travel Salem is certified EarthWISE through Marion Countyâ€™s business environmental assistance program, incorporating sustainable practices in the business such as recycling, reducing waste and saving energy. Travel Salemâ€™s Travel CafÃ© and administrative office was designed with sustainability in mind: using recycled and earth-friendly materials and features that allow for generous natural light, among other things. Two years ago, the Travel CafÃ© received an award for â€œGreen Building Retrofit of the Yearâ€ù at the 2010 Mid-Willamette Valley Green Awards.

The 100 Best Green Companies in 2011 were selected based on Sustainable Practices sections in both employee and employer surveys completed last year by nearly 19,000 employees from 415 for-profit companies and nonprofit organizations.  The 100 Best Green Companies survey was incorporated into the 100 Best Companies and 100 Best Nonprofits surveys.

The â€œ100 Best Green Companies to Work For in Oregonâ€ù is featured in the June â€œGreen Issueâ€ù of Oregon Business magazine, which is now available for purchase.

column4: Local Tourism Industry Experiences 6.6 Percent Increase in Travel Spending
column5:
Tourism is big business for the Salem area and a vital economic generator. A recently-released study, Economic Impacts of Travel prepared by market research firm Dean Runyan Associates, reports that travel spending in the Salem area grew 6.6 percent over the previous year to $496 million in 2010.

Tourism-related businesses in the Salem area employed 6,260 people in 2010. Employees and business owners who worked in travel related businesses earned $132.7 million. Travelers to the Salem area contributed $2.5 million in tax revenue and $13.9 million in state revenue.

â€œTourism is a major economic driver in the Salem area,â€ù said President & CEO Angie Morris, Travel Salem. â€œVisitors enjoy our region and contribute millions of dollars to our economy and this in turn creates jobs. Travel Salem continues to strategically position the Salem area as a premier destination, bringing in new dollars that support local economies and small businesses throughout the region.â€ù

Salem Area Travel Impacts (Marion & Polk Counties)
Accommodations - $49.1 million
Food Service - $112.9 million
Food Stores- $47.8 million
Local Transportation & Gas - $46 million
Arts, Entertainment & Recreation- $126.8 million
Retail Sales -$55.5 million
*Other Travel - $57.8 million

*outbound travel services and transportation

  • Back to newsletter

column4: Travel Salem Marketing Exchange Luncheon -- July 21, 2011
column5:
Travel Salem Marketing Exchange Luncheon

featuring

Bonnie Stephenson
Stephenson Consulting

Sponsored by Garten Services, Inc.

Thursday, July 21, 2011
11:45 a.m. - 1:15 p.m.

Orchard Heights Winery
6057 Orchard Heights Rd. NW, Salem

Member testimonial: "Thank you for all that you did! The LivePostcardâ€™s were a hit. We all had a great time [at the May Marketing Exchange/Absolutely Fabulous Awards Luncheon]." -Chelsey Reid, Woodburn Company Stores

Come listen as engaging public speaker, Bonnie Stephenson, shares heart-felt and funny antidotes and life lessons from a recent trip to Guatemala along with a powerful multi-media presentation: â€œComing Full Circle with Myself.â€ù Her presentation will infuse you with a renewed sense of personal empowerment you can apply on both a business and personal level. The backdrop for this event will be the lush vineyard of Orchard Heights Winery. Call now to reserve your seat!

Keynote Speaker: Bonnie is a dynamic, funny and passionate international public speaker and consultant. Bonnie holds a degree in marketing and has worked as a project manager with Chemeketa Community College for the past 11 years. Prior to her work with Chemeketa, Bonnie was a highly sought-after speaker in Oregon for over 10 years. As a way of supporting the local economy and helping boost tourism, Bonnie hosted a television program segment called "Welcome Home." She has also been featured in countless television commercials, and worked as an on-air personality and voice-over talent.

Promote Your Business: This is your opportunity to promote your business and services! Remember to bring your business cards and brochures for the Marketing Exchange table.

Enter-to-Win! -- Cold Stone Creamery is giving away 5 - $20 â€œOffice Ice Cream Partyâ€ù gift certificates. Be sure to enter your business card for a chance to be one of the lucky recipients. Guests must be present to win.

RSVPs and prepayment of $18 required / $23 at the door RSVP a must!

Reserve Your Seat Today -- Save $5 with advanced registration if purchased by July 18th!
-- Online - use your credit card at TravelSalem.com
-- Phone - use your credit card by calling 503-581-4325 ext. 58
-- Mail - send your check to: Travel Salem Marketing Exchange Luncheon, 181 High St. NE, Salem, OR 97301

Please remember that when we receive your RSVP, we will order and pay for your lunch. If you are unable to attend, payment for lunch is still required. Thanks for helping to make Travel Salem luncheons a success.

See you on July 21, 2011!

column4: Salem to Host Second Largest Tandem Bike Rally in the U.S.
column5:
A group of passionate Salem-area tandem riders have recently announced that next year (2012), Salem will host the 27th Annual Northwest Tandem Rally, the second largest tandem rally in the U.S. A few weeks ago Travel Salemâ€™s Director of Sales, Debbie McCune, attended the Spokane Tandem Rally to pre-promote the Salem Rally. More than 600 tandem cyclists pedaled through Spokane, Washington on the Fourth of July weekend at this yearâ€™s Northwest rally and Travel Salem was there to promote Salem and encourage cyclists to attend the 2012 event.

The 2012 event will take place June 29th through July 2nd on cycling routes throughout the Salem region. The organizer of the rally is Salem NWTR 2010 LLC, a group of about 14 dedicated tandem cyclists living in the Salem area. Salem NWTR will partner with The Grand Hotel in Salem and Willamette University for food services and accommodations.

One of the organizers, Kurt Haas, who races with local Capitol Velo Racing Club, says the group is busy planning routes and locations for events. Eventually they will welcome volunteers and sponsors for the rally.

The mission of the 2012 Northwest Tandem Rally; is to share the Wonders of the Willamette (WOW) Valley â€“ its hospitality, history, and scenic bicycle routes â€“ with tandem families and friends from the Northwest and across the US and beyond â€“ all at an affordable price.

â€œOur goal is to involve community in the ride as much as possible,â€ù he said, â€œto benefit the riders along with the Willamette Valley, the economy, local businesses and community relationships.â€ù

He says some of the routes will have stops at local businesses like E.Z. Orchards, Willamette Valley Fruit Company, Bauman Farm and others.

Tandem teams are generally well-educated, affluent, and fit, with participants ranging from 25-60 and frequently include families with their children. The majority of NWTR participants come from Oregon, Washington and Northern California, with representation from across the country and some venturing from as far away as Europe and Australia.

Organizers are excited about the energy the event will bring to the Salem area.

â€œMost people havenâ€™t seen 300 or 400 tandem bikes rolling down the road together; the rally really brings a buzz to the community,â€ù said Haas who rides tandem on a three-seated bike with his wife and seven-year old daughter. â€œMany of the tandem riders are couples and families. This is really a family-oriented activity!â€ù

For more information about the 2012 Salem NWTR, visit their website at www.nwtr.org/2012.

  • Back to newsletter

column4: Travel Salem Hosts Travel and Food Writers -- Members Add Personal Touch
column5:
On July 8th and 9th, Travel Salem hosted a handful of travel and food writers on a Familiarization (FAM) Tour through the Salem region. The hospitality and generosity of local businesses and organizations made the FAM tour a huge success.

Weâ€™d like to thank these businesses for contributing products for the writers welcome baskets: Willamette Valley Fruit Company, Smokinâ€™ Mikeâ€™s Seafood Delights, The Arbor, Grand Vines, Cherry Country Orchard and Chocolate Factory, S.L.A.B Soap and Fresh to You Produce & Garden Center.

Travel Salem would like thank the participating businesses for their partnership and share the following details of the FAM tour to enlighten others about the richness of our region. A handful of writers stayed at The Grand Hotel in Salem the first evening. The next day, the group started the morning taking a pedicab ride along the Salem Riverfront, with breakfast, tea and a tour led by Lois Cole at Historic Deepwood Estate. The writers met at the future site of the Oregon State Hospital Museum (opening April 2012) where they viewed artifacts of psychiatric medicine with local historian Hazel Patton and curator Kylie Pineâ€”special thanks to Jodie Jones, Deputy Director of the Oregon State Hospital Replacement Project. Locals Rebecca Maitland and historian John Ritter hosted the writers on a special â€œSalem Underground Tourâ€ù of downtown including a visit to a historic gold drop and a Disco Tech frozen in time.

Weâ€™d like to thank Karo Thom of Alcyone CafÃ© & Catering for donating delicious curried chicken salad and other European fare for the lunch at Willamette Valley Vineyards (WVV). Jim Bernau with WVV shared their world-class wine and dessert from their great restaurant. Next, we headed to the Radtke family business, Gilgamesh Brewing Company, who greeted the writers warmly at their brewery. Special thanks to Bryon Williams at Grand Cru Wine Tours who donated his time, transportation and expertise in wine pairing along with wine, pate and cheese to the event and John and Kevin Zielinski for a tour of E.Z. Orchards Farm Market and a taste of their amazing hard cider and fresh berry shortcake.

Weâ€™d like to also thank Chef Jeff Nizlek who prepared an unforgettable dinner at the Silver Grille in Silverton. A special thanks to Robin and Larry at the beautiful and secluded Elkhorn Valley Inn Bed and Breakfast for hosting the writers at an overnight stay and a delicious breakfast in the morning!

Brianne Bridges and Winemaker Jerry Murray from Van Duzer Vineyards greeted the writers and provided an amazing lunch. Jerry introduced his wines to the writers. We then met Ivy Hover at Left Coast Cellars, to enjoy a special barrel tasting with Winemaker Luke McCollom and enjoyed delicious appetizers from their cafe and then took a hike on one of the new trails around the vineyard.

â€œTravel Salem appreciates the generosity and integrity of the participating organizations and businesses, their flexibility and the way they epitomize whatâ€™s best about the hospitality industry," said Jenie Skoy, Travel Salemâ€™s PR Manager who organized the press trip. "The writers raved about the treatment they received in the Salem area and the exceptional hospitality by everyone they encountered. Travel Salemâ€™s partners have made an indelible mark and helped brand our region as a premier visitor destination."

  • Back to newsletter

column5: Discover the story of the Aurora Colony. Founded in 1856 by the dynamic Dr. William Keil and named for his eight year old daughter, Aurora Mills was Oregon's first and most successful Christian communal society lasting until 1883.

column4: The Confederated Tribes of the Grand Ronde
column5: Confederated Tribes of the Grand Ronde inhabited Oregon's inland valleys and parts of the coast for thousands of years before white settlers arrived. The Confederated Tribes are proud people of the Umpqua, Mollalla, Rogue River, Kalapuya , Chasta and many other Tribes.

column5: Frank Lloyd Wright's only building in Oregon. This inspirational mid-century modern house is a National Historic Site and state treasure. Guided tours every day by reservation. Walking paths, photo ops, interpretive signage, and youth treasure hunt all worth the stop.

column4: NEW OREGON WINE COUNTRY LICENSE PLATE TO BOLSTER TOURISM
column5:
WHAT: SB 442 was recently signed into law by Governor John Kitzhaber establishing the Wine Country specialty license plate, the first initiative of its kind in the nation.

Plates will be available for a $30 surcharge due at issuance and every two-year renewal. Wine Country plate proceeds will be directed to the Oregon Tourism Commission to support the promotion of Oregon as a travel & tourism destination, and will be distributed as follows: 50% to matching grants for wine & culinary tourism promotion 50% to regional tourism agencies throughout Oregon, based on an acreage formula of grapes in production

The bill was conceived and initiated by Travel Salem and co-sponsored by Senator Jackie Winters and Representative Kevin Cameron. The Oregon Winegrowers Association provided critical guidance and advocacy on behalf of the bill.

WHY: This â€œjobs billâ€ù was developed as an innovative marketing strategy to focus attention on Oregonâ€™s culinary scene, drive new tourism revenues to support economic growth across the state, and to galva-nize the tourism & wine industries. The Wine Country plate celebrates Oregonâ€™s rich agricultural re-sources and world-class culinary heritage, and serves as a moving â€œbillboardâ€ù promoting Oregonâ€™s status as an agri-tourism hotspot. The plate provides Oregonians with the opportunity to show their support for the tourism industry and contribute toward a healthy and vibrant tourism economy.

WHEN: At the earliest, plates will be available in January 2012.

RESOURCES:

column5:
Summer has arrived! The season of fun! Itâ€™s a great time to plan â€œstaycationsâ€ù close to home with family and friends: barefoot backyard BBQâ€™s, trolling on Detroit lake, live music at Salemâ€™s Riverfront Park or days spent wine tasting through our regionâ€™s vineyards. Iâ€™d love to suggest a wonderful itinerary for those seeking adventure close to home. Donâ€™t underestimate how relaxing a night away from home can be; book a room at the Grand Hotel in Salem where you can crawl into a perfect bed and not worry about making the bed when you wake. When the sun comes up, take a Salem Bicycle Taxi ride through Salemâ€™s Riverfront Park and over the Union Street Railroad Pedestrian & Bicycle Bridge. Ride it to Historic Deepwood Estate or the Bush House Museum to wander their gardens. For lunch, plan a picnic with supplies from a farm stand like E.Z. Orchards Farm Market: pints of blueberries, Italian olive oils, fine chocolates and a bottle of their champagne-like â€œHard Cidreâ€ù made from French apple varieties you might find in Northern France. Or order a dish of berry or peach shortcake with loads of whipped cream!

Pick up a pre-made picnic lunch created by Chef Karo Thom of Alcyone CafÃ© & Catering, who makes to-die-for curried chicken and golden raisin salad or a wrap with prosciutto and mint, order some smoked salmon from Smokinâ€™ Mikeâ€™s Seafood Delights and mini pies from Willamette Valley Fruit Company and drive to Van Duzer Vineyards where you can spread out a colorful tablecloth, buy a bottle of Winemaker Jerry Murrayâ€™s famous Pinot Gris and eat up! Bring along a kite, the Vineyard is situated in a special wind corridor, and when the breeze picks up, unfurl your kite into the sky to enjoy the same wind the raptors like to ride in the late afternoon. If youâ€™re in the mood to pair nature with wine, make a bee-line to Left Coast Cellars, to see beehives dotting the vineyard (wild bees theyâ€™ve collected from their native oak trees) and walk their newly-developed 9-mile trail system while you enjoy Winemaker Luke McCollomâ€™s own Pinot Noir and eat carrot cake with buttery frosting from their onsite cafe. Want to learn about the intricacies of pairing wine and food?  Invite a guest to your picnic: Byron Williams, owner of Grand Cru Wine Tours, is an expert on what wines to pair with local cheeses and dishes. Heâ€™ll bring the food and the wine alongâ€” you just pick the location!

Or head over to Willamette Valley Vineyards (WVV), order a dessert from their onsite restaurant and a bottle of delicious semi-sparkling Muscat-FrizzantÃ© (of the same requested for a special dinner hosted by former President Clinton) and sit on their veranda overlooking a Burgundy-esque valley of vineyards and farms below. If Gilgamesh Brewing Company is hosting one of their down-home brewing parties, leave WVV and follow the smell of sweet, yeasty hops to Gilgameshâ€™s wooded brewery in Turner where they make experimental brews like their springy, mint kolsch. If you want the best of whatâ€™s seasonal but donâ€™t want to do the foraging and cooking yourself, reserve a table at the Silver Grille in Silverton this month. Jeff Nizlek painstakingly prepares unforgettable dinners from scratch (he even makes his own salumi). Try his perfect summer salad of strawberries and candied hazelnuts or a chilled tomato soup thatâ€™s as sweet as candy. If youâ€™re not ready to go home yet, drive into the wilderness and stay at the secluded Elkhorn Valley Inn Bed and Breakfast where youâ€™ll feel like youâ€™ve left the world behind.

There is so much adventure right in our neck of the woods, it would be a shame if you drove right past! Plan your next adventure right in our greater Salem area! For ideas to create other  Staycation itineraries, visit Travel Salemâ€™s newly-refreshed website: www.TravelSalem.com.

~ Angie Morris, president and CEO of Travel Salem
*Originally printed in Statesman Journal, 7/31/11

If you havenâ€™t already met Travel Salemâ€™s Golden Pioneer, weâ€™d like to introduce you to our pal Sal, everybodyâ€™s favorite guy because he is part of Travel Salemâ€™s Golden Pioneer Giveaway, where visitors and folks in the community can win freebies if they log onto Travel Salemâ€™s Facebook page. People have to â€œguess where the Golden Pioneer is,â€ù in a kind of Whereâ€™s Waldo fashion or participate in other Travel Salem contests which change monthly.

Borrow Sal for the Day!

As members, you have the opportunity of taking Sal out for a day and using him to help promote your event or business or market your products!

Sal is open to creative suggestions! The skyâ€™s the limit, literally, as Sal has flown in a hot air balloon with Balloon Flying Service of Oregon! He made it to Ladiesâ€™ Night at Bentleyâ€™s Grill and went cycling at JoyRide Cycling Studio. He visited the pets at the Willamette Humane Society, helped at a rally at the State Capitol, worked as a referee at an athletic game to promote breast cancer awareness and was even on television helping promote A. C. Gilbertâ€™s Discovery Village.

Sal also hopes youâ€™ll consider giving away a prize, free tickets to your event or gift certificate that we can giveaway in connection with the Golden Pioneer Giveaway. Tell us what kind of promotion youâ€™d like to do. Would you like more BUZZ on your Facebook site? Would you like to give free coffee to the first 10 people who show up at your location at a certain time? Would you like to create a fun video to broadcast on Youtube of Sal at your event/business?

We encourage you to plan a â€œphoto shootâ€ù with our celebrity Sal. After you take fun photos, please send us the photos and captions that explain what Sal was up to. For more information contact Kathie Reeves at kreeves@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325 ext. 24.

column4: Travel Salem Launches an Interactive Online Map
column5:
Travel Salem recently launched a new Interactive Online Map, a media-rich tool on the TravelSalem.com website dedicated to promoting our beautiful region as a visitor destination. The Interactive Online Map (IOM) helps visitors plan their mid-Willamette Valley experience. Currently the map visually represents the regionâ€™s diverse cultural and heritage assets. Future phases will showcase culinary highlights, recreation hotspots, public gardens and more.

â€œTravel Salemâ€™s goal with implementation of this Interactive Online Map is to draw more attention and visitation to the Salem and mid-Willamette Valley area through illustrating and promoting the rich and diverse offerings of our area,â€ù said Kathie Reeves, marketing manager for Travel Salem.

The IOM is also a great tool to help local residents learn more about attractions in their  backyard and is a great resource to employ when planning trips for visiting friends and family.

column4: Local Heroes â€œShow upâ€ù for a Good Cause
column5:
When we remember those who gave their lives in the aftermath of the September 11th Attacks, our hearts go out to people in public service industries who â€œshow-upâ€ù everyday and work to make our community better: law enforcement, firefighters, nurses, school teachers and everyone who devotes their life to serving others. Salem wants to pay tribute to some of these people in our region who champion extraordinary causes.

Meet local hero Tammi Burns whose mission is to help people â€œbreak the chainâ€ù of domestic abuse. She created the Break the Chain Apparel line that carries empowering messages: â€œMake a Stand against an Angry Hand,â€ù or â€œItâ€™s Not Love if Thereâ€™s Fear.â€ù The stylish apparel is especially popular with teenagers and Burns regularly travels to public schools to spread the word about abuse prevention, giving students a forum for expression as they create designs that find their way onto her apparel. Her work in the schools is part of her non-profit arm called Project Change Reaction. www.breakthechainapparel.com

Last Wednesday, hundreds of friendly red-shirted locals wielding paper plates descended on downtown Salem. You may have caught a glimpse of them lining Court and Liberty streets for a â€œstand-inâ€ù for Women Ending Hunger (WEH). They held plates with handwritten messages like: â€œEnd Hungerâ€ù and â€œNo Empty Bellies,â€ù these plates represented 46,000 children who depend on free or reduced lunch at public school (9,000 more than last year) in Marion and Polk counties. Project manager for WEH, Kat Daniel, and a group of volunteers came up with the idea to create awareness that â€œthere are a lot of kids right here that need local food assistance,â€ù said Daniels.

Local resident Kris Knox initiated and organized The Linda L. Vladyka Breast Wellness Foundationâ€™s Play for a Cure, a softball tournament that began 10 years ago between 15 teams at a softball field on a rainy day in Newberg. Today it has grown to become the largest co-ed softball tournament in Oregon with 40 teams competing. She started the games (named for her mother) when her Mom was battling breast cancer because she wanted her Mom and others in her situation â€“ who couldnâ€™t meet the physical demands of a walk or run â€“ to be able to participate in an event.

Last year, the group raised $42,500 â€“ of which $25,000 went to the Susan G. Komen Foundation; $15,000 to the Salem Hospital Foundation for emergency financial aid for chemo patients; and $2,500 to the Salem YWCA for a mammogram screening program.

That annual tournament is the nexus of many inspirational stories: from the cancer survivors who throw out the first pitch from a wheelchair to the motivation behind the teams who band together to raise funds to honor their family and friends battling cancer.

September 11 will be the last day to wander through the haunting, but beautiful Patriotâ€™s Day Memorial the â€œField of Flagsâ€ù at Salemâ€™s Riverfront Park to honor victims of the September 11th Attacks and those servicemen and women who made the ultimate sacrifice in Afganistan and Iraqi conflicts. Go by today to see more than 5,000  flags and banners, or during the solitude of the evening when they are illuminated by a flood light against the dark sky. The event is sponsored by the Exchange Clubs of Salem. www.patriotsdaymemorial.com

But remember, itâ€™s not just grand efforts that â€œa hero makes,â€ù just â€œshowing upâ€ù day after day and doing your part can make all the difference!

~ Angie Morris, president and CEO of Travel Salem
*Originally printed in Statesman Journal, 9/11/11

  • Back to newsletter

column4: Oregon Days of Culture 2011: Register (also, maybe win $1,000)
column5:
Oregon Days of Culture
October 1 -8, 2011

In 2010, 65 Oregon cities and towns hosted 599 Days of Culture events: film screenings, live performances, tours, exhibits, readings, lectures, dinners, community gatherings, volunteer activities, and family events. From October 1st to 8th, Oregon communities converged across the state, from Ashland to Portland to Pendleton, from Eugene to Bend to Burns.
 
Register your 2011 events now. Registration is simple.
 
Your event page will link to your own website, ticket buying and donation pages.  We especially encourage the posting of free events:  free admission to museums, free author readings, free open rehearsals, free talks or tours.
 
Here's how to get started:

  1. Go to www.oregondaysofculture.org.
  2. Scroll to the bottom of the home page and click either Register to add an event OR Login under Add your event. Hint: You'll want to click on Login if you submitted an event last year.
  3. Follow the instructions and voilÃ , your event(s) will be published to the site in less than 24 hours.

This is Culture: 2011 Photo Content
 
For the first time, this year Days of Culture will feature a statewide photo contest. Prizes include fancy cameras, cash, and gifts from sponsors. And get this: We'll give two winners $1,000 each to donate to the cultural nonprofit of their choice. Which could be yours, right?
 
So get listing! The Oregon Cultural Trust is looking forward to the biggest Days of Culture celebration yet.
 
Any questions? Contact Kimberly Howard with the Oregon Cultural Trust at 503-986-0089 or kimberly.howard@state.or.us.

  • Back to newsletter
column6:
Oregon Days of Culture
October 1 -8, 2011

In 2010, 65 Oregon cities and towns hosted 599 Days of Culture events: film screenings, live performances, tours, exhibits, readings, lectures, dinners, community gatherings, volunteer activities, and family events. From October 1st to 8th, Oregon communities converged across the state, from Ashland to Portland to Pendleton, from Eugene to Bend to Burns.

column4: TRAVEL SALEM RANKED #10 ON THE LIST OF 100 BEST NONPROFITS TO WORK FOR IN OREGON
column5:
Travel Salem has been ranked tenth on Oregon Business magazineâ€™s â€œ100 Best Nonprofit to Work For in Oregonâ€ù list. The ranking is determined by employee questionnaires and an independent assessment. Travel Salem was one of only nine Salem businesses recognized and the organization aggressively climbed the rankings from 24th last year to 10th  this year.

Nearly 5,500 employees from 170 nonprofits and not-for-profits statewide participated in this yearâ€™s survey developed by Oregon Business editor Brandon Sawyer along with research partner DHM Research and the Nonprofit Association of Oregon. Oregon Business launched this project to recognize nonprofits as key businesses critical to the economic health of the state.

Nonprofit employees who responded this year commented that they valued a work environment of trust, professionalism and care, along with opportunities for training, support and career advancement. Flexible schedules, teamwork and taking time to have fun were noted in the surveys as key components to a great workplace.

â€œTravel Salem has been my professional home for eight years. My first role was as an intern and over the years I have been challenged and allowed the chance to try new roles. The director team is supportive of the staff putting our families first, which means more than can be expressed. We are a close-knit group who celebrates our individual and team successes in a supportive environment where you can freely suggest new ideas. I am thrilled to be a part of such a great team of exceptional people!â€ù said Kathie Reeves, marketing manager at Travel Salem.

The â€œ100 Best Nonprofits to Work for in Oregonâ€ù is featured in the October issue of Oregon Business magazine, which is now available for purchase.

Thereâ€™s light on the horizon! Itâ€™s been a dark few years across the board for individuals, business and our industry, but hope is on the horizon for the tourism industry, according to new research recently released. Our â€œState of the Industryâ€ù presentation will highlight the highs and lows of the past year and share promising news, results and trends about the travel and tourism industryâ€™s progress.

Be sure to attend Novemberâ€™s Travel Salem Marketing Exchange Luncheon to learn ways to think differently about your business, stay ahead of the curve, and cooperatively make a difference for you, your business and your community!

Call now to reserve your seat!

Keynote Speaker:
Kevin Wright
As Director of Consumer Marketing for Travel Oregon, Wright leads the agencyâ€™s domestic consumer marketing and communications programs. He supervises Travel Oregonâ€™s advertising campaigns, publications, media relations, website and interactive programs, special promotions and projects, and fulfillment. Wright joined Travel Oregon in 2005 as Manager of International and Domestic Travel Trade Marketing. Before moving to Oregon, Wrightâ€™s career included ten years of marketing experience in the Colorado ski industry where he also served as Marketing Specialist for the Colorado Tourism Office and the Colorado Film Commission. He is a 1995 graduate of Plymouth State College, New Hampshire, with a bachelor's degree in Marketing.

column4: Funding for Building Improvements in Downtownâ€™s Core Area Available!
column5:
Program designed to:

  • Serve as a catalyst and showcase for revitalization and redevelopment
  • Increase retail vitality and density
  • Attract new and/or existing businesses to the downtown core

Open House to learn more about the program:
November 9, 2011
8 a.m. - 9:30 a.m.  and 5 p.m. - 6:30 p.m.
Salem Urban Development Department
350 Commercial Street, NE

Program overview:
It is the intent of this program to enhance the character and identity of a proposed impact area. There are opportunities to enhance storefronts and buildings so they create interest and draw people to the area. These investments should be attractive to consumers, perhaps enhancing outdoor and sidewalk use for consumers or adding creative amenities that stimulate consumer engagement in the area. By offering funding for multiple properties/projects in a targeted area, the program aims to create an immediate and visible impact, resulting in a more marketable retail, office, and housing environment.

For more information, including program criteria:

  • Visit www.cityofsalem.net/RiverfrontDowntownURA
  • Contact Project Manager, Annie Gorski at 503-588-6178 or agorski@cityofsalem.net

column4: Travel Salemâ€™s PR is reaching new heights!
column5:
During the first four months of fiscal year 2011-12 Travel Salemâ€™s PR efforts have secured $1.2 million in earned media coverage (a.k.a. media leverage), already exceeding the earned media secured over FY 2010-11. In FY 2010-11 Travel Salemâ€™s earned media was up 63 percent over FY 2009-10. Some of the successful media pitches that Travel Salem secured included coverage of the Salem region in the travel section of The NY Times; a prime-time broadcast on the Food Network (Outrageous Food); Oregon broadcast on Grantâ€™s Getaways; in Womanâ€™s World, NW Palate, 1895 magazine, Sunset, The Seattle Times, and The Bulletin (Bend) among many others.

Travel Salem hosted press trips for foreign and domestic writers, including as far away as Korea and pitched hundred of story ideas to both travel and industry publications.

Travel Salem would like to thank all of the many partners involved in the press trips and for the products contributed to host these successful promotions! We will continue to aggressively promote our region so keep the amazing story ideas flowing our way.

column4: 5 ways to warm up on a fall day
column5:
The air is cool, fog rolls in, and the leaves begin dressing in fantastic colors. It's that time of year again when we slow down and wander in search of warm places to settle into. Travel Salem wants to help you up your coziness quotient this time of year, so here's a few ideas to help you do just that.

  1. Sip Soup. Try one of the fresh stewed soups at Willamette Noodle Co., including tomato basil, sausage and red pepper or creamy carrot. Or, if you're in a mood to socialize, order a bowl from the bar at Wild Pear Restaurant, where you're sure to strike up a conversation with another happy soup sipper. Try anything with chicken broth and spice or their signature coconut curry squash accompanied soup with bread baked fresh daily from dough ordered from a famous San Francisco bakery.
  2. Gaze at Art. Next, walk to bug heaven, Pheromone Gallery, to see wonders of the natural world fashioned in artistic ways by artist Christopher Marley. Check out Solar Ellipse, Southern American butterflies arranged in a winged circle that resemble a lemon and apricot-colored flower in bloom. Or create your own artwork. Paint a ceramic platter or fuse color and heat together by making a vibrant glass trivet or lamp shade at the Create a Memory studio. Or stop in at Greenbaum's Quilted Forest to buy fabric to quilt or sew with; just walking into the store is a feel-good experience, you'll be enveloped in quilts that hang from the ceiling and walls.
  3. Indulge in wine and chocolate. On Friday nights, head over to Grand Vines to listen to sultry jazz and sip Oregon port between sampling chocolates in exotic flavors such as currant and East African spices, salty caramel, black cherry pinot, chili, coconut, toasted hazelnut and guinness. On a cold day, try the truffle-flavored hot buttered rum. Swing by Travel Salem's Travel CafÃ© for a wine tasting and to view the framed pastel artwork that inspired the upcoming Oregon Wine Country License Plate. Buy a raffle ticket for $5 and enter to win the work of art.
  4. Swig cider. Take a toasty seat beside the coffee bean roaster inside The Governor's Cup Coffee Roasters. Order a whipped cream-covered latte with pumpkin spice or a steaming cup of fresh-pressed hot cider from E.Z. Orchards, available in caramel through Christmas.
  5. Get pampered. Slip into a robe that's as soft as a cloud, warm up in a sauna then finish with a deep-tissue massage from Today's Hair Salon and Spa in West Salem. Or for a quick relaxation treatment, spend 10 minutes in an Aqua Massage machine at Hydro Zen, a new business on Court Street where you lay face down and feel water pressure massage you from head to toe (and stay dry and clothed in the process).

To see images from Travel Salem's cool weather, warm-up stops in Salem, go to Travel Salem's Facebook page at www.facebook.com/TravelSalem.

~ Angie Morris, president and CEO of Travel Salem
*Originally printed in Statesman Journal, 10/23/11

column4: "Winter Party Planning" -- December First Wednesday at Travel Salem
column5:
Everybody loves a party! At Travel Salemâ€™s Travel CafÃ© we are kicking off the holiday spirit at the December 7th First Wednesday with ideas to help you party your way through 2012. Visitors to the Travel CafÃ© will enjoy delicious treats from Trader Joeâ€™s; Evergreen Aviation & Space Museum will be showcasing their museum, IMAX and Wings and Waves Water Park with a special raffle; The Lodge at Detroit Lake is offering holiday special discounts; Chemeketa Center for Business and Industry will be on hand to share all the details regarding their state-of-the- art facility; and Willamette Valley Vineyards will be pouring their spectacular wines.

  • Chemeketa Center for Business and Industry (CCBI): CCBI representatives will be on hand to share the resources available to small business at their state-of-the-art facility (626 High St. NE) as well as their Bank of the Cascades, EDGE Business Incubator program. www.ccbi.chemeketa.edu
  • Evergreen Aviation & Space Museum: Evergreen will be revealing all of the fun and educational amenities of their campus including: the Aviation and Space Museums, IMAX and the Wings and Waves Water Park. Evergreen has festive events for the holidays and they will be raffling Museum tickets and have coupons for the water park. www.evergreenmuseum.org
  • The Lodge at Detroit Lake: The Lodge at Detroit Lake will be offering special holiday pricing ending December 14, 2011 at midnight. Promo code: TS1stWED. â€œCome and stay at our beautifully rebuilt hotel!!" www.lodgeatdetroitlake.com
  • Trader Joeâ€™s: They will have a delicious array of wonderful treats and sparkling juices. Just perfect to serve at your next party. www.traderjoes.com
  • Willamette Valley Vineyards: Come sip award-winning, sustainable wines! www.wvv.com

Contribute to Travel Salem's "Absolutely Giving Back" program by dropping off a canned and non-perishable food item.

column4: Don't Miss the 2012 Salem Area Visitor Guide
column5:
Display advertising sales for the Salem Area Visitor Guide have begun. The Salem Area Visitor Guide is the official visitor guide and resource for visitors to the Salem and mid-Willamette Valley. The guide is distributed to 800 locations throughout Oregon, Washington, California and British Columbia and serves as the response piece to all Salem inquiries generated through Travel Salemâ€™s advertising, public relations and consumer engagement strategies.

column4: Looking for the Best in Oregon -- Itâ€™s time to â€˜Be Sceneâ€™ as an Award Winner!
column5:
The Oregon Festivals and Events Association is accepting nominations for its annual Ovation Awards recognizing the â€œBestâ€ù in festivals, fairs and events celebrated in Oregon during 2011.

Itâ€™s incredibly easy to nominate your favorite community event. Just go to the Associationâ€™s website at www.oregonfestivals.org and click on â€˜Ovations Nominationsâ€™. There are lots of categories. Select the category that fits your community event, fill out the form and, with the supporting documentation, send it to the association by the January 16 deadline.

Winners will be notified and asked to join association members for THE Conference for Festivals and Events awards presentation at Hilton Hotel in Eugene, March 6, 2012. â€˜Be Scene in Eugeneâ€™ (itâ€™s a Hollywood theme). This is Oregonâ€™s own festivals and events convention â€“ educational sessions, trade show, entertainment showcase, keynote presentations, speakers and lots of networking opportunities. Applications for the conference are available online. Visit the OFEA website at www.oregonfestivals.org or call Scott Ingalls at 866-904-6165 for all the details on Ovation Awards and the conference.

column4: Nominations Being Accepted For 2011 Oregon Tourism Industry Achievement Awards
column5:
2011 will be remembered as a year of extraordinary achievements by those in Oregon's tourism and hospitality industry. On Sunday, March 18, the best of the industry's best will be saluted by their peers at the 2012 Oregon Governor's Conference on Tourism in Portland.

Everyone works with someone who rises above the challenges of the day to achieve outstanding results. Those folks are deserving of special recognition from their tourism and hospitality industry peers. But it will take YOUR NOMINATION to make that happen!

To view the seven award descriptions and eligibility standards, click here. 

To download each award's official nomination form, click on the award's link below:

  • Gene Leo Memorial Award
  • International Marketing Development Award
  • Oregon Heritage Tourism Award
  • Oregon Sustainable Tourism Leadership Award
  • Oregon Tourism & Hospitality Exceptional Partnership Award
  • Oregon Tourism Development Award
  • Outstanding Oregon Tourism Volunteer Award

DEADLINE FOR NOMINATIONS: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 1, 2012
Nominations must be received at Travel Oregon no later than noon on that date.

Direct any questions about the nomination process to: Patti@TravelOregon.com 

********************************

Register NOW to attend the 2012 Oregon Governor's Conference on Tourism which is being held in Portland at the Red Lion Hotel on the River - Jantzen Beach, March 18-20.

Visit www.OregonTourismConference.com for all of the most up-to-date conference information.

Innovation is Markâ€™s middle name and bringing attention to your business is his game. You wonâ€™t want to miss his presentation.

MARK LONDON
Mark London has been working as an Account Executive for Digital Marketing for the last six years. He plays a key role in developing and maintaining strong relationships with clients. Mark has a consultative approach to understanding a clientâ€™s unique requirements. He has worked with a variety of clients on their email marketing campaigns. Some of the clients include Travel Salem, Trader Joeâ€™s, National Psoriasis Foundation, Velotech and Made in Oregon. Mark graduated from the University of Oregon in communications.
 
Promote Your Business: This is your opportunity to promote your business and services! Remember to bring your business cards and brochures for the Marketing Exchange table.

column4: Photo Call Out for New Salem Area Visitors Guide
column5:
Travel Salem is working on the 2012-13 Salem Area Visitors Guide and would like to see your photos! If you have high quality (300+ dpi) images they will be considered for inclusion in the new guide as well as TravelSalem.com.

We will consider the following shots within Salem, Marion County and Polk County: scenic & natural beauty, attractions & points of interests, wineries/wine tasting, shopping, dining, events, performances, architecture, crops, farms, gardens, downtown (skylines & specific buildings), lodging, cycling, galleries, recreation, children activities, and people enjoying the area in general.

If you think you have a great photo(s) please send it electronically to Irene Bernards, Marketing & PR Director at ibernards@TravelSalem.com by February 8, 2012. Please be sure that you have the rights to use the image(s) for publication and relay that in your email.

If you have any questions please contact Irene directly, ibernards@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325 ext. 27.

All visitors that take the survey will be entered into a prize drawing for a Salem area travel package. All employees asking visitors to complete the survey will also be entered into a prize drawing. Both prize drawings will take place in November 2012. The more surveys turned into Travel Salem, the greater chance for your employees to win.

If you would like to help Travel Salem with this survey project please contact Irene Bernards, Marketing & PR Director at ibernards@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325 ext. 27.

Featuring

Keynote Speaker: Angie Morris, Travel Salem

State of the Industry â€“ Boldly going where no DMO has gone before

March 15, 2012
11:45 a.m. â€“ 1:15 p.m.

Willamette Heritage Center at The Mill
1313 Mill Street SE, Salem

Call 503-581-4325 ext. 58 now to reserve your seat!

Sponsored by:

Travel Salemâ€™s CEO Angie Morris will be presenting Travel Salemâ€™s Annual Report outlining the successes of the last year and future marketing strategies to propel the region into the future. The rating for this presentation is â€œEâ€ù for everyone. Every unbridled idea is on the table so be sure to attend!

Call 503-581-4325 ext. 58 now to reserve your seat!

Keynote Speaker:
Angie Morris
Angie Morris was hired as the Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of Travel Salem in February 2007 after a nationwide search. Angieâ€™s high caliber of creative marketing skills coupled with her nonprofit administration, management and leadership skills, as well as her knowledge and ties to Salem made her the ideal CEO for Travel Salem.

During her tenure with Travel Salem Angie has reinvented the organization through pioneering and creative marketing, relationship development and innovation. Examples include Travel Salemâ€™s customized membership program, built to suit the diverse needs of businesses; the award-winning Travel CafÃ© Visitors Center, created through fundraising and collaborative partnerships; the creation of the nationâ€™s first Wine Country specialty license plate, that will serve as a rolling billboard for the region while generating revenue for the tourism industry; and the formation of Cultivating Communities, a foundation based on tourism education and awareness.

Angieâ€™s professional history includes serving as the Executive Director for Pentacle Theatre, and working for the Portland Opera Broadway Across America series as their Director of Marketing and Public Relations managing a $1.5 million annual budget, generating $9-12 million in ticket sales annually.

Promote Your Business: This is your opportunity to promote your business and services! Remember to bring your business cards and brochures for the Marketing Exchange table.

Enter-to-Win! â€“ A gift basket filled with goodies, art and a gift certificate from Magic Tek. Be sure to enter your business card for a chance to be the lucky recipient. Must be present to win.

RSVPs and prepayment of $18 required / $23 at the door RSVP a must!

Reserve Your Seat Today
Save $5 with advanced registration if purchased by March 12th!

-- Online - use your credit card at TravelSalem.com
-- Phone - use your credit card by calling 503-581-4325, ext. 58
-- Mail - send your check to: Travel Salem Marketing Exchange Luncheon, 181 High St. NE, Salem, OR 97301

Please remember that when we receive your RSVP, we will order and pay for your lunch. If you are unable to attend, payment for lunch is still required. Thanks for helping to make Travel Salem luncheons a success.

See you on March 15, 2012!

column5:
Travel Salem is currently collecting travel packages and deals. Submitted travel packages and deals will be:

  • Posted on TraveSalem.com and included in Travel Salem's Quarterly Consumer E-Newsletter, which is distributed to consumers that are interested in keeping up to date on what is happening in the Salem area. (Only applies to businesses that have selected the "Travel Packages" marketing option.)
  • Posted to TravelOregon.com where the packages are promoted with Travel Oregonâ€™s seasonal travel campaigns. The upcoming campaign is Oregon Adventurecation focusing on outdoor recreation which will be marketed nation-wide.

We have created an easy to use online form for submitting your information. Please visit the following link to submit your travel packages and deals:  http://www.travelsalem.com/Members/Member-Links/member-forms/travel-packages-specials.

Also, if you currently have a travel package or deal on our website, please take a moment to review existing travel packages and deals. If you have changes to an existing travel package or deal, please email Kathie Reeves, Travel Salem's Marketing Manager at kreeves@TravelSalem.com.

We appreciate your participation in this Travel Salem marketing option and in providing great vacation opportunities to our Salem area visitors!

column4: Salem Will Host 2013 Oregon Governorâ€™s Conference on Tourism
column5:
Oregonâ€™s Premier Gathering for Tourism Professionals

Salem will be the host of the 2013 Oregon Governorâ€™s Conference on Tourism, April 14-16, 2013. As Oregonâ€™s premier gathering for tourism professionals, the annual conference attracts more than 400 attendees for two and a half days of educational seminars, networking, and to develop new ways to create the best Oregon Experience possible for visitors and the industry.

Travel Salem, in partnership with the Salem Conference Center, responded to the Travel Oregon bid for a 2013 conference location. The Oregon Governorâ€™s Conference has been held in Salem one other time â€“ in 2009.

â€œTravel Salem is pleased to announce that the 2013 Oregon Governorâ€™s Conference will be held in Salem,â€ù said Debbie McCune, Travel Salemâ€™s Director of Sales. â€œThis is a great opportunity to showcase Salem and all of the wonderful offerings that make our city and region so attractive to leisure visitors, as well as meeting and event planners. Travel Salem will be working with many businesses and organization to ensure another successful and memorable conference,â€ù said McCune.

column4: AbsolutelyTix: Ticketing Outlet for Events or Tour Admissions
column5:
Your one-stop source for ticketing needs is AbsolutelyTix, a state-of-the-art network for Marion and Polk Counties. AbsolutelyTix allow consumers to easily purchase tickets at the Travel CafÃ© Visitors Center or online, and provides a single source of online information about upcoming local shows and events. 

More than 24 partners (and growing) â€” local arts organizations, non-profits, and other community organizations â€” have partnered with Travel Salem to sell tickets and transact other business over the Internet. Some partners include: Taste & See Salem food tours, Friends of the Grand Theatre, Willamette University Theatre, and Salem Film Festival. Tickets for events, theater performances, concerts and more from our AbsolutelyTix partners are available for purchase online and at the Travel Cafe (181 High St. NE, Salem). Visit AbsolutelyTix.com for a complete list of upcoming events, shows, and performances.

Those interested in partnering with Travel Salem to promote events and sell tickets through the AbsolutelyTix network should contact Barb Cowan at bcowan@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325, ext. 21.

column5:
If you havenâ€™t already met Travel Salemâ€™s Golden Pioneer, weâ€™d like to introduce you to our pal Sal, everybodyâ€™s favorite guy because he is part of Travel Salemâ€™s Golden Pioneer Giveaway, where visitors and folks in the community can win freebies if they log onto Travel Salemâ€™s Facebook page. People have to â€œguess where the Golden Pioneer is,â€ù in a kind of Whereâ€™s Waldo fashion or participate in other Travel Salem contests which change monthly.

Borrow Sal for the Day!

As members, you have the opportunity of taking Sal out for a day and using him to help promote your event or business or market your products!

Sal is open to creative suggestions! The skyâ€™s the limit, literally, as Sal has flown in a hot air balloon with Balloon Flying Service of Oregon! He made it to Ladiesâ€™ Night at Bentleyâ€™s Grill and went cycling at JoyRide Cycling Studio. He visited the pets at the Willamette Humane Society, helped at a rally at the State Capitol, worked as a referee at an athletic game to promote breast cancer awareness and was even on television helping promote A. C. Gilbertâ€™s Discovery Village.

Sal also hopes youâ€™ll consider giving away a prize, free tickets to your event or gift certificate that we can giveaway in connection with the Golden Pioneer Giveaway. Tell us what kind of promotion youâ€™d like to do. Would you like more BUZZ on your Facebook site? Would you like to give free coffee to the first 10 people who show up at your location at a certain time? Would you like to create a fun video to broadcast on Youtube of Sal at your event/business?

We encourage you to plan a â€œphoto shootâ€ù with our celebrity Sal. After you take fun photos, please send us the photos and captions that explain what Sal was up to. For more information contact Kathie Reeves at kreeves@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325 ext. 24.

column4: Travel Salemâ€™s First Wednesday Member Spotlight
column5:
Celebrate Mothers and Experience Local Products and Services

May 2 First Wednesday at Travel Salem will focus on Mothers and local products and services such as wine, food, flowers, handbags, specialty gifts and planting demonstrations. Travel Salemâ€™s Travel CafÃ© Visitors Center will be open until 8 p.m. on First Wednesday and is located at 181 High Street NE, Salem.

The following Travel Salem member businesses will be highlighted:

  • Adelman Peony Gardens will offer a drawing for 2 items:  a peony plant valued at $20 and a $20 gift certificate.
  • Alcyone CafÃ© & Catering will be pairing the following delicious appetizers:  Chicken curry salad on crostini - goes well with Pinot gris and Pinot noir.  Wild mushroom croissant puff - goes well with Pinot noir or other reds. Petite apple, sage, Swiss cheese scones - good with white wines, dry and off-dry.
  • Deb the Bag Lady will offer Motherâ€™s Day savings on all four Miche bundles:  Petite, Classic, Demi and Prima. New releases available now! Visit Travel Salem to enter a drawing for your very own Miche bag.
  • Left Coast Cellars is proud to feature their award-winning, estate-grown wines during Oregon Wine Month! Enjoy complimentary tastes of crisp 2011 The Orchards Pinot gris, creamy 2009 Truffle Hill Chardonnay, bright 1010 Rose of Pinot noir and luscious 2009 Caliâ€™s Cuvee Pinot noir. If you find something you like, bottles will be available for purchase.
  • Madrona Hills Ace Hardware will have a stunning array of gifts for Mom including plants.
  • Van Duzer Vineyards will feature their 2011 Rose, 2011 Estate Pinot gris, 2009 Estate Pinot noir and 2009 Dijon Block Pinot noir. Guests can enter to win a drawing for a tasting and picnic at Van Duzer. Included in the giveaway is a picnic basket, VDV logo wine glasses, lunch and tasting. The value is $185!
  • Willamette Humane Society will be welcoming guests to sign the â€œPaw it Forwardâ€ù pledge. Everyone who signs the pledge receives a WHS logo bracelet.
  • Willamette Valley Vineyards will offer complimentary wine tasting and 20% discount on bottles.

Contribute to Travel Salem's "Absolutely Giving Back" program by dropping off a non-perishable food item.

column4: Travel Salem's Annual Absolutely Fabulous Awards Luncheon
column5:
Thursday, May 17, 2012
11:45 a.m. â€“ 1:15 p.m.

Keizer Renaissance Inn
5188 Wittenberg Lane N
Keizer, OR 97303

Call 503-581-4325 ext. 58 now to reserve your seat!

Sponsored by:
Madrona Hills Ace Hardware
Salem Trophy

You won't want to miss the annual Travel Salem Absolutely Fabulous Awards Luncheon. Held during National Tourism Month, the "Ab Fab" Awards will recognize tourism industry partners who have gone above and beyond in 2011-12 to promote the Salem area. These award recipients are movers and shakers who have pushed the envelope and turned ideas upside-down and inside out to capture the best returns on their marketing, collaboration, partnerships, innovation and regional strategies! They are Absolutely Fabulous!

Todd Davidson, CEO of Travel Oregon and Chair of the U.S. Travel and Tourism Advisory Board will be the keynote speaker. Following President Barack Obama's Executive Order laying out a strategy for increasing international travel to the U.S., Secretary of Commerce John Bryson tapped Oregon Tourism Commission CEO Todd Davidson as chair of the U.S. Travel and Tourism Advisory Board to help implement the initiative.

Enjoy a fun-filled afternoon at Keizer Renaissance Inn while networking and celebrating National Tourism Month. The $495 million generated by visitors each year to the Salem area along with 6,260 direct jobs, is significant and worth commemorating!

Call 503-581-4325 ext. 58 now to reserve your seat!

Promote Your Business: Don't forget to bring your marketing materials (business cards and brochures) to the luncheon to promote your business and services! This is Travel Salem's annual event, so plan plenty of time to network.

Enter-to-Win! â€“ Into the Wild Equine Adventures will giveaway a Woodlands Escape Package for two (valued at $390), Madrona Hills Ace Hardware will provide a unique gift basket from their gift department, Adelman Peony Gardens will have a drawing for the colorful table centerpieces, and Amtrak will giveaway a ticket from Salem to Vancouver, BC (valued at $196). Be sure to enter your business card for a chance to be a winner. Guests must be present to win.

Reserve Your Seat Today
Save $5 with advanced registration if purchased by May 14th!

-- Online - use your credit card at www.TravelSalem.com
-- Phone - use your credit card by calling 503-581-4325, ext. 58
-- Mail - send your check to: Travel Salem Marketing Exchange Luncheon, 181 High St. NE, Salem, OR 97301

RSVPs and prepayment of $18 required / $23 at the door

Space is limited for this event. RSVP a must!

Please remember that when we receive your RSVP, we will order and pay for your lunch. If you are unable to attend, payment for lunch is still required. Thanks for helping to make Travel Salem luncheons a success.

YOU WILL WANT TO ADD TO YOUR BUSINESS SAVVY AND NETWORK BY ATTENDING THIS MARKETING EXCHANGE

See you on May 17, 2012!

Sponsored by:
Madrona Hills Ace Hardware
Salem Trophy

column4: Travel Salem Announces Recipients of Annual Absolutely Fabulous Awards
column5:
Travel Salem is proud to announce the recipients of the 2011-12 Absolutely Fabulous Awards presented at their May 17, 2012 Marketing Exchange luncheon.

The annual Ab Fab (Absolutely Fabulous) awards recognize people and organizations in the Salem area (including Marion & Polk counties) that have pushed the envelope and turned ideas upside-down and inside out to capture the best return on their marketing, collaboration, partnerships, innovation and regional strategies! They are Absolutely Fabulous!

The eight Travel Salem Ab Fab awards were presented to:

  • Dwane Brenneman â€“ Absolutely Dedicated Award
    For his dedication to Travel Salem and serving as the Associationâ€™s Chair 
  • BEST WESTERN PLUS Mill Creek Inn â€“ Absolutely 24/7 Award
    For serving as a Travel Plaza visitor information center for the Salem area
  • A.C. Gilbertâ€™s Discovery Village â€“ Absolutely Hands-On Award
    For their Hands-On approach to supporting childrenâ€™s education through fun; developing promotions that add to Salemâ€™s vibrant community and quality of life; and working in partnership to attract visitors to the community.
  • Jerry Lauzon â€“ Absolutely â€œOOM-PAPAâ€ù Award
    For his 20+ years as the Mt. Angel Oktoberfestâ€™s volunteer PR & Marketing Director and his ability to bring people together for the good of the community.
  • Lancaster Mall â€“ Absolutely Active Award
    For being active in the community and for the health of area residents (e.g. mall walkers program; serving as a visitor information location; tour & travel trade fair) 
  • World Beat Festival/Salem Multicultural Institute â€“ Absolutely Global Award
    For their tireless efforts to support all cultures and celebrate diversity.
  • Enchanted Forest â€“ Absolutely Inventive Award
    For 40+ years of innovation and outstanding creativity that has attracted millions of visitors to the area.
  • Nancy Stockdale â€“ Absolutely Fabulous Award
    For her entrepreneurial spirit; creative thinking and her support of Salemâ€™s cultural community.

Return to newsletter

column4: New 2012-13 Salem Area Visitors Guide Available
column5:
Travel Salem recently unveiled the official 2012-13 Salem Area Visitors Guide. This 65 page, full color visitors guide promotes Salem as well as Marion and Polk counties. Trip ideas, attractions and points of interest, lodging, dining, events, shopping, wineries, gardens, agri-tourism, transportation, recreation and relocation information resources are included along with tour ideas and stories.

â€œThe Salem Area Visitors Guide plays a vital role in promoting the area for leisure visitors as well as convention and event business,â€ù said Irene Bernards, Travel Salemâ€™s Marketing and PR Director. â€œWe distribute 140,000 guides to locations throughout Oregon and the twelve western states as well as Canada. Travel Salem is spreading the word that the Salem area is an authentic Oregon experience with culinary, heritage and cultural offerings and recreational opportunities,â€ù said Bernards.

Residents are encouraged to order a free Salem Area Visitors Guide by contacting the Travel Salem office at 503-581-4325 or information@TravelSalem.com or by visiting the Travel CafÃ© Visitors Center located in historic downtown Salem at 181 High Street NE.
