column4: New Oregon Wine Country License Plate Now Available
column5:
Oregonâ€™s Wine Country license plate is now available through the DMV. This wine country specialty license plate is the first of its kind in the nation. Plates are available from the DMV for an ongoing $30 surcharge due at issuance and every two-year renewal.

Wine Country plate proceeds will be directed to the Oregon Tourism Commission to support the promotion of Oregon as a travel & tourism destination, and will be distributed as follows:

  • 50% to matching grants for wine and culinary tourism promotion
  • 50% to regional tourism agencies throughout Oregon, based on an acreage formula of grapes in production

The bill was conceived and initiated by Travel Salem and co-sponsored by Senator Jackie Winters and Representative Kevin Cameron. The Oregon Winegrowers Association provided critical guidance and advocacy on behalf of the bill.

â€œThis marketing strategy is meant to focus attention on Oregonâ€™s culinary scene, drive new tourism revenues to support economic growth across the state, and to galvanize the tourism & wine industries,â€ù said Angie Morris, Travel Salemâ€™s CEO. â€œThe Wine Country plate celebrates Oregonâ€™s rich agricultural resources and world-class culinary heritage, and serves as a moving â€œbillboardâ€ù promoting Oregonâ€™s status as an agri-tourism hotspot. The plate provides Oregonians with the opportunity to show their support for the tourism industry and contribute toward a healthy and vibrant tourism economy.â€ù

  • Return to newsletter

column4: Salem Selected for 2013 BMW MOA Rally
column5:
Motorcycle event attracts 9,000 riders

The BMW Motorcycle Owners of America (MOA) has selected the Oregon State Fairgrounds in Salem, Oregon as the location for their 2013 International Rally. The event will be taking place July 18-20, 2013. â€œWeâ€™ve had some really great events in Oregon in the past years,â€ù explains BMW MOA president Greg Feeler. â€œOur Rally in Redmond in 2010 was one of our best ever. We are very excited about Salem next year!â€ù

In partnership with the Oregon Sate Fair and Expo Center, Travel Salem was instrumental in attracting the BMW MOA group to Salem. The Rally was initially bid on four years ago, and Travel Salem just recently hosted a two day tour for the rally event planners. The event has grown to average over 9,000 riders and offers its members a place to meet new people, as well as vendors who manufacture specialty motorcycle items. Event attendees can also test ride new motorcycles, or participate in one of 100 seminars and classes being offered.

â€œThe BMW MOA is the largest brand specific motorcycle club in the world that is not owned or operated by the manufactures. They are a great group of people who are looking forward to their 2013 Rally and spending quality time in the Salem area,â€ù said Debbie McCune, Director of Sales for Travel Salem. â€œSalem is a hospitable community and we want this group to feel welcome, enjoy the area, and come back time and time again,â€ù said McCune.

Founded in 1972, the BMW MOA promotes relationships between individual members and BMW motorcycle clubs, unifying smaller clubs across the US. According to BMW MOA, the economic impact of this group on the Salem area is estimated between $4 and $6 million dollars.

For more information about the BMW Motorcycle Owners of America, visit www.bmwmoa.org or call headquarters at 636-394-7277.

column4: New Hours for Travel Salemâ€™s Travel CafÃ© Visitors Center
column5:
Beginning July 1 Travel Salemâ€™s Travel CafÃ© Visitors Center will have new hours; Monday through Friday 10:30 a.m. to 3:30 p.m., closed Saturday and Sunday. These changes are a result of program realignment due to budget restrictions. Travel Salem will continue to maintain program continuity and delivery in a manner that is consistent with visitor expectations.

â€œThe new hours reflect the time of the day with the highest visitor volume,â€ù said Angie Morris, Travel Salemâ€™s CEO. â€œOur professional staff serve as the regionâ€™s concierge providing Salem visitors with expert local resources and recommendations to help them explore what the area has to offer,â€ù said Morris. The Travel CafÃ© Visitors Center offers wine tasting, ticket sales to events and attractions, GPS rentals, and customized itineraries to name a few.

Travel Salem oversees a visitor information network that includes an official Oregon Travel Plaza located at the BEST WESTERN PLUS Mill Creek Inn, which is open 24 hours a day, 7 days a week; as well as locations at the Red Lion Hotel, Salem Conference Center, Salem Airport, Amtrak, Lancaster Mall, Aurora Airport and the Willamette Heritage Center at The Mill.

After hours visitors will be able to access the Salem Area Visitors Guide, maps and other high demand resources via an outdoor brochure rack. Travel Salem offers Wi-Fi services so visitor information can also be obtained by visiting www.TravelSalem.com.

column4: Travel Salem Named Top 100 Best Green Companies to Work for in Oregon
column5:
Travel Salem has been selected as a "Top 100 Best Green Companies to Work For in Oregon" by Oregon Business magazine. Weighing in at number 84, Travel Salem was one of only five Salem area businesses recognized.

â€œWe are committed to maintaining a 'green company' and are thrilled to be counted as one of Oregon's most sustainable organizations," said Angie Morris, CEO of Travel Salem. "Sustainability is not only a philosophy, but it has become a way of doing business because 'green' business practices matter to our customers."

Travel Salem's 'Green Team,' a group of employees charged with making the workplace more sustainable, led the way in developing an eco-savvy culture with buy-in to sustainable practices. Travel Salem is certified EarthWISE through Marion County's business environmental assistance program, incorporating sustainable practices in the business such as recycling, reducing waste and saving energy. Travel Salem's Travel CafÃ© and administrative office was designed with sustainability in mind: using recycled and earth-friendly materials and features that allow for generous natural light, among other things.

The 100 Best Green Companies in 2012 were selected based on Sustainable Practices sections in both employee and employer surveys completed last year by nearly 20,000 employees from 431 for-profit companies and nonprofit organizations. The "100 Best Green Companies to Work For in Oregon" is featured in the June "Green Issue" of Oregon Business magazine.

Other Salem Businesses Recognized: #7 Salem Conference Center; #37 Green Acres Landscape; #41 AJâ€Ÿs Auto Repair; #50 Cascade Employers Association; #64 Capital Auto Group & #84 Travel Salem.

column4: Feature Your Business on the New Digital Smartphone Concierge
column5:
Is your business featured on over 800 Salem and Keizer hotel rooms and on the plasma screens in the official Travel Cafe Visitors Center? Travel Salem has a creative partnership with HospitalityVision, the host of the default television channel in over 800 Salem area hotel rooms.

Not only do the ads run eight times an hour, 160 times a day, and 5,400 times a month, this advertising medium visually reaches overnight visitors; promoting businesses who want to attract visitors to their front door. And, it is also featured on the local area â€œMy Concierge To Goâ€ù apps. Pictured to the right is "Lewis" in the lobby of the Comfort Inn and Suites in Salem.

â€œMy Concierge To Goâ€ù provides visitors with a custom, personalized digital concierge. Using the new phone app available on Android, the iPhone and other smartphones, guests can remotely review hotel amenities, hotel layout, check meeting times, agendas, play games, enjoy entertainment, book more room nights, and find partner restaurants, shops and attractions, too.

Guests simply check into a hotel, download the app or scan a QR code, enter a hotel code, and ring a bell to meet their personal concierge. The information on the "My Concierge To Go" directory mirrors the digital guest directory on the televisions. Check out a sample in iTunes. With HospitalityVision, you can take the directory out of the room and your concierge goes wherever you go.

If you would like your business featured on the Salem area "My Concierge To Go" apps and in more than 800 hotel rooms, contact Tina Winge at membership@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325 ext. 59.

column4: July 19th -- Travel Salem Marketing Exchange Luncheon
column5:
Travel Salem Marketing Exchange Luncheon

Featuring
Keynote Speaker: John Zielinski, E.Z. Orchards Farm Market

Agri-Tourism â€“ Growing Oregonâ€™s Economy One Berry at a Time!

July 19th, 2012
11:45 a.m. â€“ 1:15 p.m.
Hart of the Garden Building
Oregon State Fair and Exposition Center
2330 17th Street NE
Salem, OR 97301
 
Call 503-581-4325 ext. 58 now to reserve your seat!
 
Sponsored by:

Freyâ€™s Dahlias
Just â€˜Keepsâ€™ Kayakinâ€™
Loustic Catering
Wild Oregon Tours
 
John Zielinski, owner of E.Z. Orchards Farm Market, is in the agri-tourism business and lives it every day! Come learn how E.Z. Orchards has successfully woven tourism into their agricultural roots boosting their bottom line and the area economy. John will share what the future holds for agri-tourism and how this industry will continue to grow.
 
Travel Salemâ€™s main leisure marketing pillars are Culture/Heritage, Culinary and Recreation. Agri-tourism has been a key component of Travel Salemâ€™s marketing. Farmers markets, outdoor markets, artisan crafted beer, wine, cheese bread, chocolate and so much more is a huge asset for our region. Learning more about these agri-tourism opportunities and partnering at the highest level to promote this niche is an important part of our regional tourism engine.
Please join John as he shares more about this important industry!
 
Keynote Speaker:
John Zielinski is a 4th generation Willamette Valley farmer who manages E.Z. Orchards Farm Market, and the annual E.Z. Orchards fall Harvestfest. John has visited farm stands from New England to Arizona in the constant search of innovative and cutting edge strategies to keep E.Z. Orchards in the forefront of the industry. E.Z. Orchards offers urbanites a pleasant farm setting where they can experience the authentic agricultural bounty of the Willamette Valley.
 
Giving back to the community is very important to John. He has served on various boards including: the Agri-Business Council of Oregon and is a past president of the Salem Area Chamber of Commerce. John is currently serving on the Silverton Hospital Board, the Oregon Community Foundation North Willamette Advisory Committee, and is President of the Marion County Farm Bureau.
 
John is married and has two daughters who he hopes will join him, and his two brothers, in the family business.
 
Promote Your Business: This is your opportunity to promote your business and services! Remember to bring your business cards and brochures for the Marketing Exchange table.
 
Enter-to-Win! â€“ Enter to win a Wild Oregon Tours, trip for two to Abiqua and Butte Creek Falls; a beautiful dahlia bouquet courtesy of Freyâ€™s Dahlias; a gift certificate from Just â€˜Keepsâ€™ Kayakinâ€™; or a basket of delicious goodies from E.Z. Orchards Farm Market. Must be present to win.
 
RSVPs and prepayment of $18 required / $23 at the door RSVP a must!
 
Reserve Your Seat Today
Save $5 with advanced registration if purchased by July 16th!
-- Online - use your credit card at www.TravelSalem.com
-- Phone - use your credit card by calling 503-581-4325, ext. 58
-- Mail - send your check to: Travel Salem Marketing Exchange Luncheon, 181 High St. NE, Salem, OR 97301
 
Space is limited for this event. RSVP a must!
 
Please remember that when we receive your RSVP, we will order and pay for your lunch. If you are unable to attend, payment for lunch is still required. Thanks for helping to make Travel Salem luncheons a success.
 
YOU WILL WANT TO ADD TO YOUR BUSINESS SAVVY AND NETWORK BY ATTENDING THIS MARKETING EXCHANGE
 
See you on July 19, 2012!
 
Sponsored by:

Freyâ€™s Dahlias
Just â€˜Keepsâ€™ Kayakinâ€™
Loustic Catering
Wild Oregon Tours

column4: Wild Pear Restaurant, E.Z. Orchards Farm Market & Travel Salem Represent Willamette Valley at Feast Portland
column5:
Oregonâ€™s world-class celebration of food and drink called â€œFeast Portlandâ€ù took place September 20-23, 2012 downtown Portland. Feast was held in Pioneer Courthouse Square and held events like the Sandwich Invitational, an Asian-inspired night market, high profile chef demonstrations, conversations with food thought leaders and a whole lot of eating and drinking.

While Portland was the center of this festival Salem was offered the opportunity to shine and represent the Willamette Valley at the Travel Oregon~Oregon Bounty Grand Tasting Tent â€“ Saturday, September 22. Celebrated Salem chef Jeff James, represented the Wild Pear Restaurant, highlighting a 5-spiced cured Carlton Farms pork belly with E.Z. Orchards hard cider glaze, pears dipped in a Gouda cheese and maple syrup dip rolled in hazelnuts using the freshest local ingredients. Chef James along with, sisters and co-owners of the Wild Pear Restaurant, Cecelia and Jessica Ritter were on hand to talk to event goers and promote the agricultural bounty of the Willamette Valley and the Wild Pear. Kevin Zielinski with E.Z. Orchards Farm Market was serving tastes of their hard cidre and sharing information about their traditional French method of fermentation. Travel Salem representatives, Irene Bernards and Debbie McCune were greeting event attendees and promoting Salemâ€™s culinary scene as well as the amenities of the mid-Willamette Valley.

â€œOregon is a true cornucopia and the Willamette Valley is the corner stone of Oregonâ€™s bountiful harvests,â€ù said Irene Bernards, Marketing & PR Director for Travel Salem. â€œMarion County is Oregonâ€™s number one agricultural producing county and we had the opportunity to showcase the delicious offerings of the region and how local chefs partner with farmers and unify agricultural assets into culinary delights. We want visitors and Oregon residents to realize the foodie opportunities of our area,â€ù said Bernards.

Travel Salem approached the Wild Pear Restaurant about representing the Willamette Valley due to their commitment to local, seasonal and organic ingredients and how they use these ingredients in familiar and unexpected ways, whenever possible.

 â€œWe are honored to have represented the Willamette Valley at the Oregon Bounty Grand Tasting Tent,â€ù said Cecilia and Jessica, Wild Pear Co-Owners.  â€œWe are extremely fortunate to have Chef, Jeff James represent the Wild Pear and our mid-Willamette Valley region. Chef James has been a guest chef at the James Beard House in New York and also selected for L'Ecole des Chefs in Lyon, France and the Oregon Bounty tour for the United States Department of Agriculture in Japan. Chef Jamesâ€™ culinary culture and talents has paired well with our company where he has spent the last two years. With a diverse ethnic background of European and Asian descent, we embrace the flavors and styles of many cultures. Our food is best described as New American, which reflects the bold, bright and fresh flavors of our region and the world. We work with local farmers and purveyors to use product that is locally sourced, seasonal, and organic as much as possible,â€ù said Cecilia Ritter.

column4: Economic Summit -- Property Values, Land Use, Development and Jobs
column5:
Wednesday, October 17, 2012
5-9 p.m. at the Keizer Civic Center

Please join us to examine significant economic forces related to economic development in Marion County, and to discuss ways we can work together.

A panel of speakers from the public and private sectors will share their insights:

  • Mayor Lore Christopher, City of Keizer
  • Van Khieu, Marion County Assessor's Office
  • Jay Gordon, Willamette Valley Multiple Listing Service
  • Jim Rue, Oregon Department of Land Conservation and Development
  • Alan Roodhouse, RPS Development
  • Nick Harville, SEDCOR
  • Suzanne Dufner, Mid-Willamette Valley Council of Governments
  • Angie Morris, Travel Salem

To register, simply respond via email to drusso@co.marion.or.us and provide your current contact information. There is no fee. A modest buffet will open at 5 p.m. during the social hour; the program begins at 6 p.m. Registration deadline is October 1.

This Economic Summit is sponsored by the Marion County Economic Development Advisory Board, a group who advise the Marion County Board of Commissioners.

column5:
Travel Salem recently hosted a group of 20 wine bloggers from the U.S., Canada and Israel. Yes, Israel. They were attending a wine bloggers conference being held in Portland and Travel Salem reached out to event organizers offering a â€œSalem, Outside the Bottleâ€ù pre-conference tour for interested delegates. Our goal? To showcase this region to these 20 individuals who would in turn promote it as a great place for wine and travel.

We picked the group up in Portland and made many stops along the way showcasing wine but also the â€œoutside the bottleâ€ù amenities of the region.

Our first stop was the Evergreen Aviation & Space Museum in McMinnville. The bloggers were treated to Evergreenâ€™s varietals as well as a tour of the aviation and space museum and water park.

Then we headed south on 99W and enjoyed a relaxing stop at Johan Vineyards where a twisted horned cow welcomed us. The bloggers were busy snapping pictures and verbally and visually admiring the beauty of the pastoral geography. At Johan they experienced not only the fruit of the vine but they were introduced to â€œwiking.â€ù Wiking is a combination of hiking while enjoying wine. We â€œwikedâ€ù through the vineyard toward our final destination for the day, Left Coast Cellars.

The wine bloggers took part in a barrel tasting at Left Coast Cellars and a mouth-watering barbecue in the â€œTree Houseâ€ù â€“a rustic covering adorned with twinkle lights. The barbecue also featured a variety of Left Coast Cellars wines, including a white Pinot, and the bloggers were able to share a knowledgeable wine exchange with the winemaker.

As we headed toward Salem that night the motor coach was lit up by hand held devices. Already, these wine and travel influencers were blogging about their day. They were producing stories and posting photos promoting all they had experienced during day one of their tour. This is the reason we organized this event!

The next morning we kicked off the day at the Willamette Heritage Center at The Mill with an invigorating tour regarding Salemâ€™s wool industry and their exhibit â€œHistory on Tap.â€ù Although this exhibit is no longer available it was really interesting. Be sure to check out their next exhibit â€œThe Art & Tradition of Kimonoâ€ù (Sept. 21-Dec. 24).

Continuing on our tour we visited Willamette Valley Vineyards where all of the bloggers were treated to a cellar tour and tasting; a T-shirt that states â€œItâ€™s Willamette Dammitâ€ù and a gourmet lunch including wine pairing tips and discussion.

As we wound our way through the country roads to Piluso Vineyard & Winery the conversation in the motor coach was lively. These folks were overwhelmed by the beauty of the region. They were discovering quality wines, sharing and learning about Oregonâ€™s wine making process and many were experiencing Oregon for the first time. A large majority asked questions about moving to the area and how they would love to live here.

The bloggers discovered a â€œboutiqueâ€ù winery at Piluso Vineyard & Winery and they took the opportunity to delve into the detail of the vines, the soil and how those translate into the grape and the flavors it extracts.

We ended our tour at E.Z. Orchards Farm Market sampling peach and strawberry shortcake and their hard cidre, which is produced similarly to wine. These wine connoisseurs were delighted with the cidre and really enjoyed learning more about the process.

As the tour was winding down I realized that although I live here, and Iâ€™m well versed in the bounty and wealth of opportunities for visitors, this was the first time I experienced the Salem area through the fresh eyes of twenty â€œwine hungryâ€ù visitors. Visitors whose purpose is to share their wine experiences; to share their travel experiences and to encourage their readers to visit new places and savor all the beauty that is wineâ€_and everything that is also â€œoutside the bottle.â€ù

As I write this article, I can barely keep up with the blogs posted from the tour and the positive comments regarding our area and the tour. I would be remiss for not mentioning that everything included in this tour was donated by those mentioned above as well as four local lodging establishments that contributed the overnight rooms for the bloggers (Grand Hotel in Salem, Hampton Inn & Suites, Red Lion Hotel and the Comfort Suites Salem Airport). Thank you for helping make this promotion of the Salem area possible!

Here are a few of the bloggers comments to share:

â€œLove Oregon and Oregonians!!!â€ù ~ WineCountryGetaways

â€œThe wineries, people and wines were just the best. I am so impressed with the people we met and the wine they craft. As Mac Arthur said during WWII we will return.â€ù ~ Mikeonwines.com

â€œThe experience that Travel Salem provided for our small group of wine bloggers attending the 2012 Wine Bloggers Conference in Portland was absolutely first rate. The variety of activities was such a great blend of cultural attractions, wineries and the great Oregon outdoors. Everyone was so gracious â€“ Iâ€™m still blown away by the hospitality. Thank you, thank you and I look forward to a return visit to Salem and the surrounding counties.â€ù ~ Pursuingpinot.com

â€œIâ€™m really glad that you added cultural stops in addition to the wineries. I only wish we had more time at each place! Which means I must return for a longer visit. This was a great introduction to the Willamette Valley for me, and I now have a better awareness of what Oregon is doing in the wine world. I also appreciated the variety of wineries. I donâ€™t think we had a bad wine.â€ù ~ winefashionista.com

~Originally published September 21, 2012 on Travel Salem's blog on StatesmanJournal.com by Angie Morris.

  • Back to newsletter

Featuring

 The State of the Industry

Keynote Speaker:  Angie Morris, President & CEO, Travel Salem

November 15, 2012
11:45 a.m. - 1:15 p.m.

Red Lion Hotel
3301 Market St. NE
Salem, Oregon 97301

Sponsored by:

  

The â€œState of the Industryâ€ù presentation will highlight the achievements and milestones from the past year and look ahead to 2013.

Be sure to attend Novemberâ€™s Travel Salem Marketing Exchange Luncheon to learn how Travel Salem has been promoting the area and leveraging funding in creative ways to make a difference for you, your business and our region!

Call now to reserve your seat! 503-581-4325 ext. 58

Keynote Speaker:
Angie Morris
Angie Morris was hired as the Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of Travel Salem in February 2007 after a nationwide search. Angieâ€™s high caliber of creative marketing skills coupled with her nonprofit administration, management and leadership skills, as well as her knowledge and ties to Salem made her the ideal CEO for Travel Salem.

During her tenure with Travel Salem Angie has reinvented the organization through pioneering and creative marketing, relationship development and innovation. Examples include Travel Salemâ€™s customized membership program, built to suit the diverse needs of businesses; the award-winning Travel CafÃ© Visitors Center, created through fundraising and collaborative partnerships; the creation of the nationâ€™s first Wine Country specialty license plate, that will serve as a rolling billboard for the region while generating revenue for the tourism industry; and the formation of Cultivating Communities, a foundation based on tourism education and awareness.

Angieâ€™s professional history includes serving as the Executive Director for Pentacle Theatre, and working for the Portland Opera Broadway Across America series as their Director of Marketing and Public Relations managing a $1.5 million annual budget, generating $9-12 million in ticket sales annually.

Promote Your Business:  This is your opportunity to promote your business and services! Remember to bring your business cards and brochures for the Marketing Exchange table.

Enter-to-Win! â€“ Amtrak will give away a voucher for a round-trip ticket from Salem to Vancouver, BC (valued at $196). You might also win a Holiday Gift Basket from West Side Wine Store (valued at $150). Be sure to enter your business card for a chance to be one of the lucky recipients. Guests must be present to win.

RSVPs and prepayment of $18 required / $23 at the door RSVP a must!

Reserve Your Seat Today â€“ Save $5 with advanced registration if purchased by November 11th!

-- Phone - use your credit card by calling 503-581-4325, ext. 58
-- Mail - send your check to:  Travel Salem Marketing Exchange Luncheon, 181 High St. NE, Salem, OR 97301

Please remember that when we receive your RSVP, we will order and pay for your lunch. If you are unable to attend, payment for lunch is still required. Thanks for helping to make Travel Salem luncheons a success.

See you on November 15, 2012!

Thank you to our event sponsors:

column5:
The holiday season is in full swing and if youâ€™re still on the hunt for great gift ideas, consider a gift from one of our area nonprofit organizations. Not only will you find thoughtful presents for friends and family, but your purchase will help support our communityâ€™s best nonprofit arts, heritage and service organizations.

Art enthusiasts will be delighted with the Hallie Ford Museum of Art â€œExperience the Artsâ€ù package, which combines visual, theatre and musical performances into one unique gift. The special package includes a one-year family/dual membership to the museum, two tickets to a Grace Goudy Distinguished Artists Series concert, and two tickets to a Willamette University Theatre production â€“ all for $100.

For the kid on your list â€“ or for anyone who relishes the opportunity to act like one â€“ head over to Salemâ€™s Riverfront Carousel and pick up a $20 punch card, which is valid for 18 rides. The Carouselâ€™s colorful gift shop also offers whimsical and unique gifts for kids and adults. Whatâ€™s more, you can enjoy free Carousel rides on Christmas and New Yearâ€™s Day between 1 p.m. and 4 p.m. with a canned food donation to Marion-Polk Food Share.

For theater goers, consider a gift certificate to the Pentacle Theatre. Certificates are available in any dollar amount and can be used toward the purchase of tickets to any of the theatre groupâ€™s 2013 productions. Upcoming plays include the wacky musical Willy Wonka and Incorruptible, a comedy by Michael Hollinger.

If youâ€™re looking for a last minute gift for your pet, stop by Davenportâ€™s Den, the pet supply store located inside Willamette Humane Society. Named after a cat who resided in the shelter for many years, Davenportâ€™s offers toys, treats, and pet-related gift items. Proceeds from store sales support shelter pets.

Who wouldnâ€™t enjoy receiving a one-year membership or a set of day passes to the Salvation Army Ray & Joan Kroc Community Center? With an aquatics program, library, gymnasium, fitness center, and art studio, this local gem offers year-round activities to suit a wide variety of interests.

If a green-thumbed gardener is on your list, he or she will surely â€œdigâ€ù a membership to The Oregon Garden. Members receive free admission to The Garden all year long as well as discounts on any purchases in The Gardenâ€™s gift shop, cafÃ©, Moonstone spa, The Oregon Garden restaurant and the resort.

History buffs will appreciate a membership to any one of our areaâ€™s museums or historical societies. The Independence Heritage Museum displays the history and culture of the river town of Independence and surrounding areas. Museum memberships can be purchased online, making gift giving easy and convenient.

For hip and affordable arts and crafts by regional artisans, check out the ArtMarket exhibit at the Bush Barn Art Center. Sales from the second annual exhibition benefit the Salem Art Associationâ€™s Community Arts Education (CAE) program. ArtMarket is open through December 24.

For more information â€“ including deals and packages that would also make great gifts this season â€“ visit Travelsalem.com.

~Originally published December 13, 2012 on Travel Salem's blog on StatesmanJournal.com by Angie Morris.

column5:
Photography

Travel Salem is looking for high resolution images that we can use, rights free, throughout our print, online and social marketing platforms. We are looking for photos within Marion and Polk counties including attractions, gardens, nature, recreation, dining, shopping, events, wine tasting or any image that you think might pique the interest of visitors.

Travel Salem has found that a picture does say a thousand words. We have attracted weddings to the area just from some of the images we have used in the Salem Area Visitors Guide. We weave beautiful photography into all of our marketing efforts and we hear from visitors that the materials we produce are lovely, inspiring and gorgeous.

If you have images that you would like Travel Salem to consider please review the following criteria:

  • Photos must be a minimum of 300dpi
  • Photos should be experiential and include people when possible
  • Photos with people must have a â€œmodel releaseâ€ù included that gives permission to use images.

If your images meet the criteria please send or deliver them on a disc to:

Irene Bernards, Marketing & PR Director
Travel Salem, 181 High St. NE, Salem, Oregon 97301

If you have questions contact Irene directly at ibernards@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325 ext. 27.

Events

Please remember to self-submit your events for 2013 for TravelSalem.com through the online form. Travel Salem refers to the events listing frequently when pitching story ideas to the media. We are already pitching summer and fall 2013 story ideas so the sooner your events are submitted the better. Early event submission is also best for visitors who are already planning their 2013 vacations.

For your event to receive maximum exposure you must submit it at least 60 days before the actual event. This gives Travel Salem time to proof, edit, post and syndicate your event to local, regional and national media outlets.

If you have any questions regarding event submission please contact Kathie Reeves, Marketing Manager at kreeves@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325 ext. 24.

column4: Travel Salem Hires New Public Relations Manager
column5:
Travel Salem is pleased to announce Kara Kuh as the organizationâ€™s new public relations manager. In this role, Kuh will develop and implement public and media relations activities that promote Salem and Marion and Polk counties for leisure tourism and event business.

Kuh has more than 11 years of experience working in nonprofit communications and public relations. Before joining Travel Salem, she served as the communications specialist for Willamette Humane Society for five years. Prior to that, she worked as the media relations and marketing manager for the American Cancer Society in Portland, Ore. A native Oregonian, Kuh earned a bachelorâ€™s degree in business administration and marketing from Pacific University in Forest Grove, Ore. While studying at Pacific, she also completed a marketing and PR internship with the Washington County Visitors Association in Beaverton, Ore.

â€œKaraâ€™s many years of experience in communications and media relations will help us promote Salem and the surrounding area as a key destination for leisure and business travelers,â€ù says Irene Bernards, Travel Salemâ€™s Marketing and PR Director. â€œWe look forward to her contributions and are happy she is part of our team!â€ù

Kara can be reached at kkuh@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325 ext. 25.

column4: Importance of External Links to your Website
column5:
External links not only improve your search engine ranking, but they also provide a valuable resource to your customers. Search Engine Optimizers, those who provide Search Engine Optimization service, believe that external links are one of the most important sources for improving search engine ranking because search engines consider them to be third-party votes.*

Linking to www.TravelSalem.com illustrates your support for tourism as an economic development generator and this simple link will help www.TravelSalem.com climb in search engine rankings, which allows your business information and link to be found by even more visitors as well. Travel Salem's website isn't just for out-of-towners either; it's a valuable resource for residents too.

Take a moment to ensure your business link on www.TravelSalem.com is correct. If you find your link is not listed with your business or needs to be updated, please email your correct website link to kreeves@TravelSalem.com.

A link might seem like something small, but linking our websites together and linking to other businesses in Salem and the mid-Willamette Valley, will benefit all businesses involved. This small little link opens up a world of possibilities!

*External Links, SEOmoz.org

column5:
While temperatures hover near zero in many other parts of the country throughout the winter, our temperate climate means we generally experience much milder weather here in the Salem area. Yes, itâ€™s rainy, but with the right gear and attitude, we can enjoy the beauty of the great outdoors during the winter months. So, grab your rain gear, seize your sense of adventure, and plan a â€œwintercationâ€ù in the mid-Willamette Valley.

For an authentic Northwest adventure this winter, head to the Detroit Lake Recreation Area. Located in the heart of the Willamette National Forest, much of the 3,500 acre area is accessible year round. If you like to hike or snow shoe, youâ€™ll enjoy many miles of trails that lead through misty old growth forests and snow-covered clearings. Detroit Lake is also open to boaters in winter months. A winter boat ramp was constructed in 2009 at Mongold State Park, making it possible to launch a boat safely during the winter months when other ramps in the lake are on dry ground. Also located just a few miles east of Detroit is the McCoy Creek snowmobile area, featuring 60 miles of well-maintained trails and even a designated snowmobile shelter.

If youâ€™re heading to Detroit, plan to stay overnight at The Lodge at Detroit Lake. Renovated in 2010, these cozy cabins offer the best of both worlds: a rustic lodge feel and modern amenities including flat screen TVâ€™s, gas fireplaces, and in-room Wi-Fi. Soothe your muscles after a day of hiking or snowshoeing with a hot bath in a jetted tub, which comes standard in every room. And if you forget to bring your toothbrush, donâ€™t worry. Mountain High Grocery & Gifts is conveniently located close to The Lodge and stocks the essentials, plus snacks and small souvenir items. On your way to or from Detroit, be sure to stop at Rosieâ€™s Mountain Coffeehouse in Mill City for their famous scones, a cup of hot java, or a bowl of delicious homemade soup.

Whether youâ€™re an experienced fisherman or just getting your feet wet, winter can be a great time to plan a fishing trip. Oregon Outdoor Excursions offers guided trips throughout the year, including a â€œSiletz River Winter Steelheadâ€ù trip. Take advantage of their guidesâ€™ knowledge and expertise as you drift down the Siletz, fishing for steelhead.

Winter is also an ideal time for viewing certain types of wildlife. Just west of Salem lies the Baskett Slough National Wildlife Refuge â€“ a sanctuary for wintering geese, great blue heron, hawks and other birds and mammals. Winter is the best time to see the dusky Canada goose or catch a glimpse of the beautiful Bald Eagle.

For a unique experience you wonâ€™t soon forget, consider a horseback adventure with Into the Wild Equine Adventures, a family-owned and operated trail riding business specializing in intimate, guided group trail rides. While summer is the busiest season for tours, the company also offer a limited number of winter rides exploring the foothills of the Cascade Range.

For a cold weather outing close to the city, head to Minto-Brown Island Park. This nearly 900-acre natural park offers many miles of trails for walking, jogging, biking, and hiking, and also boasts one of the largest off-leash dog parks in the Northwest. After hiking or exploring Minto-Brown, find a place with cozy fireplace ambiance and great food and drink like Bentleyâ€™s Grill or Gilgamesh Brewingâ€™s newly opened restaurant and brewery, The Campus.

For more events and ideas for exploring the Salem area this winter, visit the Official Salem Area website www.TravelSalem.com.

~Originally published January 15, 2013 on Travel Salem's blog on StatesmanJournal.com by Angie Morris.

  • Back to newsletter
column6:
While temperatures hover near zero in many other parts of the country throughout the winter, our temperate climate means we generally experience much milder weather here in the Salem area. Yes, itâ€™s rainy, but with the right gear and attitude, we can enjoy the beauty of the great outdoors during the winter months. So, grab your rain gear, seize your sense of adventure, and plan a â€œwintercationâ€ù in the mid-Willamette Valley.

For an authentic Northwest adventure this winter, head to

column4: Our Mascot "Sal" is in Our Hotels on the New Hotel Phone App!
column5:
Hereâ€™s Sal, our Cityâ€™s other Golden Man and pioneer, ready to greet people in the Comfort Inn hotel lobby and personally welcome them to Salem. Heâ€™s also your personal hotel virtual concierge, available on all smart phone platforms.

The Comfort Inn Suites is the first hotel in Salem and one of the first in Oregon to offer "Concierge To-go," an interactive phone app which allows guests to have a full-time travel escort. With Travel Salemâ€™s very own Sal at their side, guests can tour the hotel, call the front desk, check meeting times, current events from Travel Salem, and then be navigated to local shops and restaurants. Sal will help them get tickets to The Oregon Garden or make a dinner reservation.

Visitors may be driving around Salem and wonder if the hotel pool is still open? Or, where is that new restaurant they saw on the TV and what do they have on their menu? And, what time is that meeting? When can we have breakfast? Now guests can scan the entire hotel directory info on their phones. Visitors can also download the app on the Google Play or Apple app store and enter hotel code 1244, or simply scan in a QR code that Sal provides at the front desk. The app even offers a free slot game.

Hotel staff point out "In these economic times, mid-level hotels cannot afford to hire a full-time concierge so "Concierge To Go" solves this problem and offers a 24/7 digital concierge personalized to the hotel, as well as a personal welcome from Salemâ€™s mascot."

Oregon based HospitalityVision works with Travel Salem to provide a visitorâ€™s information channel in six local hotels and at the Travel CafÃ©. Travel Salem and HospitalityVision want to see Sal greeting visitors and helping them tour Salem in many more hotels soon â€“ Salem will be the first city in the nation to bring their mascot to life as a concierge in our hotels greeting visitors.

Advertise with Sal on the smart phone app, all the hotel TVâ€™s, and the Travel CafÃ© screens for only $99 a month. If you would like your business featured on the Salem area "My Concierge To Go" apps and in more than 800 hotel rooms, contact Tina Winge at membership@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325 ext. 59.

column5:
Give Us Your Best Pitch!

Travel Salem is looking for your input regarding ideas for future articles, stories, and pitches that we can add to our â€œcontent libraryâ€ù for potential pitches and presentations to the media to encourage them to write about Salem and the surrounding area. In order to gather your input, we are hosting a â€œspeed pitchingâ€ù open house on Thursday, March 7. Anyone representing a Marion or Polk county business, group or nonprofit is invited to drop in between 1 p.m. and 5 p.m. and share with us whatâ€™s new or newsworthy at your organization.

What constitutes a â€œnewsworthyâ€ù pitch? Basically, weâ€™re looking for ideas that are unusual, new and innovative. If your organization or business has recently launched â€“ or is planning to launch â€“ a new product, service, event, or program that is unique and of interest to a large audience (especially visitors), this is your chance to tell us about it!

Hereâ€™s how it works:

  • No pre-registration necessary. Drop by the Travel Salem Travel CafÃ© Visitors Center (located at 181 High St. NE in downtown Salem) any time between 1 p.m. and 5 p.m. on Thursday, March 7.
  • The person(s) representing the business or organization will have 10 minutes (minimum) to share their idea with a member of Travel Salemâ€™s marketing staff.
  • Please send no more than 2 people per organization.
  • If you are pitching an event, it needs to occur in the late summer, fall or winter of 2013 or in 2014. (Most of the regional and national publications we target are working at least 6-9 months in advance).
  • We encourage you to bring a one-page summary of your pitch and/or a supporting document (i.e. a brochure, flyer, rack card).
  • While we hope to utilize as many of the ideas as possible, Travel Salem cannot guarantee that an idea will be used or published. 

If you cannot attend â€œSpeed Pitchingâ€ù but would like to submit an idea, please do so through our online Public Relations Request Form.

Travel Salem will be evaluating this â€œSpeed Pitchingâ€ù opportunity and if it is successful, we will add more opportunities throughout the year. We look forward to hearing all of your creative ideas!

  • Back to newsletter

This tournament will bring in girls and boys ages 10-19, and their families to play in this youth tournament. If youâ€™d like to connect your business (restaurants, activity places, bowling, family friendly places, etc.) by offering a discount to the teams when they are in town, send your logo and discount information to be listed on the Capital Cup website to: Valorie Westlund, Capital Cup Soccer Tournament, valorie@capitalcup.org, cell 503-740-6734, fax 503-974-9096. www.capitalcup.org

Over 6,000 attendees will enjoy all that Salem and the mid-Willamette Valley has to offer as they unite for their 41st Annual Rally. If youâ€™d like to connect your business with these attendees and be listed on their website, please send your special offers and logo to: Rallychair2013@bmwmoa.org. column5:
The 2013-14 Salem Area Visitors Guide (VG) is now available. Travel Salem is in the process of distributing the VG to 800 locations throughout Oregon, Washington, California and British Columbia. Visitors are responding positively to the new guide, which includes QR codes for major sections that direct consumers to TravelSalem.com for up-to-the-moment information.

Travel Salem would like to thank all of the businesses and organizations who generously supported the VG through advertising! You can also view the guide in digital format at TravelSalem.com.

To order a supply of the new Salem Area Visitors Guide contact Barb Cowan at 503-581-4325 ext. 21 or bcowan@TravelSalem.com.

column4: BMW Motorcycle Owners of America Event
column5:
The BMW Motorcycle Owners of America (â€˜MOA) will be holding its 2013 International Rally July 18-20, 2013, at the Oregon State Fairgrounds.

The BMW Motorcycle Owners of America was formed in April of 1972 as an all volunteer organization. The goal of the club is to promote the camaraderie and friendship of individual members and BMW motorcycle clubs. Since 1972 the BMW MOA has grown to be the largest brand specific motorcycle club in the world.

As the 'MOA has grown, attendance at the rally has grown as well, now averaging over 9000 like-minded riders. The rally site rotates throughout North America; previous rallies have been held in Montana, Colorado, Oregon, Illinois, New York, Connecticut, Tennessee and Trenton, Ontario. The rally is a great place to meet wonderful people as well as visit with vendors who manufacture many specialty items for BMWs. BMW Motorrad is a fixture at the annual rally, often bringing along over four dozen motorcycles which are available for guided test rides. The Rally also features over 100 seminars and classes.

The BMW MOA International Rally routinely generates $4 to $6 million in revenue for the local area in which is takes place. 

If youâ€™d like to offer any specials or discounts for your business during the rally please contact Tara Preston at 503-581-4325 ext. 58 or tpreston@TravelSalem.com.

  • Back to newsletter

column4: Salem Welcomes the Capital Cup Soccer Tournament
column5:
Salem will play host to the 2nd Annual Capital Cup Soccer Tournament being held June 28-30, 2013. At least 155 teams from Oregon, Washington, California and Wyoming will gather in Salem to compete for the honor of being named the Capital Cup Soccer Tournament champions. There will be multiple champions since the tournament is divided by gender and grade level, 3rd through 12th.

Multiple venues from throughout the Salem areawill be used, including Cascade Soccer Fields, Sprague High School, South Salem High School, McKay Park, Willamette University, Corban University and Geer Park ball fields.

The estimated economic impact of this event is $1.5 million, which is significant to Salem. Each team has an average of 16 players, plus the families that travel with the teams to support their children.  

Travel Salem has been working with the Capital Cup Soccer organizers and they have partnered with eleven local hotels to assist with housing the teams.

  • Back to newsletter

column5:
25 fields for Oregon is a registered nonprofit that recently signed an agreement to purchase 195 acres in the Central Willamette Valley just north of Salem/Keizer to build a premier youth field sports park. Upon opening, planned for 2014, this park will boast the highest quality natural grass multi-sport playing surfaces in the country and will match FIFA (Federation International Football Association) standards and regulations.

The bigger vision and the ultimate goal of 25 fields for Oregon is to support field development and scholarships throughout the state of Oregon as a philanthropic organization; granting funds and lending expertise and guidance to youth organizations in need of quality field sites. This is a singularly special opportunity for Oregonâ€™s youth sports to fund themselves.

To learn more about 25 Fields for Oregon visit www.25fields.org.

  • Back to newsletter

column5:
Travel Salem announced the recipients of this yearâ€™s Absolutely Fabulous awards at the fourth annual â€œAb Fabâ€ù Awards Luncheon, held Thursday, May 18, at the Salem Convention Center.

The â€œAb Fabâ€ù awards recognize tourism industry partners who go above and beyond to increase the economic impact of visitors. The award recipients are movers and shakers who turned ideas upside down and inside out to capture the best returns on their marketing, collaborations, partnerships and strategies. 

Travel Salem recognized six business partners for their outstanding commitment to the tourism industry in 2012-13: 

The Absolutely â€œMega Mindsâ€ù Award was presented to Salem Business Computers for the round-the-clock IT support that the company provides to Travel Salem, which helps ensure that visitors, journalists, meeting planners, tour operators and residents have online access to trip planning information 24 hours a day. 

Adelman Peony Gardens received the Absolutely Brilliant Award for turning their passion for growing peonies into a successful business and beautiful display garden that draws visitors from around the globe each year. 
The Absolutely â€œGoing the Distanceâ€ù Award went to Kurt and Erica Haas and the NW Tandem Rally for bringing the groupâ€™s 27th annual rally to Salem in 2012, which brought more than 700 cyclists to the area over a three-day period and infused $294,000 into the region. 
The new Hampton Inn & Suites was presented with the Absolutely â€œHeads in Bedsâ€ù Award for their impeccable customer service and for investing $9.5 million into the industry during a recession, which also generated 30 jobs. 
For their devotion to the art of craft brewing and engaging multiple generations of their family to build an outstanding new visitor attraction, Gilgamesh Brewing received the Absolutely â€œGilga Generationâ€ù Award.
The Absolutely Fabulous Award was presented to the new Oregon State Hospital Museum of Mental Health and the dedicated volunteers who worked to catalog the museumâ€™s vast collection of artifacts, gather stories, raise funds and open the museum. 
  • Back to newsletter

Pondering where to stay and what to see and do while in Oregonâ€™s capital city and the region? Let these creative packages and specials make your stay an Absolutely wonderful experience.

  • Limited Time Offers
  • Year Round Packages & Specials
  • Local Discount & Deal Websites

Limited Time Offers

Dinner Escape Package
Oregon Garden Resort

Enjoy a romantic Dinner Escape Package at the Oregon Garden Resort! Package includes accommodation, two dinner entrees in our Garden View Restaurant, a bottle of house wine, a full American buffet breakfast and admission to The Oregon Garden, an 80-acre botanical garden. Starting at $109.

For reservations, call 800-966-6490 or visit www.oregongardenresort.com. Reservations based on availability. Not to be combined with other offers. Valid  through June 30, 2013. 800-966-6490 or 503-874-500. www.oregongardenresort.com

 

Movies in the Garden Package
Oregon Garden Resort

Enjoy a movie under the stars at The Oregon Garden on Thursday nights. Package includes movie tickets; a picnic of wine, breads and cheeses; a picnic blanket; admission to The Oregon Garden and a continental breakfast. Starting at $150.

For reservations, call 800-966-6490 or visit www.oregongardenresort.com. This package is available on Thursday nights, July 11th through August 29th. 503-874-2500 or 800-966-6490. www.oregongardenresort.com  

 

Year Round Packages & Specials

A Grand Romance Package
Grand Hotel in Salem

This wonderful package includes overnight accommodations for two in your choice of suite, champagne or cider, fresh flowers and our complimentary hot continental breakfast buffet. Enjoy a late checkout of 1 p.m.

 

For package pricing or to purchase this package, call 877-540-7800 or 503-540-7800 or visit www.GrandHotelSalem.com. This package does not have an expiration date.

 

Advanced Purchase Package

Phoenix Inn Suites South Salem

Are you a business traveler who has a packed calendar of obligations? If you have weekly or monthly travel requirements, you can take advantage of Phoenix Inn's Advanced Purchase Package. This package offers a discounted rate when you reserve a room at least 5 days in advance with payment paid in full with no refunds, cancellations or changes.

 

To purchase this package call 503-588-9220 or visit www.phoenixinnsuites.com. (Note: Advanced purchase packages can be booked online www.phoenixinnsuites.com and must be booked 5 days in advance.) This package does not have an expiration date.

 

Complimentary Reserve Tasting for Two

Willamette Valley Vineyards

Receive a complimentary reserve wine tasting for two at Willamette Valley Vineyards. Enjoy six of our award-winning, delicious and sustainable wines at our beautiful Estate Winery. Hours: 11 a.m.-6 p.m. daily.

 

To receive this deal, you must print a coupon by clicking here and bring it to Willamette Valley Vineyards. No expiration, coupon required. 503-588-9463 or 800-344-9463. www.wvv.com

 

Create Your Own Stay

Grand Hotel in Salem

Create your own stay! Choose one option or choose them all! From A.C. Gilbert's Discovery Village to Special Romance Packages such as balloon rides, romantic dinner and flowers. Let your imagination run WILD!

 

To purchase this package visit www.GrandHotelSalem.com. This package does not have an expiration date.

 

Dinner and Movie Package
Grand Hotel in Salem

Need a fun night out? Try this package on for size. Start your stay in a suite of your choice. Check in, relax and enjoy dinner at Bentley's Grill (a $75 value). Our on-site restaurant features the finest in Northwest cuisine and one of Willamette Valley's grandest wine selections. Movie passes for two await you in your room at check-in and are valid at any one of Salem's Regal Cinema movie theatres. In the morning, enjoy our complimentary continental breakfast buffet and a late checkout of 1 p.m.

To purchase this package visit www.GrandHotelSalem.com. This package does not have an expiration date.

Explore the Waterfront Package
Shilo Inn Suites Salem

Package includes a one night stay at the Shilo Inn Suites in Salem, a gift certificate for 4 to A.C. Gilbert's Discovery Village and 4 tokens for Salem's Riverfront Carousel. Package price: $92 plus tax (additional nights $79.95 plus tax).

To purchase this package call 800-222-2244 or visit www.shiloinns.com. Requires 48 hour notice and has no expiration date.

 

The Grand Wine Package
Grand Hotel in Salem

Start your day with complimentary wine tasting at Willamette Valley Vineyards. Sample some of the Valley's most enological treasures. Continue your day with a self-guided tour of the Willamette Valley's many vineyards, and finally, a complimentary bottle of Willamette Valley Vineyards wine and an Oregon Wine Guide await you in your room of choice. The Grand Hotel in Salem wine glasses are yours to keep. In the morning, take advantage of our wonderful complimentary continental breakfast buffet. As a final touch, enjoy a late checkout of 1 p.m. Package pricing: Deluxe King - $169, Deluxe Double Queen - $179, King Suite - $189, Double Queen Suite - $199, Jacuzzi King Suite - $229. Additional tax to be added.

 

To purchase this package call 877-540-7800 or 503-540-7800 or visit www.GrandHotelSalem.com. This package does not have an expiration date.

 

Willamette Heritage Center at The Mill's AAA Offer
Willamette Heritage Center at The Mill

A tour of Mission Mill Museum interprets the history of the Thomas Kay Woolen Mill - designated an American Treasure by the National Park Service - which produced wool products from 1889 to 1962 and represents one of Oregon's earliest and strongest industries. Mission Mill also interprets the history of Jason Lee's Methodist Mission to Oregon which settled in the Willamette Valley in 1834 before the major Oregon Trail migrations. $2 off admission by showing your AAA card.

To redeem this special, present your AAA card at the time of purchase. No expiration date. AAA card must be current. 503-585-7012 or www.WillametteHeritage.org

 

Willamette Heritage Center at The Mill's 1/2 Off Offer
Willamette Heritage Center at The Mill

A tour of Mission Mill Museum interprets the history of the Thomas Kay Woolen Mill - designated an American Treasure by the National Park Service - which produced wool products from 1889 to 1962 and represents one of Oregon's earliest and strongest industries. Mission Mill also interprets the history of Jason Lee's Methodist Mission to Oregon which settled in the Willamette Valley in 1834 before the major Oregon Trail migrations. 50% off admission for up to 4 with coupon from the Entertainment Book.

To redeem this special, present your Entertainment Book Coupon at the time of purchase. Expiration date is printed on the coupon. 503-585-7012 or www.WillametteHeritage.org

 

Willamette Heritage Center at The Mill's  National Trust for Historic Preservation Offer
Willamette Heritage Center at The Mill

A tour of Mission Mill Museum interprets the history of the Thomas Kay Woolen Mill - designated an American Treasure by the National Park Service - which produced wool products from 1889 to 1962 and represents one of Oregon's earliest and strongest industries. Mission Mill also interprets the history of Jason Lee's Methodist Mission to Oregon which settled in the Willamette Valley in 1834 before the major Oregon Trail migrations. $2 off admission with National Trust for Historic Preservation card.

 

To redeem this special, present your National Trust for Historic Preservation card at the time of purchase. No expiration date. National Trust for Historic Preservation card must be current. 503-585-7012 or www.WillametteHeritage.org

 

Willamette Heritage Center at The Mill's Online Coupon
Willamette Heritage Center at The Mill

A tour of Mission Mill Museum interprets the history of the Thomas Kay Woolen Mill - designated an American Treasure by the National Park Service - which produced wool products from 1889 to 1962 and represents one of Oregon's earliest and strongest industries. Mission Mill also interprets the history of Jason Lee's Methodist Mission to Oregon which settled in the Willamette Valley in 1834 before the major Oregon Trail migrations. $1 off admission when Jason Lee bucks are downloaded from www.WillametteHeritage.org and redeemed at the museum.

To redeem this special, present your Jason Lee bucks at the time of purchase. No expiration date. 503-585-7012 or www.WillametteHeritage.org

 

Northern Lights Package
Shilo Inn Suites Salem

Package includes a one night stay at the Shilo Inn Suites in Salem and a $25 gift certificate good for movie tickets and food and beverages at Northern Lights Theatre Pub. Package price: $94.95 plus tax (additional nights $79.95 plus tax).

To purchase this package call 800-222-2244 or visit www.shiloinns.com. Requires 48 hour notice and has no expiration date.

 

Oregon Golf Package
Grand Hotel in Salem

Enjoy a relaxing night in a suite of your choice before teeing off at the Salem Golf Club. Complimentary breakfast and a late checkout will no doubt assist you in a perfect game of golf for two.

To purchase this package visit www.GrandHotelSalem.com. This package does not have an expiration date.

 

Romance Package
Phoenix Inn Suites South Salem

We do the groundwork for your surprise and you get all of the credit! The Phoenix Inn Suites Romance Package includes a one night stay in our King Spa Suite. Your room will be adorned with truffles and sparkling cider. A $50 gift certificate for McGrath's Fish House is included in the package, as well as a late checkout of 1 p.m. Package price: $199.

To purchase this package, please call 503-581-7004 or visit www.phoenixinnsuites.com. This package does not have an expiration date.

 

Salem Shopping Package
Grand Hotel in Salem

Need a night away before a good day of shopping? Treat yourself to a night in a suite of your choice. A $50 Salem Center gift card, complimentary breakfast buffet, free parking and a late checkout of 1 p.m. top off this package, making your stay relaxing, enjoyable and fun!

To purchase this package, visit www.GrandHotelSalem.com. This package does not have an expiration date.

 

Local Discount & Deal Websites

Door to Door Savings Magazine/GoldStar Media

www.DoorToDoorSavings.com

column4: New Legislation Helps Support Oregonâ€™s Tourism Industry
column5:
What if you didnâ€™t pay your taxes?  Chances are you would face the consequences. Why, then, was Oregon allowing out-of-state, online corporations to dodge their full tax obligations?

House Bill 2656 was introduced to the Oregon Legislature and recently passed. The bill levels the playing field for local transient lodging taxes. These taxes are paid by Online Travel Companies (OTCâ€™s) such as Expedia and Orbitz, and local hoteliers. 

The Oregon Destination Marketing Organization (ODMO) worked cooperatively to assist with the passage of HB 2656. ODMO is a non-profit organization representing destination marketing organizations (such as Travel Salem), convention and visitors bureaus, and chambers of commerce responsible for marketing specific geographic areas as visitor destinations.

Transient lodging tax dollars expended on tourism promotion and activities in our local communities have decreased during the recent economic downturn. This negatively impacts jobs and revenues for the state. One reason for the decrease is that out-of-state companies donâ€™t pay the same amount of transient lodging taxes as our local businesses.

Currently, some rooms booked online through OTCâ€™s do not generate the same amount of taxes as those booked directly through the hotel. In some cases, a hotel enters a contract with an OTC to provide rooms at a discounted rate, i.e. the â€œwholesale cost.â€ù The OTC then posts the rooms at a higher rate to consumers. This is referred to as the â€œwholesale booking model.â€ù

OTCâ€™s typically calculate state and local hotel occupancy taxes based on the â€œwholesale costâ€ù they pay to a hotel, rather than the â€œretail priceâ€ù they charge the customer. This practice results in lower taxes collected by state and local jurisdictions for rooms booked through an OTC, rather than directly with a hotel.

If a guest books a room directly through a hotel, the tax reflects the jurisdictions rate where the hotel is located. For example, Mr. Public books a room in Anytown, USA, through a hotelâ€™s website. The room rate is $100 and Anytown levies a 10% occupancy tax on rooms, so a total of $110 is charged to Mr. Public. The hotel then remits the $10 occupancy tax to the city.

In contrast, if Mr. Public books the same room through an OTC, the charge will still be $110 to cover the room rate, plus the OTCâ€™s â€œtaxes and fees.â€ù  The OTC then calculates the occupancy tax based on what it owes the hotel, rather than what it charged the consumer. Implementing the â€œwholesale booking model,â€ù the OTC remits only $88 to the hotel ($80 for the contracted cost of the room and $8 for the occupancy taxes), and the OTC retains the remaining $22 from the transaction.

Many jurisdictions have become aware of this strategy and have filed lawsuits against some of the OTCâ€™s for these unpaid tax revenues. In response, the OTCâ€™s are seeking legislation that would protect this practice by making it a legitimate tax exemption through a federal preemption of state and local authority.

ODMO has worked with local governments, tourism promotion groups and industry members to develop a statewide standard and to ensure state and local tourism dollars are uniformly collected. House Bill 2656 will establish a statewide standard for the rate for taxes on rooms in Oregon stating, â€œAll rooms in Oregon will be taxed at the room rate paid by the consumer.â€ù This proposal will only apply to future sales of rooms occupied after the time of the enacted date.

HB 2656 will ensure that out-of-state companies, including OTCâ€™s, pay the same amount of taxes as local businesses. This will help level the playing field and maximize the resources our communities have for tourism promotion.

Travel Salem would like to thank ODMO for their work on HB 2656 and for their advocacy for Oregonâ€™s tourism industry.

  • Back to newsletter

column4: Travel Salem Hires New Marketing and Online Manager
column5:
Travel Salem is pleased to announce that Dee Hendrix joined the Travel Salem Marketing and Communications team in June. As the new Marketing and Online Manager, Hendrix will be responsible for managing the Travel Salem website, creation and implementation of e-newsletters and managing the digital needs of Travel Salem programs promoting Salem and Marion and Polk Counties for leisure, convention and event tourism. 

Hendrix brings with her over 17 years experience in the field of advertising, marketing and communications design. Prior to joining Travel Salem, Dee worked as Communications Director for Salemâ€™s nonprofit childrenâ€™s museum, A. C. Gilbertâ€™s Discovery Village. While there, she re-developed and implemented the museumâ€™s communications plan to promote the museum, its educational programs and special events. She was responsible for creating promotional materials, and developing and implementing a thorough website redesign. She also helped A. C. Gilbertâ€™s Discovery Village by promoting events and programs using social media platforms and provided media relations for the museum.

She holds two degrees from Willamette University, with post graduate studies in Natural Science Illustration from Rhode Island School of Design.

â€œI have known Dee for many years and have always been impressed with her online and design expertise,â€ù said Irene Bernards, Travel Salemâ€™s Marketing & PR Director.  â€œTravel Salem is extremely fortunate to have added another seasoned professional to our team. The MarCom department, with Deeâ€™s skill set, will be able to implement some new bells and whistles that will enhance our efforts,â€ù said Bernards.

Dee can be reached at dhendrix@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325, ext. 25.

  • Back to newsletter

column4: Travel Salem Recertified as EarthWISE business
column5:
Travel Salem, the official destination marketing organization for Salem and Marion and Polk counties, is proud to have been recertified EarthWISE. Our Travel CafÃ©/Visitors Center in the historic Grand Hotel building was designed with sustainability in mind, including: reuse of materials saved from demolition; electrical and HVAC zoning changes to conserve energy; and creative use of natural light to reduce electrical use. 

EarthWISE is a free business environmental assistance program for Marion County businesses and non-profits.  

This unique program helps businesses with:
â€¢Recycling 
â€¢Waste reduction and prevention 
â€¢Energy efficiency and conservation 
â€¢Water pollution prevention 
â€¢Outreach and education

The program also recognizes businesses in Marion County that have made a commitment to environmentally friendly practices. Businesses that meet certain criteria in the EarthWISE focus areas may earn EarthWISE certification and will receive public recognition for their green practices.

For more information about how your business may find ways to cut waste and save money, go to: www.mcEarthWISE.net or EarthWISE@co.marion.or.us. You can also contact EarthWISE staff directly at 503 365 3188.

column4: Oregonâ€™s Third Capitol Building Celebrates 75 Years in October
column5:
On October 1, one of Oregonâ€™s most distinctive buildings, The Oregon State Capitol, will turn 75. The Oregon State Capitol Foundationâ€™s Special Events Committee, and Capitol staff, has been hard at work planning a celebration. Visitors will enjoy tours, music and special displays reflecting the history of the Capitol. Plans also include a â€œLight up the Domeâ€ù event with super-sized birthday candles surrounding the Capitol dome.

Rich in history, Oregon's present Capitol has its origins in two fires. On December 30, 1855, fire swept through a newly occupied Statehouse, completely destroying the structure. On April 25, 1935, fire again destroyed the elegant Statehouse patterned after the U.S. Capitol.

The current building was dedicated October 1, 1938. A four-story structure of Modern Greek architecture, it was completed at a cost of $2.5 million. The building houses several elected state officials - the Governor, the Secretary of State, and the State Treasurer - in addition to the entire Legislative Branch of state government. 

A Capitol "Wings" project completed in 1977, at a cost of $12.5 million, added further space for legislative offices, hearing rooms, support services, a first floor galleria, and underground parking.

In the late 1990's a series of health and safety issues were identified in the Capitol wings. The 74th Legislature approved the "Capitol Restoration Project" in June 2007. Work in the Capitol wings took place between July 2007 and November 2008.

Itâ€™s not too late to join the celebration! Do you have an idea or event you would like to host? Please email your event information to capitol.foundation@state.or.us, or email/call juliene.popinga@state.or.us (503-986-1555) for additional information.

column4: Take Advantage of FREE Marketing Resources!
column5:
Photography

We are fortunate to be surrounded by beautiful scenery and a vast array of unique and wonderful venues in the Salem and Mid-Willamette Valley area. Travel Salem wants to share this with visitors and one fantastic way is through photographs!

Images do speak a thousand words and we like to take advantage of that when it comes to promoting our region. At Travel Salem, we carefully select images that inspire and excite the viewer about our exceptional area. 

Digital images are used on the website, in social media posts, and shared with local and national media sources. We also publish a yearly, full-color Salem and Marion/Polk County Area Visitor Guide that is saturated with gorgeous images to entice visitors to our region.

We invite you to submit your photographs taken within Marion and Polk counties that include attractions, gardens, nature, recreation, dining, shopping, events, wine tasting and any other image you think captures the essence of our beautiful area.

If you have images that you would like Travel Salem to consider please review the following criteria:

  • Photos must be a minimum of 300 dpi
  • Photos should include people when possible
  • Photos with people must have a â€˜model releaseâ€™ included that gives permission to use the image(s).

Please submit images either by email or send us a link to Drop Box.

If you have questions contact Irene Bernards, Marketing & PR Director directly at ibernards@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325, ext.27.

Events

The Travel Salem Events Calendar is the local resource for activities and events in Marion and Polk counties. Any venue within the area is qualified to submit information to the calendar, whether a member of Travel Salem, or not. Many of the events on our Events Calendar are cross promoted through our social media channels or pitched to the media. Early event submission is encouraged!  You will receive maximum exposure if your events are posted at least 60 days in advance, if not 3-6 months. This allows Travel Salem time to proof, edit, post and syndicate events to local, regional and national media outlets.

If you have any questions regarding event submission, please contact Dee Hendrix, Marketing and Online Manager at dhendrix@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325, ext. 25.

Salem Area Visitor Guide

The 2013 Travel Salem Visitor Guide highlights lodging, trip ideas and resources in our area. It has been distributed to over 800 locations throughout Oregon, Washington, California and British Columbia. Visitors frequently use the guide to take advantage of all the activities and venues our wonderful area has to offer!

Make sure your business has a good supply!  The Visitor Guide is online at TravelSalem.com, available at the Travel CafÃ© (181 High St. NE) or you can order copies by contacting Barb Cowan, Travel Salem's Guest Services Coordinator at bcowan@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325, ext. 21. 

Watch your email for information on the upcoming 2014 Travel Salem Visitor Guide. It will soon be time to collect information for the next great edition!

If you have questions please contact Irene Bernards, Marketing and PR Director at ibernards@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325, ext. 27.

column4: November 21 -- Travel Salem Marketing Exchange Luncheon
column5:
Travel Salem Marketing Exchange Luncheon
Featuring

THE STATE OF THE INDUSTRY
Keynote Speaker: Angie Morris, President & CEO, Travel Salem

November 21, 2013
(RSVP Recommended)
11:45 a.m.-1:30 p.m.
Willamette Heritage Center

The â€œState of the Industryâ€ù presentation will highlight the achievements and milestones from 2013 and offer insight into whatâ€™s ahead for 2014.
Mark you calendar and make plans to attend this important Marketing Exchange Luncheon!  This is your opportunity to learn how Travel Salem has leveraged funding and promoted the area in creative ways to make a positive impact on the wonderful people and businesses in our region.
Call now to reserve your seat! 503-581-4325, ext. 58

Keynote Speaker: Angie Morris
Angie Morris was hired as the Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of Travel Salem in 2007 after a nationwide search. In 2011, she initiated Senate Bill 442 to create the Wine Country plate, a specialty license plate to support tourism economic growth across the state. This â€œjobs billâ€ù was signed into law by Governor Kitzhaber. As of 2013, there are more than 8,000 of these plates on the road, with the Oregon Wine Country plate being the first of its kind in the United States and the second fastest selling specialty plate in Oregon. In 2008, Angie launched another first with the Travel CafÃ©, the first-ever destination visitors center in the country. The Travel CafÃ© received the 2008 Governorâ€™s Award for Creative Tourism Development and the 2009 Green Building of the Year Award from the Mid-Willamette Valley Green Awards. And in 2007, she received the Governorâ€™s Award for Tourism Industry Awareness.

Before joining Travel Salem, Angie was the Executive Director for Pentacle Theatre, one of the oldest and most respected community theaters in Oregon, where she completed a $1 million capital campaign to renovate the theater.  Prior to that, Angie was the Director of Marketing and Public Relations for the Portland Opera: â€˜Broadway Across Americaâ€™ series where she generated $9-12 million in ticket sales annually. She directed the branding campaign to position Portland Opera as the 14th opera company in North America and propelled the â€˜Broadway Across Americaâ€™ series to â€œtop-tierâ€ù status nationally out of 55 markets.

Angie has a degree in Journalism from the University of Oregon, and lives in Salem with her family.

Promote Your Business: This is your opportunity to promote your business and services! Remember to bring your business cards and brochures for the Marketing Exchange table.

Enter-to-Win!: 
A â€œWoodland Escapeâ€ù trail ride package for two riders - Into the Wild Equine Adventures

Beautiful gift basket filled with goodies - Madrona Hills Ace Hardware

Guests must be present for a chance to win.

  RSVPâ€™s and prepayment of $18 required/$23 at the door. RSVP a must!

Reserve Your Seat Today â€“ Save $5 with advanced registration if purchased by:
Phone â€“ use your credit card by calling 503-581-4325, ext. 58
Mail â€“ send you check to:
Travel Salem Marketing Exchange Luncheon, 181 High St. NE, Salem, OR 97301
Please remember that when we receive your RSVP, we will order and pay for your lunch. If you are unable to attend, payment for lunch is still required.
Thanks for helping to make Travel Salem luncheons a success. 
See you on November 21, 2013!

Travel Salemâ€™s Director of Sales, Debbie McCune, will be representing Salem in Oklahoma City on November 12 during the Amateur Softball Association (ASA) Councilâ€™s annual meeting. The City of Salemâ€™s Softball Recreation Coordinator, Billy Powers, will join McCune as they promote Salem during the bidding process for the 2015 ASA softball tournaments. Communities throughout the United States will be in attendance as they vie to host these highly coveted tournaments which have a significant impact on local economies.  

â€œIt is highly competitive and we are working hard to convince council members that Salem, Oregon is an excellent site for ASA tournaments. We look forward to highlighting Salem during the tradeshow, as well as making a formal presentation in front of the council,â€ù said McCune.  Salem currently hosts Softball City USA (www.softballcityusa.com) at Wallace Marine Park. Softball City USA has received many awards, including the James Farrell award for the excellent tournaments. The 2015 schedule will be announced as soon as possible.

It's time for Oregon lodging properties to update their property listings for the 2014-2015 Travel Oregon Official Visitor Guide. Oregon Restaurant & Lodging Association (ORLA) is the official provider of lodging listings in the guide â€“ the only statewide print piece for comprehensive lodging listings in Oregon. Through a strategic alliance with Travel Oregon, all properties are afforded a free basic listing in this annual printed guide and online at TravelOregon.com. 

To get your listing included in the 2014-15 guides, go online to OregonRLA.org/LodgingListings and log in with the username and password provided in the letter from ORLA. Properties must update or at least verify the listing information is accurate in order to be included in the guides. While members of ORLA are automatically included, non-members are required to verify their information annually.

column4: End of Year Deadline for Economic Development Grant Funds
column5:
December 31 is the deadline to apply for the 2nd cycle of economic development grant funds allocated by Marion County. Grants up to $50,000 will be awarded from a fund provided to Marion County from Oregon Lottery proceeds. The primary purpose of the grant program is to assist private-sector employers to retain and create jobs.

Established private-sector business entities are eligible. Start-ups with less than three years of financial performance and nonprofit organizations are not eligible at this time. Applicants must demonstrate how they will meet the following criteria: 

â€¢ Retain or create jobs;
â€¢ Expand an employerâ€™s services or production;
â€¢ Bring in additional sales revenue from outside Marion County;
â€¢ Enhance the property tax base.

In the first cycle of the grant program earlier this year, four grants were awarded totaling $130,000. For the second cycle, $70,000 is available to award. 

A competitive process is used to score proposals and award funds. The Marion County Economic Development Advisory Board (EDAB) will review and rank all applications, then make recommendations to the Marion County Board of Commissioners for funding approval. The Board of Commissioners holds decision-making authority for all grants. â€œWe have a tremendous resource of experience and knowledge on our Economic Development Advisory Board,â€ù said Commissioner Patti Milne, who had pushed for the creation of EDAB in 2003.  â€œTheir work on this grant program and their continued interest in economic development is greatly appreciated.â€ù

Bill Cummins, chair of EDAB, said, â€œOur volunteer board is eager to stimulate economic development in Marion County and we encourage people to apply. Our priority is to assist employers already based here to strengthen their businesses. We believe economic development is critical to help retain and create jobs, increase revenue from outside sources, and improve the tax base for government and schools.â€ù Mr. Cummins is plant engineer at Diana Foods, a food processing company in Silverton, and is also a member of the Silverton City Council.

Each year, Marion County receives 2.5% of the net revenues of the video lottery games played within the county. According to ORS 461.547, that money is to be targeted toward economic development.  

The grant application form and other materials are available at the Marion County web site at www.co.marion.or.us
