Director of Communications and Interactive Marketing, Oregon Wine Board

February 20, 2014
(RSVP Required) 
11:45 a.m.-1:30 p.m.

Red Lion Hotel 
3301 Market St. NE,  Salem, OR 97301

Call now to reserve your seat! 503-581-4325, ext. 58

Thank you to our sponsors:

Courthouse Fitness Red Lion Hotel - Salem

 

       
       Viva!
      Event Management

 

 

Charles Humble joined the Oregon Wine Board staff in 2011 from a successful career in communications consulting at several agencies in the Portland area. In his current position, he is responsible for all internal and external OWB communications as well as all online and interactive communications. During his tenure at OWB, he has established a strong track record of communicating the successes and opportunities of the Oregon wine industry.

His accomplishments have included producing the winning bid for the 2012 Wine Bloggers Conference held in Portland in 2012. He also orchestrated the communications plan that turned the media environment for the 2011 grape harvest from negative to positive with a focused and hard-hitting campaign that was dubbed "the miracle harvest."

He is a graduate of Linfield College in McMinnville, OR, where he earned a degree in communications. He was a journalist at several Oregon daily newspapers, including the Albany Democrat-Herald, Oregon Journal and The Oregonian before joining the public relations profession.

He was president and CEO of Insync Communications in Portland before the agency was acquired by Waggener Edstrom Worldwide where he was an executive vice president. Charles resides in Vancouver with his wife, Lynne. His hobbies include wine, sports, reading, running and technology.

column4: Celebrating 30 years -- Travel Salem Thanks all Partners
column5:
They say 30 is the new 20.  Well we certainly donâ€™t want to go back 10 years â€“ weâ€™ve come so far! Whether you know us as the Salem Metropolitan Area Convention and Tourism Association (SMACTA) or Salem Convention & Visitors Association (SCVA) or Travel Salem; the fact is your destination marketing organization is celebrating its 30th year in 2014.

SMACTA was formed in 1984 by Salemâ€™s lodging establishments who wanted to see tourism strengthen, grow and prosper in the Salem area. Their goal was to see the tourism industry recognized as an economic development generator and to establish a self-imposed fee to fund the promotion of the Salem area as a visitor, convention and event destination.

Thirty years, and two name changes later, Travel Salem continues to serve as the marketing and public relations arm for Salem as well as Marion and Polk counties.

To thank our many partners for years of support and collaboration we have created a commemorative 30 year anniversary poster. These posters were made possible by Salem Electric, who has been a member of Travel Salem since 1984 and are FREE to each member. 

If you would like a copy of the poster please stop by the Travel Salem office (181 High Street NE) or pick one up at any of our Marketing Exchange Luncheons throughout the year.

Local businesses have benefitted from the results-oriented marketing opportunities that Travel Salem provides its partners. Check out our list of Current & Renewing Members. If you are not on the list, please call us today! We are ready to help you take advantage of all the marketing tools and resources available through Travel Salem, including our quarterly Marketing Exchange Luncheons that provide networking and industry highlighted speakers.

If you know a business interested in partnering to promote the regionâ€™s lucrative $511.3 million tourism industry that employs 6,290 people, please contact Sue Nichols, Travel Salemâ€™s Community Development Director at 503-581-4325, ext. 22 or snichols@TravelSalem.com.

We would like to thank all CURRENT, NEW, and RENEWING members for their continued investment in Travel Salem and the Tourism Industry.  We look forward to working hard for you and your businesses this coming year. 


Thank you and happy anniversary to our Mid-Willamette Valley visitor industry!

  • Back to newsletter

column4: Travel Salem Welcomes New Intern - Amber Barnett

Through the program at Chemeketa, Ms. Barnett has developed an understanding for how invaluable destination marketing organizations are to event planners, as well as to visitors. As an intern at Travel Salem, Barnett intends to expand her knowledge of destination marketing organizations as she prepares to pursue a career in event planning.

  • Posted to TravelOregon.com where the packages are promoted with Travel Oregonâ€™s seasonal travel campaigns. The current campaign is Oregon Wintercation focusing on outdoor recreation which is marketed nation-wide.

column5:
Oregon's Relentless Good News Story

Featuring

Keynote Speaker: Charles Humble,
Director of Communications and Interactive Marketing, Oregon Wine Board

February 20, 2014
(RSVP Required) 
11:45 a.m.-1:30 p.m.

Red Lion Hotel 
3301 Market St. NE,  Salem, OR 97301

Call now to reserve your seat! 503-581-4325, ext. 58

Thank you to our sponsors:

Courthouse Fitness Red Lion Hotel - Salem

 

       
       Viva!
      Event Management

 

Keynote Speaker, Charles Humble: Charles Humble joined the Oregon Wine Board staff in 2011 from a successful career in communications consulting at several agencies in the Portland area. In his current position, he is responsible for all internal and external OWB communications as well as all online and interactive communications. During his tenure at OWB, he has established a strong track record of communicating the successes and opportunities of the Oregon wine industry.

His accomplishments have included producing the winning bid for the 2012 Wine Bloggers Conference held in Portland in 2012. He also orchestrated the communications plan that turned the media environment for the 2011 grape harvest from negative to positive with a focused and hard-hitting campaign that was dubbed "the miracle harvest."

He is a graduate of Linfield College in McMinnville, OR, where he earned a degree in communications. He was a journalist at several Oregon daily newspapers, including the Albany Democrat-Herald, Oregon Journal and The Oregonian before joining the public relations profession.

He was president and CEO of Insync Communications in Portland before the agency was acquired by Waggener Edstrom Worldwide where he was an executive vice president. Charles resides in Vancouver with his wife, Lynne. His hobbies include wine, sports, reading, running and technology.

Promote Your Business: This is your opportunity to promote your business and services! Remember to bring your business cards and brochures for the Marketing Exchange table.

Travel Salem Marketing Exchange Luncheon, 181 High St. NE, Salem, OR 97301

Please remember that when we receive your RSVP, we will order and pay for your lunch. If you are unable to attend, payment for lunch is still required.

Thanks for helping to make Travel Salem luncheons a success.

The annual Travel Salem Absolutely Fabulous Awards Luncheon is an industry event we look forward to every year! Held during National Tourism Month, the "Ab Fab" Awards recognizes tourism industry partners who have gone above and beyond in 2013-14 to promote Salem and the Mid-Willamette Valley. These award recipients are professionals who have ventured â€œoutside the boxâ€ù to engage visitors with fresh ideas and content to ensure the best returns on their marketing, collaboration, partnerships, innovation and regional strategies! They are Absolutely Fabulous!

Enjoy a fun, thought-provoking afternoon at Salem Conference Center while networking with industry peers and celebrating National Tourism Month. The $511.3 million generated by visitors each year to the Salem area along with 6,290 direct jobs, is significant and worth commemorating!

column4: Put Your Business On The Map
column5:
Travel Salem is pleased to announce the launch of Phase II of the Interactive Online Map (IOM), including an upgrade to the original map produced for Phase I. This versatile tool is designed to provide visitors to the TravelSalem.com website with an easy-to-use resource to help plan their Mid-Willamette Valley experience. 

Currently, the map targets our regionâ€™s diverse cultural and heritage assets. Phase II, which we will begin to populate by early April, showcases the following categories: 

  • Culture/Heritage (e.g. historic museums, galleries, theaters, cultural museums)
  • Vineyards/Wineries (e.g. must be a producing vineyard or winery)
  • Specialty Food & Beverage (e.g. cheese maker, cider maker, coffee roaster, bread maker, candy manufacturer. No restaurants.)
  • Recreation (e.g. hiking, biking, horseback riding, golf, rafting, fishing)
  • Farms /Markets (e.g. farmers markets, farm stands, farms that allow tours)
  • Gardens
  • Birding/Nature (e.g. Baskett Slough, natural area)

    • The IOM is also a great tool to help local residents discover the wonderful resources we have in our own backyard. This makes it a great resource when planning staycations with family and friends.

    The IOM offers points of interest (POI) that will attract new visitors and lengthen the stay of current visitors to the region (Salem, Polk County, Marion County).  Since the map is interactive, visitors can see the general location of the POI. They can then zoom in as far as street level and scroll over an icon which opens a pop-up with the name of the business and a brief description. A corresponding list with photos is also located in the left sidebar and provides a direct link to businesses. 

    The Travel Salem IOM illustrates how much there is to see and do in our region, while also promoting visitation. Phase I of this project was funded by a Travel Oregon grant and Phase II is made possible through a Polk County grant.

    Want to know if your business qualifies for a listing on Travel Salemâ€™s Interactive Online Map? Please contact Dee Hendrix, Marketing and Online Manager at 503-581-4325, ext. 25 or email: dhendrix@travelsalem.com. 

    Absolutely promoting Salem and the Mid-Willamette Valley!

    • Back to newsletter

column4: Literary Life and History of Salem Featured on C-SPAN
column5:
You may have noticed the colorful vans sporting the C-SPAN logo around Salem the week of February 2 and wondered what C-SPAN was doing in Salem. Known as LCVs (or Local Content Vehicles), the vans carried producers with C-SPANâ€™s Cities Tour, who were on a quest to interview local historians, civic leaders and authors for a series of programs about Salem that aired on Book TV and American History TV in early March. 

Salem area historical sites featured on C-SPAN included the Oregon State Capitol, the Museum of Mental Health at the Oregon State Hospital, the Thomas Kay Woolen Mill at Willamette Heritage Center and the Asahel Bush House and Museum. 

Four local authors, including three professors from Willamette University, were also featured. The C-SPAN team also spoke with local cherry growers about the history and significance of the cherry industry in the Mid-Willamette Valley. 

The programs aired on Book TV/C-SPAN2 (Comcast channel 25) and American History TV/C-SPAN3 (Comcast channel 106) on March 1 and 2, but you can also view them on the â€œSalemâ€ù page of the C-SPAN Cities Tour website. 

  • Back to newsletter

column4: The Best of Oregon for Summer Vacations
column5:
'Must See Oregon' to Help Plan Vacations

From outdoor adventures and resorts to craft brews and worldâ€êrenowned wines, Oregon has it all. The stateâ€™s vast array of attractions, destinations, travel, and extended vacation opportunities will be showcased at the first annual Must See Oregon event, presented by Capitol Subaru and coordinated by Class Act Events in partnership with The Oregon Garden, Travel Oregon and Travel Salem.

Must See Oregon will be held at The Oregon Garden in Silverton on Saturday, May 17 from 10 a.m.to 6 p.m. Admission to both the event and The Oregon Garden will be free that day.  Must See Oregon will spotlight the spirit that makes this state great and the destinations and points of interest that will help you explore and enjoy all that Oregon has to offer. Attendees will learn about museums, resorts, cruises and all sorts of adventures around the state.

â€œThere is no other showcase like this in Oregon,â€ù said Must See Oregon organizer Susan Adkins. â€œWe have so many exciting opportunities in this state and youâ€™ll have one place to go for a glimpse of Oregonâ€™s best kept secrets.â€ù

Throughout the day, visitors will be immersed in opportunities to learn more about Oregonâ€™s treasured tourism opportunities, hidden in every corner of the state. There will be exhibitors from around the state, activities such as fly casting demonstrations and live presentations from travel experts such as Steve Arndt, author of Roads Less Traveled in Oregon, to help with trip planning.

For more information visit: www.MustSeeOr.com
Facebook: facebook.com/mustseeor
Twitter: @mustseeoregon
Instagram: instagram.com/mustseeoregon

Give us your best pitch! Once again, Travel Salem invites representatives from area businesses and organizations to share your best ideas for our â€œcontent libraryâ€ù that we can use for potential pitches to the media or for use in blogs, social media posts or other publications.  This yearâ€™s Speed Pitching open house will occur on Wednesday, May 21. Anyone representing a Marion or Polk county business, group or nonprofit is invited to drop in between 1 p.m. and 5 p.m. and share whatâ€™s new and newsworthy at your organization.

What constitutes a â€œnewsworthyâ€ù pitch? Basically, weâ€™re looking for ideas that are unusual, innovative and timely. If your organization or business has recently launched â€“ or is planning to launch â€“ a new product, service, event, or program that is unique and of interest to a large audience (especially visitors), we want to hear about it.

Hereâ€™s how it works:

  • No pre-registration necessary. Drop by the Travel Salem Travel CafÃ© & Visitors Center (located at 181 High St. NE in Salem) any time between 1 p.m. and 5 p.m. on Wednesday, May 21.
  • The person(s) representing the business or organization will have 15 minutes (maximum) to share their news with a member of Travel Salemâ€™s marketing staff.
  • Please send no more than 2 people per organization.
  • If you are pitching an event, it needs to occur in late 2014 or 2015. (Most of the regional and national publications we target request information 3-4 months in advance).

Youâ€™re welcome to bring a short, one-page summary of your pitch or a supporting document (i.e. a brochure, flyer, rack card).

While we hope to utilize as many of the ideas as possible, Travel Salem cannot guarantee that an idea will be used or published.

If you cannot attend Speed Pitching, but would like to submit an idea, email it to kkuh@travelsalem.com. We look forward to hearing all of your creative ideas!

column4: Spring is a Time of Renewal
column5:
It may be time for your renewal! Your membership with Travel Salem is a valuable marketing partnership. Keep your membership current and take advantage of your membership benefits.

At Travel Salem, our marketing professionals actively promote Salem and the Mid-Willamette Valley utilizing strategically designed sales and marketing campaigns. Curious about how our marketing efforts impact your business? Ever wonder how your membership impacts our regionâ€™s visitor industry? Letâ€™s take a look.

We are proud to share these highlights of a very successful year:

  • The 2012-13 estimated economic impact of visitors was $511.3 million. Specifically, travel-generated income for Marion & Polk counties. This represents a 2.7% increase over the previous year. Projections indicate a continued upward trend as market conditions reflect an improving economy.
  • The 2012-13 transient occupancy tax (lodging tax) kept pace with the previous year by generating $2.6 million in revenues for Salem. Occupancy was up 7% to 364,608 room nights sold. Average daily rates continue to rise. Already, reports reflect the 13-14 transient occupancy tax is up 13% over 12-13. 
  • The Willamette Valley received Trip Advisorâ€™s â€˜Travelerâ€™s Choice ~ Best U.S. Wine Destinationâ€™ â€“ ranking 3rd out of the top 10 wine destinations in the United States, after Napa and Sonoma. Our region proudly offers visitors from all over the globe an experience rich with culinary, recreational and cultural heritage assets.

Travel Salem works hard for your business, year-round. Our efforts and your support create a strong marketing momentum that benefits both residents and visitors in our region. Thank you for your support through the renewal of your 2014-15 membership. As a Travel Salem member, you are a vital part of our regionâ€™s destination marketing organization and the results we achieve. 

Thank you for renewing your commitment to our regionâ€™s visitor industry as a member of Travel Salem!

  • Back to newsletter

column4: Travel: Itâ€™s Not Just for Vacation Anymore
column5:
For most of us, â€œtravelâ€ù invokes ideas boarding a plane or cruise ship, or maybe loading a cooler, tent and the family dog into the back of a minivan. But lately, a picture has emerged of travel as a health regimenâ€”for our bodies and minds, our family relationships and our countryâ€™s economy.

Take, for instance, jobs. The Bureau of Labor Statistics reports that the U.S. travel industry recovered faster than other economic sectors. Since losing close to half a million jobs in the Great Recession, the travel industry has added 697,000 jobs and has outpaced job creation by the rest of the economy by 49 percent.

But unless you work for the airlines or own a hotel, does the travel rebound mean much to the average American? The answer is a resounding yes.

Travel is among the top 10 employers in 49 states, directly employing about eight million people at a payroll of $209 billion. Throw in jobs supported by travel and the number almost doubles to 15 million workers: one of every nine American jobs.

In Oregon, travel and tourism generates $9.6 billion and directly supports nearly 94,000 jobs. In the Salem area, the industry generates $537.2 in economic impact and supports 6,110 jobs.   

But travel doesnâ€™t just grow our economy and boost our productivity; it also connects us as people, keeps us healthy and makes us happy. People who travel are less stressed and happier at work. Eight in 10 seniors say travel makes them feel energized. And our travel memories stay with us: studies show that into our 50s and beyond, we remember childhood trips more vividly than birthday parties or other special occasions.

So, as we celebrate National Travel & Tourism Month this May, please take a few minutes to think about how you can support and encourage travel â€” perhaps as an employer, as a leader in your community or even just for you and your family. Itâ€™s worth our investment, and the travel effect pays us back in spades.

Back to newsletter

column4: 2014-15 Salem Area Visitor Guide Now Available
column5:
Share the wonders of our area with visitors! Keep a supply of the official visitor guide for Salem and Marion and Polk counties at your location. This free, full-color guide features trip ideas highlighting attractions, events, recreation, gardens and the liquid artistry of the area.

Request a Visitor Guide by mail
View Digital Visitor Guide

It also includes useful transportation, resource and relocation information promoting our beautiful, unique area.

â€œThe Salem Area Visitors Guide is a valuable resource for consumers during their vacation planning phase, as well as once they are on the ground in the region. With five maps, compelling articles, vibrant photography and hundreds of listings promoting regional treasures - this is the promotional piece that attracts diverse interests. We listen to the needs of the visitor and deliver the information they are requesting,â€ù said Irene Bernards, Marketing & PR Director.

The guides are distributed to over 800 locations throughout Oregon, Washington, California and British Columbia. A digital version is also available for viewing at TravelSalem.com.

Travel Salem would like to thank all of the businesses and organizations who contributed to promoting our wonderful region through advertising, providing photography and helping to distribute this valuable resource for our region.

Businesses are encouraged to order the Salem Area Visitor Guide by contacting Barb Cowan at 503-581-4325, ext 21 or email a request to bcowan@TravelSalem.com. Visitor Guides may also be picked up at the Travel CafÃ© Visitors Center, located in historic downtown Salem at 181 High Street NE.

column4: Salem Area Businesses Recognized at â€œAbsolutely Fabulousâ€ù Awards Luncheon
column5:
Angie Morris, CEO of Travel Salem presents Steve Martin, Historic Elsinore Theatre with the "Absolutely Entertaining" Award.

Travel Salem announced the recipients of this yearâ€™s â€œAbsolutely Fabulousâ€ù awards at the fifth annual â€œAb Fabâ€ù awards luncheon, held on Thursday, May 15, at the Salem Convention Center.

The â€œAb Fabâ€ù awards recognize tourism industry partners who go above and beyond to increase the economic impact of visitors. The award recipients are movers and shakers who turn ideas upside down and inside out to capture the best returns on their marketing, collaborations, partnerships and strategies. 

This year, Travel Salem presented six business partners with awards:

â€¢ The Absolutely Entertaining Award was presented to the Historic Elsinore Theatre for consistently bringing quality entertainment to the Salem area and for their commitment in preserving one of Salemâ€™s historic treasures.


â€¢ Baumanâ€™s Farm and Gardens received the Absolutely Authentic Award for their understanding of how agriculture and tourism work together and for providing visitors with an authentic Oregon agricultural experience.  


â€¢ Garten Services, Inc. was presented with the Absolutely Valuable Award for their unparalleled partnership, which allows Travel Salem to effectively reach consumers, resulting in a positive economic impact on the region.


â€¢ For choosing Salem as the 2013 site for their international motorcycle rally and generating approximately $1.7 million in economic impact, The BMW Motorcycles Owners of America Association received the Absolutely â€œHeads in Bedsâ€ù Award.


â€¢ The Absolutely â€œTrail Blazingâ€ù Award went to the Salem Area Trail Alliance for their continued efforts in building new trail systems for both visitors and residents to enjoy.


â€¢ For their ability to transport the worldâ€™s diverse cultures to Salem and for bringing thousands of visitors to the area to view the â€œBreath of Heavenâ€ù ancient Near East art exhibit, The Absolutely Fabulous Award was presented to the Hallie Ford Museum of Art.

â€œWe are extremely proud to honor these amazing people in the tourism sector, who, through their tireless work, creative energy and remarkable vision, make the Salem area one of the best places on the planet to call home!â€ù said CEO of Travel Salem, Angie Morris, about the recipients of this yearâ€™s Ab Fab awards. â€œThey truly have demonstrated a commitment to creating the best of what Salem has to offer, helping to strengthen community and building the travel industry in powerful ways.â€ù 

Back to newsletter

column5:
The 3rd Annual Capitol Cup Soccer Tournament will return to Salem, June 27-29 2014. The tournament has quickly become one of the favorite tournaments to kick off the summer soccer season and is expecting to draw over 150 teams, with an estimated economic impact to Salem of over $750,000.  All games will occur in Salem.

All of the fields are conveniently located to restaurants, tax-free shopping and great hotels. Teams traveling to the tournament will have access to a personal travel coordinator. The coordinator can help you find the hotel that will best suit the teams and can help arrange team dinner reservations and assist with scheduling team activities around your soccer games.

Nearly 90% of all teams will have a single game on Friday, which allows the organizers to honor requests for late starts. For the most part, teams will have two games on Saturday with games occurring between 9 a.m. to 7:30 p.m. All teams should plan on playing at least one game on Sunday and those games will occur from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.

All teams are guaranteed four games and each team will advance to the playoff rounds once the preliminary rounds have been completed. First and second place bracket champions will receive medals. Championship photos will be available to all families after the tournament. Players, coaches and managers listed on the roster will receive a customized souvenir pin.

For more information go to www.capitalcup.org to find out why the Capital Cup should be the event to kick-start your summer soccer season!

Back to newsletter

column4: Reminder ~ Travel Salem Seeks Story Ideas
column5:
Speed Pitching Open House
Wednesday, May 21
1-5 p.m.  

Give us your best pitch! Share your best ideas for our â€œcontent libraryâ€ù that we can use for potential pitches to the media or for use in blogs, social media posts or other publications. Anyone representing a Marion or Polk county business, group or nonprofit is invited to drop in between 1 p.m. and 5 p.m. and share whatâ€™s new and newsworthy at your organization.

Hereâ€™s how it works:

  • No pre-registration necessary. Drop by the Travel Salem Travel CafÃ© & Visitors Center (located at 181 High St. NE in Salem) any time between 1 p.m. and 5 p.m. on Wednesday, May 21.
  • The person(s) representing the business or organization will have 15 minutes (maximum) to share their news with a member of Travel Salemâ€™s marketing staff.
  • Please send no more than 2 people per organization.
  • If you are pitching an event, it needs to occur in late 2014 or 2015. (Most of the regional and national publications we target request information 3-4 months in advance).

Youâ€™re welcome to bring a short, one-page summary of your pitch or a supporting document (i.e. a brochure, flyer, rack card).

While we hope to utilize as many of the ideas as possible, Travel Salem cannot guarantee that an idea will be used or published.

If you cannot attend Speed Pitching, but would like to submit an idea, email it to kkuh@TravelSalem.com. We look forward to hearing all of your creative ideas!

Interested in promoting your business to out-of-town visitors this summer? Travel Salem is gathering coupons, special offers and promotional items (restaurant offers are especially needed) to include at on-site welcome tables and/or in visitor information packets. 

Here is a sample of some larger groups traveling to Salem soon:

June 27-29 Capital Cup Soccer Tournament est. 1,000 people
Summer 2014 Hoop Basketball Tournaments est. 12,000 people
Summer 2014 ASA Western Nationals Softball Tournament est. 15,000 people
August 2014  League of Oregon Charter Schools est. 200 people
September 2014          Gideonâ€™s International Convention est. 600 people

To promote your business to these visitors, mail or deliver coupons, special offers and/or promotional items to Travel Salem (181 High Street, Salem, OR 97301). Please provide a quantity for all events, or pick which group youâ€™d like to target (see numbers above). Please contact Tara Preston, Services Manager at 503-581-4325 ext. 58 or Tpreston@TravelSalem.com with any questions.

Coming right up, Salem will host the 3rd Annual Capital Cup Soccer Tournament, held June 27-29, 2014. More than 175 teams from Oregon and Washington will gather in Salem to compete for the honor of being named the Capital Cup Soccer Tournament champions. There will be multiple champions since the tournament is divided by gender and grade level, 3rd through 12th.

Multiple venues from throughout the Salem area will be used, including Capital FC Timbers Complex, Corban University, Geer Park, McKay High School, River Road Park, Salem Academy Christian School, Sprague High School, South Salem High School, Wallace Marine Park, West Salem High School and Willamette University.

The estimated economic impact of this event is $720,000, which is significant to Salem. Each team has an average of 15 players, plus the families that travel with the teams to support their children.  

Travel Salem has been working with the Capital Cup Soccer organizers and they have partnered with 13 local hotels to assist with housing the teams.

Join us as we welcome these visitors and provide them with information, deals and resources that make our region an exciting place to visit!

Back to newsletter

column5:
Travel Salem has created two new positions to enhance the regional marketing program to align Salem and the Mid-Willamette Valley as a unique destination and to attract events, conventions and visitors to our area.

Travel Salem is seeking a professional sales person with strong sports and event marketing skills for the position of Sports & Events Sales Manager. The main focus will be to promote and sell the Salem region as a sports and events destination.

Travel Salem is also seeking a professional with strong development and collaborative skills and experience for the position of Destination Development Manager. This position will facilitate and coordinate product development (e.g. festivals, events, attractions) in a multi-county region. 

Back to newsletter

column4: New Scenic Bikeway Rolls Through Marion County
column5:
The Oregon State Parks and Recreation Commission approved the new Cascading Rivers Scenic Bikeway in June. The Oregon Scenic Bikeways program now features 12 designated bikeways statewide. 

The Cascading Rivers Bikeway rolls through 70-miles of forested cascade foothills between Estacada and Detroit. With elevations gains of 3,125-feet near Estacada and a 1,985-foot climb near Detroit, the route offers challenges and beautiful scenery for experienced riders. A family-friendly ten-mile round trip begins on Faraday Road near Estacada, which is closed to motor vehicles.

The route follows the Breitenbush River and the nationally designated Wild and Scenic Clackamas River. There are plans for signage to be posted designating this new route by late summer. The route will be closed during late fall and winter due to snow. 

Information to plan a ride can be found on RideOregonRide.com, including a printable map, accommodations and amenities along the route.

Back to newsletter

column4: Become a Bike Friendly Business  and Enhance Your Exposure to Bicyclists
column5:
Oregon loves bicyclists. Bicycle-related tourism contributes $400 million to Oregonâ€™s economy â€“ approximately $1.1 million per day. Your business may be able to tap into this growing segment of Oregonâ€™s economy by participating in Travel Oregonâ€™s Bike Friendly Business program. The program is free and will give tourism-related businesses special recognition through Travel Oregonâ€™s marketing channels, including RideOregonRide.com, Oregonâ€™s premier website promoting bicycle travel and TravelOregon.com, Oregonâ€™s official travel website. Once your business is officially recognized, youâ€™ll also receive a Bike Friendly toolkit, stickers, window clings and a website link where you can purchase your customized Bike Friendly sign. To apply or learn more, go here.

column4: Interactive Map Highlights Resources for Visitors
column5:
Travel Salem's Interactive Online Map (IOM) is an easy-to-use digital tool that helps visitors plan their Mid-Willamette Valley experience. 

The IOM highlights the wonderful resources we have in our region. The following categories on the IOM feature points of interest in our area: 

  • Culture/Heritage 
  • Vineyards/Wineries 
  • Specialty Food & Beverage 
  • Recreation 
  • Farms/Markets 
  • Gardens
  • Birding/Nature 

Visitors can view a general region of interest, which will populate with icons representing specific venues. A viewer can zoom in as far as street level and scroll over an icon, which opens a pop-up with the name of the business, image and brief description. Vistors can also take advantage of direct links to websites for each venue. 

Find out if your business qualifies for a listing on Travel Salemâ€™s Interactive Online Map! Contact Sue Nichols, Community Development Director at 503-581-4325, ext. 22 or email: snichols@travelsalem.com. 

Absolutely promoting Salem and the Mid-Willamette Valley!

column4: Registration Opens for the Oregon Rural Tourism Studio Program
column5:
Polk County Residents Invited to Participate September 2014 â€“ January 2015

Oregonâ€™s Rural Tourism Studio (RTS), offered by Travel Oregon, is now open for registration. The fall/winter program will focus on communities in Polk County, including The Confederated Tribes of the Grand Ronde, Dallas, Falls City, Independence, Monmouth and Willamina. 

Oregonâ€™s RTS program is a series of tourism development workshops designed to assist rural communities interested in stimulating their local economies through sustainable tourism development, while protecting and enhancing local resources.  

Community leaders, tourism business entrepreneurs, tour operators, lodging property owners, land managers, guides, outfitters, outdoor enthusiasts, restaurateurs, and anyone interested in strengthening the local economy through tourism are encouraged to participate in the program. 

Although Travel Oregon recommends that participants attend all workshops and events in order to maximize the impact from the RTS program, community members are encouraged to attend any workshop or event they can. Participants who attend at least four of the six workshops or events will receive a certificate of completion from Travel Oregon. 

The cost to participate in any one workshop is $5 (and includes lunch), or $25 for all six workshops. Space is limited to 50 participants per workshop. For a complete list of workshops, dates and registration information, go to Industry.TravelOregon.com/PolkCounty. 

To find out more about the Polk County RTS, contact Shawn Irvine with the City of Independence at irvine.shawn@ci.independence.or.us or 503-837-1191.

Back to newsletter

Travel Salem is pleased to announce the addition of three new staff members to its team. 

Kristine Lindholm,
Administrative Assistant
Brian Chung,
Sports and Events Sales Manager
Lourdes Gomez,
Destination Development Manager

Kristine Lindholm is the new administrative assistant for Travel Salem. Originally from Eastern Oregon, Kristine has 15 years of customer service and hospitality experience. She currently serves in a dual role for Travel Salem, working on various projects in an administrative capacity three days a week and working in the Travel CafÃ© and Visitors Center two days each week. Prior to joining Travel Salem as a paid employee, Kristine volunteered her time assisting visitors in the Travel CafÃ© and Visitors Center. Contact Kristine at 503-581-4325 x30 or email: klindholm@travelsalem.com.

Brian Chung joins the organization as the new sports and events sales manager. In this new role, Brian is responsible for bringing new sporting events to the Salem area as well as helping current events grow and expand. Brian has more than eight years of experience in the tourism industry, including serving as the group sales manager for Visit Alexandria and as the national sales manager for Choose Chicago. He holds a degree in tourism administration from Bowling Green State University. Brian can be reached at (503) 581-4325 x59 or bchung@travelsalem.com. 

Lourdes Gomez is Travel Salemâ€™s new destination development manager and will focus on facilitating the development of new and existing tourism products and opportunities in the region. Most recently, Lourdes worked as an international sales manager for Choose Chicago. She also worked in tourism sales for the Mexico Tourism Board.  Lourdes is a graduate of Northeastern Illinois University and holds a masterâ€™s degree from Ohio University. Contact her at (503) 581-4325 x33 or by email: lgomez@travelsalem.com. 

â€œWeâ€™re so pleased to have these three talented new staff members join our team,â€ù says Travel Salem CEO Angie Morris. â€œEach one brings a wealth of expertise and experience to their respective roles, which will help us generate an even greater positive economic impact for our region.â€ù

Back to newsletter

column4: Introducing a New Partnership Program Between SwipeNow and Travel Salem
column5:
Travel Salemâ€™s new direct credit card merchant processing alliance with SwipeNow has the potential to save your business thousands of dollars a year in merchant processing fees! If you accept credit cards for payment at your business you know how quickly merchant processing fees add up. By becoming a local direct processor and pooling together the purchasing power of hundreds of Travel Salemâ€™s members, SwipeNow is able to provide association members with an average savings of 23% off other card processing rates.

SwipeNowâ€™s benefits include: 

  • A local Direct processor that works directly with your business
  • Guaranteed lowest rates
  • Free terminal paper and supplies for terminals
  • Free special event loaners
  • A+ Better Business Rating along with superior local customer service
  • No application fees or start up costs for non processors

To schedule a free cost savings analysis or to start taking credit cards, contact Tim Holstein at 503-975-0660 or email him at timh@swipenow.com

column4: 2015 GOLD 16U National Championship Heads West to Salem
column5:
The Amateur Softball Association (ASA) of America and USA Softball announced that the 2015 ASA/USA Girlsâ€™ 18-Under and 16-Under Fast Pitch GOLD National Championships, two of the most prominent tournaments in Junior Olympic (JO) play, will be hosted by the Oregon ASA. The 16U GOLD, which will be held in Salem, Ore., and the 2015 18U GOLD, which will be held in Hillsboro, Ore., are slated for July 19-25, 2015.

Known as the "Softball Capital of the Northwest", Salem, Ore. will host the 16U GOLD at Wallace Marine Park. The complex features five playing fields and is the original star designed complex in the nation. Wallace Marine Park Softball Complex opened in 1986 and was renovated in  2007, when the City of Salem Public Works Recreation Services took over running the park full time. The infields and outfields were also refurbished in 2012 after the complex was completely flooded. All fields at the complex are lighted, have scoreboards and bleacher seating, with Les Schwab Championship Stadium Field as the main field for championship games. The complex sits at the edge of the beautiful Willamette River and is a short walk across the pedestrian walking bridge to Salem's Riverfront Park which sits on the edge of Salem's vibrant downtown. 

"Salem looks forward to welcoming the 2015 16U ASA/USA GOLD participants, their families and the high caliber of play during the tournament," said Mayor of Salem Anna Peterson. "Salem is a major softball City and our partnership with this tournament is proof that Salem and softball go hand in hand.â€ù

As the capital city, Salem offers visitors a variety of restaurants, attractions and historic sites and museums. Rich with historic sites, tax-free shopping, museums, galleries, parks, wineries and outdoor recreation, Salem offers several historic properties and attractions that are located within walking distance of downtown. The city has a long history with ASA/USA Softball and has hosted 21 ASA/USA National Championships, including the 2003 18U GOLD National Championship and five girls' fast pitch Western Territory National Championships. This year Salem, also known as Softball City USA, hosted the ASA/USA Girls' Fast Pitch 10U and 12U Class A Western National Championship July 27-August 3, 2014, and the Men's Slow Pitch Class D Western National Championship August 30-September 1, 2014.

â€œIt is an honor to host the 2015 16U ASA/USA GOLD in Salem,â€ù said Debbie McCune, director of sales for Travel Salem, Marion and Polk Counties' destination marketing organization. â€œIn Salem we recognize the tremendous dedication it takes from the players to get to this level, and Travel Salem will do everything in our power to make sure this an experience that the players and their families will never forget.â€ù

Back to newsletter
column6:
The Amateur Softball Association (ASA) of America and USA Softball announced that the 2015 ASA/USA Girlsâ€™ 18-Under and 16-Under Fast Pitch GOLD National Championships, two of the most prominent tournaments in Junior Olympic (JO) play, will be hosted by the Oregon ASA. The 16U GOLD, which will be held in Salem, Ore., and the 2015 18U GOLD, which will be held in Hillsboro, Ore., are slated for July 19-25, 2015.

Known as the "Softball Capital of the Northwest", Salem, Ore. will host the 16U GOLD at Wallace Marine Park.

column5:
The Travel Salem convention and events sales staff will be covering a lot of ground in November!

Brian Chung, sports and events sales manager will be attending the TEAMS! tradeshow in Las Vegas and Debbie McCune, director of sales will be attending the Amateur Softball Association (ASA) Annual Council Meeting and Tradeshow in Reno. Both of these sales missions will be directly targeting sports events decision makers and making the pitch for them to choose the Salem, Oregon region for their next event.

At the ASA meeting and tradeshow, Travel Salem will partner with the City of Salem to bid on National softball tournaments for 2016. At the TEAMS! tradeshow, the focus will be on introducing our new sports brand â€œTravel Salem Sports â€“ Absolutely Oregonâ€ù to planners we have never met before and to invite them to hold their events in the Salem region.

â€œThis is such an exciting time for the convention and events sales department, said Debbie. "Brian and I will be gone at the same time in November to these tradeshows and the amount of people weâ€™ll have an opportunity to reach in one week will be substantial!â€ù

Back to newsletter

column4: Lodging Properties ~ Remember to list in Travel Oregon Guide
column5:
It's time for lodging properties to update property listings for the 2015-2016 Travel Oregon Official Visitor Guide. Oregon Restaurant & Lodging Association (ORLA) is the official provider of lodging listings in the guide â€“ the only statewide print piece for comprehensive lodging listings in Oregon. Through a strategic alliance with Travel Oregon, all properties are afforded a free basic listing in this annual printed guide and online at TravelOregon.com. 

Here is how to make sure your property is included:
To get your listing included in the 2015-2016 guides, go online to OregonRLA.org/LodgingListings and log in with the username and password provided in the letter from ORLA. Properties must update or at least verify the listing information is accurate in order to be included in the guides. While members of ORLA are automatically included, non-members are required to verify their information annually. 

If you did not receive a letter in the mail from ORLA:
For new properties (or if you did not receive login credentials) you will need to complete the Basic Listing Form available online. http://www.oregonrla.org/Documents/BasicListingForm-2014-prf1.pdf.

All updates for the listings must be completed by November 25, 2014.

Back to newsletter

column5:
In 2010, American Express founded Small Business Saturday to help businesses with their most pressing need â€” getting more customers. The day encourages people to shop small businesses on the Saturday after Thanksgiving. People across the country are organizing events to celebrate the small businesses in their communities. The single day has grown into a powerful movement, and more people are taking part than ever before. This year, the big day is Nov 29.

Back to newsletter

column4: Draw Visitors to Your Business with Creative Travel Packages
column5:
Whether it is a limited time offer or an annual travel package, itâ€™s time to create a special travel package for your business or organization by collaborating with one of your neighbors. If you need ideas or help contact Sue Nichols, Travel Salemâ€™s Community Development Director at snichols@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325 ext. 22.

The opportunities in the near and distant future are plentiful:

Holiday packages
There are plenty of holidays and themes throughout the year that fit a travel package: Christmas and shopping, Valentineâ€™s Day and romance, Memorial Day & Thanksgiving wineries, Independence Day all-American activities and many more. Just look at your calendar, contact Travel Salem and plan ahead.

Wine packages
Since we live in the middle of the richest wine country in the world, letâ€™s partner to bring those wine visitors here.  The wineries are always looking for partners to enhance their offerings and they have year-round opportunities.  Look at TravelSalem.com for a list of member wineries that will be happy you called.

2017 Eclipse packages 
Yes, we are already taking calls for the 2017 Solar Eclipse. Oregon is the perfect viewing location for the 2017 Eclipse and we want to be sure the Salem area has travel packages ready to meet consumer demand. Remember Travel Salem is here to help you. For more information about the 2017 Eclipse visit: http://eclipse.gsfc.nasa.gov/SEgoogle/SEgoogle2001/SE2017Aug21Tgoogle.html

Spring & Summer packages 
With a blink of the eye, spring will be here. Start thinking about packages you would like to create and have them ready by January for Travel Salem to promote. Families are thinking about spring break and summer vacations, so start planning now. 

Back to newsletter

If you need ideas or help contact Sue Nichols, Travel Salemâ€™s Community Development Director at snichols@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325 ext. 22.

column4: Something Red Art Walk and Exhibit
column5:
The 12th Annual Something Red Artwalk and Exhibit is a juried show that brings the arts-in-community to downtown Salem. Travel Salem is participating as a host business for display of art during this month-long show.

The success of past years continues as Something Red highlights the holiday season for Salem visitors and residents. The event brings vitality, ambiance and a sense of arts-in-community to downtown Salem. Participating artists benefit from sales and contacts as artwork is on display to the public during the holiday month of December. This year the event is scheduled for December 3 through December 31. 

The Art Walk opening night will be Wednesday, December 3 from 5-7 p.m. Mark your calendar and plan to stroll downtown Salem, meet the artists and enjoy some great art! For more information visit www.somethingred.org.

Back to newsletter

column5:
Photography
Travel Salem welcomes the submission of photographic images, taken within Marion and Polk counties, featuring the resources and venues of our area. Image content may include attractions, gardens, nature, recreation, dining, shopping, events, wine tasting or any image that helps tell the story of our wonderful Mid-Willamette Valley.

A picture does say a thousand words and we speak volumes every day with high-quality images from many talented photographers. Photographs help develop the first impression a visitor has of our area. Images are used in our print, online and social media marketing platforms. If you would like Travel Salem to consider your photographic images, please review the following criteria:

â€¢ Photos must be high resolution and a minimum of 300 dpi
â€¢ Photos should be experiential and include people when possible.
â€¢ Photos with people must have a â€œmodel releaseâ€ù included that gives permission to use images.

If you have images that meet the criteria please send them to:

Irene Bernards, Marketing & PR Director
Travel Salem, 181 High St. NE, Salem, Oregon 97301
ibernards@TravelSalem.com 

If you have questions contact Irene directly at ibernards@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325 ext. 27.

Your Events, Workshops, Classes and Activities
Please remember to submit your events for 2015 to the TravelSalem.com Event Calendar through this easy-to-use online form. Thousands of visitors and residents view the Travel Salem Event Calendar every month! The event content is utilized in weekly Event E-blasts and monthly Industry E-news, both with a very broad reach. 

The Travel Salem Marketing Department also refers to the Event Calendar when pitching story ideas to the media. In fact, we are already pitching summer and fall 2015 story ideas! The sooner you submit events, the more impact they may have on visitors, trip planners, promoters and the media. Travel Salem also submits events to the Travel Oregon website (some criteria apply).

For your event to receive maximum exposure please submit it at least 60 days before the actual event. This gives Travel Salem time to proof, edit, post and syndicate your event to local, regional and national media outlets.

If you have any questions regarding event submissions please contact Dee Hendrix, Marketing & Online Manager at dhendrix@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325 ext. 25.

Promote Your Business in the 2015 Salem Area Visitor Guide
The 2015 Salem Area Visitors Guide, Travel Salemâ€™s 17th edition is scheduled to be released in the Spring of 2015. The current 2014-15 guide can be viewed in digital format at TravelSalem.com.

If you are interested in advertising in the 2015 Salem Area Visitors Guide ad rates can be found here or contact Terra Moreland with MEDIAmerica at 503-445-8830 / terram@mediamerica.net

column4: New Partnership Program with SwipeNow and Travel Salem
column5:
Travel Salemâ€™s new direct credit card merchant processing alliance with SwipeNow has the potential to save your business thousands of dollars a year in merchant processing fees. If you accept credit cards for payment at your business, then you know how quickly merchant processing fees add up. As a local, direct processor and pooling together the purchasing power of hundreds of Travel Salemâ€™s members, SwipeNow provides association members with an average savings of 23% compared wtih other card processing rates. 

SwipeNowâ€™s benefits include:

  • A local, direct processor that works directly with your business
  • Guaranteed lowest rates 
  • Free terminal paper and supplies for terminals
  • Free special event loaners
  • A+ Better Business rating along with superior local customer service
  • No application fees or start up costs for non processors

To schedule a free cost savings analysis or to start taking credit cards, contact Tim Holstein at 503-975-0660 or email him at timh@swipenow.com. 

Back to newsletter

column5:
Become a Salem Greeter and Meet Visitors from Around the World

Do you love Salem and want to share your passion with visitors? Do you consider yourself a natural entertainer with knowledge of interesting, little-known historical facts? Then consider becoming a Salem Greeter and be part of a prestigious international group of volunteer guides affiliated with the Global Greeter Network.

Greeters are volunteers who take individual tourists and small groups of 6 or less on informal, unscripted tours around the cityâ€™s most iconic places and share their personal perspectives for a truly authentic Salem experience. 

Greeters are part of a global sustainable tourism effort and make visitors feel welcome, comfortable and excited about our city. If you are interested in becoming part of the Salem Greeter program, please contact lgomez@travelsalem.com.

Photo by Ron Cooper

Back to newsletter

column5:
Thousands of visitors and residents use the Travel Salem Event Calendar every month! The content is also utilized in the Travel Salem weekly Event E-blasts and monthly Industry E-news, both with a broad reach.

Our Marketing Department also refers to the Event Calendar when pitching story ideas to the media. In fact, we are already pitching fall and winter 2015 story ideas. The sooner you submit information, the better reach your event will have on visitors, trip planners, promoters and the media. We also submit events to the Travel Oregon website to reach an even broader audience. 

Take advantage of this free marketing tool! Submit your events today for 2015 to the TravelSalem.com Event Calendar.> For maximum exposure please allow at least 60 days before the actual event. This gives us time to post and syndicate your event to local, regional and national media outlets. If you have any questions regarding event submissions please contact Dee Hendrix, Marketing & Online Manager at dhendrix@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325 ext. 25.

Photo by Ron Cooper

Back to newsletter

The guide serves as the response piece to all visitor inquiries generated through Travel Salemâ€™s advertising, public relations and consumer engagement strategies.

column5:
We look forward to seeing our Oregon travel and tourism industry peers at the 2015 Oregon Governor's Conference on Tourism, April 12 - 14 at the Hilton Eugene.

Travel Oregon has three great days planned, including plenty of industry networking and partnership building opportunities with more than 450 attendees, including exhibitors, sponsors, and industry experts. We plan to get our creative juices flowing by immersing in marketing, destination development, leadership, international marketing and sales best practices workshops. 

The 2014 Travel and Tourism Industry Achievement Award Nomination process is open. We encourage you to nominate a tourism superstar who is doing great things for Oregon's tourism industry. New award categories have been added so be sure to check out the Awards webpage for details and to complete the easy online nomination form. The deadline to submit your nominations is February 23 at midnight.

Back to newsletter

column5:
Become a Salem Greeter and Meet Visitors from Around the World

Do you love Salem and want to share your passion with visitors? Do you consider yourself a natural entertainer with knowledge of interesting, little-known historical facts? Then consider becoming a Salem Greeter and be part of a prestigious international group of volunteer guides affiliated with the Global Greeter Network.

Greeters are volunteers who take individual tourists and small groups of 6 or less on informal, unscripted tours around the cityâ€™s most iconic places and share their personal perspectives for a truly authentic Salem experience. 

Greeters are part of a global sustainable tourism effort and make visitors feel welcome, comfortable and excited about our city. If you are interested in becoming part of the Salem Greeter program, please contact lgomez@travelsalem.com.

Photo: Eco-Earth Globe ~ Salem's Riverfront Park ~ Photo by Ron Cooper

column4: Request a Guided Visit of Salem, Oregon
column5:
Please read the guidelines to determine your eligibility for a Greeter guided visit. 

  • You and your group must be visitors to Salem. 
  • Your group should consist of no more than 6 people. This way, the walk maintains an intimate and personalized feel. 
  • If you are flying into Oregon from outside the state, please schedule your Greeter guided visit after your arrival day. 
  • You must register for your tour at least 7 days in advance. 
  • Any cancelations should be requested at least 48 hours in advance.

column5:
Salem is a great place to take in Oregonâ€™s history by visiting the state's historic art deco capitol and walking the charming streets of a genuine â€œmain streetâ€ù community. Set in the fertile Willamette Valley, Salem (pop. 157,000), is surrounded by world-class wineries as well as countless natural areas which provide many options for hikers, cyclists and wildlife enthusiasts.

Make the most of your visit to our wonderful city by touring Salemâ€™s cultural gems, exploring eclectic shops, markets and cafÃ©s. We also invite you to sample some of the finest food and drink available, including award-winning wines and micro brews. Salem embodies the Oregonian spirit and is the perfect gateway to Oregonâ€™s many wonders. The mighty Pacific Ocean is 59 miles west, Portland is a mere 47 miles north, Eugene is 66 miles south, and Bend is 132 miles west. 

Request a Guided Visit ~ Let one of our Salem Greeters be your friend for the day and show you what makes this charming city special. Please register for your free guided visit at least 7 days in advance. Greeter guided visits typically span 1-2 hours in duration.

FAQs for Visitors ~ Curious about what to expect on a Greeters guided visit? Learn more here.

Gallery ~ See photos of past visits and sites often showcased by Salem Greeters. 

Become a Greeter ~ Are you a person who loves sharing the beauty and history of Salem with others? Want to meet people from around the region and possibly the world? Consider becoming a Salem Greeter!

Photos by Ron Cooper

We hope you enjoy your visit!

column4: Become a Salem Greeter and Meet Visitors from Around the World!
column5:
Travel Salem Greeters Application

 

Qualifications
Greeter volunteers must enjoy meeting and talking with all kinds of people and show respect to all visitors. Volunteers must participate in official Salem Greeter trainings/orientations and be able to present Salem in an upbeat and engaging way. Greeters can select freely what tours they are available for and are required to follow through on their scheduled tours. Greeters must be accessible by phone and/or email. If you possess foreign language skills, including American Sign Language abilities, you are strongly encouraged to lend your talents for the benefit of our international visitors.

 

Time and Place
Greeter visits are scheduled from 9 a.m.-4 p.m. Monday through Friday and from 10 a.m.-3 p.m. on Saturday. The meeting location will be the Travel Salem Visitors Center located at 181 High St. NE in downtown Salem, Oregon. Visits are conducted throughout the year, rain or shine!


Benefits of Becoming a Greeter

 Greeters have the wonderful opportunity to showcase our beautiful city to the world! Itâ€™s an opportunity to rediscover Salem through the eyes of a visitor and a chance to meet people from various places, without leaving town. Travel to our area has a strong economic impact, thus your role as a greeter is an essential part of Salemâ€™s economy.

 

Click Here for Application Form

Photo of Eco Earth at Salem's Riverfront Park by Ron Cooper

column5: Please fill out the folllowing registration form. If you have any questions, please contact Lourdes Gomez, Destination Development Manager at 503-581-4325, ext. 133 or email at salemgreeter@TravelSalem.com.
column6: Please fill out the folllowing registration form. If you have any questions, please contact Lourdes Gomez, Destination Development Manager at 503-581-4325, ext. 133 or email at salemgreeter@TravelSalem.com.

column5:
How should I dress?

We strongly recommend wearing comfortable clothes and walking shoes. Weather in Oregon is fairly mild year round but can vary widely from region to region due to the stateâ€™s rich topographic diversity. We encourage you to monitor the weather in Salem prior to your visit.  Dressing in layers will help you adjust to changing temperatures throughout the day.  

 

How can I meet a Salem Greeter?

Once your travel plans are confirmed, fill out and submit the Request Form at least 7 days advance of your arrival


How much does it cost?

Salem Greeter services are offered by volunteers and are completely free of charge.

 

How will I be matched with a Greeter?

Travel Salem strives to match visitors with a greeter according to the availability of our volunteers. We will also attempt to facilitate a match based on the language needs and interests of visitors. 


When and how will I receive confirmation details regarding my Greeter tour?

If a match is made before you leave home, we will email you with information about your Greeter and your tour.


Am I guaranteed to be matched with a Greeter?

Unfortunately, there is no guarantee that that Travel Salem will match you with a greeter or be able to schedule a tour during your desired timeframe. The fulfillment of your request will depend on the availability of our greeters as well as our capacity to fulfill requests based on seasonality of the travel industry.


Can I request more than one Greeter tour during my stay?

Since different times of the year bring a varied influx of visitors, we ask that you submit only one request for a Greeter tour during your visit.


How is a greeter different from a professional tour guide?

Greeter tours are a casual affair and are unscripted. Greeters are not professional or licensed guides but they will be able to share personal anecdotes and unique perspectives about living and working in Salem. A greeter shows you around in ways a friend or family member would and may share their favorite places in the city with you. A greeter can also share tips about what to see in the area as well as orient you on public transportation.


If no Greeter is available for me, can I join another group?

Greeters are not shared among groups. When a Greeter is matched with you or your group, the Greeter will meet only you or your group.

 

Do you offer tours of nearby wineries or state parks outside of Salem City limits?

Currently, The Salem Greeter program is limited to Salemâ€™s downtown. Please refer to Travel Salemâ€™s website for complete area information. The Travel Salem Visitorâ€™s Center is also a great resource where you can pick up complimentary travel guides and brochures. Also, be sure to pick your greeterâ€™s brain for a localâ€™s perspective and recommendations of area attractions and dining options!

 

In the event I need to cancel my tour, how much notice should I give?

We strongly encourage you to honor your scheduled tours but understand that emergencies and unexpected changes happen. We ask that you please contact us immediately at: lgomez@TravelSalem.com (503) 581-4325)  For any cancellations at least 48 hours in advance.

 

Are there other Greeter programs in other cities?

Yes! Salem Greeters is part of a prestigious international organization called the Global Greeter Network. Go to www.GlobalGreeterNetwork.info to learn about greeter programs in cities around the world and to learn how you can start a greeter program in your city.

column4: Travel Salem Participates in Polk County Rural Tourism Studio
column5:
A series of Polk County tourism workshops that began in November recently concluded. The workshops were led by Travel Oregon through their Rural Tourism Studio program. The program assists rural communities interested in sustainable tourism development as a way to increase high-value, authentic experiences for travelers. Tourism development efforts contribute to community livability and ultimately increases visitation, which contributes to the local economy. 

As a result of the program, five major committees were formed to focus development efforts on cycling, agri-tourism, culinary/wine, culture & heritage, and marketing. Travel Salem is taking the lead with the Marketing Committee and the Agri-tourism Committee. Work plans are currently underway with strong support from Polk County residents and the business community.

Anyone interest in rolling up their shirt sleeves and working to implement the strategic outcomes from the Polk County Rural Tourism Studio is encouraged to contact Shawn Irvine with the City of Independence (503-837-1191 or irvine.shawn@ci.independence.or.us)

Back to newsletter

column5:
Travel Salem is seeking your coupons, special offers and/or promotional items to be included at on-site welcome tables and/or in visitor information packets and welcome bags for the following events:

â€¢ Oregon State Bowling Open Championships ~ April 11-June 7, 2015 (9 total weekends)(est. 2,000 people)
â€¢ Pacific Northwest Zone Girlâ€™s Junior Olympic Qualifier-Water Polo ~ May 1-3, 2015 (est. 400 people)
â€¢ Ultimate Frisbee High School State Championships ~ May 16-17, 2015 (est. 200 people) 
â€¢ Jehovahâ€™s Witness Convention ~ May 22-June 14, 2015(Weekends) (est. 15,000 people)
â€¢ Hoop Basketball Tournaments ~ Spring/Summer, The Hoop (est. 12,000 people)

â€¢ 3v3 Life National Soccer Tour ~ June 6, 2015 (est. 200 people)
â€¢ Capital Cup Soccer Tournament ~ June 26-28, Capital Futbol Club (est. 750 people)
â€¢ American Legion Baseball State Championships ~ July 29-August 2, 2015 (est. 300 people)
â€¢ Western Oregon Regional Cross Country Championships ~ November 6-8, 2015 (est. 400 people)                                 

What to donate?

â€¢ Products
â€¢ Promotional Items
â€¢ Special Offers
â€¢ Coupons
â€¢ Reusable Bags (i.e. cloth or plastic)

There are two options for donating coupons:

Option 1.  Email me (tpreston@travelsalem.com) the information and I will add it to an 8.5 x 11 sheet of coupons. Include discount amount, name of business, address, website, and logo saved as a .jpg file. There is no cost for this option.
Option 2. Mail or deliver printed coupons to Travel Salem (181 High Street, Salem, OR 97301) by April 17, 2015.

Free advertising opportunity

Your business can also be listed on the event website of the Capital Cup Soccer Tournament for FREE and all you have to do is create a .pdf flyer that provides special offers.  The flyer should be saved as a .pdf then email it to me and I will forward it to the appropriate contacts.  Be sure to email your logo in a .jpg format along with your web address so we can link to your website.

If you would like to get your coupons, products, special offers or promotional items in front of these visitors, mail or deliver to Travel Salem (181 High Street, Salem, OR 97301) by April 17, 2015. Consider an expiration date of December 31, 2015. Please contact Tara Preston at 503-581-4325 ext. 158 or tpreston@travelsalem.com with any questions. 

Thank you for your consideration, partnership and commitment to this beautiful region we call home!
Photo by Ron Cooper

column4: Travel Salem Scores Tournaments for Area Venues
column5:
Travel Salem is pleased to announce that both the 2015 Pacific Northwest Zone Girls Water Polo Junior Olympics Qualifying Tournament and the Oregon High School Boys and Girls State Ultimate Frisbee Championship will be hosted in Salem this summer.

The 2015 Pacific Northwest Zone Girls Water Polo Junior Olympics Qualifying Tournament will be held on May 1-3 at the Salvation Army Ray and Joan Kroc Corps Community Center. Hosting the tournament in Salem reflects the 16% growth rate of Water Polo in the Pacific Northwest. The tournament will be hosted by the Willamette Valley Water Polo Club, which is one of the largest Water Polo clubs in the state of Oregon and is comprised of players from all over the Willamette Valley.

Another first for the city of Salem will occur May 16-17 when the city proudly hosts the Oregon High School State Ultimate Frisbee Championships at the Capital Futbol Club. Currently, six boysâ€™ teams and four girlsâ€™ teams from different parts of the state are expected to attend the tournament, including Portland, Eugene and Corvallis. Salem is eager to host its first ever USA Ultimate Frisbee Tournament and hopes that more teams will enter to play for the state championships.

For more information on tournament hosting, please contact Brian Chung at 503-581-4325, ext 159 or email at bchung@TravelSalem.com.

Back to newsletter
column6: Travel Salem is pleased to announce that both the 2015 Pacific Northwest Zone Girls Water Polo Junior Olympics Qualifying Tournament and the Oregon High School Boys and Girls State Ultimate Frisbee Championship will be hosted in Salem this summer.
