column4: Blog - Explore and Discover the Mid-Willamette Valley
column5:
October 2015

Harvest Time Happenings in the Salem Area

Since ancient times, people have gathered in the fall to celebrate a successful growing season and share the seasonâ€™s bounty. Today, this tradition continues as thousands of visitors flock to area farms and agricultural attractions to celebrate with food, games and fun. This October, gather your family and friends and head out to one of the Salem areaâ€™s many harvest festivals. 

Baumanâ€™s Farm & Garden in Gervais boasts one of the areaâ€™s largest and most popular festivals, with dozens of different activities, plus the famous Giant Pumpkin Weigh Off, where competitors square off to see who grew the biggest gourd. In 2014, the first place winner weighed in at more than 1,500 pounds. 

At E.Z. Orchards, harvest time means delicious seasonal treats such as roasted corn on the cob, warm apple cider donuts and their award-winning hard cidre. They also offer plenty of activities including a corn maze, pony rides, pedal tractors, duck races and more. 

Fordyce Farm in Northeast Salem goes all out in October with a haunted corn maze featuring â€œliveâ€ù monsters lurking in dark corners. At Fordyce, you can also pick up fresh, seasonal produce and tasty baked goods, including melt-in-your-mouth scones chock-full of farm grown fruit. 

With more than 30 varieties of pumpkin, squash and gourds to choose from, youâ€™re sure to find the perfect â€“ or perfectly unusual â€“ one to complete your fall dÃ©cor at Airlie Hills Farm in Monmouth.  The farm also offers trike racing, farm animals and a special Dark Maze that challenges older kids and adults to find their way out of complete darkness. 

At French Prairie Gardens in St. Paul, visitors can enjoy the only pig races in Oregon, plus hayrides, slides, an obstacle course and more. In Dayton, Heiser Farms is open every day in October with lots of fall-themed fun, including train and fire engine rides, a giant pumpkin patch and a pumpkin cannon derby. 

Try your hand at pumpkin bowling or navigating the Living Forest Maze at family-owned Wavra Farms & Nursery in Southeast Salem. Kids can also decorate their pumpkins, climb the hay tower or see what itâ€™s like to roll around in a life-sized gerbil wheel. 

At Pringle Creek Community â€“ Salemâ€™s one-of-a-kind sustainable living community â€“ youâ€™re invited to bring your own apples (or pears) and have them pressed into cider on Saturday, October 10, starting at 11 a.m. On the same day, head to the Brunk House in Polk County for their annual Apple Festival and enjoy fresh-squeezed cider plus free tours of the historic 1861 home. 

In Woodburn, tulips are traded for tricks and treats in October as the famous Wooden Shoe Tulip Farm is transformed into the Wooden Shoe Pumpkin Fest - complete with a giant corn maze, pumpkin cannon and more. On Friday and Saturday evenings, the maze takes on a spooky vibe and offers frightful fun for those who dare enter after dark!

For more events happening this fall and beyond in the Salem area, check out the Travel Salem events calendar. 

September 2015

Stay
In Salem, youâ€™ll find a number of pet-friendly places to stay including the Best Western PLUS Mill Creek Inn, The Best Western Pacific Highway Inn, the Days Inn Black Bear. To make pets feel extra welcome, the Phoenix Inn Suites Salem hands out doggie treat bags on arrival, while the Red Lion Hotel Salem gives biscuits and has a special dog run area. 

In nearby Silverton, The Oregon Garden Resort rolls out the welcome mat for both two and four-legged guests and allows dogs to accompany owners in its adjacent 80-acre botanical garden, which includes a pet-themed garden and 19 additional themed gardens. 

If youâ€™re heading to the Detroit Lake Recreation Area, The Lodge at Detroit Lake will happily house you and your pet in one of its cozy cabins. Two of the areaâ€™s state parks, Champoeg State Heritage Area and Silver Falls State Park, also have designated cabins or yurts that are pet-friendly. 

Play
The Salem area is home to a number of off-leash dog parks that youâ€™ll want to visit during your stay. Minto-Brown Island Park is a 1,000-plus acre natural park that boasts a 30-acre off-leash area for dogs. At Keizer Rapids Park, youâ€™ll find a 3-acre fully fenced park with a separate area for smaller dogs. Independence is home to a 2-acre fenced dog park with plenty of shade trees and a water station. 

Youâ€™ll see lots of furry companions at The Salem Saturday Market in downtown, where you can shop for fresh produce, flowers, and other handmade and locally grown products every Saturday, from May through October. 

Many of the Mid-Valleyâ€™s beautiful wineries not only have their own canine â€œmascotsâ€ù but donâ€™t mind if you bring your well-behaved ones into their outdoor seating and tasting areas, too. At Ankeny Vineyard in South Salem, enjoy a glass of wine and a slice of wood-fired pizza on the deck along with your canine, and be sure to say hi to Lilly, the Black German Shepherd who lives there. Airlie Winery owners encourage visitors to bring a picnic basket and their canine companions and enjoy a glass overlooking the pond. 

Dine
If you want to grab a bite to eat with your pup in tow, The Thompson Brewery & Public House in Salem recently changed their policy to allow dogs in their backyard seating area. In Independence, The Three Legged Dog Public HouseRogue Farms, dogs are welcome as long as they keep their paws off the free-roaming chickens or turkeys that live on the farm. 

For more ideas about what to do and where to go in the Salem area, go to www.TravelSalem.com. 

July 2015

The Salem stretch of the Bikeway offers its own special charm, taking cyclists past farm markets, hop fields, vineyards, wineries and even a wildlife refuge.

The Salem portion of the Bikeway starts at Champoeg State Heritage Area, where you can park your car or camp overnight in a tent, cozy cabin or yurt the day before your journey. The 35-mile stretch from Champoeg to the city of Salem meanders along mostly flat, scenic country roads. 

As you enter Salem, be sure to stop at EZ Orchards Farm Market, where they serve up smoothies, shakes and shortcake, made with berries fresh from the farm. As you cycle towards downtown, youâ€™ll pass the historic Oregon State Capitol grounds, filled with fragrant roses and bright rhododendrons that bloom throughout the summer. For a hearty, homemade lunch featuring local ingredients, try Wild Pear Restaurant or Croissant & Company. To make it a leisurely two-day trip, stay overnight at the Century House B&B â€“ a beautifully restored turn-of-the-century home located just a Â_ mile off the Bikeway in the heart of town. 

As you leave town heading south, youâ€™ll find Ankeny National Wildlife Refuge, a 2,492-acre wetland and haven for migratory birds and other wildlife. At nearby Ankeny Vineyards, enjoy a glass of estate grown wine and a slice of wood-fired pizza. As you continue along the bikeway to the Independence Bridge, take a slight detour over the bridge and head to Rogue Hop Yard â€“ Rogue Alesâ€™ 33-acre working hop farm and tasting room. Enjoy a farmstead ale made with honey and hops grown on the farm and tour the farm for a first-hand look at how hops are harvested and prepared. 

Pedaling for Pinot
Bike Oregon Wine Countryâ€ù tours. Held every Sunday in August, these fully-supported rides include stops at three to four wineries in the beautiful Eola Amity Hills AVA, followed by a salmon barbecue and wine tasting on the patio at Eola Hills Wine Cellars in Rickreall.  

For more ideas about what to see and do on a cycling adventure through Salem, go to www.travelsalem.com. 
Photo: Bikers at Champoeg State Heritage Area ~ St. Paul, Oregon ~ Photo courtesy of ODOT 

June 2015

 

From rich roses to hardy hostas, many local growers not only showcase their plants for sale but also offer awe-inspiring display gardens that draw visitors from far and wide. The Salem area is home to a number of breathtaking botanical gardens. One youâ€™ll definitely want to visit is the Dellbert Hunter Arboretum and Botanical Garden in Dallas, where youâ€™ll find perennials, conifers, oaks, wetland species and even dryland desert plants, thanks to the varied terrain contained within the Arboretum. The Arboretum is also home to whatâ€™s known as The Old Flume -  an inclined water channel that was used to send timber cut in the high country down La Creole Creek (now Rickreall Creek) to the sawmill in Dallas.

Sometimes referred to as Salemâ€™s secret garden, the Martha Springer Botanical Garden is located on the campus of Willamette University and offers a quiet place for contemplation and reflection. Opened in 1988 in honor of Professor Martha Springer, the 1-acre garden contains 12 smaller gardens stretched along the creek that bisects the campus. 

No garden tour is complete without a trip to the areaâ€™s shining showpiece, The Oregon Garden, an 80-acre botanical wonderland located in Silverton, featuring 20 specialty gardens, a Hobbit House, water features and more. Well-behaved pets on leashes are welcome at The Garden and a trolley takes visitors on guided tours daily. 

The Willamette Valley offers one of the finest climates in the world for growing roses, and youâ€™ll find thousands of them displayed on five acres of themed gardens at Heirloom Roses in St. Paul. And if you love roses, but growing them seems to be a thorny subject, check out the farmâ€™s Saturday Rose Academy - an on-going series of monthly seminars designed to take the mystery out of growing roses.  

Roses and other fair flowers can also be found at Historic Deepwood Gardens, a 4.5-acre English-style garden surrounding Historic Deepwood Estate in Salem, created by landscape architects Elizabeth Lord and Edith Schryver in 1930. Deepwood Gardens feature covered arches and gazebos, ornamental gates and fences and a nature trail that weaves its way through the western border of the property. 

Between early May and mid-June, youâ€™ll encounter a kaleidoscope of color and 250 different peony varieties at Adelman Peony Gardens. Adelmanâ€™s tree peony, called Hephestos, received the â€œBest of Showâ€ù award at the American Peony Societyâ€™s annual flower competition in 2012. 

If you love lavender, be sure to visit Lavender Lake Farms. This family-owned farm produces naturally-grown essential oils and lavender-infused beauty products, as well as honey, chocolates, teas and salts. Although the farm is open year-round, most people visit the end of June through mid-July to see the spectacular sea of purple blooms. 

The Salem area is also home to beautiful Sebright Gardens, which offers more than 800 varieties of hastas, as well 150 varieties of ferns and other shade-loving plants. Wander through their beautiful display garden and then select the perfect additions for your yard or patio. 

For more gardens to explore in the Salem area this summer, visit the gardens section of our website. 

 

May 2015

Global Greeters Network, the Salem Greeters Program aims to foster a deeper connection between visitors and the local community by matching visitors with residents who will share their knowledge and insights about the Salem area.

Volunteer Greeters take individual tourists and small groups of six or less on free, informal walks â€“ primarily around the cityâ€™s downtown core, which is home to a number of eclectic shops, cafes, art galleries and other cultural and historical gems. Tours can be customized to meet a visitorâ€™s specific interests and typically last one to two hours.

â€œGreeters are not professional tour guides,â€ù points out Lourdes Gomez, Travel Salemâ€™s Destination Development Manager and coordinator of the Salem Greeters Program. Rather, they share personal anecdotes about living and working in Salem, along with interesting historical facts and ideas about what to see and do in the area.

Salem residents Ron Kelemen and Kathy Ellis-Kelemen have taken part in walking tours in other cities and now serve as volunteers with the Salem Greeters Program.  â€œMy husband and I look for these tours whenever we travel as it really makes a place come alive,â€ù says Ellis-Kelemen.

While more than 90 cities worldwide currently participate in the Global Greeters Network - which began in 1992 in New York City - only three other cities in the United States currently participate. Salem is the fifth U.S. city to formally adopt the program and the first in the state of Oregon.

 Anyone planning a trip to the Salem area is encouraged to sign up for a guided walk around the city. To request a tour, fill out the online request form, or call the Travel Salem Visitors Center at (800) 874-7012. Visitors are asked to submit requests at least seven days in advance of their visit. 


April 2015

Salem Embraces the Craft Beer Culture

One of the first independent brewers to ignite the craft beer revolution in the Salem area was Gilgamesh Brewing Company. Gilgamesh was founded in 2009 when three brothers â€“ Mike, Matt and Nick Radtke - along with their father Lee, started brewing out of their home in Turner. Demand for their product grew, as did the familyâ€™s desire to create a welcoming gathering place, so in November 2012, the Radtkeâ€™s opened The Campus, a full-service restaurant, bar and brewery.

Also in 2012, Santiam Brewing Company opened a 3-barrel brewery and taproom in an industrial area in Southeast Salem. In coming months, the company will expand to a 10-barrel system. At Santiam, youâ€™ll always find at least 14 beers on tap including four cask-conditioned ales. 

In the same Southeast Salem neighborhood as Santiam Brewing sits Salem Ale Works â€“ a nano brewery founded by college friends and former wild land firefighters Justin Ego and Jake Bonham. Beers reflect the ownersâ€™ quirky side, with names like Hootenany Honey Basil and Slow Roller Raspberry Mint. 

The newest brewery to call Salem home is Vagabond Brewing Company. Opened in early 2014, Vagabond is located in Northeast Salem and has a decidedly urban feel, with plenty of space for special events, including live music and even yoga classes. Beers are brewed in small batches using locally sourced ingredients whenever possible. 

New breweries have popped up outside of the city limits as well.  At Rogue Farmsâ€™ 33-acre hop yard in Independence, guests can visit the tasting room, tour the hop processing facility and enjoy the expansive outdoor space â€“ complete with picnic tables and lawn games. Four-legged family members are also welcome at the Hopyard â€“ as long as they keep their paws off the farmâ€™s free roaming chickens and turkeys! 

No ale-themed trip to Salem is complete without visits to the two relative â€œgrandfathersâ€ù in town: The Ram Restaurant & Brewery and McMenaminâ€™s Thompson House. For more than 15 years, the folks at The Ram have been brewing up award-winning brews, while Thompson House brew master (or should we say, brewmistress) Jen Kent creates inspired ales like Copper Moon and the ever-popular Ruby. 

While you can always explore Salemâ€™s breweries on your own, the best way to experience them may be with a guided tour from Ale Ways, Salemâ€™s new brewery tour company. You can sign up for one of the companyâ€™s designated itineraries or create your own customized pub crawl adventure.

For more ideas about whatâ€™s new, where to go and what to do in the Salem area, visit www.TravelSalem.com.

Photo: Gilgamesh, The Campus ~ Salem, Oregon ~ Photo by Dee Hendrix

March 2015

Spring Into New Adventures in Salem

Just as the flowers begin to bloom each spring, it seems that people are also inspired to turn their passions for food, wine, culture and adventure into exciting, new experiences for residents and visitors alike. Make plans to visit Oregonâ€™s capital to see whatâ€™s new and noteworthy in 2015.

One of the most exciting changes in downtown Salem is the recent re-opening of the historic McGilchrist and Roth Building. Originally built in 1916, this beautifully renovated building is home to three new shops worth checking out: Gayleâ€™s Italian Market, an authentic Italian shop featuring artisan cheeses, meats, wood-fired pizza and more; Rickyâ€™s Bubbles & Sweets, a bright store featuring old-fashioned candies and whimsical gifts; and Archive, a hip, urban coffee shop by day and Prohibition Era-inspired bar at night.  

Salemâ€™s culinary scene continues to grow with the addition of several new eateries this year. In downtown, tableFIVE 08 unites the culinary talents of executive chef Jason Freeburg and chef de cuisine Alexander Baccarat - both graduates of New Yorkâ€™s prestigious Culinary Institute of America. The restaurant prides itself on creating food that satisfies the palates of those who enjoy fresh, local food with dynamic flavor. A few miles outside of Salem in the small town of Sublimity is Panezanellieâ€™s Breadstick Shoppe. Back under the guidance of its original owner, this unassuming cafÃ© serves up some of the most delectable breadsticks, sticky buns and flatbread pizza in the Willamette Valley.

In June, the Oregon WWII Memorial was unveiled in Salem. Located on the grounds of the Oregon State Capitol, this $1.22 million recognizes the service and sacrifice of the 152,000 Oregonians who served during WW II. The names of the 3,771 Oregonians killed in action are also inscribed on a black granite wall that serves as part of the memorial.   

A few Salem area wineries also expanded their operations this past year. One of the newest venues was created by Brooks Winery. The 12,000-square-foot tasting room features stunning views of the vineyards and plenty of space to sip and relax with friends and family. Eola Hills Winery also expanded, this year. Their new Legacy Estate Vineyard features a rustic tasting room with a lovely view of the man-made pond, plus 300 acres that are open to visitors for hiking and exploring. In late spring, Namaste Vineyards opened a second tasting room, conveniently located on Highway 99 between Rickreall and Monmouth.  You can still visit their original tasting room and vineyard outside of Dallas and enjoy the spectacular views of the vines and the rolling hills of the Willamette Valley.

Outdoor enthusiasts will find new adventures in the area, too.  Approximately 30 miles east of Salem on the beautiful Santiam River sits the newly opened Bear Creek Campground â€“ a 15-acre campground featuring 15 camp sites, picnic tables, designated swimming areas and hiking trails. At iconic Silver Falls State Park, families can enjoy the new â€œnatural playâ€ù area   - the first of its kind to be constructed in an Oregon state park. This Â_-mile loop allows kids to hide out in a cougar's den, growl like a bear, weave a bird's nest and more.

For more ideas about whatâ€™s new, where to go and what to do in the Salem area, visit www.TravelSalem.com.

Photo: McGilchrist-Roth Building ~ Salem, Oregon ~ Photo by Ron Cooper
column6:
October 2015

Harvest Time Happenings in the Salem Area

Since ancient times, people have gathered in the fall to celebrate a successful growing season and share the seasonâ€™s bounty. Today, this tradition continues as thousands of visitors flock to area farms and agricultural attractions to celebrate with food, games and fun. This October, gather your family and friends and head out to one of the Salem areaâ€™s many harvest festivals. 

Baumanâ€™s Farm & Garden in Gervais boasts one of the areaâ€™s largest and most popular festivals, with dozens of different activities, plus the famous Giant Pumpkin Weigh Off, where competitors square off to see who grew the biggest gourd. In 2014, the first place winner weighed in at more than 1,500 pounds. 

At E.Z. Orchards, harvest time means delicious seasonal treats such as roasted corn on the cob, warm apple cider donuts and their award-winning hard cidre. They also offer plenty of activities including a corn maze, pony rides, pedal tractors, duck races and more. 

Fordyce Farm in Northeast Salem goes all out in October with a haunted corn maze featuring â€œliveâ€ù monsters lurking in dark corners. At Fordyce, you can also pick up fresh, seasonal produce and tasty baked goods, including melt-in-your-mouth scones chock-full of farm grown fruit. 

With more than 30 varieties of pumpkin, squash and gourds to choose from, youâ€™re sure to find the perfect â€“ or perfectly unusual â€“ one to complete your fall dÃ©cor at Airlie Hills Farm in Monmouth.  The farm also offers trike racing, farm animals and a special Dark Maze that challenges older kids and adults to find their way out of complete darkness. 

At French Prairie Gardens in St. Paul, visitors can enjoy the only pig races in Oregon, plus hayrides, slides, an obstacle course and more. In Dayton, Heiser Farms is open every day in October with lots of fall-themed fun, including train and fire engine rides, a giant pumpkin patch and a pumpkin cannon derby. 

Try your hand at pumpkin bowling or navigating the Living Forest Maze at family-owned Wavra Farms & Nursery in Southeast Salem. Kids can also decorate their pumpkins, climb the hay tower or see what itâ€™s like to roll around in a life-sized gerbil wheel. 

At Pringle Creek Community â€“ Salemâ€™s one-of-a-kind sustainable living community â€“ youâ€™re invited to bring your own apples (or pears) and have them pressed into cider on Saturday, October 10, starting at 11 a.m. On the same day, head to the Brunk House in Polk County for their annual Apple Festival and enjoy fresh-squeezed cider plus free tours of the historic 1861 home. 

In Woodburn, tulips are traded for tricks and treats in October as the famous Wooden Shoe Tulip Farm is transformed into the Wooden Shoe Pumpkin Fest - complete with a giant corn maze, pumpkin cannon and more. On Friday and Saturday evenings, the maze takes on a spooky vibe and offers frightful fun for those who dare enter after dark!

For more events happening this fall and beyond in the Salem area, check out the Travel Salem events calendar. 

September 2015

Stay
In Salem, youâ€™ll find a number of pet-friendly places to stay including the Best Western PLUS Mill Creek Inn, The Best Western Pacific Highway Inn, the Days Inn Black Bear. To make pets feel extra welcome, the Phoenix Inn Suites Salem hands out doggie treat bags on arrival, while the Red Lion Hotel Salem gives biscuits and has a special dog run area. 

In nearby Silverton, The Oregon Garden Resort rolls out the welcome mat for both two and four-legged guests and allows dogs to accompany owners in its adjacent 80-acre botanical garden, which includes a pet-themed garden and 19 additional themed gardens. 

If youâ€™re heading to the Detroit Lake Recreation Area, The Lodge at Detroit Lake will happily house you and your pet in one of its cozy cabins. Two of the areaâ€™s state parks, Champoeg State Heritage Area and Silver Falls State Park, also have designated cabins or yurts that are pet-friendly. 

Play
The Salem area is home to a number of off-leash dog parks that youâ€™ll want to visit during your stay. Minto-Brown Island Park is a 1,000-plus acre natural park that boasts a 30-acre off-leash area for dogs. At Keizer Rapids Park, youâ€™ll find a 3-acre fully fenced park with a separate area for smaller dogs. Independence is home to a 2-acre fenced dog park with plenty of shade trees and a water station. 

Youâ€™ll see lots of furry companions at The Salem Saturday Market in downtown, where you can shop for fresh produce, flowers, and other handmade and locally grown products every Saturday, from May through October. 

Many of the Mid-Valleyâ€™s beautiful wineries not only have their own canine â€œmascotsâ€ù but donâ€™t mind if you bring your well-behaved ones into their outdoor seating and tasting areas, too. At Ankeny Vineyard in South Salem, enjoy a glass of wine and a slice of wood-fired pizza on the deck along with your canine, and be sure to say hi to Lilly, the Black German Shepherd who lives there. Airlie Winery owners encourage visitors to bring a picnic basket and their canine companions and enjoy a glass overlooking the pond. 

Dine
If you want to grab a bite to eat with your pup in tow, The Thompson Brewery & Public House in Salem recently changed their policy to allow dogs in their backyard seating area. In Independence, The Three Legged Dog Public HouseRogue Farms, dogs are welcome as long as they keep their paws off the free-roaming chickens or turkeys that live on the farm. 

For more ideas about what to do and where to go in the Salem area, go to www.TravelSalem.com. 

July 2015

The Salem stretch of the Bikeway offers its own special charm, taking cyclists past farm markets, hop fields, vineyards, wineries and even a wildlife refuge.

The Salem portion of the Bikeway starts at Champoeg State Heritage Area, where you can park your car or camp overnight in a tent, cozy cabin or yurt the day before your journey. The 35-mile stretch from Champoeg to the city of Salem meanders along mostly flat, scenic country roads. 

As you enter Salem, be sure to stop at EZ Orchards Farm Market, where they serve up smoothies, shakes and shortcake, made with berries fresh from the farm. As you cycle towards downtown, youâ€™ll pass the historic Oregon State Capitol grounds, filled with fragrant roses and bright rhododendrons that bloom throughout the summer. For a hearty, homemade lunch featuring local ingredients, try Wild Pear Restaurant or Croissant & Company. To make it a leisurely two-day trip, stay overnight at the Century House B&B â€“ a beautifully restored turn-of-the-century home located just a Â_ mile off the Bikeway in the heart of town. 

As you leave town heading south, youâ€™ll find Ankeny National Wildlife Refuge, a 2,492-acre wetland and haven for migratory birds and other wildlife. At nearby Ankeny Vineyards, enjoy a glass of estate grown wine and a slice of wood-fired pizza. As you continue along the bikeway to the Independence Bridge, take a slight detour over the bridge and head to Rogue Hop Yard â€“ Rogue Alesâ€™ 33-acre working hop farm and tasting room. Enjoy a farmstead ale made with honey and hops grown on the farm and tour the farm for a first-hand look at how hops are harvested and prepared. 

Pedaling for Pinot
Bike Oregon Wine Countryâ€ù tours. Held every Sunday in August, these fully-supported rides include stops at three to four wineries in the beautiful Eola Amity Hills AVA, followed by a salmon barbecue and wine tasting on the patio at Eola Hills Wine Cellars in Rickreall.  

For more ideas about what to see and do on a cycling adventure through Salem, go to www.travelsalem.com. 
Photo: Bikers at Champoeg State Heritage Area ~ St. Paul, Oregon ~ Photo courtesy of ODOT 

June 2015

 

From rich roses to hardy hostas, many local growers not only showcase their plants for sale but also offer awe-inspiring display gardens that draw visitors from far and wide. The Salem area is home to a number of breathtaking botanical gardens. One youâ€™ll definitely want to visit is the Dellbert Hunter Arboretum and Botanical Garden in Dallas, where youâ€™ll find perennials, conifers, oaks, wetland species and even dryland desert plants, thanks to the varied terrain contained within the Arboretum. The Arboretum is also home to whatâ€™s known as The Old Flume -  an inclined water channel that was used to send timber cut in the high country down La Creole Creek (now Rickreall Creek) to the sawmill in Dallas.

Sometimes referred to as Salemâ€™s secret garden, the Martha Springer Botanical Garden is located on the campus of Willamette University and offers a quiet place for contemplation and reflection. Opened in 1988 in honor of Professor Martha Springer, the 1-acre garden contains 12 smaller gardens stretched along the creek that bisects the campus. 

No garden tour is complete without a trip to the areaâ€™s shining showpiece, The Oregon Garden, an 80-acre botanical wonderland located in Silverton, featuring 20 specialty gardens, a Hobbit House, water features and more. Well-behaved pets on leashes are welcome at The Garden and a trolley takes visitors on guided tours daily. 

The Willamette Valley offers one of the finest climates in the world for growing roses, and youâ€™ll find thousands of them displayed on five acres of themed gardens at Heirloom Roses in St. Paul. And if you love roses, but growing them seems to be a thorny subject, check out the farmâ€™s Saturday Rose Academy - an on-going series of monthly seminars designed to take the mystery out of growing roses.  

Roses and other fair flowers can also be found at Historic Deepwood Gardens, a 4.5-acre English-style garden surrounding Historic Deepwood Estate in Salem, created by landscape architects Elizabeth Lord and Edith Schryver in 1930. Deepwood Gardens feature covered arches and gazebos, ornamental gates and fences and a nature trail that weaves its way through the western border of the property. 

Between early May and mid-June, youâ€™ll encounter a kaleidoscope of color and 250 different peony varieties at Adelman Peony Gardens. Adelmanâ€™s tree peony, called Hephestos, received the â€œBest of Showâ€ù award at the American Peony Societyâ€™s annual flower competition in 2012. 

If you love lavender, be sure to visit Lavender Lake Farms. This family-owned farm produces naturally-grown essential oils and lavender-infused beauty products, as well as honey, chocolates, teas and salts. Although the farm is open year-round, most people visit the end of June through mid-July to see the spectacular sea of purple blooms. 

The Salem area is also home to beautiful Sebright Gardens, which offers more than 800 varieties of hastas, as well 150 varieties of ferns and other shade-loving plants. Wander through their beautiful display garden and then select the perfect additions for your yard or patio. 

For more gardens to explore in the Salem area this summer, visit the gardens section of our website. 

 

May 2015

Global Greeters Network, the Salem Greeters Program aims to foster a deeper connection between visitors and the local community by matching visitors with residents who will share their knowledge and insights about the Salem area.

Volunteer Greeters take individual tourists and small groups of six or less on free, informal walks â€“ primarily around the cityâ€™s downtown core, which is home to a number of eclectic shops, cafes, art galleries and other cultural and historical gems. Tours can be customized to meet a visitorâ€™s specific interests and typically last one to two hours.

â€œGreeters are not professional tour guides,â€ù points out Lourdes Gomez, Travel Salemâ€™s Destination Development Manager and coordinator of the Salem Greeters Program. Rather, they share personal anecdotes about living and working in Salem, along with interesting historical facts and ideas about what to see and do in the area.

Salem residents Ron Kelemen and Kathy Ellis-Kelemen have taken part in walking tours in other cities and now serve as volunteers with the Salem Greeters Program.  â€œMy husband and I look for these tours whenever we travel as it really makes a place come alive,â€ù says Ellis-Kelemen.

While more than 90 cities worldwide currently participate in the Global Greeters Network - which began in 1992 in New York City - only three other cities in the United States currently participate. Salem is the fifth U.S. city to formally adopt the program and the first in the state of Oregon.

 Anyone planning a trip to the Salem area is encouraged to sign up for a guided walk around the city. To request a tour, fill out the online request form, or call the Travel Salem Visitors Center at (800) 874-7012. Visitors are asked to submit requests at least seven days in advance of their visit. 


April 2015

Salem Embraces the Craft Beer Culture

One of the first independent brewers to ignite the craft beer revolution in the Salem area was Gilgamesh Brewing Company. Gilgamesh was founded in 2009 when three brothers â€“ Mike, Matt and Nick Radtke - along with their father Lee, started brewing out of their home in Turner. Demand for their product grew, as did the familyâ€™s desire to create a welcoming gathering place, so in November 2012, the Radtkeâ€™s opened The Campus, a full-service restaurant, bar and brewery.

Also in 2012, Santiam Brewing Company opened a 3-barrel brewery and taproom in an industrial area in Southeast Salem. In coming months, the company will expand to a 10-barrel system. At Santiam, youâ€™ll always find at least 14 beers on tap including four cask-conditioned ales. 

In the same Southeast Salem neighborhood as Santiam Brewing sits Salem Ale Works â€“ a nano brewery founded by college friends and former wild land firefighters Justin Ego and Jake Bonham. Beers reflect the ownersâ€™ quirky side, with names like Hootenany Honey Basil and Slow Roller Raspberry Mint. 

The newest brewery to call Salem home is Vagabond Brewing Company. Opened in early 2014, Vagabond is located in Northeast Salem and has a decidedly urban feel, with plenty of space for special events, including live music and even yoga classes. Beers are brewed in small batches using locally sourced ingredients whenever possible. 

New breweries have popped up outside of the city limits as well.  At Rogue Farmsâ€™ 33-acre hop yard in Independence, guests can visit the tasting room, tour the hop processing facility and enjoy the expansive outdoor space â€“ complete with picnic tables and lawn games. Four-legged family members are also welcome at the Hopyard â€“ as long as they keep their paws off the farmâ€™s free roaming chickens and turkeys! 

No ale-themed trip to Salem is complete without visits to the two relative â€œgrandfathersâ€ù in town: The Ram Restaurant & Brewery and McMenaminâ€™s Thompson House. For more than 15 years, the folks at The Ram have been brewing up award-winning brews, while Thompson House brew master (or should we say, brewmistress) Jen Kent creates inspired ales like Copper Moon and the ever-popular Ruby. 

While you can always explore Salemâ€™s breweries on your own, the best way to experience them may be with a guided tour from Ale Ways, Salemâ€™s new brewery tour company. You can sign up for one of the companyâ€™s designated itineraries or create your own customized pub crawl adventure.

For more ideas about whatâ€™s new, where to go and what to do in the Salem area, visit www.TravelSalem.com.

Photo: Gilgamesh, The Campus ~ Salem, Oregon ~ Photo by Dee Hendrix

column4: Travel Salem Recognized as Bike Friendly Business
column5:
Oregon loves bicyclists â€“ and so does Travel Salem! We are pleased to announce that the Travel Salem Travel CafÃ© and Visitors Center has achieved recognition in Travel Oregonâ€™s statewide Bike Friendly Business Program. 

 

Bike Friendly businesses are those that demonstrate a commitment to serving visitors who ride bikes by providing specific amenities they may need. Specific amenities offered by Travel Salemâ€™s Travel CafÃ© and Visitors Center include complimentary charging for personal devices (tablets and phones); free water refills; access to a public restroom and visitor information geared towards bicycle riders. 

Bicycle-related tourism contributes $400 million to Oregonâ€™s economy annually, according to a 2012 study by Dean Runyon Associates. Travel Oregonâ€™s statewide Bike Friendly Business program is the first of its kind in the nation and is designed to help Oregon businesses reach out to this quickly-growing segment of the tourism economy. 

Oregon has been a bicycle-tourism innovator since 2010, when Cycle Oregon and the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department co-created the only Scenic Bikeways program in the nation - beginning with the Willamette Valley Scenic Bikeway, which runs through the heart of Salem. 

In addition to providing amenities for cyclists, Travel Salem continues to offer services to help all visitors make the most of their stay including free copies of visitor guides, ideas about what to see and do in the area, complimentary Wi-Fi and ticket sales for many of the areaâ€™s arts, culture and heritage events.

For more information about Travel Salem, visit www.travelsalem.com or call 503-581-4325. For more information about the Bike Friendly Business Program, go to www.industry.traveloregon.com/BFB. 

Back to newsletter

column4: "Must See Oregon" Provides Showcase for Businesses
column5:
The second annual Must See Oregon tourism showcase will be held at The Oregon Garden in Silverton on Saturday, May 16 from 10 a.m.to 4 p.m. Admission to the event is free with Oregon Garden admission. This state-wide event is in partnership with Travel Oregon, Travel Salem and The Oregon Garden; featuring destinations, attractions and activities all around Oregon. The goal is to encourage Oregonians to travel in Oregon and to provide information about travel opportunities in our own state. 

From outdoor adventures and resorts to craft brews and worldâ€êrenowned wines, Oregon has it all. The stateâ€™s vast array of attractions, destinations, travel, and extended vacation opportunities will be showcased at Must See Oregon, presented by Capitol Subaru and coordinated by Class Act Events. 

â€œThere is no other showcase like this in Oregon,â€ù said Must See Oregon organizer Susan Adkins. â€œWe have so many exciting opportunities in this state and youâ€™ll have one place to go for a glimpse of Oregonâ€™s best kept secrets.â€ù

Throughout the day, visitors will have opportunities to learn more about Oregonâ€™s treasures from over 40 Oregon destinations and attractions. Families can experience activities such as skiing demonstrations, geocaching and rock climbing, plus presentations from travel experts such as Steve Arndt, author of Roads Less Traveled in Oregon, to help with trip planning. Food and beverages avilable from Gilgamesh Brewing. Proceeds from Must See Oregon will benefit SMART and SKEF. A $2 donation is suggested.

For more information visit: www.MustSeeOr.com
Facebook: facebook.com/mustseeor
Twitter: @mustseeoregon
Instagram: instagram.com/mustseeoregon

Photo: The Oregon Garden ~ courtesy of The Oregon Garden

Back to newsletter

The goal is to encourage Oregonians to travel in Oregon and to provide information about travel opportunities in our own state.

column4: Join Us ~ The 'Absolutely Fabulous' Awards Luncheon ~ May 21
column5:
6th annual 'Absolutely Fabulous' Awards luncheon
Thursday, May 21
11:45 a.m. to 1:30 p.m.
Salem Convention Center ~ 200 Commercial Street SE in Salem

Keynote speaker ~ Professor and Historian, John Ritter 

The Ab Fab awards recognize tourism industry partners who went above and beyond in 2014 to increase the economic impact of visitors. The award recipients are movers and shakers whose collaboration, innovation, vision, product development and regional strategies are â€œabsolutely fabulous!â€ù This yearâ€™s Ab Fab Awards luncheon is sponsored by Courthouse and Salem Convention Center.

Attendees are encouraged to bring brochures and business cards to promote their business and enter for a chance to win local goods and services. Door prizes include gift certificates for E.Z. Orchards, La Lumiere Massage Boutique, Left Coast Cellars, Oak Knoll Golf Course and Wavra Farms & Nursery.

The cost to attend the luncheon is $18 in advance or $23 at the door. Reservations are required and can be made online or by calling 503-581-4325, ext. 158. For more information, go to www.travelsalem.com.

column4: Travel Salem Greeters Program Gets National Media Attention ~ Help Spread the Word
column5:
Travel Salemâ€™s newly launched Greeters program is receiving national and statewide media attention for good reason.  As one of five Greeters programs in the nation this new visitor services is in demand and you can help us spread the word! Salem Greeters is now providing volunteer guides for visitors to downtown Salem. 

Greeters are volunteers who take individual tourists and small groups of 6 or less on informal, unscripted tours around the cityâ€™s most iconic places and share their personal perspectives for a truly authentic Salem experience. 

Greeters are part of a global sustainable tourism effort and make visitors feel welcome, comfortable and excited about our city. If you are interested in becoming part of the Salem Greeter program, please contact lgomez@travelsalem.com.

Photo: Eco-Earth Globe ~ Salem's Riverfront Park ~ Photo by Ron Cooper

column4: Tom Prochaska and Christy Wyckoff: In the Footsteps of Charles Heaney
column5:
May 9-July 19. In 2014, Portland artists Tom Prochaska and Christy Wyckoff embarked on a journey to retrace the footsteps of Portland painter Charles Heaney (1897-1981), who often traveled to remote regions of Eastern Oregon in search of artistic inspiration. This exhibition features 30 drawings created by the artistsâ€™ during their road trip. Museum hours: Tues.-Sat. 10 a.m.-5 p.m.; Sun. 1-5 p.m.; closed Mondays.
Hallie Ford Museum of Art
700 State St.
Salem, OR 97301
503-370-6855
www.willamette.edu/arts

column4: Travel Oregon Announces Oregon Wine Country Plates Matching Grant Program
column5:
The Oregon Wine Country Plates Matching Grant Program was signed by the Oregon Legislature in 2011 to promote wine and culinary tourism in the state. The revenues from the sale of the Wine Country license plate will be used to support culinary projects and tourism programs in Oregon. The program launched May 1, 2015. 

The mission of Travel Oregon is: â€œA better life for Oregonians through strong, sustainable local economies.â€ù Travel Oregon has established a program to make grant awards to â€œtourism promotion agencies for tourism wine and culinary tourism.â€ù The revenue generated by the sale of the Wine Country Plates is enabling over $230,000 available for grant awards in grants of not less than $2,500 or more than $40,000, inclusive of match and subject to matching and other requirements described in the Grants Guidelines.

Oregon Wine Country Plates Matching Grant Program: The revenues from the sale of the Wine Country license plate will be used to support culinary projects and tourism programs in Oregon. Guidelines to implement this effort are being developed. The 2015/2016 grant cycle has $230,000 available to be awarded in grants of not less than $2,000 or more than $40,000, inclusive of match and subject to matching and additional requirements. Oregon Wine Country Plates Matching Grant Program Guidelines

Eligible Applicants
Incorporated nonprofit or government units responsible for tourism promotion of a destination on a year-round basis, a nonprofit entity that manages tourism-related economic develop plans, programs and projects, and regional or statewide associations that represent entities that rely on tourism-related business for more than 50 percent of their total income are eligible to apply. Successful grant projects and initiatives must be directly related to promotion of wine and culinary tourism in Oregon.  

Interested in Applying?
Any eligible organization interested in a grant application will be required to contact the local Destination Marketing Organization and Regional Destination Marketing Organization to discuss grant project ideas prior to submitting the Grant Project Idea Worksheet to Travel Oregon. Once the idea worksheet has been reviewed, grant applicants will receive the link to submit an application online. These details and more can be found in the Grant Guidelines.  

Oregon Wine Country License Plate ~ Image Credit: Oregon DMV

Back to newsletter
column6: The Oregon Wine Country Plates Matching Grant Program was signed by the Oregon Legislature in 2011 to promote wine and culinary tourism in the state. The revenues from the sale of the Wine Country license plate will be used to support culinary projects and tourism programs in Oregon. The program launched May 1, 2015.

column4: Don't Miss The 'Absolutely Fabulous' Awards Luncheon
column5:
6th annual 'Absolutely Fabulous' Awards luncheon
Thursday, May 21
11:45 a.m. to 1:30 p.m.
Salem Convention Center ~ 200 Commercial Street SE in Salem

Keynote speaker ~ Professor and Historian, John Ritter 
Salem Underground ~ Fascinating Glimpse of the History that Lies Beneath Your Feet

The Ab Fab awards recognize tourism industry partners who went above and beyond in 2014 to increase the economic impact of visitors. The award recipients are movers and shakers whose collaboration, innovation, vision, product development and regional strategies are â€œabsolutely fabulous!â€ù This yearâ€™s Ab Fab Awards luncheon is sponsored by Courthouse and Salem Convention Center.

Attendees are encouraged to bring brochures and business cards to promote their business and enter for a chance to win local goods and services. Door prizes include gift certificates for E.Z. Orchards, La Lumiere Massage Boutique, Left Coast Cellars, Oak Knoll Golf Course and Wavra Farms & Nursery.


The cost to attend the luncheon is $23 at the door. Reservations are required and can be made online or by calling 503-581-4325, ext. 158. For more information, go to www.travelsalem.com.

column4: 2015-16 Salem Area Visitor Guide Now Available
column5:
Share our beautiful and bountiful area with visitors! Keep a supply of the official visitor guide for Salem and Marion and Polk counties at your location. This free, full-color guide features unique experiences and resources highlighting attractions, events, recreation, gardens and the liquid artistry of the area.

Request a Visitor Guide by mail
View Digital Visitor Guide

It also includes useful transportation, resource and relocation information for the Mid-Willamette Valley area.

â€œWe believe this guide will jump off the racks into visitor's hands!  The information throughout is great for both inspiration and trip planning.  We have started distribution to our 800+ locations throughout Oregon, Washington, California and B.C. Travel Salem is so grateful to all of our supportive partners!â€ù said Irene Bernards, Marketing & PR Director.

The guides are distributed to over 800 locations throughout Oregon, Washington, California and British Columbia. A digital version is also available for viewing at TravelSalem.com.

Travel Salem would like to thank all of the businesses and organizations who contributed to promoting our wonderful region through advertising, providing photography and helping to distribute this valuable resource for our region.

Businesses are encouraged to order the Salem Area Visitor Guide by contacting Barb Cowan at 503-581-4325, ext 21 or email a request to bcowan@TravelSalem.com. Visitor Guides may also be picked up at the Travel CafÃ© Visitors Center, located in historic downtown Salem at 181 High Street NE.

column4: Travel Salem Scores Points with Sport Teams
column5:
The Travel Salem sales team has been busy over the past month drumming up new business and hosting tournaments in the Salem metro area. Brian Chung, Sports and Events Sales Manager, attended the National Association of Sports Commissions Annual Symposium in Milwaukee, WI with over 30 prescheduled appointments with potential sports events organizers. Brian brought back 19 potential leads including the U.S. Quidditch Association, Soccer by Design, and the United States Australian Football League.

Travel Salem also secured these sport events:

The Willamette Valley Water Polo club hosted the 2015 Girlsâ€™ Water Polo Pacific Northwest Zone Junior Olympic Qualifier at the Kroc Center on May 1-3, 2015. Nearly 300 athletes, accompanied by coaches and parents from Washington and Oregon, competed in Salem for the chance to participate in the Junior Olympics in Orange County, California later this summer.

On May 16-17, 2015, twelve boysâ€™ and girlsâ€™ Ultimate Frisbee teams from throughout Oregon traveled to the Capital Futbol Club in Salem to compete in the Oregon State High School Championships. Nice weather and pristine field conditions greeted over 200 players, parents and coaches for the two days of competition at the complex. The winners qualified to play in the Western Regional Championship in Corvallis at the end of May.

Photo courtesy of Creative Commons

Back to newsletter
column6: The Travel Salem sales team has been busy over the past month drumming up new business and hosting tournaments in the Salem metro area.

column4: Total Solar Eclipse of 2017 â€“ Groupies Welcome
column5:
An Eclipse and a Rock band have a lot in commonâ€_groupies! For loyal Eclipse followers the â€œheadliningâ€ù act for August 21, 2017 is the Total Solar Eclipse. Visitors and residents will have the finest seats available right here in Salem, which is one of the best viewing locations in the United States. Salem is on the direct trajectory path of the eclipse, and Travel Salem is already fielding inquiries about eclipse activities, themed lodging packages and events.

To prepare for â€œEclipse 2017â€ù we need to get the creativity flowing to be able to turn Salem into the â€œSolar Eclipse Capital of the World!â€ù

Here are some inspirational ideas to consider: 

â€¢Eclipse lodging package 
â€¢Eclipse wine label (i.e. Umbra Pinot -The umbra is the darkest part of the Moon's shadow) 
â€¢Eclipse-themed events 
â€¢Eclipse menu (i.e. Solar Burger, Lunar Lemonade, Absolute Magnitude Porter)
â€¢Eclipse exhibit (i.e. sun/moon, celestial artwork)
â€¢Significance of astronomy in history

Share your plans with Travel Salem and we will market â€œEclipse 2017â€ù to the far reaches of the galaxy, or at least nationally.

To learn more about the 2017 Eclipse visit:  
www.eclipse.gsfc.nasa.gov

Back to newsletter

column5:
The 2015-16 Salem Area Visitor Guide is now available. Travel Salem is in the process of distributing the Visitor Guide to 800 locations throughout Oregon, Washington, California and British Columbia. Visitors are excited to see the new guide which is packed with fresh, new content that highlights the great diversity of our area.

Travel Salem would like to thank all of the businesses and organizations who generously supported the Visitor Guide through advertising! You can also view the guide in digital format at TravelSalem.com.

To order a supply of the new Salem Area Visitors Guide contact Barb Cowan at 503-581-4325 ext. 121 or bcowan@TravelSalem.com.

Back to newsletter
column6: The 2015-16 Salem Area Visitor Guide is now available. Travel Salem is in the process of distributing the Visitor Guide to 800 locations throughout Oregon, Washington, California and British Columbia.

column5:
Travel Salem provides many resources to reach visitors and help elevate the level of awareness of the wonderful businesses and experiences our area has to offer.

One is the Travel Salem Visitor Guide which helps promote our region to over 180,000 visitors from near and far. Now is the time to get on board for the 2016 issue! Members have the option of listing and/or advertising in the guide. If your business isn't listed in the current guide, now is the time to make sure you are included in the 2016-17 issue. For information please contact Sue Nichols at SNichols@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325, X122. Sue will be happy to step you through the simple process for a listing. 

TravelSalem.com is another great resource for businesses. Each month thousands of visitors form all around the globe view events, attractions and more on our website! As an added bonus, infomation on TravelSalem.com is shared with Travel Oregon and Willamette Valley Visitors Association (certain restrictions apply) for an even broader reach. One popular feature members can take advantage of is the 'Travel Packages & Specials.' So take a little time, reach out and partner up with other businesses to offer attractive travel packages that help enhance our tourism industry. If you would like more information or a few ideas of unique packages, please contact Sue Nichols, SNichols@Travel Salem.com or 503-581-4325, X122.

Back to newsletter
column6: Travel Salem provides many resources to reach visitors and help elevate the level of awareness of the wonderful businesses and experiences our area has to offer.

column4: Salem Area Businesses Recognized at â€œAbsolutely Fabulousâ€ù Awards Luncheon
column5:
Travel Salem announced the recipients of this yearâ€™s Absolutely Fabulous awards at the fourth annual â€œAb Fabâ€ù Awards Luncheon, held Thursday, May 21 at the Salem Convention Center. The â€œAb Fabâ€ù awards recognize tourism industry partners who went above and beyond in 2014 to increase the economic impact of visitors. The award recipients are movers and shakers who turned ideas upside down and inside out to capture the best returns on their marketing, collaborations, partnerships and strategies. 

This year, Travel Salem recognized nine business partners for their outstanding commitment to the tourism industry: 

â€¢ The Absolutely â€œCultivating Successâ€ù Award was presented to The Oregon Garden for creating an outstanding new event â€“ Christmas in the Garden â€“ which drew a record-breaking 22,500 visitors over 14 nights in 2014. 

â€¢ The Hampton Inn & Suites received the Absolutely â€œ5-Starâ€ù Award for their impeccable customer service and Number One ranking on Tripadvisor.com out of 314 hotels in the Willamette Valley. 

â€¢ The Absolutely â€œScorinâ€™â€ù Award went to the Capital Cup Soccer Tournament for bringing 191 teams to Salem for the 2014 tournament and for the partnerships theyâ€™ve forged with other organizations to encourage attendees to experience additional activities while visiting Salem. 

â€¢ Publishing company MEDIAmerica was presented with the Absolutely â€œAbove the Foldâ€ù Award for the exceptional job they do producing Travel Salemâ€™s annual visitors guide â€“ considered one of the best guides in the state. 

â€¢ AleWays Brewery Tours and owner Bobby Marcum received the Absolutely â€œHoppingâ€ù Award for his dedication to promoting Salemâ€™s craft beer industry and the gracious hospitality that he always shows to guests on his tours.  

â€¢ The Absolutely â€œCrÃ¨me de la CrÃ¨meâ€ù Award was presented to Wild Pear Restaurant & Cateringâ€™s Jessica Ritter and Cecilia Ritter James for helping to spark the Mid-Valleyâ€™s culinary renaissance and for their commitment to showcasing the bounty of the Willamette Valley in their inspiring dishes. 

â€¢ Shawn Irvine, economic development director for the City of Independence, received the Absolutely â€œActivatedâ€ù Award for his success in securing a Travel Oregon Rural Tourism Studio (RTS) Grant â€“ designed to boost sustainable tourism in rural communities - and for his unwavering efforts to support tourism development in Polk County.

â€¢ The Absolutely Fabulous Award was presented to Willamette Valley Vineyards for the recent remodel of their tasting room and creating an award-winning visitor destination that showcases the Mid-Valleyâ€™s fine wine, breathtaking scenic beauty and locally-sourced food. 

Back to newsletter

column4: Eating Salem: An Exhibit of Restaurant History
column5:
June 19-August 22. This exhibit explores the history and culture of dining out in Salem by highlighting notable restaurants and the people who made them successful. Artifacts and photos from community collections will be on display. $7/Adults; $6/Seniors; $4/Students with ID; $3/Youth 6-17; Free/Children 5 and under.
Willamette Heritage Center
1313 Mill Street St.
Salem, OR 97301
503-585-7012

column4: 2016 Oregon Wine A-List Awards ~ Nominations Open until November 1
column5:
The Oregon Wine Board nominations for the 2016 Oregon Wine A-List Awards opened on Sept. 1. The Oregon Wine A-List Awards recognize restaurants throughout the state that do an exceptional job of supporting Oregon with wine lists that showcase the stateâ€™s wine. Anyone may nominate a deserving restaurant on oregonwine.org/a-list between Sept. 1 and Nov. 1. The 2016 Oregon Wine A-List will be announced in January.

The judging panel will review all nominations to determine the final award recipients, which will be announced at the Oregon Wine Symposium on February 24, 2016.

Back to newsletter
column6: The Oregon Wine Board nominations for the 2016 Oregon Wine A-List Awards opened on Sept. 1.

column5:
Travel Salem is pleased to announce the addition of two new staff members to our team.

Maricela Urzua,
Destination Development Director 

Maricela Urzua is Travel Salemâ€™s new destination development manager. In this role, Urzua is responsible for facilitating the development of new and existing tourism products and opportunities in the region. Prior to joining Travel Salem, she worked as a program manager for the Alliance for a Healthier Generation. Before joining the Alliance, she served as a program officer for the Meyer Memorial Trust. Maricela holds a Bachelorâ€™s Degree from Oregon State University and an MBA from the University of Phoenix. Contact Maricela at 503-581-4325, x133 or murzua@TravelSalem.com. 

 
Marney Roddick, 
Guest Services Coordinator 

Marney Roddick joins the Travel Salem team as the new guest services coordinator. Marney oversees guest services and all operations related to the Travel CafÃ© Visitors Center as well as the distribution of Travel Salemâ€™s annual visitors guide.  Marney has extensive experience working in the visitor and tourism industry, including positions with The Oregon Garden, the Oregon State Fair and Expo Center and most recently, as the events coordinator at The Oregon State Capitol. Roddick earned her teaching credentials from California State University, San Bernardino. Contact Marney at 503-581-4325 x121 or mroddick@TravelSalem.com. 

 â€œWeâ€™re so pleased to have Maricela and Marney join our organization,â€ù says Travel Salem CEO Angie Morris. â€œEach brings a wealth of talent and expertise to their respective roles. We look forward to their many contributions.â€ù

Back to newsletter
column6: Travel Salem is pleased to announce the addition of two new staff members to our team.

column4: Travel Salem Attends Connect Sports Tradeshow
column5:
Brian Chung, Sports and Events Sales Manager, recently attended the 2015 Connect Sports Marketplace in Pittsburgh to promote Salem as a premier sports destination to event organizers from around the country. At the conference, he met with 32 sports organizations interested in hosting their next event/tournament in Salem, Oregon. After five days of networking, Brian returned with over 13 new events prospects for the region. For more information about the conference, feel free to contact Brian Chung at bchung@travelsalem.com.

Photo by Mason Shoultz

Back to newsletter
column6: Brian Chung, Sports and Events Sales Manager, recently attended the 2015 Connect Sports Marketplace in Pittsburgh to promote Salem as a premier sports destination to event organizers from around the country.

column5:
Travel Salem is pleased to announce its continued partnership with MEDIAmerica for the 2016 Salem Area Visitors Guide â€“ Travel Salemâ€™s 18th edition.

Work is underway on the Visitors Guide, the official regional (Marion & Polk counties) response piece for all inquiries generated by Travel Salemâ€™s marketing efforts. The Salem Area Visitors Guide is utilized as a vital resource during the trip planning process and while visitors are enjoying the region.

"What a wonderful publication your printed travel guide is!!...I give your publication design team a 10 out of 10...Thank you...Weâ€™re looking forward to exploring the Salem area in just a few weeks from now."
M. Moore
Estes Park,  Colorado

We distribute a total of 140,000 guides per year and we have 800 distribution locations throughout Oregon, Washington, California and British Columbia. Some of the 140k guides are distributed through the 800 locations and some are distributed through advertising requests and meeting planner/sales packets and at events. The 2016 guide will also be in digital format at TravelSalem.com.

If you are interested in advertising in the 2016 Salem Area Visitors Guide contact Terra Moreland with MEDIAmerica at 503-445-8830 / terram@mediamerica.net.

Back to newsletter
column6: Travel Salem is pleased to announce its continued partnership with MEDIAmerica for the 2016 Salem Area Visitors Guide â€“ Travel Salemâ€™s 18th edition.

column5:
Travel Salem welcomes the submission of photographic images taken within Marion and Polk counties. Photographs help develop the first impression a visitor has of our wonderful area. Images are used in our print, online and social media marketing platforms.

Image content may include attractions, gardens, nature, recreation, dining, shopping, events, wine tasting or any image that helps tell the story of our wonderful Mid-Willamette Valley. If you would like Travel Salem to consider your photographic images, please review the following criteria:

â€¢ Photos must be high resolution and a minimum of 300 dpi
â€¢ Photos should be experiential and include people when possible.
â€¢ Photos with people must have a â€œmodel releaseâ€ù included that gives permission to use images.

If you have images that meet the criteria please contact Irene Bernards, Marketing & PR Director
ibernards@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325 ext. 127.

Back to newsletter
column6: Travel Salem welcomes the submission of photographic images taken within Marion and Polk counties.

column4: Travel Salem Seeks Story Ideas from Polk County
column5:
Give us your best pitch! Travel Salem invites representatives from Polk County businesses and organizations to share your best ideas for our â€œcontent libraryâ€ù that we can use for potential pitches to the media or for use in our blogs, social media posts or other publications. Anyone representing a Polk county business, group or nonprofit is invited to drop in between 10 a.m. and 2 p.m. on Tuesday, October 20, at the Polk County Fairgrounds and share whatâ€™s new and newsworthy at your organization.

What constitutes a â€œnewsworthyâ€ù pitch? If your organization or business has recently launched â€“ or is planning to launch â€“ a new product, service, event, or program that is unique and of interest to a large audience (especially visitors), we want to hear about it.

Hereâ€™s how Speed Pitching works:

  • No pre-registration necessary. Drop by the Polk County Fairgrounds any time between 10 a.m. and 2 p.m. on October 20.
  • The person(s) representing the business or organization will have 15 minutes (maximum) to share their news with a member of Travel Salemâ€™s marketing staff. 
  • Please send no more than 2 people per organization.
  • If you are pitching an event, it must be at least 6 months prior to the event date. (Most of the regional and national publications we target request information 4-5 months in advance).
  • Youâ€™re welcome to bring a short, one-page summary of your pitch or a supporting document (i.e. a brochure, flyer, rack card).
  • While we hope to utilize as many of the ideas as possible, Travel Salem cannot guarantee that an idea will be used or published. 

If you cannot attend Speed Pitching, but would like to submit an idea, email it to kkuh@travelsalem.com. 

Back to newsletter

column4: Make Plans Now for Total Solar Eclipse
column5:
Visitors are already booking lodging for 2017, because for the first time in 26 years, a total solar eclipse will occur. Salem is in the direct path and we will play host to thousands of the world's eclipse-chasers.

The shadow first touches land near Newport, Oregon at 17:15:50.6UT (at about 10:15 in the morning) on August 21, 2017 and lasts a full minute and fifty seconds of totality.

Within two minutes the shadow extends eastward toward Dallas, Albany, Corvallis, Lebanon, Philomath, McMinnville, Woodburn, and yes, Salem. The length of totality will vary based on distances from the centerline. On the steps of the State Capitol in Salem (the first of five state capitals the shadow will visit), lucky viewers will be treated to 1m54.5s of shadow at just after 10:17am. 

1. This will be the first total solar eclipse in the continental U.S. in 26 years. 

(The next one will be on Tuesday, July 2, 2019. You can see it on land at sunset, from small spots in either Chile or Argentina.)

2. A solar eclipse is a lineup of the Sun, the Moon, and Earth.  The Moon, directly between the Sun and Earth, casts a shadow on our planet. If youâ€™re in the dark part of that shadow (the umbra), youâ€™ll see a total eclipse.

3. A solar eclipse happens at New Moon. The Moon has to be between the Sun and Earth for a solar eclipse to occur. The only lunar phase when that happens is New Moon.

4. Itâ€™s all about totality. Only totality reveals the true celestial spectacle: the diamond ring, the Sunâ€™s glorious corona, strange colors in our sky, and seeing stars in the daytime.

5. First contact is in Oregon. If you want to be the first person to experience totality in the continental U.S., be on the waterfront at Government Point, Oregon, at 10:15:56.5 a.m. PDT. There, the total phase lasts 1 minute, 58.5 seconds.

6. The centerline crosses through 10 states.

Here are some inspirational ideas to consider: 

â€¢ Eclipse lodging packages (i.e. partner up with wineries and restaurants to create an experience package)

â€¢ Eclipse wine label (i.e. Umbra Pinot -The umbra is the darkest part of the Moon's shadow) 

â€¢ Eclipse-themed events 

â€¢ Eclipse-themed souvenir items (i.e. T-shirts, mugs, bumper stickers)

â€¢ After-eclipse party or meal

â€¢ Eclipse menu (i.e. Solar Burger, Lunar Lemonade, Absolute Magnitude Porter)

â€¢ Eclipse exhibit (i.e. sun/moon, celestial artwork)

â€¢ Significance of astronomy in history

Share your plans with Travel Salem and we will market â€œEclipse 2017â€ù to the far reaches of the galaxy, or at least nationally. 

Of Note: Submit information by spring of 2016 for long-lead pitches. This allows maximum exposure for events. For PR questions please contact: Kara Kuh at KKuh@TravelSalem.com or 503-581-4325, X 124

To learn more about the 2017 Eclipse visit:  

http://eclipse.gsfc.nasa.gov/SEgoogle/SEgoogle2001/SE2017Aug21Tgoogle.html

Back to newsletter

column4: Salem to Host US Quidditch Northwest Regional Championship Tournament
column5:
A little bit of Harry Potter-inspired magic is coming to Salem next year. Travel Salem is pleased to announce that it has secured the 2016 US Quidditch (USQ) Northwest Regional Championship Tournament, which will take place February 6 and 7 at the Capital Futbol Club Soccer Complex in Salem. 

The 2016 tournament will be the second regional championship for the Northwest region. (The 2015 event was held in Tukwila, Washington). Fourteen teams - approximately 280 players - from Oregon, Washington, Idaho, Montana, Wyoming and British Columbia are expected to compete in the 2016 tournament. 

Brian Chung, Travel Salemâ€™s sports and events sales manager, estimates that the cash infusion into the local economy from the tournament will be approximately $58,240.

 â€œWeâ€™re really excited to host the USQ Northwest Regional tournament in Salem,â€ù said Chung. â€œNot only does it mean a spike in business for hotels, shops and restaurants during a time of year when business is typically slower, but hosting an event that is still relatively new to the Northwest is sure to generate positive publicity for Salem and draw plenty of spectators who want to see how the sport is played.â€ù

Inspired by the game featured in the Harry Potter book series, quidditch is a gender integrated, contact sport that mixes elements of rugby, dodgeball and tag. Each team has a chaser that can score goals, a keeper who defends the goal, two beaters who try to â€œknock outâ€ù other players and a seeker who tries to catch the snitch â€“ which consists of a ball attached to a neutral player. Players must carry a broom between their legs at all times. 

To be selected to host a regional USQ tournament, a city must be able to provide certain essentials, such as electricity, adequate field space for matches and visitor information services throughout the tournament. â€œWe were impressed with Salemâ€™s facilities, the level of support from the city and the enthusiasm for the sport of quidditch,â€ù said Sarah Woolsey, USQ events director. 

The top qualifiers in the Northwest Regional Championship Tournament will move on to compete in the US Quidditch Cup 9, April 16-17 in Columbia, South Carolina. 

Although there is no Salem area team currently registered with US Quidditch, itâ€™s feasible that a team could join the organization and meet the basic requirements in time to compete in the Northwest Regional Tournament in February. 

â€œWeâ€™d love to see a Salem area team form and then play in the regional tournament,â€ù said Woolsey. Membership in US Quidditch is open to teams and individuals in any age group in the United States. 

History of US Quidditch

Quidditch got its start in the United States in 2005 at Middlebury College when then-freshman Xander Manshel and his classmates were looking for a variation on their normal Sunday activities. Manshel and his friends laid the foundation for a game that has grown to become a widely respected, physically intense sport. Today, there are more than 4,000 athletes on almost 200 teams nationwide. 

For more information about quidditch or forming a team, go to www.usquidditch.org. 

Back to newsletter

column4: Travel Salem Makes List of 100 Best Nonprofits to Work For in Oregon
column5:
Travel Salem is pleased to announce it has been selected as one of the â€œ100 Best Nonprofits to Work For in Oregonâ€ù by Oregon Business magazine. The 100 Best Nonprofits list is comprised of the top 34 large, 33 medium and 33 small nonprofits that participated in the survey. Travel Salem was ranked as the 25th best small nonprofit.  

The rankings were based on an independent assessment of an employerâ€™s workplace practices and the confidential input of employees, who were asked to rate their satisfaction in a number of categories including work environment, mission and goals, career development and learning, benefits and compensation, and management and communications. More than 150 nonprofits and over 5,000 employees participated in the seventh annual survey. 

â€œThose of us who choose nonprofit careers do so for the chance to serve a cause greater than ourselves,â€ù said Angie Morris, president and CEO of Travel Salem. â€œTravel Salem attracts and retains amazing, talented staff, who bring their â€˜A-gameâ€™ and give a little bit of their heart to their job every single day. There is no question why they are some of the best in the industry.â€ù

The free, voluntary survey was conducted by DHM Research along with a research editor at Oregon Business magazine. The â€œTop 100 Best Nonprofits to Work For in Oregonâ€ù is featured in the October issue of Oregon Business magazine.

Back to newsletter
